When I came here I got the fish ceviche. It was pretty good, but a bit spicy for my liking. I liked how the fish wasn't too fishy of a taste and more limey. It was served with chips on the side. I wish they gave me more chips. They have standard portions and bit pricey. But they're more upscale so I guess it's okay?

I like how they have a lot of vegetarian and pescatarian options! A lot of the dishes you can opt out of the meat, so that's pretty cool. :)

I would like to come back if I'm ever around the area and try more of their foods and drinks. (Most likely before going to Ruby Skye LOL)
author: Kim C.

description: Was looking forward to amazing Carnitas which I've enjoyed here many times before. The first time they came around the pork was raw (not pink, chewy raw in the center). The second try was (I believe the same piece of pork) shredded and cooked beyond recognition into a dry extra crispy mess. The rice and the cocktail were very good, but overall a disappointing experience this time around.
author: C N.

description: Amazingly fresh guacamole and great selection of tequila for sipping but also margaritas. The prawns with mole is fresh and full of flavor. The steak filet  was cooked to order with lots of complimenting pepper flavor and also great mole. Wish we found this restaurant earlier to eat here again! Make reservations if you want to eat before 6.30p.
author: Tiffany Z.

description: Was excited to grab drinks at this place until we were seated by the hostess at a table. We were sitting there for a total of 2 min when a man, if he was the manager he should be fired, came up to us asked us if we were going to order food. We answered no, which we made very clear to the hostess already. He then proceeded to tell us that we couldn't sit there unless we were ordering food. He tried to force us to sit at the bar, even though there were no open seats. We asked him point blank, "are you telling us to move?" He said "yes."  No apology or anything. So we got up and left. There is absolutely no reason why we shouldn't have been able to sit at a table, especially if we informed the hostess of this information AND she sat us. WILL NOT BE GOING BACK. TERRIBLE SERVICE. he should have tried to move us and then when it didn't work out chalked it up to a loss.
author: Heather T.

description:
Second time coming here for dinner,&this place never fails that I wanted to write an update review!

Sopes Surtidos (sope assortment w/ beans, chickens, shredded pork & sautéed veggies w/ crumbled queso fresco,onion & sour cream) - favorite meal of the night! The base is a fried tortilla but tasted like a puff pastry. The sope assortments had great flavor & texture, w/the crunch from the sope&softness from the toppings.

Camerones en Mole de Tamarindo (sautéed prawns in mole w/ corn cake) - shrimp was perfectly cooked. The mole tasted delicious,& the corn cake really complimented the whole meal altogether. 

Overall, service was very good as our waiter was attentive & very patient since we kept ordering more of their addicting, warm ,fresh tortillas. The food was absolutely amazing, once again. This place has become me & my bf's favorite place to eat downtown. Def recommend!
author: Trina N.

description: This was not a good experience. From service to food it was all pretty bad. The only thing decent was the guacamole and chips but getting enough chips was a chore. Drinks too FOREVER to come. The fish tacos were terrible- pineapple with a mayo based sauce. I feel like I get what they were trying for- something I've had poolside at a carribean resort but completely missed the mark. And the "chile relleno" was a cooked pepper with some cheese. Not battered, no sauce. And did I say service was terrible? Not worth the stop.
author: Piper W.

description: They managed to squeeze us in despite being a busy Saturday night. The margaritas (refreshing bliss and macho margaritas) were the BEST I have had. Highly recommend!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Delicious! My boyfriend and I came here about a week ago and we had a great experience. 
My boyfriend is a vegetarian and they were very accommodating and offered to make the sopes vegetarian. 

For appetizers we had the guacamole and sopes surtidos. The homemade tortillas were so good my bf and I wolfed them down. 

For our entrees I had the shrimp mole which was very savory and the corn cake was perfectly soft and sweet. My boyfriend had the tortita de papas which he really enjoyed. 

Our waiter was very attentive. I will def be coming back here to try the pozole.
author: Alyssa S.

description: This restaurant has an excellent staff, ambiance and food. We ordered the chille relleno and sopes and they did not disappoint. I would highly recommend this place.
author: Larry L.

description: Good food, I took a Mole. The sauce was a bit bitter, though. Like the ambiance, and very fast and nice waiters.
author: Alex G.

description:
The food is delicious and authentically Mexican. The atmosphere is wonderful, if a bit noisy.  Get the carnitas, they're delicious. If you get the guacamole, the mild spice level is perfect.  The margaritas are terrific!! 

Parking can be difficult. The easiest is mass transit or taking a cab/walking.

The space seemed a bit cold but not uncomfortable.  If you come, you might want to bring a sweater.  Thursday are $25.00 margarita pitcher nights.  Enjoy!
author: Living T.

description: The food was good although I doubt we would ever go there again. We had reservations and were seated promptly at 5:30.  We had tickets to see Christmas Carol at 7pm across the street at Curran Theater. The food came out one dish at a time (there were 7 of us), the last two at 6:45.  Basically each of us were eating alone. From 6:15, the waiter kept saying the food was coming??? The last two had to wolf theirs down so we could pay and leave. Not the kind of dining experience you want to repeat, especially for that price.  By the reviews I see that this has happened to others. What a shame.
author: Inhae P.

description:
A day of shenanigans I ended up here bringing my friend. 

For my first time here I thought it was going to be a little posh for me. As we entered on a Saturday afternoon around 3 pm we were seated right away next to the window. 

It's very small. Some elbow room please! The bar is right in front of you as you enter. 

Waiter was very attentive. I ordered the fish tacos, guacamole, and an old fashioned! $2 extra for chips? Seriously?!?!?  Lame! My drink was surprisingly $7. Tortillas were legit! Small, yet thick! Legit handmade Mexican style tortillas! Guacamole and salsa were on point! Fish tacos were a hit! Drink was nice and strong!!! Touché! 

A great place for a meet up or potential first date but I'm skeptical of how packed it can get... $2 for chips though? Seriously? Smh 

A great place though! I shall come back to try an actual dish when I have more of an appetite! Fish was nicely cooked! All the toppings made it so much tastier! Definitely a good spot to come and check out!
author: Ernesto D.

description: Amazing little place around the corner from our hotel!  The past reviews drove me to seek it out for dinner one night while I was in town for business.  I was not disappointed and was surprised as to the incredible quality of "real Mexican" flavors that was combined to make delicious Mexican food.  My dinner was homemade corn tortillas and homemade guacamole that was served fresh with one amazing taste.  The tortilla soup was incredibly smooth and very tasty to the palate, while spicy and cheesy to make it worth the wait.  The big surprise was the margarita which delivered a real punch of fruity smooth taste with a punch of tequila at the end.  An experience you should not miss while in Union Square.
author: warren b.

description: Drinks and food are great.  Hit the spot!  Carnitas, guac and chips, empanadas.  Second time here and will come back.
author: Tracy D.

description:
I loved this bartender. He knows what he is doing every well. 
Margarita of the month, tequila and beer my favorite
author: Saurabh M.

description:
I came here for a weekday lunch and really enjoyed several of Colibri's offerings:

1. Enchiladas with cheese: They don't use 'merican cheese; not sure if it's queso fresco, but it was rich. Had the texture of ricotta. Comes in threes with a green and red sauce. All three ladies in my party preferred the red. It was more flavorful and possibly a bit spicier.

2. Ceviche: Totally worth it. Get this. Hearty portions and scrumptious.

3. Carne asada: Delicious and a perfect portion size. The meat isn't super tender, but not overly tough. Well seasoned. Black bean sauce was... lacking. Wish there had been more.

4. Hand made corn tortillas with three types of salsa: The tortillas are served warm and I loved how sweet the mild yellow salsa tasted.

5. Mango agua fresca: They only have one agua fresca flavor everyday. I'm not a mango fan, but I tried a sip and it tasted like fresh mango.

This is the place to go if you're looking for a higher end (ie not in the Mission) Mexican dining experience. Prices are slightly higher for dinner.
author: Michelle K.

description: Mexican food from from central Mexico. very friendly staff and a great happy hour. Love this place!The fish tacos are plentiful and delicious. The guacamole and chips person is huge!
author: Roger V.

description: Great food!! Excellent bartender he was awesome, I most definitely recommend the happy hour menu and the lunch enchiladas!!! Had a blast
author: Mick W.

description: The pozole verde is the best.  I was wanting something light but this dish was light yet filling.  The rellenos were so tasty and the empenada appetizers were wonderful.  Having homemade corn tortillas, endless, brought to the table with a three different types of salsas was a nice touch and different spin on chips and salsa.  The macho margarita, made with jalepenos, was an awesome treat.  The pomegranate margarita was a bit sweet and was heavy like a syrup. Our server only checked on us twice yet the busboy checked on us repeatedly and refilled our tortillas two times.   I highly recommend this place if ever in the city of San Francisco.
author: Chris S.

description:
This review might be unfair because we came only for the bar and the atmosphere. The $20 price tag of 1 pinot gringio and 2 well drinks was reasonable considering how pretty the interior of the restaurant was. The service at the bar was wonderful. It might've helped that my boyfriend and I were super chatty--we were the only people at the bar who couldn't stop talking. They have this old Mexican soap opera movie playing that we spent the entire time there trying to interpret what was going on since we couldn't hear any of the dialogue. At one point, we were watching a Walter White clone fighting a Mexican lady in a kimono in the movie.

I'm not really sure where this review is going but we had a relaxing pleasant time here. I wish we ate here but the bar, the atmosphere, and lovely company made this restaurant experience very enjoyable.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description: Great sangría the salad was fantastic...fresh, light, great with shrimp!!  The sopa tortilla was also fantastic.  Bartender was great!
author: Amber Leila E.

description: Came in for brunch since we were staying at the hotel next door. Brunch was amazing! I had the Mexican breakfast & my fiancé had the carne asada breakfast, both plates were so good we had to share them. I had the $14 bottomless mimosas and my fiancé had a few micheladas- he said they were fire (the best micheladas he's ever had) After brunch we tried the churro dessert with ice cream TRY IT! It was so good my fiancé ate half of it and he never eats dessert whenever we eat out! Food & drinks were great but only 4 stars because our server wasn't very attentive which seems to be an issue here as I can see from other reviews.
author: Julissa L.

description:
Excellent food and service. 
Ordered wine so I can't comment on the cocktails.
Staff was friendly. 
Food was delivered fairly quickly. 
Only 4/5 stars because I wasn't overly impressed with the menu options. 
Ordered the fish tacos and was very happy with them.
author: Dee A.

description:
Dinner and a show! The magic of San Fran...and yes, we did see a magic show and were starved following the event. We ran into Colibri Mexican Bistro, which apparently was reviewed as a great place to eat. 

I can't negate that the food was delicious. Or should I say the child size portion of it.

Menu/Food: Despite the fact that there's the "Vegetarians Go Wild for This Place," the menu isn't actually that vegetarian friendly. In fact, it is quite meaty! The menu posted outside wasn't even current and the dish that looked interesting wasn't offered. For a Zagat rated restaurant, this move is klassy with a "k." The guac was absolutely delicious - order it this second! The three salsas were also interesting. One was a hot and spicy green salsa, a red roasted one, and an interesting pineapple salsa. I ended up ordering the beet salad which had two varieties of beets, coated pumpkin seeds, and arugula (no cheese please). 

Pricing: They had a problem adding mango to my dish, but no problem adding an extra charge for it despite the fact that I had excluded cheese which actually would have cost them more. They also had no problem charging extra for chips #tacky. But, at least we also got the warm homemade tortillas.

Atmosphere: It is actually a small, oddly shaped restaurant. Service was okay, if lacking in a feeling of genuineness and friendliness. 

So delicious food, ridiculous prices, and tiny portions. I think the dessert I ate at home was bigger than my meal.
author: Libby J.

description: Amazing guac!!!! Service was wonderful!! Our table was ready so fast!! Oh, and house margaritas... perfect!!!!
author: Ashley E.

description:
The drinks here are strong and GOOD! I recommend the strawberry and basil margarita if you want to experience something new and refreshing.

The guacamole was good, but it comes with corn tortillas which is really weird. We had to pay $2 for chips, which my dining companion that was ridiculous.

Filete Mignon was so tender and tasty. It was so good I was sad when it was all gone.

Carnitas dish wasn't really enjoyed by my dining companion. She found it to be to dry and lacking flavor.
author: Norm J.

description:
I spent last Saturday night in the city with my 3 girl friends. Everything we ended up doing was completely spontaneous and proved to be for the best. Around 9:30pm, all of us were starved and knew a night of fun needed to start with a filling dinner. Two doors down from our hotel, close to union square, was a Mexican restaurant called Colibri. We didn't have reservations and when we asked for a table for 4, they said it was one hour to an hour and a half long wait. Sadly, we retreated to find less of a wait elsewhere. We wandered the streets for about 20 minutes and found nothing of interest that had a reasonable wait. We decided to settle on a pizza by the slice place. We were passing by Colibri again when one of my friends geniously decided to recheck the wait. Surprisingly they had a table for 4, no wait.

I was pleasantly satisfied with the quality of everything  I ate that night. Having not read any reviews, I was hoping to find something to love. We ordered chips and guac, which were so fresh and had an excellent lime taste. They also brought out 3 different types or salsa. Something for everyone. For my entre, I ordered the Filete Mignon. Their filet was cooked perfectly medium rare, had an ancho chili stuffed with goat cheese and was served with mashed potatoes mixed with spinach. I literally cleaned my plate. It was one of the best meat dishes I've had in a long time. I was so thrilled.

The next morning, we decided to check out their brunch. I ordered a bottomless mimosa for $10 and the Torrejas Colibri. This was their house special Mexican cinnamon toast  served with a variety of fruit. The presentation was fantastic and looked beautiful. The dish was quite tasty, but the cinnamon toast was a little mushy.

My only set back in general was the customer service. While my dinner was delightful, our waitress was so dry and never smiled.
author: Justine C.

description:
It's so easy to hate on Union Square if you're a local especially when it comes to weekend brunch but you know what? Bottomless mimosa brunch at Colibri did not suck at all.

We made reservations at Noon but didn't need it. There were plenty of other tables opened which made us wonder why we got stuck in the furthest table in the restaurant right by where the servers dump the dirty dishes. But compared to the long lines at other brunch places, it wasn't bad at all. Our server got us up and running with our [$10 bottomless] mimosas, warmed tortillas, and salsas (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/colibri-mexican-bistro-san-francisco?select=Hy9L2WqwxqKC_yL7LIlrog#Hy9L2WqwxqKC_yL7LIlrog) quickly. 

It's a fun brunch menu. Apart from classics like Mole and ceviche, they take a playful Mexican spin on brunch classics. My carnitas omelet (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/colibri-mexican-bistro-san-francisco?select=Hy9L2WqwxqKC_yL7LIlrog#Qaie-M5Zpwo-bSKkcFy90g) was chocked full of meat and perfect hangover brunch food. The carnitas didn't seem to have the crispiness one would expect from a deep fried piece of meat but it did possess quite a bit of slow-stewed flavors. My friend's Mexican Egg Benedict (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/colibri-mexican-bistro-san-francisco?select=Hy9L2WqwxqKC_yL7LIlrog#e4C3TfIP_OZgS3g3a5_QQg) was pretty good too. The corn shells were an interesting sub for the English muffin and the chipotle hollandaise sauce pulled everything together. 

Our server was slow with topping up our mimosas mid-way through the meal but maybe that was because of our obscure table in the corner. He was pretty good at refilling our glasses after we asked him. All in all, we had a good brunch at Colibri and I would definitely recommend it if you want something a little different and waiting in long lines isn't your thing. Just make sure you ask not to get the very last table in the restaurant like we did.
author: Jon L.

description: Salsa, service drinks amazing food full of flavor and even better service our bartender Jeanette Was great she knew the menu and was able to offer suggestions and custom made a cocktail that was absolutely perfect. We had carnitas and chicken tostada ap everything was cooked perfectly and full of flavor so stoked to find this gem in SF
author: Events i.

description:
I don't like Mexican food too much but anyway, their food was not so good. 
It was better than other places but not the best option for a delicious dinner. 

If you are a Mexican food lover you would love it. But I don't
author: Payam E.

description: I will never come again ! We were used to go to this place .... We have made a reservation .... Unfortunateky we were sick ... So we have to cancel ... They charge 10 dollars per personne for the cancellation
author: Emilie P.

description: Excellent margaritas, tasty food. Good high-end place to go before heading to the theater.
author: Bethany H.

description:
We've been here three times for various reasons - often based on location, availability of reservations, and the fact that it's a nice enough place - not too loud, fairly easy for mid-sized groups, ok for the gluten-free, and a decent atmosphere. The only time we came for the food was the first time, and we were disappointed - since then, we have lowered our expectations.

The first time we made special arrangements to come for the pipian chicken, but we were quite disappointed by it. Since then, we have tried to stick with safer items, like carnitas - which are fine, but obviously, there are SO many other places with much better carnitas for a lot less. The tortilla soup is a safe enough bet but the pozole had an overwhelming chicken taste that none of us liked - in fact, I'd caution against any of the chicken dishes, as they only seem to be rescued by dominant sauces - but it's not really worth it. The tortillas were one of our favorite parts.
author: Lisa K.

description: Visiting from the East Coast and was told that Colibri was the one place I had to visit when I came to SF. Wonderful drinks and great food. The staff was welcoming, even when we arrived late for our reservation. Will definitely come back next time I am in town!
author: James W.

description:
We went there at lunchtime as we wanted to have some Mexican food and the place looked good.

The food is OK and incredibly delicate, tortillas really look like they're freshly made (I guess they are), however servings are tiny for the price: you might walk out if the restaurant still hungry.

The ambience is peculiar (a lot of bottles of all sorts of liquors behind the counter) and quite cozy (dim lights, I'd say almost too much for lunchtime).

Maybe it's more ideal for couples going out for dinner
author: Dario B.

description:
After a long day filled with training at HQ, our CA team and leaders went to this place. I think our reservation was for around 20 of us and we were seated right away. Because a few others couldn't make it there were about three extra seats. This was the day of record breaking amounts of rain and power outages all over the city, so I think that just a few people not making it, wasn't too bad. 

This was a work dinner and I didn't pay for my meal, so I can't elaborate on the prices. We had a set menu with a few items to choose from. I explained to the waitress that I didn't want anything with tomatoes and she said that nothing on our set menu had tomato. Low and behold, the first thing that they brought to me was a tomato based soup. I asked for a salad instead, and the other waiter reluctantly brought it out after he questioned me. The salad was good, so I can't complain about that, because and they did accommodate me after I'd initially ordered the tortilla soup. My entree was Chile Relleno stuffed with Chicharron, it was ok... but by that time I had a few of the five star margaritas. 

Our choices for desserts were flan and an ice cream and stuffed churro. I went with the churro option and it didn't disappoint. The flan option didn't appear to be bad either.  

I wouldn't go back, but overall, it was a good experience.
author: Heather P.

description: Not your typical Mexican restaurant serving ordinary burritos and tacos. Had the slow roasted lamb and it was delicious. They had a great selection of margaritas as well.  Would come back.
author: Mary-Jane A.

description: I love this place. Great food, booze & service.   All just as good as last time I ate here, but no flan anymore even though it's still on the menu.  Waiter said many complaints of no flan (it was exquisite) but owner is not going to provide it.  I had what the menu described as platinos flambé.  But they were not platinos.  Only hard banana.  It was not a good dish.
author: Ken M.

description:
I always pass by this place and it is always packed! Their front window is decorated with scores of achievements from Michelin, Zagat, and other food-praising companies.

My boss took me and a few other coworkers out to lunch the other day and I was thoroughly impressed by my experience.
Everything is clean, well-presented, and elegant. It is not really fine-dining, but it is definitely more classy and not like your usual Mexican restaurant.

The menu is short, precise, and to the point. There are very very few vegetarian options, and even less vegan options. But luckily our server was very knowledgable and pointed me to some dishes I could enjoy.

The salads without cheese and dressings on the side are vegan friendly. They are fresh, beautifully plated, and super delicious!
The warm tortillas and fresh salsa are amazing! Loved all the flavors and the spiciness wasn't too overbearing.
Guacamole is freshly made and also quite the treat!
For my entree, I had the nopales dish-consisting of sauteed cactus and mushrooms. I ate it with the warm tortillas, guac, and salsas.
For my drink, i tried the watermelon agua fresca. Super refreshing and tasted just like biting into a watermelon would!

Service was spot on, atmosphere very warm and cozy, and great tasting food. Only wish there was more vegetarian and vegan options available. This place can get a very long wait sometimes so maybe try to come in between hours or snag a seat at the bar.
author: Lanie L.

description:
One word Horrible! 

My partner and I had been wanting to try Colibri Mexican Bistro for awhile. Finally we got around to checking it out. 

The place was not busy at all, so we let the host know that we wanted a table for two. We were sat immediately and from there we waited 25 minutes and no one came by or said anything to us so we walked out. 

A group of five that walked in ahead of us and sat in the bar area walked out as well. I would say this place does not care about it's potential customers. 

Thanks for nothing!
author: Charles B.

description: Stopped in for a small lunch when walking the city. Atmosphere is very pretty, staff was quick and friendly. The "hot"(green-was my favorite), medium, and mild sauces are more like Mild, tomato sauce, and sweet. The tortillas were the best I've ever had, the empanadas were also very tasty, as was the chili rellano (the crunchy topping wasn't for me tho, it was so hard, I thought I bit into bone). All Calibri lacked was some heat!
author: Kalynne M.

description: Would have been 1 star but they had good margaritas / tequila selection. Thoroughly disappointed in our $104 Mexican dinner (two margaritas, guac/chips, 2 entrees)... There are so many other fantastic mexican places in SF, I believe this is a tourist trap/location thing. I can literally think of 6 'expensive' mexican places that would have had better tasting food, same or better drinks and bill would have been 50-60ish.
author: John O.

description:
High class Mexican food at very affordable rates. Simply delicious!
The menu is short but everything is fresh made. Great selection of Tequilas and Margaritas.
author: Torsten S.

description:
Had dinner here last night and it was pretty good. 5 Stars for the margarita of the month! Dang it was strong, only need 2 for a strong buzz. 

Then we both had the filet mignon. And they cooked it over what we requested, so if you like med-rare, order rare and it will come out correct. But it was still good regardless, good portion not too huge. I would go again
author: Rebecca S.

description: The margaritas were amazing! We then started with the guacamole and chips. Nothing special but definitely not bad either. They brought our warm tortilla and three salsas (sweet, spicy and green) So delicious! We then had the tostadas...those were my favourite! Then we tried the empanadas. The least favourite that night. We ended with the churros...as you must at any Mexican restaurant..they did not disappoint. The final bill 2 margaritas each, guacamole, tostadas, empanadas and churros $111.00 ..expensive but we didn't leave hungry. Next time we will try and entree!
author: Donna L.

description:
Brunch was disappointing. Service was lackluster - even at the bar. Waited a long time for only partially heated, but decent food. Asked for water refills. Asked for extra salsa. Asked for check. You get the idea. 

Also, it doesn't seem like pre-meal tortillas are included with brunch.
author: Kim C.

description:
A unique menu the manager told me represents true regional dishes. Not extensive but interesting. If you're looking for burritos and tacos etc pass this one by. The tequila and margarita list is extensive. 
Their made in house salsas span sweet and mildly chipotle flavored to spicy with a good lingering heat on the other end. Not flaming by any means. 
I decided to go basic and ordered the carnitas. I was not disappointed. The meat was substantial and not dried out, came with its own sauce and using the onion, rice and fresh corn tortillas and other salsas provided made awesome soft tacos. I was full. 
I'd go back for their chili rellenos which sound awesome and are how I usually rate Mexican restaurants. 
Why no 5 star? Because I've got to have a truly exceptional experience for his. But I'd give 4.75 if I could. 
Go!  I doubt you'd be disappointed as long as you dare to try a different "Mexican " menu.

2 days later: I went back for the chili relleno with carnitas and chicharron and this dish influenced my increasing the rating to 5. Why you might ask. Because to me a relleno is about the chili peppers and this pepper was meaty and flavorful which wasn't overwhelmed by the meat stuffings own excellent flavor. All this perfectly cooked (not battered and fried as is commonly done) on a bed of sweet and smooth black beans. Overall a real mixture of individual but complementary flavors. Again the salsas were an added benefit. 
Go.
author: Eric Z.

description:
The corn tortillas alone should be the reason you come. They are fresh and they are real. Served with 3 dipping sauces that range from hot to sweet to mild. 

Appetizer was the chorizo con queso which was finger licking amazing! The hubby and I  truly wanted to keep ordering more. 

I got the duck stuffed with white rice and her ordered the fillet mignon with polenta. We kept wanting to reach across and pick off each others plates. 

I ordered iced tea and it was also amazing. I will have to return to ask about the tea alone. We were stuffed and couldn't order the churros for dessert which only means we will be returning tomorrow. 

Good portions and amazing rich flavors that are authentic.
author: Nando R.

description:
SEA BASS! SEA BASS!  $20 SEA BASS!

Ok so long story short. Great food (especially the Sea Bass), great service (especially when serving my Sea Bass), and fun energy (enhanced by eating Sea Bass).

Long story long, my man and I walked in and sat at the bar to avoid the hour long wait on a Friday night (not knowing the Sea Bass goodness to come). There were some free corn tortillas, fresh corn chips, and 3 lovely salsas; all made in-house (my Sea Bass was not made in-house, it was made in the sea by Mr. Sea Bass and Mrs. Sea Bass.  But my Sea Bass was made into yummy food in-house).  My man got some chicken dish which was amazing (but not as amazing as my Sea Bass).  

If you can't tell already, I was in love with the fish of the day. You guessed it, SEA BASS!  Perfect crispy skin, flaky inside.  The Sea Bass was flavored simply with generous amounts of black pepper and a bit of salt, but was not over-seasoned. The sea bass was on a perfectly cooked bed of asparagus and a light creamy sauce on the bottom.  The simplicity of the seasoning and perfect preparation let the yummy fish shine like the star in the velvet night sky.

My man was pretty much sick of hearing the word "Sea Bass" by the end of the night.  Much like you are probably sick of me writing the word "Sea Bass" so many times in this post.

This was quite healthy and surprisingly affordable considering the location and the quality of food and service.

I'm a fan and will return.
author: Susan C.

description:
Came here with the hubbie and a friend on a recent visit to San Francisco.
The place is located near Union Square so it could be a tourist trap but we were happy to find that it was not.

The service was prompt and very friendly. The decor really authentic depicting real Mexican Dia de los Muertos decorations.

The guacamole is prepared table side and it was really , really good. The chips were fresh and the Margaritas were the bomb!. We were lucky to have been there during Happy Hour so they were 2 for 1. Yay!!

The food was also really good. I tried mole a long time ago and did not like it so i didn't have it again. However, being in San Fran i figured i couldn't go bad with Mexican food so i decided to try the chicken mole. It was delicious!!!.Our friend also tried the mole and my husband had the burrito.
Everything was fresh, well prepared and the whole staff made us feel welcome and well taken care of. Me like.
author: Carolina M.

description:
This is just for dessert and cocktail. My boyfriend and I just had a bad experience at a previous Mexican restaurant we attempted to eat dinner at; I was still craving Mexican food so we thought to come here, just for the stuffed cajeta churros, other yelpers were raving about. I also ordered a pomegranate Martini, (had to take bad mole taste out), and my bf ordered a Cuba Libre while waiting for dessert. 
Place- seems upscale but was not, our churros came with vanilla ice cream on top of what looked like brown sugar, at first bite I knew that it was crumbled Maria's cookies, nice touch. Camera churros-warm, freshly made, yummy! Martini was refreshing, advice to one bartender, to quite, learn to BS with customers..I thought they teach this in bartending school
author: Mari H.

description:
Came here on a quiet Tuesday with hubby hoping to get some authentic Mexican food. He previously ate here a year ago and bragged about their filet mignon which is the second most expensive dish they have on the menu after lamb shank. I was so stoked about it and of course we wanted to pair them with margaritas. We ordered house which they charge 10 bucks. Didn't like the flavor and it was very weak. It tasted like a lemonade. Slurped it very quickly. I assumed because it is house margarita, let me switch to premium one, ordered another with the meal. God damn! Weak as hell again. No margarita flavor whatsoever and it is $12! 
Ordered fillet mignon medium and came out well done on top of a tiny mashed potato. I believe It was half the size of a fillet mignon because it only took me 4 bites to finish it. Thank god we also ordered the corn bread with it but it still didn't help my stomach growl. Spent $150 with tip, no buzz and still hungry... No Bueno Colibri!
author: Emre T.

description:
small portions, big prices.  i had a tamarind prawn dish, and the plate basically just consisted of 5 prawns and a corn cake.  good thing they give you a lot of fresh tortillas and salsas, b/c that's what got me full.

i guess they used to make guac fresh at the table, but not anymore.  the portion looks really big, but they actually put a little plastic plate in the molcajete, so it's a lot more shallow than it looks.
author: Helen T.

description:
Found this place before coming on vacation and boy was I happy I made a reservation! Even on a Monday night there was a 2 hour wait! And for good reason... this place is amazing! First off their margaritas are made with authentic, flavorful tequila, and they don't skimp on the alcohol.

The fresh guacamole is a must-try, along with their house made tortillas. We also had the prawns in mole sauce and the carnitas, which simply melted in your mouth. Their fresh baked chocolate cake was a great ending to the fabulous meal.

I wish I lived in San Fran just so I could go to back to this restaurant!
author: Kiva L.

description:
I'm slightly intrigued at the high ratings - while Colibri offers upscale Mexican cuisine, I still can't believe they charge $14 for Guacamole with chips. While the Guac is delicious and is served beautifully with a spread of 2-3 additional sauces, the prices here are just pretty steep for Mexican food in my opinion. 

I dropped nearly $100 on Guac, a "pitcher" of mediocre sangria (really just a carafe) that had no fruit in it at all, and a couple of beers/drinks.

The lighting is bright and the inside feels pretty casual, albeit "upscale." Although the food is decent and they make authentic tortillas (handmade by a tortilla lady in the kitchen and they come out piping hot), I just don't think this spot is a good value for a date night or two people. It is probably more oriented for large party sizes so all the entrees can be shared in a large group setting. 

Overall, a convenient Mexican restaurant by Union Square, but nothing to rave about. While I don't mind spending money on good food, I personally prefer Mexican food to be filling, tasty, but also of good value.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Came in on a weeknight on Monday and loved the ambience. They have soft music playing and the decor on the walls brings about a serene atmosphere. 
I ordered a chicken dish for entree called Pechuga. 
The concoction was very interesting, it had a delicious sauce on which the slightly crusted grilled chicken was served. The chicken was stuffed with corn and mushroom which very much complimented each other. I shall definitely be back to try something new when I come next. Definitely recommended!
author: Neil S.

description: Amazing fresh guacamole!  We've eaten here twice, and every dish at the table was delicious.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I never thought I would have the chance to order a filet mignon at a Mexican restaurant, but since I had the opportunity here I knew I had to.

I went here with a friend based on recommendations--she had been hearing it was a great spot and always wanted to try it. I would say the food is very good and authentic, but not exactly what you'd expect at a Mexican restaurant. We had chips and salsa and guacamole, but there were a lot of dishes on the menu that felt more like elegant dishes that would be available a more American restaurant, but with a twist (like a sauce) that's more common with Mexican food.

I would recommend trying it, though I think I'm more of a fan of less authentic Mexican food and am more drawn to those restaurants.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Went here for a birthday dinner last Friday night with three other girls and I must say it's now a cool spot I can add to my list of places to eat/drink near Union Square. It was refreshing to hear they take reservations and although it was decently packed it was never too loud and the ambiance was relaxing and hip. 
Some cons: 
-they don't serve complimentary chips BUT they did give us some corn tortillas to have with a trio of salsas, which I didn't object to.
-their dishes are pricey but it's an upscale-ish restaurant, so I figured that going in. 

I ordered the chile relleno with vegetables and cheese and I was surprised to find that it was much healthier than I expected. Don't get me wrong -- I love the batter in traditional chile rellenos so I was expecting that with my dish but it was just the chile stuffed with veggies and cheese and some sour cream on top. It admittedly lacked a bit of flavor but I used the salsa on the table to spice it up a bit. I wouldn't order it again -- but other dishes at the table looked pretty good. 

Overall, it's not my preferred place for upscale Mexican food (I like West of Pecos in the mission and Comal in Berkeley better) but I would be interested in coming back and trying more of their menu. Also their brunch and bottomless mimosas sound awesome!
author: Jean L.

description:
Preface: Avoid eating here at all costs.
We came here last week for our friend's birthday dinner. We had Miguel as our waiter and he was alright until the check came--totaling almost $450. As a party of six, with each couple totaling around $65, we quickly brought the attention to our waiter to "fix" our bill. I have attached a photo as evidence. He charged us an extra 3 margaritas, beers (no one ordered beer), tostadas, a filet entrée, duck entrée and several other meals that we never ordered/or were served. His first attempt at "fixing" the bill meant taking $100 off--but it was still WRONG. The third attempt he brought over the manager, a short and stout soft spoken man who then started arguing with us at the table about what we ordered. He and the waiter go back for 30 minutes ((it is now past midnight and we just want to leave the restaurant)) and come back with a 4th bill that is STILL WRONG. At this point everyone at the table is very upset at being mistreated, they obviously thought we were drunk enough to just throw our credit cards in the folder and not check that they weren't scamming us. Then the manager yells at our table and then points at me and says, "You come out back with me!". Excuse me? I refuse and our friend, who is celebrating his birthday, goes outside with the manager instead. As soon as the little man leaves the area, this large Hispanic woman, named Natalie Lopez (as she proudly says to report her as)  pounces on our table and accuses all of us of being "racist pigs" because we were disputing our bill. She says that we have "white privilege" and goes on and on expressing her grievances. She screams at us for a good ten minutes, while we try to defend the fact that we were being charged more than $250 over what we ordered! This woman was out of control, not to mention out of line for yelling at paying patrons of an establishment, and should NEVER be working in a customer-service environment. So all in all, this place should be reported for falsifying bills and I would definitely check your credit card receipts if you've eaten here! They have very shady practices! Don't eat here!
author: Elizabeth H.

description: We had a large party come in on short notiice, and the serving staff could not have been more flexible and accommodating.  We very much enjoyed the food, especially guacamole, ceviche and fish tacos.  Thank you to the management and servers who were so kind, accommodating and generous.  Highly recommend this as a great place for a range of palates and foodies as they have mild to moderately spicy food, fresh ingredients, creative dishes, and both veggie and meat options.
author: Deborah D.

description:
This was a great find!!!! My wife and I had brunch here and it was amazing!!!! I had the shredded chicken omelet and it was soooo good! Taste explosion. My wife had the chiliquelies(sp?) and she said it was the best brunch/breakfast dish she had ever had. 

It is not in in the best part of town BUT sometimes that is where you find the best eats. Our service was fine.... Not sure what all these haters on Yelp are griping about the service for. 

I would highly recommend this place for brunch. We will go back next time we are in SF.
author: Chris E.

description: So good! The food was fast and tasty. All the servers were nice. I would absolutely recommend this place to any San Fran travelers.
author: Ashley A.

description:
I've always loved this place, but tonight, I came in alone and ordered the guacamole. My waiter caught me tirelessly picking the cilantro out of my guac with a fork, like I do, because after eating Mexican food regularly for 31 years I still forget to order food without it. He INSISTED on getting me a new bowl of guacamole, even though I'd already eaten half of the cilantro-infested one. When another waiter delivered the new bowl to my table, he teased, "Guacamole, extra cilantro!"

Seriously, I love you guys. Keep up the good work.
author: K H.

description: Walked in on a Saturday night and was told that if we don't have a reservation it's an hour wait. We ended up just sitting at the bar to eat and meanwhile all around us were empty tables the entire time we ate at the bar. Passed the bar they have a bigger seating area that was half empty the whole time as well. I'm not sure why we were told that it was an hour wait but it's disappointing. When it comes to the food, it was decent but very small portions considering the price paid. $14 for a side of guac???!! I guess coming from San Diego where there is amazing, cheap Mexican food everywhere it was a shock. We didn't even get drinks because the food prices and sizes were not adequate.
author: Nkechi M.

description:
Dining experience was fair.   
My husband ordered a Michelada that consisted of beer, lime and a salted rim with a tiny flask of tomato juice for us to pour in ourselves.   Where is the rest of the spices?   We were eager to taste their signature homemade tortillas, but greeted with semi cold tortillas instead.   The salsa's were tasty but keep in mind chips are extra so don't anticipate any automatically coming to your table.  We ordered the chile relleno plate.    The vegetable and cheese relleno is  pretty much a chile stuffed with vegetables.  If your a "cheese" fan you will definitely be disappointed.  The desserts if anything were decent.  I recommend the churros.   They came to our table warm, soft on the inside and crunchy on the outside.  The crepes were acceptable but extremely sweet.  I will not be eager to return having closer authentic Mexican restaurants in my neighborhood.
author: Qiana V.

description:
Made with purpose.

At work: www.imperative.com/

At dinner: Legendary guacamole is that good. Served in a huge bowl with homemade tortillas. Together they make a fresh, delicious combo. Medium spice was just enough.

Glad there was still room for the chicken breast stuffed with mushrooms, zucchini and fresh corn. Rich in flavor especially paired with a rich garlic sauce. Each ingredient shined.

Everything goes well with sangria. Especially here with a "secret ingredient" that remains a secret. Plenty of fruit. Plenty good.

We went early but by 7pm the place was filling up and had a consistent but not overpowering buzz. Space is filled with bold color and a personal feel. Table felt intimate despite the crowd.

Surprised such an established and touted restaurant near Union Square could still price entrees in the $15 - $20 range. Felt worth it. Friendly and attentive staff made us feel welcome. 

Four purposeful stars.
author: Jason B.

description: Always a favorite. Great staff. Real Mexican food. Sit at the bar and order from the full menu. Last night Posole Verde was exactly what we needed. That and a couple of margaritas with the tequila of the month. Don't miss it if you are in town for business or pleasure.
author: Tiger A.

description:
After reading the pretty stellar reviews for this place, I decided that I had to try this place out.  One reviewer named it the "best Mexican restaurant in the U.S."
So I got roped into this place by the reviews.

Keep in mind, this review is based on a one-time visit.

We made reservations, and then we had to switch the time at the last minute and it was no problem.  It was a weekend at peak time, so I thought they would be packed, but they weren't.  That, for me, wasn't a good sign.  When we arrived, we found many open tables.

Here's what we ordered:

COCKTAILS - We ordered a Mojito and another one I can't remember, but they were both very strong.  I didn't really care for mine, so I asked if they could add more mango puree to my drink.  Kudos to them for offering to get me a new drink.  Still didn't like the second one they brought me, although the pressure was on for me to like it!

CHICKEN CHILI VERDE - Waiter's recommendation.  Sorry, wasn't my thing.  Didn't like the sour taste of the salsa.  It was served over tortilla chips. 

CARNE ASADA PLATE - My wife seemed pretty happy with this plate.

CHURROS - Probably the best dish of the lunch.  Filled with a caramel/custard filling.  Very good. Hit the spot.

Based on the food I had this time, I'm not motivated to come back.  There are way too many restaurants in SF to try and so little time.  I'm afraid I'm going to have to move on.  As I mentioned earlier, first time here, but I'm pretty sure it's not one of the best Mexican restaurants in the U.S.  Pretty confident in saying that some Yelper was definitely over-reacting on that one.
author: Darien R.

description:
San Francisco is well-known for it's foodie reputation so when I have out-of-town visitors, they always expect an awesome meal, and Colibri never disappoints!! Between me and my various visitors, we've had pretty much every item on the menu. Let's be clear: this is NOT "tex-mex". This is authentic central Mexican food, meaning there are NO burritos are on the menu. What's great about this is that I feel like I've inherited an adorable Mexican grandmother who insists on cooking for me every time I come over, except, in reality, I've stumbled onto a gem of a restaurant that I can eat at anytime I want! 

Top Food picks: get a Guacamole for the table (comes with handmade tortillas and three fresh salsas - YUM), Tostadas de Tinga, either carnitas or the Filet Mignon for main dish, and finish it off with the churros and ice cream dessert....you'll be glad you did! 

One of my favorite things about Colibri is their extensive drink menu. Their tequila collection is absolutely incredible. I can't seem to leave that place without at least one house margarita, but I've also asked the waiter for a surprise margarita and have always liked what they brought me. (bonus: bottomless mimosas during their weekend brunch for $11! WIN.) 

The servers are always so on top of it, often times filling up waters and replacing tortillas before we even realize they're low. Not once have they forgotten something we asked for, and I never feel like they're rushing me to finish. Tonight, the manager (Dennis?), stopped by our table to make sure everything was perfect, and I have to admit that it's no surprise that everyone is so on top of it in that restaurant! It's apparent that he truly values each customer and wants to make sure we have a good experience. His attitude is clearly rubbing off on his team, and it's my experience tonight that made me want to write this review, although I've been eating here for years! Keep up the good work Colibri! : )
author: Melanie M.

description:
I won't write a long review here, because this place has probably got a million good reviews already.  I will just say two things:

1) This place was recommended to me by one of my good friends who has lived in San Francisco for a long time, and she knows what she's talking about. Her family has been involived in the hospitality industry for many years. So I knew Colibri would be good.

2) We ordered the appetizer of guacamole with hand made corn tortillas. The guacamole was delicious, just the way I would expect it to be made.The hand made corn tortillas - those were the best I have ever tasted in my life. You won't find many hand made corn tortillas... Hard to compete with the tortilla making machines.. But as soon as I opened up the warm towel containing the corn tortillas my eyes lit up.   The best I have ever seen or tasted in my life, and I have had hand made corn tortillas many times.
author: Harry M.

description:
I really didn't want to 'do' Mexican in San Francisco, especially coming from Los Angeles. Luckily, I was cajoled into going to Colibri. What an experience.

From the moment we were seated, walking past the ornate, tequila-centric bar into the dining room - adorned with old art from Central Mexico as well as one of the more impressive tequila collections housed on the West Coast - we were treated like royalty. The staff was excellent, and so were the margaritas. At only $5 with a lunch special (and this was at 3pm), we worked our way through the first delicious agave concoction while munching on the homemade, warm tortillas with three salsas - a beautiful, smokey number; a fruity, light salsa and a hard-hitting serrano verde. Great start to the meal. 

Following up with the pozole verde, we were transported to puebla or michoacan as the rich lusciousness of the broth was matched only by the harmony of the hominy and tender chicken. The generous cabbage, radish, red onion, oregano & lime condiment plate was the standard perfectionist complement to the starter. Served with tostadas, this was easily a meal in itself. 

For the entrees, we ordered the mole poblano - a work of art in itself, and as delicious as it was beautiful - as well as the tacos surtidos, which included a trio of fresh, fist-sized tacos (fish w/ papaya pineapple; chicken w/ chipotle cream; steak with red onion & cabbage). 

We couldn't resist ordering dessert. The churros rellenos reflected the traditional pastry, filled with cajeta & caramel & served with dulce de leche ice cream, it made for a perfect cap on a wonderful meal. 

I will absolutely recommend Colibri Mexican Bistro on the same level as a Red O, Mercado or La Serenata De Garibaldi in Los Angeles. Great food, buen sabor.
author: Evan L.

description: Sangria was a little weak and the guacamole under-salted... But the corn tortillas are soft and flavorful, the posole was rich and delicious and the churros look AMAZING! They're served with dulce de leche ice cream and next time we'll indulge for sure.
author: Rachel B.

description: Delicioso! We enjoyed our dinner very much. Everything was very tasty. Especially the Chile Rellenos, sopa de tortilla & sopes. Homemade tortillas and salsas were a great start!
author: Beth E.

description:
Oh Colibri, how could you get a bottomless mimosa brunch so wrong? Let me count the ways.

My friend and I sat at a booth table directly next to other patrons, despite the fact that the restaurant was mostly empty and there were plenty of other seats. I just want to say I'm not a fan of this style of seating, I feel like I'm involved with the other party's conversation, maybe because I'm a serial eavesdropper. Either way, whatever, it was a seat and the restaurant is really nice inside. 

So we ordered bottomless mimosas which are $10 with an entree and were asked if we wanted to order, but we said we wanted to have a few drinks and look over the menu before choosing our food. So our glasses emptied. And we waited. And waited. And flagged down busboys and waiters and were largely ignored. 

Ummm, it's bottomless mimosas and we are paying customers, I think it's only fair to keep the glasses full, and there were not many other people in the restaurant. This happened several times, and we were asked several more times if we were ready to order. I was having flashbacks of my childhood, basically being told that I had to eat my veggies before I could have a dessert. They were definitely holding out on our drinks, and we were not having it. 

Side note: even if we didn't order an entree, they would have made MORE money off of us if they had charged per glass, so not sure why they were pressuring us to order and not serving us drinks. ALSO, the mimosas were excessively sweet, like syrupy sweet, I added a little lemon juice which made them bearable.

So when we did order our entrees, we were both unimpressed. She had the Pozole Verde ($13) which was very small for the price, but the flavor was pretty good. It came with diced radish and romaine lettuce garnish. I had the Tacos de Huevos con Chorizo ($12) which consisted of three teeny tiny corn tortillas with a scrambled eggs/chorizo combo and grilled Nopales. The tacos were bland, but our waiter brought out a tray of different salsas, my choice was habanero and it was very spicy and made the tacos taste better.

Overall, I must say that I will not be back, nor would I recommend this spot to others. One star for being a nice restaurant and one star because our server was nice after we ordered our food. There are plenty of other Mexican restaurants that serve larger portions and serve tastier food.
author: Crystal C.

description:
When I first stepped into Colibri I thought this place looks too fancy to be an authentic Mexican restaurant. That misconception went out the window when I started to talk to the hostess and bartender. 

The bartender Jesus was amazing. He was attentive, friendly and knowledgeable of his tequila and he is from La Capital, El DF. He was on top of my order and drinks, I even offered to buy him a shot of Don Julio. He accepted the shot and then he got me two sample shots of tequila, Casa Noble and another one I forgot the name. Maybe I should stop drinking?

I ordered my food and Jesus brought out some handmade tortillas and three salsas. I love the concept of no chips and salsa and just bring out some awesome tortillas. The portions were well served and not too big. Now on to the Carnitas. First a little Carnitas history since Carnitas are from my parents home state of Michoacan. Carnitas are a gift to you from the lovely people of Michoacan, you're welcome. Carnitas means "Little Meats", the pork is simmered until the meat is tender and cooked over very low heat. Once the Carnitas are cooked the heat is turned up and the top of the pork begins to crisp. Colibri has their Carnitas game down. 

The meat was soft yet crispy on the outside, the rice was traditional Spanish rice served with a side of beans. As I was eating my Carnitas more delicious tortillas came out. Jesus suggest we try the dessert.  My friend had the Caballeros Pobres which means "The Poor Gentlemen" when I tasted this dessert it automatically reminded me of a traditional Mexican dessert my mom makes, its called Capirotada. It is pretty much a very sweet bread pudding. If I can pinpoint this traditional Mexican dessert that my momma makes this place is LEGIT! 

I ordered the Churros stuffed with Cajeta and served with a side of ice cream. I ate each and every single crispy cinnamony churro deliciousness. Colibri is outstanding, their bartender Jesus was awesome and their food delicious.
author: Veronica H.

description:
This place is amazing. As a native of Phoenix, AZ, I was not sure what I would find for excellent, classy Mexican food in San Francisco. This place exceeds my expectations. 

We got the guacamole, filete mignon, mole poblano and the coffee-tequila flan. The guacamole was amazing and came with excellent small tortillas, fresh-made and hot. The steak was perfectly cooked, tender, and had an amazing sauce with delicious mashed potatoes. The mole poblano was perfectly smoky and rich, and didn't overwhelm the chicken it covered at all. And the coffee-tequila flan was delicious as well. All would be must-gets if you come here, but I'm guessing everything else is delicious as well.

We also got a tequila flight (I'm a tequila fan) and it was excellent. It also led me to a new favorite tequila - clase azul.

We will definitely be back for a nice dinner in the future.
author: Samuel F.

description: I ordered a bloody marry and it was nice and spicy. However the guacamole lacked alittle flavor. Other than that the food was great and be service was fantastic.
author: Jasmine T.

description:
Atmosphere is a cozy-busy with focus on the bar, which is where I'd recommend parking yourself.  If you go my route and order the lavender real, you'll be relaxed in no time!  Great drink with a chilled, subtle flavor.

They bring your out some homemade tortillas and a trio of sauces, it's just like being back in Baja California.  Sweet, spicy, and afterburn, there is something on the sauce plate for everyone!

The food was delicious, though a by pricy, but it seems most of San Francisco is, never thought I'd find DC to be cheaper!
author: Kate B.

description: Grabbed a quick drink and guacamole at the bar on NYE day. Surprisingly quiet despite the proximity to Union Square. Fantastic margaritas with a wide selection of tequila.
author: Nicholas N.

description:
Food was amazing. Fresh, hot homemade tortillas with fresh variety of salsas.  Queso fundido was jaw droppingly delicious.  Pozole was splendid, flavorful, fresh - so yummy.  Bottomless mimosas...uhm...yes please.

Service was impeccable - you Rock Armando!!!!!
author: Rachael C.

description:
We were staying at a hotel just around the corner and decided to try this place out after seeing pictures of their dessert. It's a bit on the pricier side but soo worth it. 

Their handmade tortillas are amazing as well as the 3 different salsas, the perfect thing to munch on while you wait for your meal. 

We decided to order the guacamole as a starter which was really fresh and yummy! Not sure it's worth the $12... but I can never say no to guac. 

For our entrees we ordered the Mole Poblano ($18) which I only had a few bites of but the flavors were amazing. I ordered the Pato en Mole Verde Pipián ($22) and it was SO. Freakin. Good. Hands down the best duck I have ever tasted and it went perfectly with their special green mole sauce. Worth every penny.

We also ordered a Strawberry Basil Margarita (not bad) and The Last Mariachi (super strong).

By the end of our meal we were so stuffed that it wasn't until after we left that we realized we forgot our main reason for going there...to order dessert!
author: Ashley Y.

description:
Every part of our meal at this place was amazing! I'm not a huge Mexican food fan, but this place has me sold.

We went for lunch. The meal starts with warm tortillas and three kinds of salsas. I got the tacos three ways (fish, chicken, steak). At $15 for three small tacos, it was kind of pricey, but they were delicious. For $5 extra, you can add on a margarita or chips or churros. My friends went with margaritas, and I got the churros.

The churros were HEAVENLY. One order comes with 4 churros as well as a scoop of dolce de leche ice cream. The churros were freshly made and super crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Probably the best churros I have ever had in my life. They were really sweet, though. I split the four churros with two other people and I think it was a perfect portion.

TL;DR: get the churros.
author: Maggie Y.

description: We went for a early dinner hoping the service would be quick . But we were disappointed. We had to ask for water at least 3 times and our drinks took 20 minutes to arrive even when we could see the bar tender was just chatting with some other customers. Food was not unusual for San Francisco standards. We had fish taco and tostadas Tinga and for main course we had chicken mole and stuffed chicken .
author: Bhumi D.

description:
Nice place and most of the food tasted good. My friend thought her dish (sopes) tasted a little off so I switched plates with her and I was the only one to get food poisoning. I threw up many times over two days, was nauseated for almost one week, and missed several days of work. I reached out to Colibri via phone and through their website and no one has contacted me. 

Maybe it's a one time deal - a cook or server didn't wash their hands well enough, but since this place completely ignored my complaint, I feel like they couldn't care less that their food made me incredibly sick. Not going back and will never recommend.
author: Erica G.

description:
Another wonderful brunch at Colibri!  Every time I come to town brunch here is first on our list!  Considering all dining options in the city, this spot is the one we keep returning to.
The service is outstanding and the food is delicious!  You can't beat the $10 bottomless mimosas and stacks of their wonderful corn tortillas.  
The friendly staff and warm décor makes for an outstanding experience!
author: Brienna W.

description:
Looking for some delicious Mexican fare? This place has it goin' on!
From phenomenal guacamole (some of the best I've ever had), cheesey quesadillas, fresh seafood dishes, and a tequila list longer than most, I say that this place deserves a solid five stars from this gal!

The staff is friendly, the food is fresh, the drinks are delicious, and their margarita selection is impressive! Come on a date or group dinner, they have room to fit larger groups in their comfy booths. Gotta love a good booth! No matter how small or big your appetite is upon arrival, I highly recommend getting some of their guacamole along with their delicious complimentary chips and sauces (they give you 3!). Very very good.
author: Akvile D.

description:
Came to Colibri with my girlfriends on a Sunday night for appetizers & drinks! 

We got seated right away (made reservations -- literally, minutes before we walked in) 

For appetizers we got guacamole & the queso fundido con chorizo. BOTH delicious & I highly recommend! They also hook you up with warm tortillas & 3 different salsas. I rolled up some queso in the tortilla & it was yummy. *Note* eat the queso while it's still hot.. Dipping chips into hard cheese is no bueno!

For drinks our table got margaritas & sangria. I don't think you can mess those up in a Mexican restaurant :P 

Overall, great place near Union Square to dine in, grab a few drinks & catch up with some friends.
author: Rose R.

description:
We had lunch today at Colibri based on many of the 4 and 5 star ratings. The lunch was disappointing and expensive. I tried the carnitas for $20. It was a small portion, tasted like it was mostly deep fried and came with tiny portion of rice. How much extra would it cost Colibri to serve a reasonable portion of black beans and rice? Instead they want you to buy it as a $5 side.

This restaurant has unremarkable food at remarkably high prices. With so many outstanding mexican restaurants in SF that have better food for a lower price, the only reason to pick Colibri is the location (which is why we at there).

I have no need to try it again.
author: Bob E.

description:
I haven't found anything about the restaurant to give it 5 stars, but their take on mexican food is pleasing and tasty.  The chorizo queso is deliciously greasy, the guacamole is one of the best I've had (Tacolicious and Chipotle have other "best" guacamoles by my standards, 'NO' to the brownish slop sitting all day that most taquerias shovel at you) the filet steak, the tacos, fish, chicken dinner, margaritas- loved it all.  I really prefer the option of going to a nice, non-chain sit-down restaurant for Mexican food once in a while, as a change from the dine and dash feel of taquerias.  GET THE CORNBREAD!

The food isn't necessarily good for you, but you can make some good healthful choices form the menu.  The atmosphere is different between the front and back of the restaurant- the back is harshly lit with a more ragged feel while the front is embellished and elegant.  Will be coming back for more soon!
author: Xander M.

description:
I've never heard of Colibri before but a couple friends and I decided to catch up for brunch here. I try and avoid most restaurants nearby the Union Square area since most are geared to tourists and out of towners but it sufficed and I didn't regret dining here. 

We started off with an order of guacamole which accompanied corn tortillas. You fill your tortilla with guacamole and eat it like a guacamole taco. Interesting but tasty. For my entree, I had the Huevos Rancheros. Had the basics of any decent HR dish. It was okay bordering good. 

Service was fine. No complaints. Our bottomless mimosa flutes were constantly refilled without us even noticing we needed top-offs.

Colibri is nowhere near the best Mexican food available in the SF but I suppose a good option when in this part of the city. As someone who's been eating Mexican food for as long as I can remember, I wasn't particularly wowed by it. But one thing's for sure, it beats going to the Cheesecake Factory and chowing down on their mini-pillow sized burritos or their 3,000 calorie'd nachos with all the fixin's.
author: Esther A.

description:
Meh, not as impressed as everyone else said. The food had potential, but didn't exactly deliver. I ordered the carnitas after reading all the rave reviews about how tender it was. Since it was cut into large chunks, the inside was kind of dry and lacking flavor. Being from the South, I couldn't help but compare it to pulled pork (or even Chipotle's carnitas)... and this couldn't compare to the flavor it should have had. Portions were okay for me, but some of my guy friends expected more food for what they paid.

Not a bad deal for the experience. The tables and interior were really nice, and the hostess warned us to not hit our knees on the table legs (which we did anyway, but she did the best she could). The server was nice, but didn't come around as much as I expected. We split the check five ways (sorry), and he brought out a weird assortment of receipts--some pairs of receipts were printed twice, some only had the customer copy. Oh well, good intentions.
author: Kimberly Y.

description: The restaurant has a very nice feel to it and the food is very good. However, there are some things that bring my rating down to average. One, our server was not very friendly, especially (I feel) after she found out we were not getting drinks. Two, when you order Camarones con Mole, you are literally getting shrimp in mole sauce. They do not give you any sides, so if you want more you have to pay more, which I feel is cheating the customer a bit since you are already paying a lot for their food. I will say what I ordered was delicious as well as their home made guacamole. And granted, this is the city, but still, don't expect a lot of food for a decent price.
author: Dani W.

description: Wow! What an experience. Great food great service. If you're ever in Union Square you must come here.
author: Sal S.

description:
My boyfriend and I tried this place about a month ago while Christmas shopping in SF. We weren't super hungry so we just wanted a snack and drinks.  Even on a Sunday, it was pretty packed in there so we decided to sit at the bar.  Bartender was attentive and all our food came out as specified. 
PROS:
-Dark and dimly lit inside (I like that vibe)
-Black & white Spanish movies playing on the TV in the bar
-Guacamole (fresh and yummy)
-Trio of Salas (yellow, sweet mango one was the best)
-Interesting drinks (there's a margarita made with jalapeños drenched in 151 and then lit on fire) 
-Warm homemade tortillas
CONS:
-Chips cost extra and they're something like $3 a basket, so you feel like you have to ration your chips 
-Food is good but not phenomenal (chips, pozole, empanadas) 
-A bit on the pricy side
-Pretty small restaurant, so not for people that dislike feeling cramped or get claustrophobic 

Overall, this is a cute spot with good drinks and decent food.  I haven't tried the entrees so maybe those are their specialty.  I think I'd come again if I was in Union Square and wanted a drink and small bite again.  I don't know that this will be a regular for me though as it's pretty expensive for what you're getting and didn't really blow me away.
author: Jen H.

description:
I come here all the time and this is by far my favorite high end mexican restaurant in SF. Ive become quite the margarita snob and these are some of the best imaginable. My favorite food item is the filet mignon on the dinner menu and to drink is the fresh jalapeño margarita. Both are must haves for anyone visiting.
Also they have an excellent happy hour during the week and a great bottomless mimosa brunch on the weekends.
author: Zino M.

description: I love this place. Have been three times in the last month or so. Great margaritas, yummy food. Brunch is really great. My only recommendation- thicker chips that will hold up to the very delicious guacamole & queso fundido.
author: Ernest S.

description:
What a lucky find, thanks to yelp. On my trip to SF my bf & I were hungry after a long day doing the touristy things. We stayed at Parc 55 so we looked on yelp for nearby locations. It was a fast walk-- maybe 5 minutes away. 

They give you some warm tortillas with 3 salsas, I believe 1 hot, 1 mild and another sweet? Anyways, they were all good, but my fave was the hot one! For my entree I ordered the Carnitas (Michoacan-style marinated tender chunks of pork served with guajillo, arbol chili salsa, and Mexican rice.) And the bf ordered the special (I forgot what it was..maybe tacos but it was DELICIOUS, better than my dish). My dish was good but after trying my bf's food, I was jealous.

For dessert, I had the "Churros Rellenos" (Traditional Hispanic pastry filled with cajeta caramel cream and served with dulce de leche ice cream.). I am a dessert person, and I was very happy with ending my meal with this.
author: Kristel B.

description:
Food was good, service was not. Host appeared upset that we didnt have a reservation during lunch on a Wed! Also we didn't have anyone come to our table to take orders or bring waters until I finally flagged someone. 

Another note, portions are small for the price so don't come hungry.
author: Omar O.

description:
went in on a sunday afternoon. BOTTOMLESS MIMOSAS ??? Woot woot !
food is solid, and very filling. 
I ordered the guacamole medium, and the Desayuno Mexicano. 
The guacamole was absolutely delicious, with a lime tang I very much enjoyed. 
The desayuno Mexicano comes with small skirt steak, that is very tender and juicy. It comes alongside rice and refried beans, it is too much food for one person, so I recommend coming with another person.
author: Ericka M.

description:
Had planned to go to Tropisueno that night but it was closed due to some maintenance problems. Luckily with some fast yelping and determination to find a good margarita, my friend and I found Colibri. 

The hostess stated a 45 minute wait, but I felt more like 25 minutes, so they definitely overestimated, which I'd rather have than underestimated. But you can order drinks at the bar while you're waiting. I ordered the house margarita, which was quite amazing. I like my margaritas strong and more on the sour side than sweet and this was the perfect mix. 

When we got seated to out table, service was fast.  My friend and I ordered the guacamole to share, but for some reason you have to add $2 for chips. Not sure why you have to because I'm not sure what you'd with the guac without chips unless you're on a low carb diet, but in that case you probably shouldn't be at a Mexican restaurant. The guacamole was creamy and spicy. I would definitely recommend. 

For the entrée, I ordered the carnitas, which were dry. I wasn't impressed. My friend got the mole poblano, and his was a lot more tender and juicy. Definitely would recommend that over the carnitas. 

Overall, I wasn't impressed or excited about Colibri food, considering how everything on the menu was about $20+. I've definitely had better Mexican food for cheaper.
author: Jade L.

description: A friend and I were in the area to see a show nearby. He had been here before so we stopped in for some dinner. No reservation and the hostess said they had a table but needed it in an hour. Which was fine since we had the show anyways. So we were seated. There seemed to be plenty of empty tables. And it didn't get much fuller by the time we left, a little over an hour later. I'm sure there's some padding anyways Or they're trying to seem more popular than it really was. We started with drinks. I had a glass of sangria. It was delicious. Mmm. For food, I ordered the fish tacos. I thought I heard the waiter repeat it back to me. But out came the chile relleno. Does fish tacos sound like chile relleno? Maybe. I maybe should have ordered it how it's stated on the menu - tacos de pescado. We were on a bit of a schedule and I was hungry so I didn't send it back. It was a ok dish but I was disappointed that I didn't get fish tacos. Didn't meet my expectations. *sigh* I think I was only get a choice of meat with the chile relleno but I wasn't asked nor did I taste any meat so it was probably the cheese and veggie version. I need my meat. And that might've cleared up any confusion if he asked what type of chile relleno. Oh well. I doubt I'll be back in this area any time soon. Not great, in my opinion but I had a fluke time.
author: Alison W.

description: Nothing short of 5 stars. 3.5 star average does this place a disservice. Guac is on point, duck breast is delicious and the churros do not disappoint!
author: Harry E.

description: Pretty rock solid and if you want, they even do brunch. The queso dip is awesome, richly perfumed by the fat of chorizo. Please don't complain about sausage grease when your dipping into 1/2 pound of hot melted cheese. Of surprising note here are the dessert! Really fantastic but do know the chocolate cake takes 15 minutes.
author: Rob B.

description:
This place was very close on Geary to the Westin St. Francis, so off I went to explore.  I highly recommend that you call ahead and reserve a place. This place is very tiny and extremely crowded. 

I was seated promptly and I noticed that their prices are a bit on the higher side given their less than average portion size. Quality over quantity I say. 

They have a fantastic selection of tequilas and margaritas (a bit pricy though). They also offered a sampler for around $20-$30. 

I ordered the Sopes Sutros (a trio of savory treats on a small bready crust) in vegetarian only. I checked out the size of these at a nearby table and decided that I needed more food. I ordered the chips - which were fantastic!  Shortly after I started to munch on my chips, the waiter brought over some thick corn tortillas with 3 types of salsas. The mild one in yellow was the most flavorful one in my opinion. I started eating them and I was stuffed. So in the future, I would just order a main course with just chips and guacamole for appetizer. 

The Sopes finally showed and man were they worth it!!!  All I can say is wow!  By the time I polished off the last of the Sopes, I was stuffed. No room for an entree or a dessert. 

The reason I gave them only 3 stars is because of the slow service. The tables next to me were served promptly but not mine. 

I will be back again and will be a bit more intelligent with my order. I am going to try out a couple of margaritas. 

Note:  For people that enjoy hot and spicy salsa, ask your waiter/waitress for the hot habanero salsa. It will take some time to get it to your table, but well worth the wait.
author: Gopal R.

description: Piping hot, fresh tortillas.  That's pretty hard to beat.  The margarita went down easy, and the ceviche had a good amount of kick and flavor.
author: CK K.

description: The best thing I had at colibrí was the elote. It was delicious.  I chose the carnitas as my main meal and they were underwhelming. Maybe I will try something different next time. I do want to give credit for their extremely friendly customer service. The hostess was kind enough to find a table for us in a prompt manner even without a reservation. I wish I remembered our waiters name, because he was amazing. Very sweet and attentive. The ambience in laid back and it is a good place to have a nice quiet dinner.
author: Melissa L.

description: Great atmosphere, amazing happy hour and great staff!!  Great selection of tequilas, too!  Food is out of this world - tacos, etc. are so good!!!  Great spot of Geary St. for happy hour!
author: Joe M.

description: Great food and fresh tortillas. Fell in love with the bartender. She knows who she is.
author: Life I.

description:
Great food, Amazing atmosphere. Love them and made tortillas and fresh guacamole.
Best margaritas ever!!
author: Sylvia R.

description: Best queso fundido around! Excellent service and solid drinks. The chillequiles and mole both great.
author: Chase T.

description: Good food and great service. Arguably the BEST guacamole I've ever had -- ask for spicy. Even their salads were great and zesty. If you're in SF and jonesing for Mexican, this is the spot.
author: Conrad M.

description: This is the place for you if you want some acceptable Mexican food and want to pay for the ambiance. The place is pricey, and while the guac, salsas and entrees are good, you could get better food at half the price in other areas of the city. The tortillas are great because they are homemade. I was not impressed with the tortita de papas because it came with a sauce that was rather tasteless. The salsas that come with the guac are great, so I was surprised that the sauce on top of the entree didn't have enough spice. Overall, I would come here if I wanted to go somewhere "nice" and spend money.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
