People love throwing around expressions like "Authentic" and "Genuine" as ranking criteria when reviewing Mexican food. A few of the reviews I skimmed marked Colibri down for this.

My question to you: who gives a damn?! If it's good, it's good. End of story. "Authenticity" means nothing to anyone other than coin collectors and pretentious non-artists. It has no place in the dining world. Your tongue does not distinguish "authentic" no matter how refined you think you are.

What I will say about Colibri, is that the food is VERY good. We had ceviche, chilaquiles, and queso. Each almost made me cry with every bite. Do not count calories here, as it will just make you depressed. Just savor the bites.

I saved the best for last: the margaritas. It is DAMNED hard to find a decent margarita that isn't sugar mix, tequila, and salt. Most margaritas are more likely to give you diabetes than get you drunk. We had a Jalapeño (my favorite), Mezcal (super smoky), and Blackberry. I am biased towards the Jalapeño, but each were great in their own respect.

Ambience: 5/5
Food: 5/5
Service: 3/5
Drinks: 5/5
Overall: 5/5
author: Jeff B.

description:
Holy guacamole! This place is consisitently awesome.  

Order the chicken with mole sauce and make sure you sip on an Avion margarita on the rocks! 

The guacamole is delicious and served with corn tortillas.  (Chips and salsa are extra my compadres.) 

It's a great spot for small groups - just be sure to book ahead of time - and reasonable prices abound.

If you love Mexican eats - this is a fabulous location for a more upscale / gourmet take on the cuisine.  

Give it a shot! And, have a shot while you're there - the tequilla options flow nicely...
author: Gigi L.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Mexican. I really don't remember a time when I wasn't. Then I moved to New Mexico, and fell in love with their food. So because of that, I really want Mexican food to be full of flavor, and a lot of places in California are just bland in comparison. My parents suggested that we try Colibri as they've recently discovered it. I was a bit hesitant after their last suggestion, but we went for it.

I'm really glad we did. I made a booking for a Friday night around 8 pm. The place was busy when we arrived, but not packed. They do seem to have the weird partial communal dining set-up going along one wall, but luckily the table next to us was a massive table of six, so we had a lot of space to spread out. 

We ordered the guacamole and the queso fundido to start. Here, everything is served with small, delicious corn tortillas. We did pay the extra $2 for chips, but hey, the tortillas are fantastic, so it doesn't really matter. It's a bit strange though, because we weren't sure they heard both of the orders as the guac came really early (and even though we asked for it spicy, it wasn't really that spicy) so we weren't sure the queso was coming. It did finally make an appearance, and it was quite tasty. For mains we had the chicken mole and the braised lamb shank. It's sometimes easier just to eat half and split, so that's what we did. Since the mole was best (my partner swears it was better than the one I make, which reminds me I need to make it again), my partner was slightly disappointed when he had to give it up. The lamb was tasty though, just didn't really match up to the mole.

No desserts as clearly we had already eaten too much, but my partner decided to get a tequila tasting to end, and the tequilas were brilliant. And the sangrita it was served with was deliciously spicy. I just went for the Mexican coffee.

The service was a bit weird as we never really knew what was going on, but overall it was fine. Definitely one of the tastier places to get Mexican, if you find Cali-Mex bland, as I do. If you're a huge Cali-Mex fan, this may not be the place for you.
author: Grant T.

description: This place was ok, waiting staff was friendly but a bit slower than normal. The food wasn't bad by any stretch but did not wow me. The location and ambiance were cool. It feels like an upscale sports bar with a Mexican vibe. Although it didn't "Wow" me I would go back.
author: Adrian A.

description: A satisfying palette of authentic Mexican cuisine! Delightful food! Fresh ingredients create bold flavor and the mole tastes just like the mole from Merida. The salsas are fresh and unique. The mouth truly delights!
author: Kim C.

description:
A Spanish villa in Union Square, who would have guessed?

From the outside, it has black awning and signs; you would never imagine a beautifully decorated interior existed. If I could imagine a romantic, Spanish movie this is how the house would look. 

We came here with a friend who loves this place. So when she suggested we get the guac at around 10AM, I was a little hesitant. That and because I have been trying to avoid chips (of any varieties) like the plague, so I wasn't too keen on eating spoonfuls of guac. However, little did I know it was served with warm tortillas...jackpot. Not spicy, great flavor and a great appetizer for breakfast. Guac of champs :)

Our original server was awesome, he was attentive, helpful, and genuinely a sweet human being. Then his, who we assumed was his manager, came over and was awful. She tried to take our drink order when we'd already placed it, then she demanded we order shortly after. She was curt, not friendly...I'm not really sure why she even came to our table. We were content with our lovely server, whose name is currently slipping my mind.

Slightly hung over or something, I wasn't into the menu much. It's not huge, but very Mexican themed. I decided all I wanted was egg whites (which I specifically asked if they make) and a side of Spanish rice. However, when my food arrived I had two over easy eggs and my rice. I literally didn't want to interact with this woman/manager/employee, so I just ate the whites from the eggs.

Oh the coffee...that stuff was amazing. We jokingly asked the server why it was so good, he teasingly responded "because it has tequila in it"! It gave us all a good laugh, hours after we left our breakfast adventure. The coffee cups are small, espresso sized to be exact, but they kept filling our cups. I think the three of us averaged 5 cups during a 2 hour breakfast span. The coffee was perfectly roasted and the flavor was buttery delicious, I only added a hint of sugar, which is unlike me (normally it's a packet or two per cup).

We decided to splurge and shared dessert - the churros and the doughnuts. I think the doughnuts name loosely translated to poor gentleman. Of course, with that name I was destined to love that dessert more. The churros were not good, over fried, and the caramel center tasted very artificial. However, this poor gentleman doughnut was like Texas toast rolled in sugar and cinnamon. It was crunchy and soft, with just the right amount of sweetness (which tasted great with my 5th or 6th cup of coffee).

It's a tad pricey, but find a place that isn't in Union Square. The décor was adorable and we were able to guzzle gallons of delicious coffee, with one the sweetest servers ever. Their menu deserves more attempts on my part, so I won't mind visiting again...

Guac and coffee don't normally go together...but here, it's acceptable!
author: Steph G.

description:
Delicious and definitely worth the wait. They were very busy but worked quickly to find a table for us. The food is amazing and the ambiance is great. The homemade, fresh, and bottomless stack of tortillas made the whole trip worth it. But then the other dishes came out and they were even more flavorful and filling. The 4 of us shared the tostadas, sopes and plenty of tortillas, and everyone left feeling full. 
Would definitely recommend!
author: J P.

description: I was underwhelmed with the food. I may have just picked the wrong things, but they did not seem very authentic or tasty. It wasn't bad, but it didn't inspire me to go back. Seemed like it might be a better place for drinks than food. The ambiance was good but it was loud. The service was fine.
author: David T.

description: Everything was delicious. Waiter was courteous and attentive. Ordered the churros and the flan for dessert. Both as equally delicious and the food.
author: Shiree C.

description:
We had a nice ladies brunch here before a girly day of Union Sq shopping (because sometimes it's fun to live like a stereotype). I wanted something a little more unusual, so chose Colibri instead of the usual mimosas & toast spot (I'm from the North--Mexican food is a lot rarer to me). 

We shared some guacamole to start, and it was creamy and delicious, though the chips could have been better (tasted a bit stale). My entree was the carne asada estilo. Pretty satisfying, but nothing super remarkable. Service was okay. The decor is lovely, though.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Any place that charges $12 for guacamole and an extra $2 for chips... well, I should have known better. 

I took a pic of my entree, which kinda says it all, but for the avoidance of doubt: $18 went towards their "legendary" mole poblano, which is a few tbps of of bitter mole sauce poured over four bites of chicken. Not even boneless chicken. My dinner companion's vegetarian stuffed pepper was about the size of a sushi hand roll. No wonder the servers strongly encourage you to get one of their $12 appetizers: you will leave hungry (unless, like me, you eat all the warm tortillas). 

Nice atmosphere, friendly servers, nice presentation of the dishes, all that. But the money you spend will literally weigh more than your food.  Would be a good date spot on one of those first dates where your date doesn't actually want to eat and you feel like dropping some coin.
author: Rob R.

description:
Fancy little spot that does large groups well. Ease up on the chips and apps so you can make a decent dent in your main.

I had the chicken mole because it's been too long. It was better than I would have made it but still not like my grandma's - which, out of respect for my grams, was probably for the best. 

Hella margaritas and hella tequilas. My crew even did a tequila flight.

Nice spot with lots of reassuring review stickers on the door.
author: Loli L.

description: Sunday brunch was delicious! The chilequeles with green were on point, enchiladas divorcidas had just the right amount of heat and were tasty. Bottomless mimosas flowed freeley even after paying the check. The only reason for 4 stars and not 5 was they did not have any drinks for our 10yo. I guess the soda machine is broken so only options were virgin bar drinks. Otherwise, I would recommend this place as a must try!
author: Sean R.

description:
Were I a less generous man, my review might lend closer to 3.5 stars, but I'll give Colibri the benefit of a pretty good experience. There guacamole was good (and the flour tortillas are a great alternative to chips, IMO). The mole was also quite good.

Prices were a little high for medium-high quality Mexican, but the space is nice, the decorations pretty, and the location very close to my hotel! I met my friends here and we had a couple of Firestone DBAs, which was a nice option next to the standard Mexican lagers. A nice place to spend a couple of hours, though I would have to go again before recommending for Mexican purists.
author: Yan T.

description:
Our family of 4 thoroughly enjoyed our dinner at Colibri (thanks Yelp). Ramon was our server, but he had help from a young lady whose name I didn't catch. The entire experience, though, from food to service to atmosphere was such a wonderful treat after spending two days on a train from Chicago to San Francisco. 

We had the guacomole for starters, but the real hits were the entrees. My son and I both had the empanadas from the appetizer menu, my  wife had the chile relleno, and my daughter ordered the carnitas. We also shared a couple of sides--the savory cornbread and the cactus leaves.  Nothing was overpowering, and it all worked together. 

I highly recommend.
author: John P.

description:
Came here after shopping around Union square. Had ensalada flor de verano. Butter lettuce, mango, avocado, flower petals and jícama with a cilantro-basil vinaigrette. This is a fantastic salad and the dressing is especially refreshing. ($10)

Also had the soap de tortilla. A pasilla chile and tomato soup with tortilla strips, avocado, cheese and sour cream. Mild spicy soup and so rich in flavour. ($10)

The guacamole is a good way to start served with soft tortilla. ($12). They charge $2 extra for tortilla chips. 

Service. Quick and attentive. Very good service. 

Ambiance. High ceilings. Great background music. Low noise level so great for dinner conversation. Casual dress.
author: Tim N.

description:
The food was good but the service was no bueno.

$12 for good guac I'm ok with but then an additional $2 for chips. Obscure up charge. The saving grace was fresh tortillas. Situation defused. The red (hot) is nice but the green is more a kick in mouth. The orange is way to sweet for me.
Happy Cheese (Queso Fundito) $13 owweee gooowee goodness. 
Carnitas $18 but the chili relleno was a close second. Should have gone with the second. The carnitas was meat on a plate with a side of roasted salsa. While good, it was boring. Maybe with more tortillas to make my one tacos, but no. In fact, our server disappeared and we did not receive any refills. The queso went cold with no vehicle to import it into my mouth.

My guess is the bar scene is great at night but for lunch, the crowded little restaurant had no energy, just hungry paitrons looking for the tab.
author: Mark F.

description: Pretty good margaritas. The fresh homemade tortillas and salsa flight are AWESOME. I had the sopes surtidos and they were good overall -- shredded chicken and grilled veggie were amazing, but I didn't find the shredded pork one as flavorful.
author: Sarah F.

description: Casual but cool atmosphere with a wide alcohol selection. Tortillas and salsa are a must and to finish the meal the churro relleno
author: Gail N.

description: Stopped by here while wondering around the city. The atmosphere is very warm and welcoming. The drinks were phenomenal (I had the "Tequila of the Month" made with Casa Noble and the hubs has a Modelo). The bartenders were very sweet and educational. Great spot!
author: Catie C.

description: Food was decent. Bottomless mimosas for brunch.  Waitress never brought any waters for the table for the entire meal even though we were drinking and eating a lot.
author: Erin R.

description:
Nik.T wanted mexican so we were looking around at a decent join near Union to grub up on. Didn't wanna wait in line on the eve of Gay Pride so we made sure we had reservations! The place was full. No line though. Hurray for Open table. Swankier than your average mexican joint but hey it's within Union Sq. Food was good overall. Some hits and ONE BIG MISS. Can't win them all! But great seats sure helps! Great for a pow-wow with friends - Ask them for a booth :) 

1. Chili soup - creamy and not spicy (don't be fooled by the name) 

2. Lamb shank - Good! Tender with thick, brown gravy. 

3. Pork Belly - Excellent! 

4. Guacamole and chips - The  Guacamole was awesome. The chips a tad bit too hard!!! i think I might have chipped a tooth? 

5. Fish tacos - Officially the WORST I've ever had. PASS!
author: Amanda L.

description: I only had the dessert and the caballeros pobres was amazing!!! A must try if you go there. Cinnamon gooey deliciousness.
author: Brett M.

description:
I stopped by Colibri for lunch on a weekday it was surprisingly empty when we arrived around noon. This is a great place for business meetings or a casual meal with friends given the ample space, relatively quiet environment, and fast/friendly service. 

We started off with some guacamole for the table. Despite the $12 price tag, it was ordered by literally every table in the restaurant. This seems to be their specialty and is definitely worth a try. Even without the chips, the guac tastes phenomenal with their warm homemade tortillas and salsas. 

For my entree, I chose the carintas based on some yelp recommendations. When my order arrived, I was surprised that the caritas served more closely resembled pork medallions as opposed to the shredded pork I'm more familiar with. None-the-less, the pork was extremely tender and had a good ratio of fat marbled in.  It lacked a little in the flavor department but it's served with a side of salsa and lime which I drenched the meat in. 

Overall, I was very pleased with the food and service at Colibri and I hope to come back to try their chicken mole and tortita de papas! Look out for an updated review on those dishes!
author: Tiffany W.

description: A delicious explosion of flavors! Be sure to order the guacamole that comes with a variety of salsas including mango & pineapple, some smoky salsa, a green salsa, chips and soft, warm homemade corn tortillas. We had the Posole which came with a wonderful Mexican oregano and a variety of fresh vegetables. We were too full for dessert but they sure sounded good.
author: Dawn C.

description: Amazing food, can't remember if I have ever really been disappointed here.  Been here for brunch and dinner several times, and never had a bad meal.  Most of their dishes are really good and some are just ok.  Their guac is always on point, only rivaling my wife's.  Their margaritas are well balanced, and never sugary which I appreciate! Service is good, polite but they don't fawn over you.  Definitely recommend if you want some higher-end true Mexican food.
author: Saminda W.

description:
I like this place. 
We ordered 3 different dishes of pork, beef, and chicken. They were all amazing. The churros for dessert was the best churros i have ever had. 
However, the services were not as good. The waiter and waitress were rude to us.
author: Angie N.

description:
Wow their dishes were fantastic and the bottomless mimosas just kept coming!

Went here for brunch with a Friend a few Saturdays ago, it's in a very convenient location-near bart and all the mall/shopping adventures you could ask for.  The way that they served the guacamole, with little mini tortillas instead of chips, perfection!  I had the huevos poblanos con pollo, idk... it's on the menu and I added chicken since I planned a full day of Cider Summit-festing and I didn't know if they would have food.  I also got the bottomless mimosas (of course) and I truly enjoyed my experience.  
The ambiance was traditional American-Mexican with Lucha Libre on the television and a vast selection of tequila, also the place was really clean... I mean we could see that there was no dust what-so-ever on the 100 tequila bottles in the front window, pretty impressive.  They also have some interesting seating arrangements, pretty interesting.
I would definitely come here again and I would bring an appetite! Their sauces are sooooo good and the service was pretty on point, a few hiccups but nothing to subtract from my tip.
It was about $42.00 per person with bottomless mimosas, guacamole, and an entree.
**Side note, mimosas are only bottomless/$10.00 with the purchase of an entree.**
author: Sara N.

description:
My feelings on Colibri are directly correlated to the ratio of the chips to guac we received... 

A bowl of guacamole (good), have to order chips to go with it (What? ok, fine), 6 chips arrive for 6 people (GO right on out of here Colibri, go on out of here). 

1. Let's just bake in the price of chips to the guac. This feels stingy and weird. Chips go with guac -- is there another way a group of 6 would enjoy it? No. It is not a cutlery endeavor nor could we take turns licking globs out of the bowl. BRING THE CHIPS AND BRING THEM FREELY OR DO NOT SERVE GUACAMOLE. 

2. The servers were not friendly. 

The bill for 6 was not too bad ($200), and we enjoyed the sangria. 

Everything just felt a little uninspired. Granted we were all jet lagged, but it just wasn't festive and the staff surely didn't seem to be enjoying anything about being there that night. 

So that's how I felt, too. 

3-stars is pretty nice, I realize -- but the food was pretty good.
author: Colleen C.

description:
Went here last night with my wife, food is great, service is great but the internet connection was not, I had no service. 
So make sure you have lots to talk about if you're going with your wife.
author: John T.

description:
Not your typical Mexican restaurant. Colibri is a classy higher-end modern version of your favorite local Mexican eatery. The food is every bit just as good if not even better. 

I was lured here by Dine About Town event and I have never heard of this place before. Since they didn't post their DAT menu online I really had no idea what I was getting into. Most of the dishes on their DAT lunch menu were part of their regular menu. That is a welcoming sign. I really dislike it when some restaurants, especially those more expensive ones, only provide some cost cut watered down DAT 'specials' that are nothing like their regular dishes. The idea of DAT is to encourage people to get out and discover new places. It is just plain crazy to not show your customers the best. 

Out of everything I have tried, the Carnitas (Marinated chunks of pork) and Chile Relleno with Carnitas and Chicharron (Poblano pepper stuffed with pork) really stood out. They did both of these pork dish really well. The meat was well seasoned, nicely cooked to a tender yet crisp texture. Carne asada estilo Sonora (Grilled steak with cactus and portobello mushrooms) was just mediocre. I didn't find the sauce too memorable. I guess I still prefer to have my steak cooked the caveman way (grilled on open fire, seasoned with salt and pepper).

For dessert we all had the Churros Rellenos. Not sure if that is available on the regular menu but oh boy that was good. Friend of mine said that was the best Churros she had. While I am not sure if I could agree, those churros was indeed very delicious. 

The restaurant is nicely decorated with a colorful and vibrant ambiance. The bar looks lovely. I imagine it would be a great place to grab a drink at night. Can't wait to come here again for some bottomless mimosas and a weekend brunch.
author: Mona W.

description: The Restaurant has a very nice atmosphere. I did not have reservations so I sat at the bar.  Sangria was very good. I had the tortilla soup. Not good at all.  It was like having a bowl of enchilada saucI've had this soup in Mexico, Florida, Puerto Rico, Texas and New York. This is the worst yet.
author: Zoritsa R.

description:
Spending $90 to save $20... thanks BloomSpot!

Upscale Mexican is a totally unnecessary concept but, if you're going to do it, you'd be hard pressed to do it any better than Colibri.  

Here's what I tried, all of it 5-star delish.  I'd return right now and have it all again.: 
 
* A few margaritas (all different) @ $10 - $14 apiece;
* The freshest, most I'LL-HAVE-MORE-OF-THAT inducing Pescado Ceviche for $16;
* Excellent vat of guacamole served with prepared-for-me corn tortillas ($12; could've used more spice, even though we told 'em we wanted it spicy);
* Little tacos stuffed with roasted pork and pickled red onions ($12, muy perfecto); and
* Coffee-tequila flan ($8, a-ok) 

I like the look and feel of Colibri a lot.  It's got cool light fixtures, a great assortment of unusual tequila bottles in the window, comfy seats, and really good service (thanks Camilla!).  

It's always well-populated with a nice assortment of hipsters on up, many of them grabbing drinks or appetizers  before a show at ACT (which is right across the street).  Really, nothing not to like here, except for the price, which definitely adds up.  

Colibri has inspired me to learn how to make my own ceviche.  

Definitely worth checking out, expecially before a show.
author: Tracey A.

description:
This is definitely not authentic Mexican (which I knew ahead of time), but rather some sort of nouveau Mexi-Cali fusion.  Maybe?  I guess.
Service was fair at best - slow, unattentive, and uninterested.
Salsas and homemade tortillas were great while waiting for lunch.  Nice change from typical chips and salsa.  Guacamole (made to order) was good, but not great. Veggie/Cheese Chile Relleno was the same - good, not great.  Stuffed with lots of carrots, other veggies, and a sprinkle of cheese at most. 
Overall, it had great potential, but was a bit of a let down.
author: Brian H.

description:
The food is excellent, as authentic Mexican as it gets. Get the chips and salsa and freshly made tortillas.
The tequila is WAY overpriced and the service looks like it's good although I think we got the only not very attentive waitress.
author: Fernanda P.

description: Nothing special about the food we ordered, shared app with guac/salsa which was mediocre a lot of things were not freshly prepared which is kinda weird for the prices they charge. Had the tortilla soup which was meh (I've had better), Tortita de papa was decent however I asked for no mushrooms and they said it comes in the sauce and they would put it on the side and lo and behold when it came it was everywhere (bleh) potato cake was okay but it was just on some boiled spinach (flavorless) and what kind of mexican restaurant doesn't give you rice and beans? If you want upscale mexican food go to tropisueno maybe 4 ish blocks away
author: Raymond H.

description: This was a very sweet experience. We were tired and hungry and our dinner was so satisfying. The food was delicious! The mood was perfectly set by the nice service and friendly waitress. Love it!
author: Davianne W.

description:
Just across the street from the Curran Theater so great for grabbing dinner before the show. Loved the guacamole but wish chips didn't cost extra-I mean come on! And at 2 bucks for a small bowl, you really are looking at at least $4 for something to accompany the guacamole. 

Different salsas are great but I'm not sure why we got them with the guacamole and tortillas. Not sure why you would want salsa without chips (which you have to pay for). Our second batch of chips weren't fresh or warm either :(

I can forgive the chips only because the Mole Chicken was so so good! One of the best plates of food I've had in SF. The dishes of my dining companions were similarly tasty (chile rellenos, carnitas, sope, stuffed chicken). 

Service was good if a little aloof at times and prices were fair for portions and quality. 5 stars for the entrees, 1 star for the disappointing chip situation.
author: Semuteh F.

description: So disappointed with this place. I read reviews and heard great things so I made reservations and my fiancé and I were very disappointed with the food, service and drinks. It seemed like they only had 1 server that Friday night. It took forever to place our order. The drinks we got were not the ones we ordered and by the time the server came to check on us we were so over the experience that we just drank the regular margaritas when we ordered macho margaritas. The food was okay, not worth the wait or money. I've had better Mexican food for a lot cheaper. Poor service, poor drinks, poor food.
author: Khat S.

description:
An on-point barman and good flavor make Colibri an expensive, but great place to grab some authentic and substantial mexican food.

I dropped in by myself for a bite and had to wait a long time at the door, another party passed me and sat at the bar (taking the seat I wanted). A waiter/bus staffer turned around and I asked if I could get a seat, as I had been waiting for 5 mins. He responded rudely and asked if I had reservations, I said it was just me and could I sit at the bar and he pointed the way. 

Once at the bar, my night turned around with a lightning quick bartender who responded to my slightest body language to serve me. He put my order in right away and had a free appetizer ready in a jif. I was super hungry, so the plain tortillas with 3-types of salsa hit the spot. I liked the tomatillo one the best, as it was spicy but not overwhelming, and the mango was sweet and interesting.

My mole chicken was good, but could have come with a side (or two). I thought the chicken was a good portion, with a rich and complex sauce, but for $18 it should come with a side. My black beans were tasty and authentic. My bill and the receipt came so quickly I was stoked to get out of there so full.

So, if you want some good, if pricey, modern mexican food in the union square area head on over to Colibri and try to sit at the bar.
author: Jim A.

description: Came here as walk in, luckily there was no wait time. Seriously food was super disappointing. Didn't finish anything or even started to try after a few bites that was it for me. Called it quits, finished my drink and got the bill and went back to the place that I had originally opted out for this place.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Service is lovely, food tastes and presents deliciously. We come here every time we're in town.
author: Deborah G.

description: The food was very clean for Mexican food. Filet Mignon was great! A friend introduced us to the Pizole and it was delicious! Fresh corn tortillas with an array of salsa temperatures. Definitely will be back!
author: Candicd E.

description: Yum!!!This is more of an upscale Mexican spot...so you won't be seeing the same things you may see in your typical Mexican and or Taqueria restaurants. I ordered the Pozole Verde, and it was real good! I wish I had some more room in my stomach to try out some of the other dishes, but the pozole left me full and happy. My hubby who is a meet a potatoes kinda guy, ordered a filet mignon, which was really good (I had to to grab a few bites off his plate :)) I will def be coming back as I want to try a few other things from their menu :)
author: Xochitl L.

description:
Across from the Curran Theatre sits this place, which feeds a few things you may not expect, mostly in your favor.

Mainly, I am referring to what I ate: a chile relleno. "Normally," those dishes tend to merely be stuffed with cheese, but here, there was the option to have the fire-roasted poblano pepper stuffed with carnitas and chicharron!

While not a 5-star dish, I simply had to try this alternative carnivorous option, as I love pork. Also got a bottomless mimosa, which tasted slightly watered down, but decent nonetheless. Intriguing overall, and well-decorated for Day of the Dead.
author: Garett T.

description: Great spot for great food before a show! The tequila menu is extensive and the margarita selections are well curated. We split the ensalada mixta which was delicious although light on the pecans. We moved on to the main courses, camerones en mole' and chili rellenos. The sauces were incredible and the preparation and presentation was on the nose. We finished up with an after dinner tequila for a perfect finish. All in under 60 minutes and on a Friday! We will be back!
author: Don A.

description: Best Mexican I have had in SF. The fundido is out of this world. Great drinks and atmosphere as well.
author: Julia M.

description:
Great location next to my hotel. I am here on business and went to grab a bite. Sat at the bar and the bartender was super rude with zero personality (and I speak spanish). ordered a house Margarita, which was decent, and tortilla soup and mixed salad. the soup was cold, and the salad was overdressed... almost inedible. 
I was underwhelmed and won't be returning.
author: Natalie C.

description: I read previous reviews and was hoping it would be  half as good as they wrote.  I will have to say it was even MORE.  My husband ordered the rellano, it may have been the best rellano we have ever had (and we are from Texas).  I had the Filet.....magnifico.  Their selection of tequila was very impressive, we actually sat at the bar after dinner and ordered another shot as dessert.  The obience was great....we are not used to close seating but it was actually very comfortable and nice.  We made reserations about 90 min before on a Sunday night and we're seated right way.  If we come back to San Francisco this place is on our GO TO list.
author: Karla T.

description: Really good food. The guac was out of this world. We arrived before 6 and a little confused where to sit because no one greeted us. We sat at a table and were moved to the bar because they weren't offering table service at the time. This was all fine but just service was a little slow and didn't have to be so confusing.
author: Kimberley D.

description: Amazing happy hour with strong, $7-8 margaritas. The bartender was extremely nice and made good drinks. He also gave my sister and I a free birthday shot of great quality tequila, as well as salt and lime. They serve food as you wait for your order. We got complementary thick corn flour tortillas with three sauces as we waited for our quesadillas. We got the quesadillas with poblano chile strips and they were delicious and hot, with crusted cheese on the sides. The bar was well lit and the tv was quietly playing in the background.
author: Chandni L.

description:
Was looking for some Mexican food for brunch, so Yelped our way through San Francisco and found this cute little joint. Probably the most overpriced Mexican food I've had... but I suppose it's because of this nice environment.

Ordered:
Guacamole (fresh made to desired spice served with warm corn tortillas) - The Guacamole was SUPER good. I wish it was a little thicker for texture, but the flavors were bursting to compensate. Can't complain :) The fresh made warm corn tortillas were so fluffy! But it tasted more like flour to me.. for $2 extra you can order a side of chips as well. Did that and received a super small bowl of chips... still worth it though :) This started comes with 3 different types of salsa. Highly recommend!
Egg Tacos (service with green peppers and black beans) - Didn't like this dish at all :( So very try and it was lacking flavor on all three components of the dish. I've had better canned black beans than the ones they serve here... and the beans were so mushy. SO not pleasant. I had to drench my tacos with salsa..

$10 bottomless mimosas!

Service was great! Our server came by to check on us more often than not. He also tried to crack a few jokes... but we were all too hungover to laugh :( sorry!

It's a nice restaurant. But if you're looking for good Mexican food, I don't think this is the place to come. Nice place for a date though!!
author: Anna M.

description: Real Mexican food! With actual vegetables! I know my AZ peeps have never heard of such a thing, but you should try it:)
author: Cady B.

description:
I found this place on Yelp, looking for a nice restaurant near our hotel.  Although we had a reservation, we showed up an hour before and were able to get a table.

The server was slow to come by and seemed a little bored with being there.  But we stared with a couple of their specialty cocktails and settled in.  The basil and strawberry margarita and refreshing bliss were outstanding drinks (we had two each!).  We then got guacamole, which might have been the best we ever had.  By the time we ordered, we realized we might not be hungry enough for large entrees, so we stick with a couple more apps for dinner.

The soup, street corn and tacos were all very good, but they came out here and there, seemingly with no particular reason or order in how they were delivered.....no big deal really. My he only issue was that the server did not bring one item, insisting that we'd never ordered it.  That, along with the fact that it took so long for her to show up was just disappointing since there were only a few other people in the restaurant.

All in all, I'd try this place again because the food and cocktails were very good.  Perhaps our server was just having an "off" night.
author: Toni M.

description:
This place has the absolute best margaritinis I've ever had. The Carnitas were very good, but the portion of them was a bit smaller than others I have seen. With the quality, I didn't mind. 

Definitely loved the tortillas! 

This place by food and drink alone really deserves five stars, but I have to give four stars because they had to be reminded to give us a booth we had made reservations for, the service showed up right after I wondered where they were, and the lights were funky, constantly shifting levels. 

Four and a half stars. Authentic. A bit slow. Wonderful margaritinis.
author: Helm Z.

description:
Had the Pechuga Ranchera ($18) and tequila coffee flan ($8).  The meal came with warm corn tortillas and 3 sauces.  I was very disappointed.  A sad attempt at Americanized Mexican cuisine, it missed the mark of being a fine dining restaurant with a Mexican flair and, instead, dulled the rich flavor of Mexican food down to baby food for Americans.

The Pechuga Ranchera consisted of a chicken breast on top of mashed potatoes drenched in a mild paprika sauce.  The flan consisted of flan topped with a tequila cream sauce and coffee beans.  The tequila sauce reminded me of drinking a French Vanilla International Coffee Creamer spiked with tequila yet was, oddly, the best part of the meal.

The food was bland and unremarkable.  Not enough to offend but not enough to impress either, I give this restaurant an average rating overall.
author: Linda H.

description: What a great place, we should of gone here a long time ago when we arrived. Great food huge tequila selection that's ready to go and tequila flights. We had sides and a few apps to go with and wow they were good. The one thing that sets this place apart is the tortillas. Not only are they fresh and warm and ready to go but they are legitimately made probably everyday by hand or presser   They all have the same shape and thickness but the awesome thing about is it that they are not the kind you buy at the store. Which makes it ten times better when your eating.
author: Elfego S.

description:
I cannot believe I hadn't written a review for this place yet. I would describe this place as upscale, and definitely a great date spot! It is a bit pricey but you definitely get your money's worth. The food is supreme, and very tasty. I always order the chicken and it never disappoints. Last time my date had the carnitas; I had a bite and those were pretty delicious, too. 
They have a great selection of drinks, wine, etc. Usually I am not a big fan of margaritas but I ordered the strawberry one last time and it was really good. You can pick the margarita based on the different tequilas.
The service is polite, available and great at giving suggestions!
author: Dodi G.

description: My husband and I came here for a date night. It's conveniently located - just a walk up from Macys in Union Square. The ambience is nice, service was very professional and polite but the food was just alright. The guac comes with warm corn tortillas (which are delicious) and you have to order the chips if you want them. We also had fish tacos which were a good size. Between those 2 items, we were full - the helpings aren't large, just filling. I would def. come back to try out the bar and maybe another entrée!
author: Shikha S.

description: Just plain fabulous every which way.
author: Maren E.

description: We were headed to see a play at ACT and heard this place had good food.  Was I amazed at how good the food was.  I had the tortilla soup which was nice and thick.  The waiter brought homemade tortilla with 3 sauces which were FANASTIC!  Then I ordered the street taco - one chicken, shrimp and the other steak.  I was so full!  They have excellent margaritas, as well.  Will definitely go back!
author: Pamela S.

description: Make sure to get the carnitas, they were delicious! Perfectly cooked with crunchy on the outside and tender on the inside. The waiters were very knowledgable and friendly. Great experience!!
author: Sarah G.

description:
Guac, yes please!!

Ordered 5 of 6 dishes between 6 of us. The food was good. The drinks were flowing. The price was EVER SO SLIGHTLY higher than I'd like. But we're in the hear of SF, so maybe thats asking a bit much. 

Had the mole, the filet mignon, fish and carnitas. Of those, I would order the filet and fish again. Not that the other two were bad, but the filet and the fish were just that much better.
author: Benny N.

description: Wonderful!  Chili relleno with carnitas yummy!  Guacamole very good and flavorful!    Definitely a return spot. Margarita really good too!
author: Sheryl I.

description: 3 visits to this establishment and they are now back to good.  The food has always been excellent but the service is hit or miss.  My most recent visit had phenomenal service and the best Eggs Benedict I have ever tasted! I subbed meat (I believe it was supposed to be chorizo) for veggies, the veggies were outstanding as was the Hollandaise and i can't say enough about the perfectly poached eggs!  Oh, added bonus: bottomless Mimosas!
author: Vickey A.

description:
My husband and I went in for Saturday brunch. I ordered eggs with blue corn tortilla and baked beans. My husband had chicken enchiladas. Both of our food was absolutely delicious. The bottomless mimosa for $10/per person was not bad at all.
We also ordered churros with dulce de leche ice cream. That was really good.
Definitely will comeback!
author: Ind B.

description:
I noticed this place just by walking by.  It was close to our hotel so I figured we should try it out.  My gf and I are from LA, so we have had plenty of good mexi food.  When we walked into this place there was a wait of 45 minutes so we opted for the bar seating.  The bar had a few openings so we sat right down.

I ordered the Chicken Mole which was beyond good.  Normally I don't even eat Mole but I heard I probably have had the wrong ones.  So, I figured I'd live on the edge.  This one was really good.  Not too sweat either. 

My gf ordered the quesadillas which aren't on the menu, they were really good.  The cheese and tortillas were very juicy.  

We also ordered the house margheritas which were real margis.  These were no wanna be margis.  They had real lime in these.  I wasn't expecting real ones.  They were phenomenal. The bartender was very personable and warming.

Instead of chips and salsa they give you tortillas and salsa.  I felt the salsa could be a little hotter but that's my preference.  I also like chips instead of the tortillas.  Therefore we ordered the quac/chips.  The quac was really creamy and good.
author: John A.

description: One of my top 3 favorite Mexican restaurants in the city. And if you know the city, you'll realize that this is as good as it gets. Great drinks and desserts. They'll sure add up to the bill, specially if you have a big appetite, because some portions come a bit small. Still I make an effort to book in here when in SF.
author: Daniel A.

description: I feel like this place is only yelpy because it is near Union Square and there arent that many Mexican places within walking distance. I just wanted to come here for the guac and churros. The guac is $12 and it isnt much. It was really salty and what sucks is that if you want chips or tortillas, you have to pay for those. Seriously I have never heard of such a thing. The empanadas come in three and those were ok. You definitely need the guac or sauce since it is quite dry. I got the carnitas platter and aside from the few stripped pieces, the meat was damn dry and not worth it. I was quite disappointed in this place since I was expecting Lolindas status. I also tried the churro dish and the churros were too tough and over baked. I did really enjoy the ice cream with caramel or dulce de leche but dat churro tho. The churro had some creme inside which was cool but overall still not the best. I would pass on this place.
author: Amy H.

description:
Went here before the theater cuz it was close.  

Amazingly taste food and great ambiance. 

But, the service sucked, and, although I'm not a big eater, I feel the portions were extremely small for the price. 

I probably won't go back.
author: daniel w.

description:
I have always enjoyed Mexican food at hole-in-the-way joints that have that endearing black and white tiled floor and salsa music blasting, and I wanted to keep it that way. I never thought I'd go to a Mexican restaurant where the food is served on big white plates, but going to Colibri was a great way to realize that Mexican food isn't just about the quick burrito or massive taco. It's definitely a lot pricier and fancier here, but some of the dishes are actually still great served this way.

annnnnd, I did not expect those empanadas to be so addicting. Buttery, flaky, and light pastry crust with warm filling make for the perfect balance, creating a delicate and delicious empanada!! Guacamole was plentiful and delicious. Instead of appetizer chips, Colibri serves warm tortillas that come out wrapped in white towels. Super classy, super different, but also super tasty paired with their salsa trio and guacamole on top. 
The mole was very chocolate-y and strong. The carnitas was tender and flavorful. The filet mignon was done nicely and comes with a decent serving of sides. Other dishes are a la carte, so you'd have to order a side of rice or beans if you want something else to eat with your meat haha.
author: Tuwie N.

description: I came here on Valentine's Day with one of my friends and I have to say I loved the food, service, and the entire experience.  We were immediately seated and our waiter Armando came over to explain the menu and drinks to us. We both got a speciality drink and we both enjoyed our drinks. I ordered the filet mignon and really enjoyed it.  The meat was cooked beautifully.  The churro desert is a must and can be shared by a pair.  If I'm ever in the area I will definitely stop by for another delicious meal.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Service wasn't the best. Took a long time to serve us. Expensive and mediocre food. Would recommend something else this is way overpriced
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Needed a place to go in Union Square with friends. I know that Union Square is a tourist trap where you're going to be overcharged for small portions of mediocre food, but this was quite possibly the worst bang-for-buck experience I've ever had.

They do not have complementary chips and salsa; instead, you can purchase guacamole for $12 with the opportunity to buy chips for an extra $2. (Because, you know, some people might just want $12 worth of guac without chips.) We ordered chips with salsa; they claimed the salsa was complementary, but they failed to refresh it at any point during the evening.

I ordered a beer, which they can't water down, but my five friends ordered various forms of mixed drinks. Instead, they received soda with trace amounts of alcohol. Let's just say nobody was well lubricated.

I ordered a chicken dish for $18, which was the minimum for any dish. Okay, that's fine; it's union square. I wasn't expecting the best mexican food, but I was expecting a normal sized dish. Instead, my dish arrived with two tiny chicken wings and a small cup of corn salsa. That's it. Had this been an appetizer, or a single tapas dish where you were supposed to order 5 dishes to fill up, it would have made sense. Instead, all I could do was look at my girlfriend, who was laughing, knowing that I could have eaten five times the portion set down in front of me without blinking. The quality was mediocre - not terrible, probably best described as bland.

What they lacked in food portions, they attempted to match in ambiance. It was a Monday night with Monday night football and playoff baseball happening. However, the single, small TV above the bar chose neither sporting option, but instead replayed a muted black and white spanish film. I'm sure tons of patrons come to a bar wanting to watch soundless, colorless foreign films, right?

I don't mean to be harsh - I'm not in the business of ripping on restaurants...but at the same time, we spent ~$40 per person for a tiny portion of mediocre food and a watered-down drink. I'd take my chances at any other random place before I went here again.
author: CJ R.

description: If you're near Times Square and you're down for Mexican food look no further. This place is the bee's knees. I was very surprised by the quality of the food and the overall dining experience. I will definitely be back!!
author: Jay H.

description: Food was a bit meh. Came here for the bottomless mimosas and was not disappointed in those.
author: Rajinder S.

description:
Three stars for A-OK, in a good way. Reservations for 5 on a Friday night was perfect. Ambiance was cozy and comfy, although they could have dimmed the lights a bit more to be even cozier.  Our waitress was really nice and attentive throughout the meal, even for having a busy section although one other hostess/waitress (not sure) seemed to rush us when taking our drink orders (my personal opinion). 

Food:
Guacamole and chips- You must have this guacamole. Soooo good. Lots of lime and lemon flavors and perfectly creamy. Only downfall is there charge $2 extra for chips. Between a party of 5, you will need another bowl of chips unless you are content with the warm tortillas they bring out in the beginning with three different sauces. And those sauces are excellent. Spicy, mild and fruity. Thumbs up. 

Drinks- All around no complaints in this department. 2 folks ordered fancy tequila (I can't remember the kind) and it was delicious. Others were specialty cocktails that hit the spot.

Entrees-SMALL, but really good. I ordered the Ceviche off of the appetizer menu for my entree. A bit on the lemony (or limey) side, but excellent. My boyfriend and his friend ordered the Filet Mignon which my boyfriend describes as "good, but the portion wasn't big...but then again it was 22 bucks. I like the chiles + the spinach and mole sauce were good." End quote. My two girlfriends ordered off the appetizer menu too and were not as satisfied. Chicken tostadas (shredded chicken on a chip) and the Mole Shrimp (I think there were 3 shrimps on her plate). I didn't taste their dishes so I can't comment. Overall, the entree wasn't the highlight for all 5 of us. 

Desert: You basically must have the stuffed churros + ice cream..... Just do it and hit the gym in the morning. With the smaller portions, you should have room. I could have just eaten that for dinner (no lie). 

Overall, I don't think I would go back unless I wanted to have a drink, guacamole and share some appetizers. I prefer Tropisueño (don't hate me Colibri).
author: Gyasi W.

description:
::Lunch Review::

Came in with a group for lunch.  Around 1:00pm on a Friday.  We ordered the Guacamole and chips to start.  Excellent for a start.  They come with chips, make sure you ask for the warm homemade tortillas ans the 3 different salsas.  I ordered the Casa Amigos margarita, it was good.  Nice size and tasty.  

Food:  
I ordered the Tacos.  Very tasty and good size.  One chicken taco, one fish taco, and one steak taco.  All were excellent and served with black beans.  The Mole was excellent, just the right spice and the chicken was tender.  The chile relleno was good (from what I heard), and for the vegetarians, they have nopales, (cactus), rice sides, beans,  all very well cooked and seasoned.  

Service:
Overall the service was excellent, friendly staff, attentive, and was friendly when we asked for more chips, or tortillas.   

Overall, I would come here again if in the area.  The place does have a charm to it.  

Cheers
author: Frank M.

description: I just love this restaurant. Great authentic food and friendly staff. I look forward to eating here every time I visit SF
author: John C.

description:
I hate to leave a poor review for Colibri, when their margaritas are awesome and their food quite good. I always thought it was a great place to send people to, when they're down in the area and aren't brave enough to venture out to other parts of the city.

Two stars is for very bad behavior and no customer service follow-up what-so-ever. My husband and I had lunch their during the weekday a couple of weeks ago. The waitress decided to gift herself an additional $5 on the tip, by changing the "4" in "14" to a "9" - changing the tip we left from $14 to $19. My husband called the restaurant and left a message and never heard back from them. Now we have to go through our credit card company to address the rip-off.

When we eat out - we are very conscientious about leaving GOOD tips for servers - SF is not a service-industry-worker friendly city and we recognize that. But that doesn't mean we want to be ripped-off when we go out. Obviously.
author: S.T. C.

description: Went here before going to the Symphony ( although it was far from the symphony). I have been here a few times before going to the Curran Theatre . We were greeted by friendly staff. Both my husband and I enjoyed the Gucamole which was freshly made to our specifications and more than we could ever finish. We both had tacos which also. had freshly made tortilllas overall a fantastic place to eat service was good. Staff were friendly and helpful  Customer service was great told them we had to be at the symphony at a certain time and we finished in plenty of time to get there.. The price was right for alll the food you get. I would highly recommend this place
author: Beth A. O.

description: I absolutely hate it when staff at a restaurant comes out to start clearing off your plates early even when you are still eating. I don't know if this is a trend in SF restaurants (since i rarely go anymore) but they are rushing you out and it is irritating, esp. if (as in my case) you are entertaining an important customer. I would have given them two stars if this was the only problem, but the food was bad and expensive (chili relleno was awful and carnitas tasted like it had come out of a can) and the $13 margarita was horrible. Skip this place, esp. when taking out a client on a business dinner.
author: George K.

description: Delicious food.  The service more than excellent.  Margarita and cheese with chorizo.  Soon yummi. I highly recommend this place.  Homemade tortillas.  No words to describe how good is this place.
author: Ana C.

description: A bunch of coworkers and I came to Colibri for dinner after a long day at a convention. This restaurant turned out to be a diamond in the rough (or Tenderloin). The service was terrific, the food was very good, and for tequila snobs like myself, they had a terrific selection that would satisfy most connoisseur's tastes and budgets. We ended up going back for lunch and dinner the next day, so between us we pretty much ordered the entire menu. The standouts were the pork, the tostadas tsinga, and the fillet. The only disappointing dish was the chicken mole. Also the Mexican chocolate cake was delicious.  And the pricing was appropriate for the food and the service. Only thing holding it back from 5 stars is that some of the dishes were merely good, not great.
author: Jason M.

description: The duck breast is a must try. The meat was tender with well balanced fat and juice, accompanied with veggies. They also provided three types of chilli sauses if you order guacamole. The waiter and waitress served us were nice. If you want try their wine, they provide you with good advice.
author: Yi H.

description:
Had a delicious late night snack here earlier this month. Servings were on the delicate, tasting, side of the spectrum.

The handmade tortillas were heavenly and each salsa tasted fresh, distinctively different.

Pozole hit the spot - ingredients bright and flavorful. 

Empanadas were tiny, tasty.

Yummy sandia aguas frescas.

Can't remember what my brother had to eat, it disappeared quickly!

It was crowded and rowdy here on a Friday night.
author: Leslie T.

description:
The Margaritas are very good, get two!

The Guacamole Dip is good. Do get it if you want something before your dinner arrives and why not your in a great restaurant. 

I had the Pork Chile Relleno and likely wouldn't have it again. It didn't really have that much flavor. 

For $143.00 we had:
Three House Margaritas (Very Good)
Guacamole Dip
Tostaditas
Pechuga Ranchera
Carnitas
Tacos Pescadero
Tamales Pescadero
Chile Relleno Pork
Three Coffee. (Very good)

I'll be back, often.
author: Justin S.

description:
I typically won't rate a place poorly after 1 visit but this place left a horrible taste in my mouth...and I'm not talking about just the food.

The wait was 1.5 hours which was somehow reduced to only 5 minutes when someone in our party complained that there were a ton of open tables. The margaritas were super sweet, service was poor and unfriendly, portions were tiny and the food was unmemorable. I did not feel welcome in this restaurant in any way. The stars go to the guac and homemade salsas but I wouldn't return for it. Glad I could expense this one. Sorry Colibri.
author: Kelly M.

description: Excellent food and service... Good beer on tap and friendly atmosphere.  Came for dessert and a beer and wasn't disappointed...
author: Cinnamon S.

description: Super disappointed. Loved the ambiance and atmosphere... The drink I had was horrible. The handmade tortillas were awesome but the service was too horrible to make me want to go back. So sad.
author: Andrea D.

description: I love this place, Jesus is the best. Sit at the bar and order the filet and a few cocktails and you will have the best meal of your life!!
author: David R.

description: Good margaritas and tacos.  Would've preferred chips instead of tortillas with their salsas.
author: Dave C.

description: Delicious drinks, delicious food! What else can you ask for!! Maybe fantastic service, yup they've nailed that too
author: Marc W.

description: Great place to eat authentic Mexican Food from the fresh made tortillas to the churros & flan.would recommend the chile verde Pozole & the Camarones con mole. The sauce was so flavorful and smoky and it all worked well together.
author: Sergio T.

description: Had a michelada and some flan there. Really enjoyed the flan. They had an interesting way of making a michelada but was still tasty.
author: Cristian G.

description: Came here with the fam tonight and let me be honest, I could have just eaten the tortillas and three sauces they bring out. SO delicious. But alas, we ordered more...way more. Started with the sope appetizer. I ate the veggie one, but the chicken and pork also got rave reviews. They were offering a special that three of us ordered. Slow cooked rice, octopus, scallops, shrimp, mussels, and clams in a red sauce. When asking what the server recommends, she sold us on it by saying well we only offer this dish once a year...SOLD. Sooooo delicious. Flavors were on point and you could tell they had slow cooked everything. For dessert we ordered the chocolate cake and mango creme brûlée. Again, amazing.
author: Christine E.

description: Great find, thanks to Yelp. Fantastic food, great service. We had brunch here. We were starving and had low expectations but were blown out of the water!
author: Sarah P.

description: Good chocolate cake dessert. Many customers came here to eat. Delicious Mexican food.
author: Mengze Z.

description:
Strong drinks, good food and great atmosphere.

Portion sizes were a bit on the small end.
author: Courtney W.

description: Just got in to San Francisco and had to hurry to make our reservation. So we were tired and really did not have a lot of expectations. My wife and I were kind of shocked by how much we liked this restaurant. The food was incredible as was the service and ambience. One of the best dining experiences I can remember in a long time.
author: Carl A.

description: Delicious and worth the splurge. Skillfully prepared dishes, fabulous flavors, kind service, festive. A highlight of our time in SF. Will recommend!
author: Clare H.

description:
We had a wonderful experience here. We were staying across the street and I read some yelp reviews to find a place near by. There were some mixed reviews about Colibri but it sounded good and I took a chance anyway. We had two appetizers, Panuchos de Cochinita Pibil and the Ceviche. both were excellent! My lady had the 
Camarones en Mole de Tamarindo and I had Carnitas. My lady doesn't love mole but really enjoyed her meal. My carnitas meal was very tasty I enjoyed it very much.

We both enjoyed our meal with the feel of the restaurants and service. Was worried about taking a chance on a place with mixed reviews, was glad I did. Made our night with this great find.
author: Nick V.

description: Overpriced food, it was not authentic, and the service was horrible. I've had food trucks taste better than this, major fail. Don't come here unless you just want to have a margarita.
author: Jessica H.

description: Compliments to the Chef and kitchen staff for such a greatenu! Carnitas, so awesome and the camarones with mole (asked to placed on the side) and that heavenly jalapeno cornbread is divine!  Nice & friendly front of the house staff too. Let me stand up to clsp & say BRAVO!!!
author: Lena H.

description:
Yeah - I've been to San Francisco. Colibri is the best Mexican food in the Pacific region not counting the places I haven't been which includes Mexico. But we did get to the Mission and Colibri is better than any thing I tried at the place we went down there. 
Huitaloche - amazing!  Mole - extraordinary, and not made from any part of a mole.  San Franciscans who whinge on yelp about service and food in this fantastic place should come to Sydney and try the local Tex Mex, then they could really whinge with authority. This place is a beautiful thing.
author: Andrew O.

description: Was there for dinner on friday night, must have been the best filet mignon I have ever had.  Definetely visiting again next time i am in SF. Hostess sat us within 5 minutes, it was busy and we did not have a reservation.
author: Adina R.

description: Yummy guacamole and bottomless mimosas were delicious!!  No need for a 2nd drink because he margaritas are high content tequila!!  Chihuahua man this place is good!!!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
My friend and I had dinner here before Jersey Boys tonight and we were blown away. We shared the guacamole and it was fantastic. It had the perfect citrus and avocado blend. The salsa they had was to die for, especially the mango salsa. My friend loved the green salsa so it was a perfect mix. For dinner I got the Mole Poblano and was thrilled. It was the perfect portion and the Mole was phenomenal. The chicken was succulent and delicious. My friend had the Chile Rellano and said the same thing; great portion and fantastic flavors. She said the arroz a la Mexicana was great and I literally was in heaven when I got the papas al gratin. They were cheesy with the perfect kick from the poblano chile cream. 


Their margaritas are delightful, all of them. I will most definitely be coming back again, as well as suggesting it to anyone and everyone who goes to the city!

Great service, great food, got us to the show on time, 5 stars!
author: Channing M.

description: This place is so good!! We were in San Francisco for a work trip and this place was right across the street from our hotel. Seriously, so good. We got guacamole and queso to start both great choices. For dinner I got the ceviche, best ever! One of my co-workers got chile relleno and the other got pechuga rellena de huitlacoche (chicken with mushrooms) and they both loved their entrees as well. Definitely try this place!
author: Kristen A.

description:
3.5 stars.

I really liked the food, but the service was really bad -- I even overheard a pair of tourists sitting next to us commenting on the sloppy service. It's not what I expected for a place that garnered quite a bit of praise over the years from food critics.

Onto the food. A Mexican friend recommended this place, so we had high hopes for the food. We started with the guacamole, and had the mole poblano and duck in green mole sauce. Of course, there was the complimentary fresh tortillas and salsa -- you could also request chips.

The salsas (spicy, tomatillo, pineapple) were very good. I couldn't stop eating them, and the pineapple salsa was really fruity and delicious. The guacamole though, disappointed me. We asked for spicy, but barely any spice showed through. It was very fresh...but what guacamole is not fresh in California? ;)

Onto the main dishes. The mole poblano was rich and delicious, and the dark meat was very tender and good. The breast pieces were unfortunately a bit dry, but I'm just nitpicking ;) Whereas the duck with green mole was fabulous. It was juicy, tender and delicious, and totally over shadowed the mole poblano. Guess what I'm getting next time.

Desserts were good too. The stuffed churros were different from the usual variety, and didn't disappoint. They also have agavero, which is the best sweet tequila there is on earth.

If only their service wasn't so sparse and unattentive...they didn't clear plates out despite the table being full, and we had to flag them down when we needed attention. Fix the service and this place will definitely be a star.
author: Alice C.

description:
I recently celebrated my birthday at Colibri, and I must say that the food is delicious. I love the idea of traditional Mexican food with a twist. The Pozole Verde, Pechuga Rellena, Torta de Elote and Churros Rellenos are a must, but do note that the portions are small. I wouldn't recommend the Queso Fundido, not cheesy enough for my taste. 

Oh, and did I mention the homemade tortillas and array of tequilas? Overall a great dining experience.
author: Diana C.

description:
1st I would like to say we came here last night and had a bad, very bad experience with the hostess. My significant other decided we had to try this place again. (And actually try the food) we came here today and being Mexicans who love authentic Mexican food we instantly fell in love with the food offerings. 

The margaritas are amazing! Not too sweet and a good amount of tequila. He has a vampiro too and he liked it. 

The service was good, the food was great and came fast. I honestly felt like I was at my Tia's house. I had the green posole which I struggle to find out in LA (surprising I know) but I love it. On the menu they said "Sinaloa style" my family is from Sinaloa and I can honestly say I was pleased with everything we ordered. 

You have made a customer for life thanks to my experience today. We loved it, every time I'm in SF (every other week) I'll be coming here. Thank u guys
author: Michelle A.

description:
Well being from New Zealand I don't feel qualified to say what good Mexican food should taste like, but the food here was good and the staff were great.

@ $100usd + tips it was good value, as my wife and I had 2x starters, 2x mains, 1x side dish, 1x dessert, 2x cocktails and a beer.... And a fun night.
author: Richard E.

description: When I was here, everything was amazing. Seating was quick and everyone we encountered was friendly. The food was delicious and fresh. Fresh hand made tortillas were the best I have ever had. The fried cheese is I am still want more of. It was served to perfection! The environmental is not dressy but not to casual. It's the perfect place for a date night! The price is reasonable for everything you get. I can't wait to go again!
author: Cindy S.

description:
Saw some of the menu online, saw a bunch of aztec-looking words that I've never seen before. Like something something with Xochilt sauce, huh? (Its a joke!)

But really, I saw the menu and I saw the $$$ signs on yelp, and was a bit worried I was gonna eat crappy, expensive food. But we went out on a limb and tried it out.

We walked in on a busy monday night. The hostess in the front told us the wait would be about 10 minutes. Five minutes later she walked us over to our table. As we walked past the bar, there was a live band playing, which really gave a nice feel to the place. 

Our service was amazing! Denis was our waiter, and he was very friendly and attentive. He constantly checked up on us, and made sure our water was always filled and we had enough chips for our appetizer which was the guacamole. VERY DELICIOUS.

I was not disappointed at the food. I had the pechuga ranchera (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u30abI5AtOKAddJRxUfZTg?select=5K7mn0o2Q3mwLMqpk6DgbA#5K7mn0o2Q3mwLMqpk6DgbA) which was amazing! It was juicy, and the gravy on top went VERY well with the mashed potatoes at the bottom. 

My parents had the Camarones en Mole de Tamarindo (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u30abI5AtOKAddJRxUfZTg?select=5K7mn0o2Q3mwLMqpk6DgbA#L4ausZN7JDeYGP3AdaAs_A) 
and the fish of the day
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u30abI5AtOKAddJRxUfZTg?select=5K7mn0o2Q3mwLMqpk6DgbA#sd1IY3VXuY5kDkP2iGTIRQ) 

I tried a little bit of the camarones, and it yummy! 

For dessert my parents got the flan, and I got the chocolate cake. Oh my goodness. As a chocolate lover, I fell in love again with chocolate when I ate the dessert. It was a warm chocolate cake, with warm chocolate syrup, and then nice cold vanilla ice cream on the side. Oh my goodness! 

I'll def be back.
author: Sophia G.

description: Everytime I go to San Francisco I go here. When anyone mentions going to San Francisco I recommend it. I often day dream of coming back just to eat here. It's truly that delicious. Try the mole' . They also have the largest selection of tequila's I have ever seen. I didn't partake because I had things to deal the next day.
author: J D.

description: This is our First time in san francisco so we seeked guidance from our hotel concierge. They recommended this restaurant and after looking at the yelp reviews, we decided to go with it. As an appetizer we ordered the panuchos pibil  (2 small crispy tortillas) which were very tasty. For the entree, we both ordered the pork chille relleno which to our surprise, was one roasted pepper stuffed with meat on top of black bean SAUCE. That's it folks no sides come with this dish. Now don't get me wrong. The dish was delicious but I was surprised to pay $18 for a single stuffed pepper. I also ordered corn on the cob which was also delicious but for $5, I don't feel my two items totaling $23 was worth the cost. I think my biggest disappointment was that considering this is a "mexican" restaurant I expected authentic cuisine like enchilladas, tacos, burritos, refried beans, etc. There is none of that here. It seems more like a fusion restaurant since they have fillet mignon, shrimp, chicken breast, etc, on the menu. I'm the kind of person that will return over and over again when I find a particular place fabulous. This didn't happen here. The place is tasty but just keep the above in mind.
author: Rose J.

description: This was our 3rd visit to Colibri, and the 3rd time without a reservation. Fortunately all 3 times we got seated, but I would recommend making a reservation. It gets pretty packed from 7pm on, with a wait out the door if you don't have a reservation. Fortunately we love to eat early, so it has worked out in our favor. LOVE this Mexican Bistro! We're from Los Angeles, so we've set the bar pretty high for authentic Mexican and this place hits the spot. Their speciality item is their Mole Chicken, which is SPOT on, served with a flavorful white rice, and my hubby loves their Carnitas, which never disappoint. You must order the guacamole, with their homemade chips and homemade tortillas. They've got a vast assortment of beers and tequilas and we've never had dessert because we're too stuffed from the guac and dinner. Definitely check it out when in town. It's always the first dinner we have in town.
author: Roma B.

description: Food: 8/10, service: 1/10. Be prepared to wait a long time (for your drinks, food, condiments, the bill, etc.). You'll have to repeat yourself multiple times, and you'll likely be served the wrong food/drink. To top it all off, our waiter was rude (after I waited 15 minutes for a glass of water, he finally showed up with a mimosa, which I didn't order. I said "I ordered a water." He said "okay okay lady! it's coming, I have 10 tables right now." This lady will not be returning.
author: Laura S.

description: Absolutly charming. Food was succulent. I definetely recommend the corn on the con and the empanadas.
author: Aïcha S.

description: Had a wonderful experience! Res got lost, but they accommodated us despite being full booked. Wonderful food, great service....excellent dinner! Thank you!
author: Suzie P.

description:
I admit, I am biased. I came here four years ago and ordered the best mushrooms I've ever had. I went back to NYC and tried to replicate it, but it was never sweet enough or the chile pepper flavoring was off. Needless to say, I was ecstatic to come back here and finally taste the heavenly mushrooms again. But my heart sank when the waitress told me they removed it from the menu. NOOO!!! WHY??? She admitted they were really good, too. So whyyyy would they take it off the menu?? Ugh!!!

But enough of my mushroom misfortune. I do not recommend getting the shots sampler. It's like $10 a shot and my friends said it wasn't that great anyway. You chase it with tomato sauce or something. The ceviche was drenched in lime juice, making the fish too soggy. The guacamole was pretty good and spicy, although the portions are small for what they charge.

I ordered the mole entree. And realized that I do not really like mole sauce. So there's that. Sadly this was a disappointing dinner and I don't think I'm coming back here again (unless maybe if they bring back the mushrooms).
author: Margaret F.

description: Outstanding Mexican food!  Starting with the medium guacamole and some great drinks, our night was off to a good start.  The chile relleno stuffed with carnitas was delicious.  Take some time to visit this authentic Mexican restaurant if you have a chance.
author: Randy V.

description: Guac was phenomenal... also had fish tacos which were very good... service was a little slow but the place was jam-packed so understandable...
author: Andrea M.

description: Let me start off by saying, I came here one time for brunch and dinner in one day! That is how amazing the food is. Make sure you get their hand made tortillas and order the Guacamole to dip the tortillas in. So good!
author: Jeremy A.

description: Had lunch here on the nostalgic day, April 21st, when Prince died.  That was a coincidence, however.  Usually at Colibri for dinner, but lunches are festive also, that is, if you don't have to go back to work.  We sampled four of the appetizers which were all on the mark and enjoyed our entrees.  The drinks were great as was the service, as usual.  My favorites were the Queso Fundido and the entrée Chile Relleno!  Near the Powell BART Station, so no need to drive.  Look forward to my next visit at this culinary gold mine!
author: Steve Anthony A.

description: Packed Saturday night here at Colibri the weekend before Christmas. The four of us were a little underwhelmed given our previous experience and the restaurant's Zagat rating. I had the fish tacos antijitos--came to the table lukewarn and flavor just ok. Two others had the Chile Rellenos and were disappointed at the small portion. We had the Noble (?) margaritas which were ok. Will try again but...we were disappointed this time.
author: M F.

description:
Amazing lunch @ Colibri Mexican Bistro (11-23-12); for sure I will be back for more. For starters, we had the guacamole with chips. If this is your first time, you will miss out if you don't try the guac! My lunch entree was the carnitas and all you can eat homemade tortillas. My wife and son ordered the Tortita de Papas. For an extra $5 you get the house margarita on the rocks which was excellent. The service was extremely friendly, attentive, and prompt as I expected it to be. My carnitas tasted delightful with the mild chile sauce (ask for extra right off the bat). I was anxious to try their mojito since I am on a ninja mission to find the perfect mojito, and too bad it's not here.  The drink was way too sweet for my liking.  But this was no problem, and they exchanged it for a margarita-sweet!  

Used a google offers voucher: $25 for $40 worth of lunch credit. 

Highly recommend! 

(+) house made tortillas
(+) variety of margaritas
(++)wholly molly guacamole!!
(+) Family friendly (lunchtime)
author: Denis A.

description: Great place to come to the drinks and appetizers. Right in the heart of downtown San Francisco.
author: Lynnette B.

description: Handmade corn tortillas in unlimited supply, need I say more?  The guacamole and accompanying bottomless tortillas were wonderful (but adding $2 for chips is unreasonable). The fish tacos were delicious but a little spicy, but I used the tortillas from the guacamole to scoop up extra sauce from the tacos.  Good service.
author: Sona P.

description:
This was our first time at Colibri, and we were led here by Yelp when looking for a place to meet up with friends near Market.

I suspect this place receives its disproportionately high ratings due to its location and patronage from tourists who sadly have never had mexican food. :( Either that or we came on a really, really, really off day for the chefs.

Atmosphere: 4 stars. Great location, great decor, great lighting.

Service: 4 stars. Hosts and waiters were really friendly and attentive. A really pleasant staff.

Presentation: 4 stars. All our drinks and dishes were presented beautifully, and each dish was a miniature piece of visual art. It's a shame that the flavors didn't compare.

Food: 1.5 stars.
We started with the guacamole, which was mediocre at best. It had a nice creamy texture, but didn't taste particularly fresh. They claim it's "freshly made," but I am very, very skeptical. I'd much prefer Wholly Guacamole from your local grocery store aisle over Colibri's guac. (I'm a guac fanatic, so I can definitely recommend some decent restaurants with amazing housemade guacamole.) We also had to pay an extra $2 to add chips to our guac, which was a bit unusual. The chips were hard.

Per Yelpers' recs, I ordered the Mole Pablano and my husband ordered the Chile Relleno (veggie and cheese). I'm sorry to say that Yelpers have led me astray this time. ):

The Mole Poblano chicken was dry, and the sauce tasted merely of cocoa and nuts, devoid of any spices. Very dark and plain, IMO. The side of rice that came with it lacked flavor, as well. Perhaps I'm just not a mole poblano fan, but this dish definitely did not impress. I couldn't even finish it, and the portions weren't very large to begin with.

The Chile Relleno was subpar to what we could make at home, and we aren't the best chefs when it comes to Mexican. The chili pepper itself was fine (just your average pepper, I guess!) but the vegetables (a mix of squashes) were bland and mushy. We're not even sure if there was cheese on it. When I turned away from my mole poblano, my husband offered me his chile relleno, and I really couldn't find either one appetizing.

Strangely enough, both dishes reminded me of the type of flavors in your microwaveable Lean Cuisines from the frozen aisle. Curious.

The highlights of the meal were the complimentary salsa (the salsa verde was decent) and corn tortillas (fresh and fluffy; much better than the chips), along with the company, of course. Friends who ordered drinks said the mojitos were pretty good, too.

Our friends ordered the duck (Pato En Mole Verde Pipian), and said it was decent, so I guess if we ever need to come back, we would opt for the mole verde. I don't see that happening, though.
