Mango creme brûlée: decent sized creme brulee with chunks of mango in the bottom - leading to an interesting mix of warm creme brulee and cool mango chunks. Really good.
Had a lot of fun and quite enjoyed the food.
author: Corey L.

description: This place is awesome. Excellent happy hour. Chris the bartender is outstanding and ultra attentive. My, my associates alcohol receptacles were never empty. Food is exquisite. Multiple tequila shots, many of them on the arm... $5 for a house margarita. It only takes 2-3 to achieve intoxication. $6 per plate when you're drunk, can't beat it. The happy hour is worth it, trust me Yelpers. DEATH BY COLIBRI!
author: Chris L.

description: One of the best Mexican restaurants I have been to! I had a really unique salad, with mango, Mexican yam, a delicious basil dressing, and flower petals (!!). I highly recommend it! I also would recommend the churro a. So delicious! Will definitely be back again!
author: Daphne M.

description:
Uh oh, everyone else gave Colibri a good review. What to do - What to do? Regardless, the following is my experience.

The bar and bartender were good.

Overall, the food was very underwhelming. Chips and salsa are substituted with fresh tortillas and salsa. Tortillas are for filling, not dipping and scooping. The pork was VERY bland. I didn't know pork could taste that way. Pork, alone, is very tasty. What happened? The stewed chicken was ok, but I'm not a big "stewed chicken" guy. The fish tacos were typical grilled fish tacos. Again, bland.

I simply don't like Colibri's tastes. It's not my cup of salsa.
author: Kent J.

description:
Colibri is an excellent authentic Mexican restaurant ! it is not a taqueria where you get cheap mexican food. Colibri really offers true " Mexican Cuisine", The quality of food, fresh ingredients are just amazing. That translates to delicious varieties of dishes.
I brought several friends to this restaurant in the past, and all said they were amazed how good it is. I also like this restaurant a lot because it breaks the stereotype that mexican food is cheap food. The price/quality is great and I never had a bad meal here.The gaucamole is always fresh and flavorful. I love their mole! Anyways, for those who love high quality ingredients with reasonable price, this is definitely the restaurant to try out.I highly recommend it!
author: Ann W.

description: Came here after a show and it was hopping- delicious sangria and mango creme brûlée. The bar server, Jorge, was kind and funny. And he bonded with my friends over To Wong Foo.  Cheers!
author: Tasha C.

description:
Went here on 7/22/14  for dinner. Walked in and they could only offer me a table for an hour so we opted to sit at the bar. We stayed a few hours to talk, have dinner and drinks. 

Bartender seemed annoyed we were there but his drinks were amazing. Ended up trying several different drinks off of the extensive drink menu. Lots of tequila options if you are so inclined but many other options if you don't like tequila (like me).

I ordered the chicken dish and it was delicious! I cleaned my plate, the portions were just right. Not too much and not too little. My husband had the filet mignon and said it was amazing! 

Overall I would recommend dropping in and getting some great food and drinks!
author: Kasie C.

description: Wow! Different cuisine than any other Mexican restaurant I've been in. More like being in the Mexican countryside at a relatives home. I never had a lamb dish like this one. Delicious! Lamb Shank falling off the bone after being wrapped in Plantain leaves and baked with an exquisite sauce. Flavorful but not too spicy. Get a side of rice with that. The Chili Relleno was fantastic also. For dessert try the Mango Creme Brûlée, wow like pudding, with chunks of Mango, so great! Chef Castro out does himself and Natalie our server was so kind and gave a warm welcoming experience. I wish all servers were like her. I felt like she owned the place in how much care and comfort she provided us. The decor is old world and I enjoyed watching, on silent, an old Mexican black and white movie while we we there. A wonderful dining experience all the way around.
author: C's M.

description:
As so many yelpers mentioned, guacamole is REALLY good.So fresh yum! We also tried fish tacos and staffed poblano peppers.The rest of food was good too, but not as memorable as guacamole :)
This place deserve some credit for being one of the best dinner option in that area
author: Anna V.

description:
This is the best restaurant, within spittin' distance of the A.C.T. Geary Theater (right across the street) ...which may be the true reason that this place is so popular. I would definately recommend reservations, especially if you have tickets for a show. 

The food is ok, but there seems to be something missing that is hard to place a finger on. It's good, I guess - just nothing exceptiional. The margaritas are good, just a tad to sugary for my taste. 

It's a shame that the area has either really expensive, touristy or dive-y restaurants. Being on the edge of the Tenderloin, yet firmly planted in the Union Square area will do that. Colibri does split the chasm of variety, taste and price point. It is loud and comfortable enough and the food will fill your belly. 

...I say go for it.
Hey, you could do a lot worse.
(And, Montezuma will certainly not seek his come-uppance)
author: David G.

description:
"Upscale Mexican" kinda strikes me as a contradiction in terms like "partially pregnant" or "Bush intelligence". Maybe that's why I've been to Maya only once and still haven't been to Tres Agaves. Creature of habit that I am, I guess I prefer the bargain home-style Mexican dishes in the Mission overall, but ah, Colibri may just change my mind, at least as a once-in-a-while dining destination.

My friend Maggie and I ended up here quite by accident since we were browsing photos of the Rolling Stones at the San Francisco Art Exchange a few doors down. Remembering how a few Yelpers raved about this place, I thought it would be worthwhile to set ourselves up at a bar table and give it a go. We were sitting next to the sunny guy who ground the fresh avocados into their house specialty guacamole. Granted it costs $10, but it is awfully creamy-tasty, and there was plenty of it. Odd, at least to me, they serve it with small homemade tortillas instead of chips - which is an extra charge.

We then tried the $9 Tamales Oaxaquenos. Luckily, there were two, and the mole sauce was velvety perfection over a nice, little pillows of chicken obviously made from scratch and not picked up in the freezer at Trader Joe's. Next up were the $14 Carnitas, chunks of fallen-off-the-bone pork served with a special chile salsa. I'm a complete sucker for good carnitas, and these were genuinely yummy.

The last thing we ordered was a wedge of savory cornbread, the $7 Torta de Elote, filled with bacon and onion bits and ladled with a thick poblano pepper cream sauce. It might as well have been dessert for all its rich flavor. The relatively compact place was packed with people staring at our dishes as they streamed in and out. It's obviously targeted to the dressy theater crowd, but I certainly liked it enough to consider coming back with a reservation and everything.

FOOD - 4.5 stars...really tasty dishes, just a tad pricey to me when the Mission is just a Muni ride away
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...nice hacienda decor, damn crowded though
SERVICE - 4 stars...cordial and responsive
TOTAL - 4 stars...upscale Mexican...OK, I can dig it
author: Ed U.

description:
The food here is not typical
Mexican fare. It is really good. Tortillas are amazing, Sopas are great, the quality was high. Only downside was that foods weren't as spicy as I like them, but this is really a high quality place with a good vibe. I'd go back!
author: Chris H.

description: Really great place to eat and grab a drink.  The food is very flavorful and the staff is awesome!
author: Toby B.

description: Cute restaurant in the Union Square area for brunch.  Can't beat the  $10 bottomless mimosas! The rest of the menu is affordable as well.  I tried the enchilada with chicken, which was flavorful and filling.  It was a light, but filling, dish.  Our server was extremely attentive and courteous.  He made sure our glasses were always full with mimosa and was even kind enough to take the dish my friend did not enjoy off the tab.  Will keep this place in our brunch rotation.
author: Stephanie T.

description: I think I just died and went to heaven!! Fabulous margarita, the best corn tortillas I've ever had in my life!  Fresh salsas.  Chef is from Merida!  So far I had the panuchos and sopes.  The churros were sinful!  Absolutely delicious. I actually returned a few days later and had the carnitas and a different margarita.  I was not disappointed : )
author: Nadine R.

description:
Nice decor and good food! 

Filet Mignon is my favorite. Margaritas are on point

4 stars because hostess always seats us 15 minutes after reservation time.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Thanks Yelp for recommending a great restaurant!  We made reservations on Open Table and, thank God, because it was so crowded.  

We started out with the guacamole ($12), which is not exactly made tableside but at a station somewhere.  We asked for it spicy and it came out mildly spicy but it was so tasty and so much of it.  It comes with corn tortillas. They charge an extra $2 for chips with the guacamole but the tortillas are so good, you won't want the chips.  Plus, you eventually get free chips and salsa so it's not really worth it.

The margaritas here are excellent! Both the Macho Margarita (a little spicy and $13) and Margarita Amate ($12) were super tasty.  The sangria ($8) here is really sweet, so don't order it unless you like sweet sangria.  The fruit in the sangria has soaked up a ton of alcohol, especially the mango.  I've never had mango in sangria but it is a great addition.

The carnitas ($16) here are mind-blowingly good.  Best I've ever had.  We also tried the duck ($20), which was ok.  Probably best to stick with the carnitas.  

Finally, the churros rellenos (churros with whipped cream, caramel, and nuts and $8) is a great dessert.  Service was good as well. Check this place out for great, inventive Mexican food in the city.
author: Holly C.

description: Service was super fast and the people were very polite. My food was good (chicken enchiladas) but it taste very different from what i'm used to. If you are a picky eater go with what my fiancé got , Cantinas. She loved them.
author: Jimmylee R.

description: I've been here at least 3 times and the food and desserts are authentic and the large selection of margaritas and tequila are excellent.
author: N A.

description: Delicious Mexican restaurant centrally located. I ordered the carnitas (not on the menu) and they were great. You can make tacos with them with the corn tortillas they bring to the table. Definitely recommend.
author: Maria S.

description: Came to this place with some peers at work. The place is a very casual place with awesome mohito's. Do order the guacamole for the table and be surprised with the salsas that come with the nachos. I order the mahimahi which was cooked very nicely. Do end the meal with some flange.
author: Sid B.

description:
What can be better on a sunny San Francisco day than exploring the city and its restaurants? Sure, $17 for an entree and dessert is a bit on the high end side for a college student, but the food at Colibri is pretty darn tasty.

For starters, I was given a trio of salsa and homemade tortillas, which really hit the spot.

I ordered vegetarian chile relleno and churro relleno (fried dough + caramel sauce + dulce de leche ice cream + a strawberry rose = mouthwatering goodness). The chile relleno was delicious, excluding the fact that it was suuuper spicy and I had to drink a sip of water after every bite. The fact that it wasn't covered in egg batter and deep fried (like the traditional ones) was a pleasant surprise (it made me feel a little less guilty about eating a fried dessert). I really recommend the churro relleno, although you may want to go for a walk afterwards... shopping maybe? What I ended up doing was walking from Colibri to Castro St... yup, 1 hour and 11 minutes (Google map it). 

Anyway, if you're looking for a nice ambience, VERY friendly service and traditional Mexican food, Colibri is the place to go
author: Jessica R.

description: Awesome food, attentive service in a authentic atmosphere.  Not one dish is bad, but I finally made it past the Mole and the lamb was outrageous.  The drink with cucumber is also dangerously tasty.
author: Ilicia Maxine R.

description: Great restaurant!  We sat at the bar and had great drinks & dinner!  The guacamole was delicious, grilled artichoke & eggplant was excellent and the chicken mole was perfect! The bartenders were friendly and very personable..a wonderful experience!
author: Miriam G.

description: The food was okay, prices high, slow service, but great design. In terms of food they had a great variety of dishes. I had the carnitas which were slightly over with rice, chips, salsa, and guacamole. I don't find much on my plate to be particularly flavorful or a standout. Thee tortillas were good and made traditionally. The spicy guacamole was a standout and was delicious with my chips. The prices are genuinely high relative to the quality of the food. I'm a big fan of Mexican food and really wanted to like this place but the food was only okay. Service was lackluster. I heard my server complain several times to another server about wages and being ready to go home. I totally get those feelings but I thought the middle of the restaurant wasn't a place for that type of conversation. My unhappy server was slow and dampened my enthusiasm with their attitude. The design of the place is great and it was quite full so take of that what you will.
author: Allistair J.

description: Holy Pozole I'm in heaven!! Oh the drinks and food!  A favorite is the strawberry basil drink
author: Dina F.

description:
I must say I love this place!

We went here on a weekday but the place was packed so we ended up ordering a sangria ($8/ glass) and waited at the bar for a table to open.

We waited for about 20 minutes and were seated in the back of the restaurant. A waiter came immediately to show us the menu and we ordered a Guacamole ($12 ) for appetizer. It was made fresh at our table so it was very entertaining to watch. The only complain I have is that the chips were an additional $2! Although it came with soft tortillas but seriously, who eats guacamole with soft tortillas? Other than that, it was very tasty and I'm happy to have a custom made guacamole!

For entrée, we both ordered Pechuga Rellena de Huitlacoche ($16), which is chicken breast stuffed with a mix of huitlacoche , zucchini and fresh corn, served over a roasted garlic sauce (yes, I took the description from their menu page). OMG, it was so yum! If I were at home or no one was looking, I would have licked the plate like there's no tomorrow! The meat was melt-in-your-mouth soft and the sauce complimented the entire dish.

It took a while for the check to arrive but over all, the service was speedy and friendly. I'd recommend this place to people who are looking for something other than the usual burritos!
author: Alice L.

description:
Went here on a Saturday night. It was all booked and we had a 30-40 minute wait which wasn't so bad. 

We all ordered different dishes. From what I remember, we had a lamb dish, spicy chicken, and two other dishes that I don't remember.

What is do remember is that every single dish was DELICIOUS!! When asked for spicy they made the dish spicy unlike other Mexican restaurants. 

Absolutely love this restaurant. Planning on going back soon!

All in all, great food, atmosphere, and customer service!

P.S. They have good Margaritas as well!
author: Anjana S.

description:
Stayed next door and had a late lunch here. Had delicious fish tacos, whose black bean smear made them just that much more interesting. Tostadas with chicken tinga were piled high on small tortillas, definitely not a finger food. Crispy tortillas and well-cooked but not falling apart tinga, with crema and avocado to smooth out their mild heat. The monthly margarita special added a nice buzzy haze. 

The people who are writing that the complimentary tortillas and salsa are wheat flour are idiots who never had an excellent, fresh, white corn tortilla. Confirmed with the manager - they do not make or use wheat flour tortillas in anything.
author: Thomas T.

description: Overpriced horrible service the waiter had attitude and twe had to ask for chips and water so many times the food was not good the guacamole was horrible no flavor overpriced we waited to eat here and were so disappointed how can all the waitstaff have an attitude why?! It's was restaurant and we should have had excellent service not what we experienced
author: L T.

description: Amazing food with amazing atmosphere in the heart of sf Union square. A mathematical is a must with any food order
author: Marvin M.

description: Colibri has fantastic, authentic Mexican food. We had the pork Carnitas and a seafood entree.  It was absolutely delicious. The fresh tortillas appetizer they provide with the sauces are to die for. I highly recommend this restaurant when you're in San Francisco. You won't be disappointed.
author: Connie H.

description:
This place is definitely a great Mexican restaurant.  I do live in the Mission and have a plethora of restaurants to choose from when it comes to Mexican cuisine.  Sometimes Colibri can remind me a bit of Tres Agaves but i do have to say that Colibri does it's best to replicate authenticity.  The margaritas here are amazing so bring your pocketbook and drink up!

I highly recommend bringing some friends. starting off with some guacamole and giving a go at the Chile Relleno.  Yummy!
author: Kevin J.

description: Good guacamole ! The mole was not bad either. Total middle of the road food though. I'll be back if I'm walking by and was really hungry.
author: Vin A.

description: Oh Yum! Bring on the yummy Guacamole made table side and super creamy and perfect, the Pozole that is so green and good with the side of things to add..the butter leaf lettuce salad with fruit and avocado... This place is so good. It's cute, the servers are very nice, and the price is moderate so it's a good place to go.  My friend liked the Chile Relleno very much too...  I do wish that it was a bit quieter,and although the fresh soft tortillas are a good start I kinda miss the crispy chips... but still overall.. SOOO GOOD!
author: Maren H.

description:
I was out late and made it a point to get up early and get some work done. Instead I logged onto Yelp, approved compliments, approved a friend request and sent compliments. So since I'm here I might as well write a review right?

Claro que si.

My friend Devo (yes, that is his nickname) stopped by here last night. We had a 6:30 reservation and arrived a little early. They had a table for us and seated us right away.

The first thing that caught my eye were the bottles of tequila glistening behind the bar. I knew in an instant that this was my kind of place. Our server arrived within a few short minutes and made it a point to show us the drink menu. Ah Yes! Drinks! Si como no!

Lately margaritas have bee such a let down. Most are made too sweet and the taste of the tequila is completely lost. It's been all about the mix and less about the tequila. But after reading the reviews and how great their margaritas are I thought I should give it a shot. I went with the Tres Agaves Blanco ($11) which is a "pure and unaged, capturing the clean and herbaceous taste of pure agave". Devo went with the Herradura Blanco ($11) a "moderate earthy aroma, slight amounts of spice, citrus, and floral scents; aged for 45 days in white oak".

I was impressed that both margaritas were served in short tumbler glasses. One of my biggest pet peeves is when they come out in those huge wide froofy glasses that are the size of a gold fish bowl. I guess this is tradition, but I would rather drink out of something that I can actually hold. So props to Colibri for using normal glassware. Each margarita came out with a wedge of lime and on the rocks. No need to specify rocks or blended here, they do it right. The margaritas were almost crystal clear which is a good sign. I took my first sip and was immediately in love. The tequila was shinning through and just the right amount of mix to help liven it up. I tasted Devo's and liked his too, but preferred the one I ordered. 

What next? Table side guacamole ($12)? Si.

We asked for "spicy" and within minutes a freshly made batch of guacamole along with fresh house made corn tortillas was sitting on table. Served with a trio of salsas, this appetizer was delicious. They do have chips, but we both preferred the tortillas. My only complaint is that the tortillas were extra tiny, the size of a small Swedish pancake. So piling on the goodies was a challenge.

When it came time to order, I was torn between the chili relleno and the carnitas. As I was ordering I just decided to let whatever comes out of my mouth be my dinner of choice. Carnitas ($16) then rolled off my tongue. Devo went with the chicken mole ($16) and we both shared sides of black beans ($6), rice ($6) and corn bread ($8).

The portion sizes are small, but I think that is how it's meant to be and may be more tapas style and meant to be shared. I will remember this in the future. Both dishes were amazingly good. The carnitas were tender and perfectly cooked. The mole was deep, dark, complex and full of flavor. The chicken like the pork, perfectly cooked and not over done. I would get either dish again in a heartbeat. The sides were good, pretty much standard and solid. The cornbread was the least exciting of the dishes, and I only had a small bite. The only bummer was again the tortillas. Since I was having carnitas, piling on the toppings was a problem. 

The atmosphere is fun and a little more civilized than say a Chevy's or a an El Toritio. The food is way better than either of those as well. The service was excellent and our server checked on us often and made sure we had plenty of warm tortillas at our disposal. For Mexican food, it was on the expensive side. $123 (pre tip) for dinner for two with two drinks each. But this will not keep me from coming back.

Muy excellente Colibri!
author: Rene C.

description:
A diet high in Avocado will make my skin glow, hair shine, and help me live forever. Avocado + other tasty things = Guacamole. Guacamole is an integral part of Mexican Food. Colibri serves good Mexican food. Ergo, a high Colibri diet will make my skin glow, hair shine, and help me live forever. 

Gotta love the transitive property to justify a high Mexican food diet and I'm happy that there's a sit down restaurant with good service that offers up authentic Mexican where there's little to be found. Their soft tortillas seem fresh pressed and are awesome with the three complimentary salsas and of course, a generous heap of guac made to order (or for $2 you can get chips). We had Pork Panuchos and Fish Tacos, both were fresh, moderately portioned and tasty. For $20-$25/person, you  maybe able walk out looking a little better than you walked in, or, just fatter.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
Let me start with a promise that I won't refer to "the" anything in this review (e.g. the wife or the girlfriend or the mistress or the ... you get the idea ...).

Worst empanada ever (and I've probably tried over 50 different empanadas which either means I'm really old or really love empanadas).  Need I say more?  Whether I need to or not, I probably will.  And on that note ...  

Seriously (we'll see how long this lasts), how do you screw up an empanada?

Speaking of the Cornbread appetizers, I assumed that they were deliberately bad to cue us up for the main courses (i.e. by comparison, we would relish the main courses).  Little did I know.

On a positive note, the Guacamole was great and nobody got food poisoning.
author: Mark B.

description: Really good food & great service even though the restaurant was packed. Be sure to save room for dessert, served alongside an anejo tequila or agavero.
author: Alex L.

description: I don't think the guac is THAT good.  It's just like regular guac.  Now the green and sweet mango sauces are something else - so delicious!  The tortillas that are the size of the palm of your hand are delicious.  We had the nopales and the pork chile relleno to share and both were good.  The nopales got cold fast (maybe it's because we were talking too much) and the wait service was a bit unattentive (but our waitress was very nice and sweet).  Other than that, I'm glad I checked this place out - I didn't know it existed before.  The churros and the dulce de leche ice cream are DELICIOUS.  There's caramel drizzled thoughtfully on the plate and the middle of the churro was warm and yummy.  Get the churros!
author: Chris L.

description: Had dinner there yesterday evening. The guacamole and chips were tasty with the ability to adjust your heat level in the guacamole. The Margaritas were many, skillfully crafted and well balanced in all favors. I was, however, disappointed in the pan seared duck I had. Much of it was overcooked and dry. Some parts resembled duck jerky it had dried so much in the oven. I can't recommend the duck right now, certainly everything else.
author: Robert O.

description:
Sat between 2 different groups and each one said how amazing the food is. 
I've been coming here for years already.

Fun old fashioned black and white movies on the big screen TV above the bar.
author: Nancy G.

description:
I am generously giving this place 2 stars...mostly for the nice bartender (William).

First of all, how far in advance does one need to call to get a reservation here? I called early in the day and there weren't any reservations from 4:30 to 8pm. Ok the place is small and apparently popular, I get it but later I'd realize it's not worth the trouble. We showed up around 6 and took our chances. There were several open tables but were told at this point that the earliest we could get one was 10pm. We ended up sitting at the bar, which actually worked out better because looking around, the restaurant tables looked cramped and uncomfortable. 

Second, I'm not cheap but seriously? The portions and prices don't jive. We got the infamous guacamole (btw it's $12 for the guac, plus $2 for chips) and it was good but it definitely wasn't the best I've ever had. It needed some lime juice or cilantro or something. It was sort of bland. It comes with warm tortillas which I expected to be out of this world, but they tasted like the ones I get at the grocery store. You have to order chips separate. I'm sorry, I know it's SF but $14 for a shallow dish of guac and chips? Eh. The margaritas were good too but again, not the best in the world. The bf ordered the fish tacos...same theme..just ok. I ordered the mole prawns..which I think were $20. There were 6 total with a little cornbread muffin...the muffin was actually amazing and the single best thing I ate that night. But for a $20 dish I'd rather go somewhere else.

I think this restaurant has a bigger ego than it should. I don't live in the city but I imagine there is far better and slightly less expensive Mexican food elsewhere. I will likely never go back, but if you go, look for William!
author: Gabrielle N.

description: Fantastic food!! Great customer service!! If you are looking for a true authentic Mexican food experience I highly recommend!!
author: Steve B.

description: Warm corn tortillas with three salsas, complimentary. Awesome arhat it's, with a massive selection of tequilas and mezcals. Food is unpretentious, authentic and terrific.
author: John P.

description:
Wow. I am so surprised that the place has good ratings! I rarely give a one star rating but this is just inevitable.  I would never return back, ever again. 

I arrived with a party of 8 people at 8pm on a Friday night. 

-We found TWO PIECES OF HAIR (one long and tangled inside a dish, and one short after finishing a soup dish discovered after the soup was eaten to completion) in two dishes for two different people. We were all disturbed and sickened by this. I understand that this can happen but two hair incidents in one sitting? That is unacceptable. 
-The restaurant did nothing to remedy the situation except for exchange to make the dish again but didn't offer to waive anything off the bill or to offer a complimentary item and we did get charged and paid for the full gratuity. 
-The service was so slow, we ordered our drinks at 8:10p and did not get it until 8:30p
-The drinks were very weak / we all agreed on this, and it was also inconsistent in taste.

I ordered the camarones dish with a corn cake and overall, it was tasty and had nice spices. 

Unfortunately, due to the nature of this restaurant, none of us will be returning back to Colibri. This was a huge disappointment and one of the biggest regrets I've had in dining.
author: Brenda T.

description: This is a great place!  The staff is helpful and the service is quick.  It would be a crime to not get the guacamole!  I recommend getting it "medium".  The three salads are great and make a perfect pairing with the guacamole.
author: Kate R.

description:
I ate here with a party of 7 today. I've had good experiences in the past, but today, myself and a friend BOTH found a chicken bone in our food. There was also an old tortilla on my plate, when I picked up my napkin roll to put salsa on it. This means they don't clean their dishes? My appetite was destroyed after that but I didn't want to eat nothing at all, so I ordered soup. Chicken Soup. I had to ask if they would be putting bones in the Chicken Soup, too, while the other guests at my table had to giggle at my question, I was 100% seriously asking if they would be doing me wrong one more time. 

The one star is because the soup actually was pretty yummy, and bone-free. Yay. -_-
author: Natalie L.

description: This is not TexMex. It is SO superior to TexMex. Everything I ate at this restaurant was delicious. For starters, along with chips, you can get tortillas with three different salsas (I adored the mango salsa). The sangria is the best I've ever tasted. All of the entrees that I tried were great, but I think it's really the extras that make this restaurant special. I would highly recommend. I went with a large group and everyone was satisfied.
author: Cameron M.

description:
We chose this restaurant based on the other Yelp raves, and I'm so glad we did! This is the way I like my Mexican food - authentic and full of flavor, not the usual combo enchilada plate. In fact, I don't think they even had an enchilada on the menu.

I had the filete mignon - it was perfectly cooked, lean, on a bed of mashed potatoes, surrounded by a most delicious and spicy chipotle sauce. It was just the right amount of food for me. My hubby had the prawns in tamarind mole sauce - he liked it but the sauce was a bit too sweet for me. Others in our group had the mole poblano and the scallops. We also got an order of Torta de Elote, which I thought was a bit dry and dense, but the others enjoyed.

Service was excellent - we were well attended to, and dishes and wine glasses were removed promptly. Our waiter was really friendly and gave us some suggestions from the menu. It was quite loud in the restaurant, but it didn't make it too hard to hear across the table.When we were running late, I called and they moved our reservation back a half-hour, even though they were clearly packed. Colibri is a winner!
author: Deb F.

description:
Found this gem on yelp while on a quick trip in the city. 

Duck with green sauce and pumpkin seeds is phenomenal. Guacamole and margaritas were on point. Chocolate cake was delicious and not overly sweet. 

A little overpriced and sides of rice/beans are a la carte. But overall a great find!
author: Angela S.

description: The food is decent, but the portions are tiny, especially for the price. Bathrooms are dirty, waitress was distracted and it was not a busy time. Not worth the trip.
author: Ray W.

description: Wish I came here when I lived two blocks away. Sooooo good and naturally almost everything is gluten free ... thank the GF gods!!
author: Shiho F.

description:
Looking forward to a nice dinner at Colibri...

Service was great, cocktails tasty and sala with soft tortillas were delisious.

Main course gets a thumbs down, while it wasnt bad, it did not meet the expectations that we had when we went to Colibri for brunch. Small portions and not much to help the flavor of the meat. I had carnitas and it was just that, a chunk of carnitas. tasty but could have been served with a side to help compliment the texture and flavors of the meat.

All and all we will probably return to Colibri for another meal but would prefer brunch over dinner.
author: Joe M.

description: Amazing Brunch! Traveling by myself and stumbled upon this place. Guac was delish as well as the homemade corn tortillas they give you.  SO GOOD!
author: Marnie L.

description:
Having frequented the Union Square area for a decade and a half now, I thought that most of the restaurants within walking distance were overpriced tourist traps, Colibri has changed my mind.  

Oh the trio of salsas were amazing and free!  Mango, verde, and my favorite, a spicy red salsa, I requested for extra and poured it over pretty much everything I ate.

Started with two appetizers:

Sopes surtidos, three little corn 'boats', three different ways: chicken, carnitas, and sauteed veggies, topped with crumbled cheese and sour cream-Superb trio that left me satisfied, the three flavors had a chance of blurring into one, but Colibri managed to keep them distinct.

Tacos de salmon a la parrilla, grilled salmon w/pineapple chipotle sauce, wrapped in you guessed it, the corn tortillas again, at this point, we were just all tortilla'ed out, the salmon was well done, and didn't have much flavoring, liked the fresh pineapple, but it really was not inventive or punchy like the previous, maybe b/c it was not smothered in any sauce?

The ensalada mixta was uneventful and very forgettable, a medley of mixed greens, candied pecans, blue cheese, tomatoes with a barely visible cherry viniagrette, I doused this salad with the spicy red salsa to give it SOMETHING, anything!

Lastly the skewered filet mignon with veggies, came with Mexican rice, pureed black beans, verde salsa, and a chipotle salsa.  The filet came with melted goat cheese on top, was not digging that aspect of it, but it was cooked nicely, lacking in flavor though, more marination was needed.  Loved the pureed black beans, but the sliced avocados tasted terrible.  

Very nice place to energize before a long day of tooling around the city!
author: Cynthia C.

description: Excellent food, great environment, and good service.  Empanadas were flavorful and the fresh tortillas were amazing.  I can't wait to come back.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I won't go back unless I am dragged there by others.  I didn't have overly high expectations going into it, but my experience was even worse than I thought it would be.

The guacamole and margaritas were fine.  Nothing worth complaining or raving about.  Then I ordered the carnitas.  I never send things back, but this just had to go.  Big chunks of dry, tough, overcooked meat that not even a tub of sauce could save.  Even the people sitting at the next table chimed in on how awful it looked.  The waitress quickly switched out the order to something else, but didn't really do much in terms of apologizing or justifying.  (Then again, that was all her service style was -- just adequate enough.)  I will say my chicken mole replacement meal was significantly better though.

Overall, with "meh" service, and food that was okay at best, why bother?  I only went due to proximity to the Curran Theatre.  Overpriced and underwhelming.
author: Sonia D.

description:
Great mexican place all the usuals plus a whole stack more!
With the interior, I could be anywere in the world, especially as I'd just flown into San Fran the day before, but I was downtown and sitting in a comfy booth with colleagues.
I had the Tortita de Papas (just $14) and most of my party had something with meat and I think even with Sangria we were under $35 a head.
It's odd the that chips have to be purchased separately when ordering the standard guacamole but hey, the service was OK.
author: Rickie J.

description:
The service is slow, the food is not only mediocre but steeply overpriced (and filled with MSG or possibly some food poisoning-inducing substances!), and the final strike is how we were not given a birthday dessert on the house! Seriously, we paid for that $8 churro tower (that ironically was the best-tasting thing of the evening). So unfortunately, all the negative reviews about this place are true!

Good things:
- Churro dessert: At $8, this dish, along with everything on the menu, is greatly overpriced with its 4 measly little deep fried sticks of sweetness and tiny scoop of dulce de leche ice cream that quickly melted. Still, it was a nice ending to the meal. The churros were surprisingly light.
- Home-made (?) corn tortillas: I thought they would charge us for our second round of tortillas (they charge $2 for extra chips...) but after much prompting, they finally provided us with some more of these warm, soft DELICIOUS tortillas.

Not so good things:
- Food that makes you sick: Alright, that's an overstatement, but both my friend and I felt drowsy immediately after eating our meals. Overdose of MSG? Perhaps it was the guacamole that really wasn't as amazing as the reviews say...It's been two days later and I still feel like my stomach is funky.
- Service: I feel like this is hit or miss. Our waiter was really nice, but our hostess sat us in the worst possible table even though I had made reservations. Service was also really, really slow even though the restaurant wasn't that full.

This was not the greatest food experience I've had. I have officially given up on Mexican food in NorCal.
author: Shira C.

description:
Awesome breakfast Food, Incredible home made salsa's and corn tortilla's served while you wait.   We tried a couple omelets.  RECOMMEND the Carnita Omelet.  The Chile kile's (an egg/breakfast nacho's) was incredible too.  Bottomless mimosa's - what more do you want?  We didn't want to fight the lines at the 3 diner's on Mason and Geary for average food.  Even the fast food places were packed.  This place had plenty of room, and probably less money in the long run.
--Jer
author: RibChamp Z.

description:
Margarita Avion: was very crisp, with herbal notes of mint and rosemary.

The Mojitos were very aromatically stimulating burst of fresh mint, and limes. And It felt like a fully encompassing experience of euphoric bliss, as I heard birds chirping, and the sound of growing foliage upon each savory sip.
 
Sope Surtidos: were the perfect sharing-portion for 2 people.. very flavorful shredded pork, greens, topped with creamy crumbled queso fresco.

The Ceviche Camarones served with plantain crisps wasn't as acidic as some other's I've had.. I think due to the added orange juice, mango, and tomato and you can lightly detect these flavors as you're eating it.. there was also a nice flourish of sunflower seeds to add some earthy flavor to it.

The standard tequila flight was great, and honest with a variety of: Blanco, Reposado, and Anejo.. I don't know my minority liquors that well, so I'll refrain from writing more in-depth.  On a sidenote: I made a mistake of sipping the tomato chili chaser in between, so I couldn't really taste much after.  I was perplexed by how satisfying some of the discomfort felt as I was sipping on this until the chili chaser was gone, then again I don't drink enough tequila to truly understand this phenomenon.  Our server Camilla was great though, very playful, upbeat and had a lot of great energy and charisma.

I will probably pass on the rich chocolately Mexican Coffee next time (with tequila and Kalua).. it is a bit too decadent for me, and I haven't really developed a taste for coffee with a spicy mouth/throat feel quite yet.

I am not so much a fan of when it comes to the chop and dice places like the ones located in the Mission.  However, this place is really exceptional.
author: Ty T.

description:
Mole chicken is on the bone n comes with no sides at all. Chips are bordering stale. Guacamole is lemony. Sesame crusted tuna is pretty good. Stuffed chicken is partially on bone, some not. Creamy sauce is good n chicken is moist. 
Bathroom needs help. You may smell like dinner when you leave.
author: Christine A.

description:
There might be a temptation to say this is a Mezcal and Tequila influenced vote, but it is not. Food is really some of the best I've had in the US or Mexico. The food was delicious, the décor just right. The customer age range varied depending on the time you go. That goes to show you good taste is universal. 

I was only in SF for the weekend, but I had to eat here twice. Great trio salsa, paired with hand made tortillas. Freshly made and perfectly spiced guacamole. Tried the ceviche, chorizo, green pozole, and the mole and I had no complaints for anything which is rare in my book. The Mexican cuisine offered is homey but you can tell a chef cooked it, taking the meal to another level.

The only fault I found was a boring bathroom, but that's not worth knocking out any points. So what are you waiting for? Head on over!
author: Sandra V.

description:
I've known about this place forever and have passed by it hundreds of times always noticing how busy it always is.  So, we finally made plans to have dinner here, and to my surprise, Colibri also owns Consuelo at Santana Row, one of our favorite restaurants in San Jose.  Little did we know that Colibri is so similar and has the same handmade warm tortillas and three sauces that come with your meal.  We were so ecstatic!!  We tried the table-made guacamole - delish!  We didn't order the separate chips, but spooned it on our warm tortillas - yummmm!  :)  

I ordered the carnitas and enjoyed it immensely - tender, tasty, kind of reminded me of Hawaiian kahlua pig, loved it!  And I had a tasty, summery sangria - mmmm!  My bf and friend both ordered the lamb shanks - my bf's plate was clean, he loved it!  

The service was really nice & friendly, and the ambiance was fun & festive - great for groups!  We will definitely be back as this place is so close to home - yay!!

Dinner w/ Geraldine # 26

About $35/person with app + drink - not bad!
author: Maile N.

description: Awesome guac, fresh tortillas, and carnitas. Festive environment. Reminded me of a more casual Fonda San Miguel in Austin.
author: Andrew K.

description:
A different astonishingly slow hipster eating place in a very area turning out to be messed up by means of hipsters and wanna be foods snobs!

1: 00 over a Saturday and, being hipster San Fran, there is a brand beyond your entrance.
The coordinator can be standing at this time there hunting clueless on the brand, certainly not having down labels and numbers of individuals within the a variety of get-together.
Subsequently the woman cellular phone rings, your woman responses and writes the particular title on the person down on the list and says "Ok sign on with all the coordinator when you appear and you will be placed. inches

Actually? Meanwhile we've been standing at this time there with regard to 10 min's and you do not get our own labels down, but another person whom calls on the cellular phone gets main concern.
Plus the kicker, your woman responses the telephone ONCE AGAIN and contributes yet another title for the list!!!!

Of course, this specific organization none it truly is other destinations may ever before view a nickel regarding my very own!!
author: James T.

description:
Yelp let me down this time! We expected spotty service but the food left much to be desired.

We arrived early for a 10 pm reservation and were seated promptly.

Drinks were okay -- not as flavorful as other restaurants in the area.

Tortillas salsa and guacamole were good.  But the meal itself wasn't anything special. Some of the items on the online menu were not on the actual menu. 

We're vegetarian and there were limited options and there wasn't much they could modify and make vegetarian.
author: R P.

description:
I liked this place, but boy was it expensive.  We came here at lunch, service was nice, and there was a lot of bigger groups there (6+ people)

Food wise it's a solid 4/5 but the price really dropped it.  The guac was great and the salsa was tasty. We ordered the carne asada and it was again, very tasty.  Loved the cactus & portabella mushrooms.  Even for someone that doesn't typically like corn tortillas, I ate 2 of them.

Their chips are thicker and almost too hard, but not really.  They make excellent salsa and guac vehicles though.

We tried 2 of their cocktails, overly sweet but different at least.  I was really impressed with how much tequila this place had.  Not only a huge selection but just 3+ bottles each, wondering what this place is like at night..
author: Van W.

description:
I tend to judge Mexican food restaurants by their fish tacos. These were OK, nothing special. The guacamole was fresh and well-seasoned, but there wasn't enough of it to satisfy a group of four.


Note:
The service was very good and the house margaritas were pleasantly strong, but I think that Colibri should be listed as $$$ not $$. The Zagat reviews listed the average price of a meal as $36 which would be "$$$ Spendy" on Yelp, and our meals averaged more than that (Yelp classifies $$ as $30 or less).
author: Meghan P.

description:
I do highly suggest that if you want to have dinner at Colibri make a reservation, this place gets packed! The staff was very nice and the food I though was okay, nothing amazing. I am a Mexican food lover so maybe I'm a little picky? I ordered the Pork dish and I did like that my portion was small it did lack creativity, it was just meat and grilled green onions....a little more on my plate please? I also thought the guacamole was just okay as well, guac is meant to be amazing not just okay...it needed a kick, it was kind of on the boring side.

This is not the worst restaurant to end up in down town, give it a try and be the judge.
author: T C.

description: Didn't have time to go to Mission District for Mexican but found this gem near our hotel by Union Square. Cozy place with dark wood furnishings which I like. Please play traditional Mexican music though, not top 40 music, would add to the charm. Service was pleasant, food was excellent!
author: Helen S.

description:
The food was amazing; the one star off is only for the music, which was blaring right above our table and was not the best choice for Mother's Day.  I asked them to turn it down but the change in volume was minimal.  Other than that, everything was perfect - I wouldn't have imagined such a nice interior and great food from outside on the street.  The waiters were extremely accommodating and polite to our party, which with the exception of my Mexican boyfriend required completely not-spicy Mexican food.  Few places are willing or able to do this, and the waiters seems perfectly happy to make everything chili-free and even reassure my mom that those were tomatoes, not raw onions in the guacamole.  And, they brought my mom a free mimosa since it was Mother's Day, which she didn't want so I can say it was delicious. ; )  

The salsas that came with the guacamole and tortillas were great; actually I only tried the mild one (mango chipotle) and I jealously guarded it for the rest of the meal and had to be careful I didn't end up licking the dish!  I think out of all of us my mom ordered the best dish (carne asada with nopales, mushrooms, and beans).  I had the huevos poblanos; the rice that came with it was very exciting (for rice) and the eggs had a great texture.  The interior of the restaurant is very beautiful, and since we all loved our food I am sure I will be back.
author: Mara H.

description: Colibri had to be one of my favorite spots anywhere in the world to eat fine Mexican food - and that includes Mexico City, Puebla, and Oaxaca city. While this last visit (May 2014) seemed to reveal some slippage, the restaurant is still a fine example of what fine Mexican cuisine can be. The restaurant leans towards the traditional and resists hip trends, which I more than appreciate. The Mezcal and Tequila menu is good, and in general I would say the service is very good as well. While I won't say it's the best dining one could have in SF, it's a sure thing if you're in the area, or looking for a nicer Mexican dining experience.
author: Mike B.

description: Amazing drinks and delicious food!! Definitely recommend the margaritas, homemade guacamole, carnitas and chile rellenos!! You can't go wrong with anything on their menu. We definitely come back next time we're in SF.
author: Neyra V.

description:
Pros:
Good Food

Cons:
Small Portions (Doesn't bother me, but isn't reflected in price)
Squished together seating areas
Servers that really don't want to be there and seem overworked and rude
Made my party wait, even with reservations
Did I mention how squished together they place everyone?
author: Chris I.

description: I wish I knew how the food was but we left before we could eat..service was bad..not attentive waiters , last round of drinks were really bad.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Kinda torn about Colibri. We came for dinner yesterday evening with two other friends. We decided to start with a pitcher of sangria, which was very tasty, though at $22 it's worth figuring out whether your whole table enjoys sangria before getting it. We ordered the sopes as an appetizer - there was one veggie sope, one chicken, and one pork. The pork was cooked in their mole, I think, and it was very good, but the other sopes were unremarkable (the veggie one kind of tasted like a chicken pot pie, weirdly enough.)

For mains, I ordered the carnitas and my date ordered crusted scallops on some kind of bean puree. I now understand after reading some Yelp reviews that even the main dishes are meant to be tapas style, and I can say that if you don't know this, your main dish ends up being pretty boring. For example, the carnitas I got was ONLY carnitas: wads of meat, cup of salsa, the end. Because the other plates happened to look slightly more like complete meals, I thought my carnitas dish was just unusual and I should've gotten something different.

Anyway, the carnitas weren't that hot. The *quality of the meat* was superb, and the meat was cooked superbly, but there was nothing particularly carnitas-y about it. Add to that the fact that that's all my entree consisted of, and you'll know why I was pretty disappointed with that.

To top it off, the service was pretty poor, even though the restaurant never got that full.

However, Colibri really redeemed itself with dessert. I usually don't order whole desserts, I just nibble, but the desserts we got here made me wish I had a dessert all to myself. We got one chocolate pudding and something that basically consisted of vanilla ice cream on top of a beignet-like churro. They were great!!

I'd come back here strictly for dessert, coffee, and tequila (I can't deny that they appear to have a good looking tequila stash, though I did not try any on this visit.) I would rather go next door to Katana-ya for my main meal though! :)
author: Josh K.

description: If you're in the mood for Ceviche this is an awesome place to come!! It was delicious!! Had lots of fish and flavor- absolutely loved it. Also has lots of crafty drinks and chill scene.
author: Maureen M.

description: Although I was sick from my stomach when I went, They're food was good. Close enough to the real deal. They're waiters were great. BUT for the amount of food served the prices are ridiculous. If you're going to charge $20 a plate at least throw in some more rice if it's not the main dish. Anyways dessert was good definitely worth paying for.
author: Jacky A.

description: Great meal at this restaurant. The duck with the polenta cakes was amazing, so was the filet mignon spinach and mashed potatoes.
author: Karen A.

description:
It's been seven years since my first review, and the place has held up very well.  The ambiance is still the same.  Service is very casual and not always efficient, but sweet and friendly.  As others repeatedly complain, the table-side guacamole isn't table side unless you insist.  The menu seems to have simplified, for lunch at least, but all the dishes are big, filling, and tasty.  Salads are all nice, especially the jicama.  Their homemade salsa trios are good, and the green (tomatillo, no red chile)  pozole is solid.

I've probably been here a dozen times over the years, it's a solid, comfortable standby and an excellent non-touristy option for anyone going to the theaters across the street.  Every time I come my eyes are glued on the monitors where they show old black and white Mexican films with magic wrestlers, tragic damsels, and singing cowboys.
author: Gil S.

description: I had the Carnitas and it was GREAT!  The flour tortillas were a perfect complement to the dinner and the service was impeccable.
author: Jeff S.

description: Nothing special. Last night, my family and I dined in at Colibri. The server was pretty rude but the service was quick. We ordered the Tostadas as an appetizer. The portion was just right and it tasted fabulously! I ordered the Mole Poblano for my main course. It was a bit pricey for the size and Poblano sauce didn't quite have the balance of sweet and spice that I usually go for. However, it was pretty O.K. Overall, I wouldn't come back here. It wasn't anything special, food was just O.K., and the server was not very friendly.
author: Andrea L.

description: This place sucks. Balls. Pathetically small portions for a laughably inflated price. Hold off on Mexican food until you're in a less touristy neighborhood. Soooo not worth it!
author: Cindy Lou W.

description:
Great spot to get a meal before heading to the Curan Theater before a show, but go early, give yourselves plenty of time, as the other reviewers say, the service is slow.  I mentioned it to the waiter who initially took our drink orders. I had given him my credit card, then we didn't see him again, another server took over and was not in a good mood at all.  We asked for water refills upon getting our food and she didn't respond, just made a face and walked away.  She looked like she was at the end of her rope.

The 7 of us got two trays of 3 salsas with great warm tortillas. We also ordered guacamole for the table and got a little bowl with 8 chips, served by food runners.  The guac was excellent, I got a taste with my fork, next time I'd ask for a big bowl of chips.  

The food tastes fresh.  We sat by the kitchen where you can see the tortillas being made and just about everything looked to be prepared as ordered and not pre-made then reheated. We were with a group ranging in age from 15 to 80 and everyone found something they liked on the menu.  The older folks had a hard time hearing and asked to have the music turned down.  We were there Sunday at noon and the tile floors, open kitchen and loud music make for a noisy meal.

I had the Tinga which was fine - just chicken with light sauce in a tortilla.  The carnitas looked better.  Everyone got the black beans as a side dish but some of us got a teaspoon and some had a pint of them on the plate.  The plates came out really sloppy, beans dripping down the side and fingerprints in beans.  Not fancy Mexican food but a filling meal.

The check came my credit card wasn't in it.  I got up and tracked down our first server, got my credit card back and asked where he'd been.  He explained that it was the grouchy servers second day and he was training her.
author: Dena M.

description:
Delicious! Fancy Mexican food in the best way imaginable! Enjoyed the Pescado Del Dia which was seared ahi tuna over mashed potatoes in a butter sauce and asparagus. EVERY single bite was full of flavor and texture. The tuna was crusted, seared perfectly, and had the right amount of sabor! Muy delicioso! I can't believe I ate the entire plate. 

My friend ordered the Carnitas with huge chunks of juicy, marinated pork. And since we also ordered the fresh Guacamole as an app, our very helpful server recommended my friend save some guacamole to make some killer carnitas tacos!  And boy that guacamole with freshly made tortillas is legit!

I don't doubt that every single item on this menu will transport you to Cuernavaca, Mexico!
author: Anna R.

description:
I went to Colibri on a Sunday evening with friends from out of town. We ordered the spicy jalapeño margaritas, guac with chips, and I ordered the Ensalada Flor De Verano. The salad was amazing and prepared with fresh ingredients. The margaritas were refreshing and spicy. My friends brought their kids with and although there isn't much selection for the young ones, the restaurant made an exception and prepared some quesadillas for them. 
Overall food and service was good, but this it's an upscale Mexican restaurant - not a typical place to order tacos and burritos nor will you receive free chips and salsa.
author: Alya G.

description:
El Santo on the tube while having dinner.

A black and white El Santo film played on the bar tv while diners toast to happy hour or in our case, dinner before theater.  Make reservations as this is a hot spot for drinkers and diners, esp those with theater tickets.  Let your waiter know you have a show coming up and they will take care of you.

Starter:  guacamole served in a traditional volcanic mortar with a side of fresh flour tortillas, tortilla chips, and three sauces.   The beet salad was refreshing and delicious but it's the chicken mole we wanted.  Four pieces of tender chicken enveloped in a rich, dark, chocolate mole sauce had incredible intense flavors.  We ate it in various ways-with tortillas and guacamole, with Spanish rice we ordered, or just by itself.  A 3 sip margarita (too small for $10) and strong coffee rounded out the meal.  While our waters were refilled, it was a little difficult asking the waitstaff for tortilla refills, but as soon as we did, they reappeared, warm and wrapped in a white dinner napkin.  Covet any leftovers you have, if any, to extend the meal another day.

Buen apetito.
author: Jen L.

description:
The food here is delicious and done well.  Can't skip the homemade tortillas.  Unfortunately, the service isn't as polished. Service here is slow. Let me repeat that S-L-O-W.  Don't expect to get out of dinner in under 1.5 hours ... never going to happen.  But, I like coming here casually so I'm never in a rush.  

Here's the other thing to know: if you have allergies, be very specific. I have specific allergies and they definitely do NOT specify what all is in a dish.  Be ready to be surprised.  Case #1 in point: "What comes with the fish of the day." "Mashed potatoes."  (they came with fried plantains... under the mashed potatos and fish. delicious but kind of a giant thing to leave out).  Case #2 in point: "No mushrooms in this right?" "Nope." (It was full of mushrooms).
author: Discretio ..

description:
From the bartender's custom beet margarita to the exceptional fish ceviche with juices that ran up my sleeve (and I didn't mind) this place was a pleasure. All we kept saying is, "Why don't we have a place like this in Monterey?" 

Everything is a la carte including rice, beans and chips which is a little different than we're used to in a Mexican restaurant but every bite was a wonderful experience.  The servers were all very friendly and courteous. The price is quite a bit more than we are used to but I'd definitely recommend the place and next time we go to the Curran, we'll be back for sure.
author: Peri B.

description: Pretty mediocre. My guests and I were sat at a table in a terrible spot right beneath the bar. The drinks were okay. You would think that the margaritas would be amazing but they were totally half-ass. The bartender huffed when I asked if he could make my spicy margarita a little less spicy than states on the menu. Food was okay but if you're going to have Mexican, go to the mission!!
author: Alan T.

description: No manners, no concept of service. The bartender just knocked a drink over my $3,000 laptop at the bar. She couldn't have cared less.
author: Devin D.

description: This place was packed!!! We had excellent service and I love that they serve tortillas instead of chips! Their table side guac is to die for, their Mojito was fabulous and I could have licked my plate...I ordered the duck breast. Great little find in the city!
author: Olivia R.

description: Nothing to brag about. Overpriced for the amount of food you get. The food wasn't very Mexican. If you're looking for traditional Mexican fare this is not it.
author: Bella W.

description:
I remember coming here at least two years ago, so when my friend said he wanted to try out their brunch, I was all over it like a fat kid on cake. We went in Sunday morningish for brunch and were absolutely not disappointed.

I ordered the vegetable omelet, which was packed full of veggies, while my companion picked the chorizo tacos. Their black beans are actually more a sauce with cheese sprinkled over it but it's super tasty. 

The decor is fancy looking, but the menu is pretty affordable. I was tempted to get the bottomless mimosas, but figured chugging back three glasses that early in the morning (to get the $10 value out of it) wouldn't be prudent given the rest of our day's plans.

Service is polite and quick with soft corn taco appetizers with sauce being refilled at your whim. 

If you're looking for something a bit more upscale than a burrito taqueria or Chipotles, this is a good option.
author: Cassandra J.

description: I always enjoy the food here but today my experience was a disappointment because of the rude male host (May 24th @ 2:45pm).  So because he had a stick up his @ss and was extremely rude, I have to rate it a 3 star today.
author: talk t.

description:
I made reservations at Colibri mostly because it was right across the street from the Curran Theatre where we would be seeing The Book of Mormon. Optimal location; even with 5:30 pm reservations, my friend and I managed to talk so much that we nearly missed the 7:30 pm opening (luckily, it's a two minute walk from the theatre).

We both ordered the mole chicken and margueritas. The drinks were strong and the chicken's mole sauce was plentiful - right up my alley. 

The place was a little expensive - especially for Mexican food, which most Californians aren't comfortable paying more than $10 for in one meal - but with the classiness of the restaurant and the convenience to the theatre, I'm giving it 4 stars.
author: Jen B.

description: Really good food! As a Mexican I enjoyed the mole poblano and the panuchos!!!! Armando did a great job and recommended the churros rellenos they where also great!
author: Ana A.

description:
Fabulous appetizers (we had pork, chicken and cheese tomales) with the smoothest, creamiest corn dough I've ever had. I was a little disappointed in my entree which was Camarones en Mole. The shrimp tasted oddly like dirty dish water. My BF loved his Mole Poblano. The coffee at the end was nasty, but I'm a coffee snob.  

Otherwise, loved the ambiance (one of the rare restaurants in the Bay Area that's not deafeningly loud), decor and the service was excellent: not too pushy and not too slack.
author: Sarah S.

description: Dissapointing. 12$ guacamole for a tablespoon of it; ridiculous. Overpriced for what it is. The food was good, flavorful and I really enjoyed the meal, but I wouldn't go back there. I felt it too much of a tourist trap.
author: Adriana A.

description: The food is tastey but the menu is limited. The menu definitely features more of an authentic line up of Mexican fare. I sampled from the appetizer menu: fish taco and the cochinita pibil. Fish was too fishy but the pork was just right - albeit a bit messy! Service is good.
author: R G.

description: A little pricey, but good solid mexican food.  The guacamole is delicious, but $12 for guac borders on craziness.  Everytime I come here I get the carnitas and it never disappoints.  The lamb shank also looks pretty solid.
author: Harsh K.

description: Stopped in for happy hour and are at the bar. The restaurant had nice ambiance. The bartenders were attentive and nice. The margaritas were so so.  I started out with an appetizer, 3 crisp tortilla chips with shredded pork, avocado and sour cream. They were excellent.  They then brought out warm home made tortillas and 3 types of salsa which was a nice surprise.  I then had the vegetarian chili relleno.  I was disappointed as the chili tasted like a bell pepper, there was no hotness to it whatsoever.  It was fire roasted but not long enough, seemed a bit underdone.  The presentation though was beautiful.  I would come back but try a different dish, maybe I had a bad pick.
author: Caddie W.

description:
Normally, I do not like to eat in the downtown area of SF, preferring to venture out into the different neighborhoods, but a dear friend, who is Mexican suggested we meet here for dinner, since alot of the dishes being served were dishes he grew up with. So, we planned on going with 4 other people, we were six altogether. 

We started with a large of guacamole and asked them to make it spicy. It was quite delicious, personally I think it could've been much more spicy.  We ordered the following dishes and pretty much shared them: Mole, Puchucga, carnitas and Pato en Mole Verde Pipián (duck with mole verde).  I have to say everything was delicious, we literally devoured everything on our table. Plus they keep giving you more homemade corn enchiladas whenever you wanted. 

With that said, I would definitely go back for the food. The problem that I have with this restaurant is the NOISE. It is so noisy we were literally screaming at each other. And, to make it worse, there was a mariachi band playing.  Sure it's fun and festive, but as soon as you leave, it feels like you've gone deaf.
author: Randy D.

description:
Tasty, well executed upscale Mexican fare.

I'm a big fan of homemade tortillas so they get high marks from me off the bat.
We had their guac, fish tacos, and Yucatan pork. Everything was delicious.

Had a michelada (Mexican bloody Mary) from here a long time ago, that made me a fan. Haven't had a better one since.
author: Derrick V.

description: We were a party of five for dinner and each of us agreed that the super small portions and lack of flavor from the entrees were not worth the $18$-$26 per entree. Wonder if my review will be shown? All of the factual negative reviews of this place were there.
author: T S.

description:
If you haven't eaten at Colibri in San Francisco, well my friend you are missing out! 
I have tried about 75% of the menu while on business trips and have never been let down. The best yet on the menu... Callos con Crust de Tortilla (corn tortilla crusted scallops over purple Peruvian mashed potatoes and sautéed poblano pepper, cactus leaves,corn and portobello mushrooms). So good you'll keep coming back for more and more.
author: Monika A.

description:
I was disappointed - when I got to the bar, they had fresh strawberries, blackberries, mint, and cilantro - I asked the bartender what drink he could make me using some of those ingredients and he offered me the cocktail menu.  I ordered the strawberry and basil margarita and I didn't see any of those fresh ingredients go into it.  I didn't taste the basil in the drink at all.  I decided to give him a second chance and he made me a blackberry margarita - there definitely were fresh berries blended in the drink and it was a strong margarita but I wasn't wowed like I am at some of my favorite Mexican restaurants in Raleigh.  At $12, I don't want a drink just to get drunk off, I want to savor the fresh fruit and the beauty of the drink.
The fish tacos are not that good.  I ordered them off the happy hour menu - 3 fish tacos in corn tortillas for $6 is a great deal but the sauce/aioli topping was too creamy and the fish and tortillas didn't taste as fresh as I would have liked.
The guacamole was good - but a person flying solo shouldn't have to order guacamole for 2.  I like that they make it to your taste - mild, medium, or hot. The tortillas are presented in a cloth napkin and 3 sauces - sweet (mango pineapple), medium (green - cilantro, jalapeños, tomatoes, onions), and a hot (red with Mexican peppers) also come with it.  All the sauces were tasty but the hot was seriously not hot at all - think it was missing something.  At $12, I am not sure if the guacamole appetizer is worth it - it needs something more.
I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Noa N.

description:
Came here with the girlfriend's parents -- my first time taking them out to dinner. They live in Asia and crave Mexican food when they visit the States, so the challenge was finding a place that's tasty but on the nicer side in terms of ambiance. Unfortunately, that leaves only a few options, and if you're strict about it and rule out Spanish and Peruvian food, then your options are really limited. It came down to here and Mamacita for me, and although the food is okay at Mamacita I've just about had it with the Marina and its unsurpassed white douchiness. So, Colibri it was, even though I'd never been before.

Fortunately, it did not disappoint. The restaurant is on the fringe of Union Square, which made me a little afraid that it'd be touristy, but that wasn't the case. When we arrived, I immediately enacted my plan to prevent the parents from paying for our meal. I shook hands with our server -- I think his name was Anthony, that good man -- and slipped him my credit card with the understanding that they should just pay our bill automatically at the end of the meal. He was the epitome of professional and didn't show any expression beyond a smile and the briefest of nods.

Our food was excellent. The guacamole is justifiably raved about, as were the pibil pork and the carnitas entree. We also had tasty cocktails -- mojitos, although I can't remember now what kind.

The decor is a little drab, and the tables are dark brown with the sort of matte finish that makes them look never quite as clean as they probably are. Mamacita definitely has a leg up on environs. But, it is what it is, and I'd highly recommend Colibri for a solid Mexican dinner on a weeknight out.
author: Albert L.

description: Pretty good upscale Mexican food. They have a great tequila selection and dessert was pretty good. This was the second time I had eaten there and I will go back again. The filet was good and the pork stuffed poblano was ok.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I think the only reason vegetarians go nuts at this place is because they don't have vegetarian options. I'm not a vegetarian, but someone in our party was, and she actually had to modify a dish to fit her needs because they don't have any vegetarian options.

The margs are good, and I liked that they gave you warm tortillas and an assortment of salsas. I ordered the carnitas, and it was a major miss. I wasn't a big fan, I thought it would be shredded pork, but it came in big hunks of pork. Plus portions are kind of small here for their price.

Probably wouldn't go back, not that impressed.
author: Margaret L.

description:
Outstanding restaurant!  Tried the Pechuga Rellena de Huitlacoche (chicken breast stuffed with a mix of huitlacoche , zucchini and fresh corn, served over a roasted garlic sauce).  It was one of the best dishes I've had anywhere.

Nice atmosphere...though I went on a Sunday night, so it was crowded but not overly so.  This isn't the place for "cheap eats", but it was worth the money (IMO).
author: Darren_Hilarie D.

description: This place is awesome.  Food is delicious, beyond my wildest dreams.  Salmon was perfect.  Mashed potatoes with filet mignon. Deserts were oh so tasty.
author: Walter B.

description:
Colibri has me wrapped around it's little Mexican finger. After the incredibly awesome meal I had here, Colibri can do no wrong in my eyes... or mouth. Hey, I love a great hole-in-the-wall that bangs out the most bad-ass burritos in town just as much as the next guy, but this place seriously rocks. The mole chicken is finger lickin', but everything here pretty much is.  I need a moment in silence for the tor... the torrr... the tortillas!! I get goosebumps just thinking about those warm perfect bundles of perfection. It's just a tortilla, right? Wrong! It's the best tortilla I've had in any restaurant and makes whatever you chose to stuff inside it taste so good you'll wanna sneak off to the darkest corner and do whatever you do in dark corners. 

Take your family. Take your friends. Hell, go by yourself. Just make sure to make rezzies and order... everything.
author: Jen Y.

description: Not your average Tex-Mex restaurant. From appetizers to entrees everything is fresh and delicious. The Mole Poblano is out of this world. Only advice I would give is to make a reservation in advance if able although walk-ins are taken.
author: JT S.

description: A really awful dining experience, from start to finish.  We had to take the initiative on all of our ordering, including asking repeatedly for water refills. We were never asked if we would like to continue with our wine. All of the waiters treated us like they were doing us a favor by serving and even acknowledging us. The food is very mediocre, and the mole was burned pretty badly. There is a Jack in the Box nearby. I probably would have had a better time there.
author: Austin H.

description:
Really enjoyed this place.  We ended up eating at the bar (it is pretty popular), something we don't usually enjoy doing.  Great service, great drinks and we had an ahi fish of the day special that was one of the best ahi tuna dishes we've had in a long time.  A bit noisy but worth it!

If you are in the Union Square or downtown area, check it out.
author: Steven W.

description:
I first went to this restaurant shortly after it had opened back in 2005. I remembered it as being extremely good, so naturally, on a recent business trip to San Fran, I went back.

Again, it truly was phenomenal. We shared the guac and queso to start. Of course guacamole in California is going to be superior to most other places because the avocados are just that much fresher, but regardless, it was well seasoned. The queso was also great. The gound nature of the chorizo really allowed for each scoop to be similarly flavorful and delicious. 

We then shared the tortilla soup and the carne asada. The tortilla soup was good, but probably the weak link as the meal went overall....solid but nothing overly special.  The carne asada however, was perfectly cooked and very yummy. The garnish was well balanced and the rice and beans were good.

The tortillas that are served with several salsas were quite possibly the best part of the entire meal. The mango salsa was out of this world and the tortillas we just couldn't stop eating.

I highly highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Laura B.

description:
Colibri is mexican food crack.  You crave it!  Your mouth waters when someone starts talking about their guacamole. You twitch thinking about the carnitas or chicken mole dancing on your tongue. Then you start to think about what you would do for another napkin filled with their homemade tortillas made two seconds before they arrive at your table.  Just typing this review has me sweating a little as my mind wonders into a colibri margarita memory.

Seriously this is the real deal.  I love this place.  Outside of Tommy's out in the avenues, this is the best mexican restaurant in SF.
author: Brandon M.

description:
We had 2 good Margaritas at the bar from a very bad bartender,  rolled up sleeves with scull tattoos,  did not give us personal service, looked everywhere but never our way. Rude. 
Sat down to have dinner and waiter kept  looking at his portable p.o.s. machine and stood there playing with it,  when we asked him what the specialty of the house, he kept  playing with p.o.s. and never gave us eye contact  and said carnitas , kept playing with p.o.s., 
we ended leaving without  ordering
author: Mark P.

description:
Great location, and great food - had the eggs/mole and quesadillas for appetizer. Each was full of flavor, serving size was perfect.

Margaritas were perfect. Many choices of tequila.
author: Stacey S.

description:
Ate here last night after some friends suggested it.  I am always against spending a lot of dough on varying combinations of meat, tortillas, and sauces.  I prefer a Mission Taqueria for that.

Nonetheless, despite being expensive, other annoyances were:
1.  15 different margaritas - not talking flavored - I think the only difference is the tequilas.  Too many choices.
2.  Service was very poor.  We were eating at the bar and had to ask repeatedly for more drinks.  I think the bartender may have been a little "out of it"
3.  Food was pretty expensive at around $15-18

Probably would not stop in here again.
author: Jeff M.

description: This place has terrific and AUTHENTIC Mexican food, and a margarita menu to end all others. The service is quick and considerate. And, they have a weekend brunch set up with bottomless mimosas that should probably be better known than it is. It's a little pricey, but usually it's well worth it.
author: Mark H.

description: Upscale Mexican. Nice menu. Guacamole was awesome. Quite noisy in back section though. Friendly wait staff. Atmosphere seemed rushed!
author: Cliona B.

description: Delicious food, awesome margaritas! I had the tostaditas from the happy hour menu. They were wonderful, as were the house made corn tortillas and salsa.
author: Holly W.

description:
I needed Mexican food so bad.. and didn't know of any in the downtown area where I live. There are a bunch of taquerias, but coming from San Antonio, these are not what I really consider taquerias, not at .all. So I was surprised to find this place just a couple of blocks on Geary, across from Curran theatre. I've never noticed this place before even though I walk by here every day.

So anyways, we went of course! First impression, very nice decor, a little more upscale than what I expect from Mexican restaurants. But then again, this is a bistro so I dig it. The bar looked really well stocked, mostly with varieties of tequila. But it was Sunday morning.. a little too early for alcohol haha. They did have brunch and bottomless mimosas.. decided to pass that up.. maybe next time. As you sit, they bring out what tasted like home made corn tortillas served with 3 types of sauces.. nice touch. Ordered the quesadillas surtidas for appetizer.. nice gooey oaxaca cheese, mushrooms and peppers. I had the Desayuno Mexicano from the Eggs section, with chorizo, steak, potatos, rice and beans. Very good! Steak was so tender. My partner enjoyed the Mole Poblano. Just a note that servings are on the smaller side, but price is not the cheapest ($15 each dish).
