However, I accept the price/size ratio because of the quality of the food. Location is also downtown and probably on the tourist-y side, so I understand the prices. No problem though.. food justifies it like I said. Oh, and service was very good. We'll be back! Maybe next time to try one of their tequilas.
author: Vol T.

description: One word...DELICIOUS..everything I have ever had here has been amazing.   Have only been there for brunch and my experience is based on those menu options.
author: Katherine B.

description:
Downtown Mexican Bistro on Geary street, located 1.5 blocks from Union Square Park. Bistro feels a little tourist. Food was nicely plated, but super dainty and a little pricey. 

Ate:
* Guacamole $12 Made fresh just tell us how spicy you would like it; served with fresh handmade corn tortillas. Add chips $2. (4 of 5) It was really fresh and delicious. The corn tortillas were delicious. But rarely do people eat guacamole without chips. So it was $14 for fresh guacamole and chips! And too bad, the bowl was so shallow. Dipped the chip in for a scoop of guacamole and it broke off when it hit the shallow end of the bowl. And the chips for $2, not stale, but not great either. Found some chips where a stack of 8 chips were fried together. Not really satisfied with $12 guacamole or $2 chip bowl. I think I like Chevy's chips more. However, I think the $2 add on charge is for unlimited chips. I cannot confirm, but if I go back, I will double check.  
Mole Poblano $17 a legendary blend of spices, chiles, nuts and chocolate made into a rich and flavorful sauce,in the traditional Puebla style, served over chicken. (3 of 5). Tasty mole sauce, but only got three pieces of chicken nuggets. 
Pato en Mole Verde Pipián $20 pan seared duck breast in a delicious green mole sauce made with pumpkin seeds, tomatillos, nuts and spices. (3 of 5) Duck was nice, but not juicy. And the flavor was mellow for a duck piece. I was really confused when I saw spaghetti on my plate. But it was spaghetti. I think this dish needs some re-design, no spaghetti please. 
Churro with Caramel Sauce Filling (2 of 5). I thought this was a great idea, but I don't think it was executed right. The churro was hard and the caramel sauce I expected to flow out or at least be soft, was nothing like that. Oh, I would like to try a creative new twist on Churro, but this was not it. 

Next time, I would try Chamorro de Cordero $20 (lamb shank marinated in a paste of Muscat wine and spices, wrapped in banana leaves and steamed to perfection). Someone else ordered the dish and that seemed the best bang of meat for the buck.

This restaurant left me somewhat unsatisfied. I was expecting a filling or tasty Mexican dinner. But all the dishes were just presented nicely, they did not fulfill my hunger.
author: Janice T.

description: My day after Christmas dinner experience : Poor service, food was not good at all, and drinks were nothing special. How this place has a 4 star review on yelp is mind boggling, must be from people who have NOT had many other options with Mexican food.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Fantastic experience and amazing range of margaritas. The jalapeño margarita is superb if you're a jalapeño fan. The guacamole was delicious and is highly recommended.
author: Paul C.

description: Free chips and good margaritas, do i need to write more?
author: Brittini S.

description:
I have always been a fan of this place...

That is, until my last visit a few days ago.  Their table side guacamole is always something to look forward to.  Unfortunately, this is only fun when they actually make it for you table side.  This did not happen.  It's okay, we still had the entire meal to look forward to.  We were armed with margaritas and ready to go.  As usual, the rest of the meal filled with carnitas, prawns, chicken, and fish was excellent.  We even ended it with dessert after!

The unfortunate turn of events came after we received our bill. $325 meal for five was not a high price to pay when you are sharing it with longtime friends whom you have not seen in over a year.

The server kept coming by every two minutes to ask if we needed anything else.  She cleared the table a little each time she came, first the plates, then our margarita glasses, next our napkins, and finally our water.  Okay lady, we get the hint!  It wasn't even 30 seconds after she cleared our water when the manager came by and asked if we needed anything else.  This prompted me to yell out, "we get the hint and are leaving now!!". Two hours and over $300 later, this is how Colibri treats us.  The ironic thing is that there wasn't even a party of five waiting for our table.

Note to Colibri - perhaps I'll return when your staff learns some proper etiquette!

Note to other Yelpers - go for the food but don't expect good service!
author: Sharon S.

description:
Pretty good place. Had a reso at 8pm and got there a tad early. Migrated our way to the bar to grab a waitale (waiting cocktail) but was informed about 3 mins after our arrival that our table was ready. Sweet!
Sat down and had a good look-see over the entire menu. We ordered our drinks and fundido and hot damn! Both were pretty good! the tortiallas were thick and freshly made. 
We ended up getting the chiles rancheros and carnitas. The chiles were not bad but the carnitas were crispy and moist. Goooood stuff. I must say I get the carnitas often when I get Mexican comida  and this is of 4-4.5 star quality! 

Why it's not 4 stars:
-In tourist central! Out of towners swarm this place and the entire area. Good luck finding parking thats under $30
-Bill was up there for as much as we got. It was a special occasion so I didn't care but be willing to drop a dollar or two
author: Matt G.

description: Okay, so this review comes with a caviat. It's one of my favorite restaurants. I love their food. And as a gluten free celiac person, I love eating here. They have great drinks and for the location- everything is reasonably priced. I have to take off two stars because the service is always horrible. They always mean well - so nice. But SO SLOW. if they could work on that - it would be 5 stars EASILY. love you guys.
author: Rachel W.

description:
My friends and I came here for a friend's birthday dinner on a Saturday night. We had a reservation for our group of 8 and were seated quickly. 
The menu was very interesting and varied. Our group ordered:
Filet Mignon (served with pashed potatoes)
Tostadas de Tinga (little tostada appetizer with chicken)
Pechuga de Pollo (stuffed chicken breast)
Fish tacos (appetizer of little tacos)
Scallops (served with mashed potatoes)

Before our food came, we got the "chips and salsa" of Colibri- fresh-made tortillas served with three salsas. Delicious!

Our waiter was nothing special, but we were also not trying too hard to interact with him. 

Food impressions:
Small portions for the price (our 6 foot something guys left hungry)
Scallops (what I ate) were well-cooked, one was a little undercooked. Served with mashed potatoes and avocado sauce. Good flavors. 
Tostadas were nice and spicy. Good balance of hot, creamy.
author: dina s.

description:
This is the first and only fine dining Mexican joint I've been to and I have to say that I'm really impressed! The make the guacamole in front of you, the food is really good and so are the desserts. Service is good, too. 

I know you can get a mean burrito across the street for under $5, but if you're thinking about upscaling that, then check out Colibri.
author: Camille R.

description:
Margaritas were $10 not bad for union square I guess. 
The guac was really good. The filet was really really tiny.

Atmosphere was chill and loud.

Small so make a reservation
author: farah b.

description: Great margaritas and the guacamole is delist!  They make it in front of you and ask how spicy you want. This place gets crowded so if you want a table make a reservation in advance.
author: Liz D.

description:
After reading all the enthusiastic reviews, I was a little disappointed.  Maybe we visited on an off night?

My husband and I came here for dinner on a busy Friday evening.  I was sorry that we were only a party of two, because we were given a narrow table crammed into what must have been a walkway at one time.  There were a few other tables situated in this manner.  The servers had to shimmy up and down the aisle to get to all of us.  I think for this reason, we weren't visited very often.

The food was good, but for the price, the portions seemed pretty tiny.  However, the guacamole was tasty (and we seemed to get a lot of it), and the fresh tortillas were delicious.  I'm a sucker for those, and I probably could have eaten twenty of them.  For my entree, I ordered the carnitas, and was surprised that the only thing on my plate were a few small pieces of pork and one green onion.  No beans, no rice.  I suppose this was mentioned somewhere on the menu, but for $18, I guess I was expecting more.

Since Colibri is just off Union Square, maybe we're paying tourist prices?
author: Raina S.

description:
$12 margarita is WORTH every penny.
Service was impeccable.
Made-to-order guacamole wasn't as good as mine, but I'd give it a solid B+
Entrees were delicious, juicy and perfectly cooked (had the stuffed chicken and filet) but could have been presented with a bit more flare to add to the 'upscale' feeling.
author: Lydia D.

description: Exactly what we were looking for! Great margarita, incredible food and wonderful service. Definitely worth a stop.
author: Mathew L.

description:
The food was good but the overall experience needs improvement.

Reservations:  we were going to be 6-7 on a Monday night. When we called 3 days in advance, we were told we could fit 6 people, 7 "if we were friends" in the booth that was available at 7PM.

Reality: we ended up being 6 in the booth and we barely fit. It was a *large* square table so awkward to talk, but the square configuration also made it very uncomfortable to sit. We are not large people and yet felt very crammed in.

Service: service was both slow and poorly paced.  We waited forever for drinks throughout the meal.  Main courses were served before appetizers were finished.  Plates were not cleared.  At the end of the meal, we ordered the 20-minute chocolate cake and some sangria to sip while waiting; the cake arrived 10 minutes later, the sangria, 15 minutes later. Unacceptable.

Billing: the bill came with the expected service charge for a party of 6; this is fine, since it was less than we'd normally tip and so generous for the less than stellar service. It also came with the obnoxious "Healthy SF" service charge, which is simply the restaurant picking this one cost of doing business to highlight and charge separately to the customer. I find this insulting both to me as the customer and to the workers who deserve this benefit. To top it off, restaurants will often recoup large amounts of this fee at the end of the year if the services have not been used. Cheaper restaurants, and more enlightened restaurants such as Park Tavern, don't charge the fee. I won't return here until Colibri discontinues it.

Food: The food was good and mostly fresh.  I really liked the small handmade tortillas served with salsas and along with the meal.  In each meal ordered by my group, one side was included.  We were concerned about portions based on Yelp reviews, so also ordered several additional sides.  This turned out to be largely unnecessary, however I thought the portions were generous enough for the cost.  It's not a cheap meal, but it's also not over-priced, given the atmosphere and location.  I loved the Tortilla Soup but be forewarned: it is very rich.  The scallops I ordered for dinner had a nice sauce but could have been fresher.  If I were to do it over I'd order a salad for appetizer and the soup for dinner.
author: Martha M.

description: Ask about the specials of the month - my fiance and I both ordered them and they were fantastic.  Food is reasonably priced, drinks are spendy but strong.  Went on Cinco De Mayo - live music, great atmosphere, good times.
author: Jon H.

description:
One of the best Mexican restaurants north of the border.

I found this place about two years ago on a business trip and after dinner was suprised to learn I knew the owner, we grew up together in Central Mexico. 

Since then, every time I am in town I bring a couple business associates and clients. And every single time my friends thank me for the culinary experience.

Some ara amazed at the variety of tequilas. The Margaritas, mojitos and sangria are pretty good. While you wait for your food you get fresh, just-made tortillas with three really good salsas.

The Pato al Pipian (Duck with green mole), Mole Poblano, Carnitas and the fish are all extraordinary. All of them excellent. My favorite, though are the apetizers. The tostadas the tinga are absolutely delicious. I can't help but order two sets of sopes. This last time my friend ordered the fish al pastor which was delicious.

Then it was time for desert....wow. The Crepas con Cajeta were succulent. Flavorful, served with vanilla ice cream and a Mexican cookie. I wanted to clean the plate with my tongue.  My friend asked for the Chocolate Pudin which was intense and decadent.

Including drinks and desert we paid about $40 each I think. Reaosnable for an OK restaurant, a baragain for such an extraordinary meal at one of my all-time favorites.
author: Gerardo D.

description:
First of all I have to start by saying that I was there with a friend and we only had about 40 minutes to catch a show in the Golden Gate Theater. So when we set down, we asked the waiter whether it's possible to serve us that fast, and he said he will make sure we will catch our show in time.

And so he did! Everyone was very fast, we got out yummy guacamole in a matter of seconds, I ordered the chicken mole, which was amazing and my friend ordered the tamales, which was very tasty too. The best part is that they didn't get flustered when another friend showed up right when they brought out our main courses. She ordered , got her food and we all finished up together.

One thing you have to keep in mind: for most of the main courses you have to order a side dish. I didn't know this and my chicken mole felt pretty lonely on the plate :-)

P.S. We made a reservation on Open Table and even thought we were 20 minutes late, we still got a table as soon as we walked in. (we called them to let them know we wil be late)
author: Timea B.

description: My friends took me her for my birthday. The food was really good. Best brownie ice cream ever!
author: Puja M.

description: The food is deliciously overpriced. They jacked up the price for Valentine's Day, offered us a table and then told us we would have leave by 6 because the table was reserved. Staff is snotty and the service is slow. When asked if it was happy hour (after reading a happy hour sign out front) we were told no and that it wasn't posted anywhere (meanwhile changing the sign out front). We were staying at the Diva next door and this place was recommended to us. While the margaritas and food are both delicious, I'm not sure it's worth the price or the snarky attitudes when SF has so much else to offer.
author: Nikki H.

description: Delicious Mexican food! We ordered too much as the guacamole is HUGE! So yummy and fresh!!! The fish taco was also amazing
author: Alison M.

description: We headed over to this restaurant cause it was close to the hotel. The Margs are decent.  Certainly not the best I have had.  The ceviche was amazing and so was the guacamole and the medium heat was on the spicy side which I liked.  Service was decent and I'd go back again to try a full meal.
author: Julie M.

description: A friend was visiting from out of town and staying at the Hilton in Union Square, so we wanted to grab a drink at a place close by. It was a really great find. It felt like pretty authentic food. We just ordered some guacamole because I saw the great stone serving platters and new that it was going to be good. I was a bit disappointed that is was served in a plastic container inside the stone but I guess with a restaurant that busy it is pretty hard to keep up with the dishes (what???). There were so many great variations of margaritas and drinks made with mescal. The only reason I am not giving the place a 5 star rating is because of the cost and being filled with tourists. I don't think the cost is comparable to other great restaurants around the city, I think it is purely based on tourism.
author: Jodee M.

description: Considering the high marks over many reviews I had higher expectations. Didn't realize the place was a deep cavern with very little light in the back. Got the quesadillas surtidos (hongos, huitlacoche, , passilla pepper), and the rellenos w/ carnitas and chicharron. Food was a bit on the lukewarm side and under seasoned. definitely helped a lot with some salt but the heat issue still stands. The guac is great but way overpriced. The good part is them knowing since they're near the theaters to get their line to fire entrees really quickly, so we got in and out in good time.
author: Kim N.

description:
Union square mexican?  I went in with low expections, they were confirmed by the end.  

Most bland cheeseless chile relleno I've ever tried.

Only saving grace for this place is $10 bottomless mimosas for brunch.  

If you want real mexican food--go to El Faralito on 24th and Mission.
author: Mike I.

description: Really amazing Camarones con Mole Tamarindo!!! Would definitely suggest! The sauce was so flavorful and smoky but sweet and the corn cake was perfectly spiced and sweet but savory and it all worked perfectly with the shrimp! Additionally, the homemade tortillas and salsa they give you at the beginning of your meal are super fresh and definitely a highlight. However, the Sopa de Tortilla was a disappointment.
author: Zehra V.

description:
my friends and i were in desperate need of mexican food after a long flight. we looked this place up on yelp and decided to try it out.  i would rate the overall experience pretty low. 

we were a party of seven and the hostess said she could put two four tops together for us and then when we got to the tables she said she couldn't. so that was weird. we sat down and then asked our waiter why we couldn't all sit together and then, after acting weird, they put the two tables together for us. 

then it took about 5 minutes for him to take our drink order, 5 minutes to get the drinks. we ordered the guacamole and some cheese dip. the guacamole arrived in a large stone bowl but it was to our dismay that there was another bowl inside with a depth of about an inch. we each got about two chipfulls of guac.  this guac was 12 dollars.  the cheese dip was meh. 

also, they brought chips to the table in what appeared to be a cereal bowl.  so like 10-15 chips... for our party of seven.  the chip bowl lay empty for about 5 minutes. then they brought another.  empty in 5 seconds. i had to ask for two extra bowls for the table and was given the most confused look. 

we got our food and my enchiladas divorciadas con pollo was delicious. and everyone else seemed very happy with their food. but none of it came with rice or beans or both which i feel is pretty standard. 

i don't think i would go back or recommend this spot.
author: Mars E.

description:
Ate here for lunch today.  Everything looked and tasted decent at the time.  Ordered the tortilla soup and chicken flautas.  The soup is basically enchilada sauce in a bowl with avocado and cheese.  

About an hour after the meal I started feeling sick.  Been having food poisoning like symptoms since lunch and have not ate anything else all day.
author: Ronald Z.

description: I has enchiladas and they were ok. I asked for bean and cheese instead of bean and chicken. The waiter said no, but he could just take the chicken out and give me cheese enchiladas. I was still charged for the full amount without anything being added. Salsa was not refilled. Tortillas were delicious. Beer was nice and cold. Chips were good and salty. I'd give 3 stars if the prices weren't so high.
author: Miranda B.

description:
OUTSTANDING restaurant. Great food. Fast, responsive staff. Nice ambiance.

I had the carnitas - delicious.

It is pricey - it's downtown SF, so no surprise there. The only thing keeping this place from a five-star rating is the tight quarters (tables are very close together) and lousy acoustics (very noisy).

I'd definitely go back.
author: Chris E.

description: This was the best Eggs Benedict I have ever tasted!!!  It had carnitas, was on a thick homemade tortilla and a very mild (I think chipotle) hollandaise sauce. It was outstanding!!  My boyfriend had the Pozole Verde which he said was delicious as well. It was spicy enough and tangy from the salsa verde. The homemade tortillas and salsa they serve when you sit down were also amazing!!  I can't wait to go back for brunch!!
author: Alex R.

description:
I would classify this restaurant more fusion than authentic Mexican.

Recommend the Pato en Mole Verde Pipián, and Callos con Crust de Tortilla.

Try the Guacamole plus eat your meal with tortillas fajita style if you're hungry.
author: Francis M.

description:
I have been here twice and both experiences have been extraordinary.

I love the fact that it's almost a hole in the wall. You walk past the nasty 24-hour Jack in the Box on Geary, aggressive bums begging for money, and you arrive. You open the door and you're a little taken aback. It's beautiful inside. Rich, warm lighting, large chandeliers, large booths, and a gigantic space.

If you made a reservation for a specific time (which I suggest you do on Open Table), there is absolutely no waiting around. You are seated immediately, even if the place is packed.

The food (which arrives in a reasonable amount of time) is AMAZING. The homemade guacamole and tortillas (or chips if you prefer) is out of this world. The appetizers and entrees we have tried on both occasions have been out of this world. Friends ranted and raved about the cornbread, but I wasn't all that impressed. My favorite entree is the scallops. Couldn't get enough of that dish!

This place is on the pricier side, but I feel that you get what you pay for. This is quality food, quality service, in a quality atmosphere.
author: Lizzy C.

description: Excellent food. Salsas were great. I love the warm tortillas for dipping instead of chips. Fish taco had great flavor.
author: Mark B.

description: My wife and I stopped in for a early dinner last night, and took a couple seats at the bar.  the place was pretty much full up, but not overcrowded.  The food was good, and what I consider simple fare....if you're wanting American or Tex-Mex bathed in cheese and sour cream, move elsewhere.  I had Carnitas and my wife had the Vegetarian Chile Relleno, both were tasty.  the salsa and tortillas were fresh and nice. Margaritas were very well done, and Chris behind the bar knew his tequilas....wish i had sampled more of those.  Portion sizes were on the smaller side for the price, but I'm OK with it because quality was great.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Stayed at a hotel on the same block and needed a place to eat late night on a Friday. Absolutely nothing was open as far as I could tell, except for Colibri, and am I glad it was!

Quite possibly the best guac bowl I've ever had. made right on the spot, it was a huge bowl of deliciousness that I didn't want to end.
author: John C.

description:
Who are these people who rate this a 5?
Give me a break.
Way overpriced , barely passable food, average service at best, 
Margaritas done with a sugar mix. No chips
Need I say more?
No thanks.
If you actually enjoy Mexican food, avoid .
author: Matt M.

description: An excellent restaurant, recommended to me by an SF  friend as the best Mexican in the Bay Area.  It's certainly the best Mexican food I've ever had.   Having had lunch, brunch and dinner there during two trips to SF recently, I can't wait to go back.    Fine dining, excellent, prompt service.    Unimprovable.
author: Richard B.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place. Maybe my expectations were too high? Not sure.. Just read all these great reviews and did not really feel that it was worth all the hootin' and hollerin' 

I ordered Chicken Mole, which had a few small pieces of chicken in the middle of a huge plate with 3x as much sauce.. &  fresh white corn tortillas with various sauces on the side...  It seemed like something was missing..maybe a little side salad or veggies? or something? But that was it... 

My friend ordered the Poblano Ranchero, which was slightly tastier,  yet completely smothered in sauce. His meal actually came with a little bit of whipped potatoes and spinach. 

We indulged in dessert, which was by far the best part of the meal, we shared the Poudin A Chocolate.. which was to die for! 

As I was scoping out the restaurant, I noticed some very appetizing meals.. maybe we just happened to order the two worst ones there?
author: Cassandra E.

description: I'm a big Mexican food connoisseur and had high hopes for this place. Overall it was very average at best. Ordered the carnitas - it came out quasi plain which I wouldn't have minded, but it was way over cooked. I needed to sip my water/marg to swallow it was so dry...   Shrimp my girl ordered. It was decent. Friend ordered the pollo which was probably the best of the three. Marggies were good just not exceptional. I wouldn't come back though given the price relative to the quality.
author: Jared T.

description: The guacamole is the best I have ever had in my life. The fresh salsa and hot tortillas brought to the table as a starter are hot and tasty. I went twice, had the carnitas the first time, and the 2nd I had the sopes appetizer and everything was tasty, quickly served, and the atmosphere is just fabulous. Great and not too far away from the hotel and the center of things either.
author: Alfonsina S.

description: We started with guacamole you get a choose if you want it spicy or mild . The ingredients are all typical of a guacamole dip. It's very fresh and tastes excellent with the fresh tortillas. I ordered the tortilla soup it was tasty but I kept comparing it to traditional tortilla soup this one reminded me more of a tomato soup.
author: Mari A.

description: Visiting from LA...I was craving Mexican food and this place was close to my hotel.  Total disappointment! The waiter actually acknowledged that the Pozole I ordered was not made that same day ( god knows how old!), $14 for a small bowl!!!! Chilaquiles verdes were Ok. Bartender did not know how to make a Michelada! I gave this place 1 star because the fresh guacamole was really good and the handmade tortillas were awesome! I guess for some this place is ligit and that's why it gets good reviews! Or perhaps it was good a few years back! Can't wait to get back to LA and have some REAL Mexican food!!!!!
author: D. A.

description: Drinks were good. Food was garbage, mostly pre-frozen stuff they thawed out. Disapointed in yelp's reviews as they led us to this place. Go for the drinks, leave for the food.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I went here on a Friday evening around 7pm.  The restaurant was not really busy, however they have a back part of the restaurant that seats a decent number of people.  

The service here was superb.  The waiters were very nice and helpful.  It made the experience good.

The food itself however, wasn't the best or worth the price.  You'll see a lot of reviews about the 'tableside' preapred guacamole.  They don't advertise it that way, but dumb yelp reviewers here do.  First of all, it's not tableside.  It's done at a stand in the middle of the restaurant.  Second, the guacamole is already prepared before being brought out.  The stand is just to mix some ingredients such as tomatoes and onions into the mashed avocado.  Third, what really got me, was that it came in this massive mortar and pestle-type bowl.  I thought we were getting a massive amout of guacamole for the price.  However, they put a shallow dish on top of the opening such that it was actually a disappointing amount of guacomole.  I'd say 1.5 avocados at most.  And I'd put the taste at normal compared to other mexican establishments.  

I make guacamole every two weeks, where a large avocado is $0.99 at a grocery store, so I know volume and pricing.  Was it worth $12 + $2 for chips?  No.  Not even the labor justifies it.  Also, shame on you yelp reviewers who don't know what good table-side guacamole is.  

Also ordered the Carnitas ($17) and a special of the day Pork steak ($17).  They were both good.  They also give tons of tortillas for free, which is great.  The carnitas dish is probably the best.  Pretty tasty, although a little dry.

Overall, give 2 stars are for the great service plus 1 star for the carnitas.  Not enough to make me wanna come back.  Skip the appetizers.  Go for the entrees.
author: Jon K.

description: Honestly the food wasn't that bad but the pricing is ridiculous. 12 dollars for a pretty small bowl of decent guac WITHOUT chips is kinda insulting. Service was ok. Just another fancy overpriced and overhyped Mexican place in the city. Go somewhere else.
author: Alec B.

description:
OMG....Everything was delicious. 

First...let me say...I am Mexican. So it is very hard for any "Mexican" food to impress me. I took my mother here for brunch...and we were both super impressed. 

I had the Enchiladas Divorciadas and my mom had the Chile Relleno...both superb. They were both made different than we ususally cook them but really really good. 

For dessert we had the chocolate cake, which was more like a brownie with ice cream and a strawberry. I am not a big fan of chocolate however I did enjoy the couple bites I had. 

They also had bottomless mimosas for brunch.
author: Lidia Z.

description:
Hungry. Hungover. Hungry. Hungover.

What's that across the street?! Ah yes, a Mexican Bistro. 

Our friends split to Max's for their American breakfasts, but we were adamant about having guac and Mexican food, an upscale alternative from Taco Bell.

We ordered the following:

1) Guac ($10) - It was just plain alright. I don't like raw tomatoes in my guac, but the cilatrno, lemon, and onions were good.

2) Desayuno Mexicano ($12) - equivalent to a Mexican full breakfast. Refried beans, blue tortilla, and steak. We were so hungry, we inhaled it.

3) Bottomless Mimosa ($8) - why did we ordered this, we don't know. It sounded good and it WAS good, but we did not finish the first pour.

$60 for two. Not bad, but not good for a recessionista. Next time, we will turn the corner and hit the Tenderloin for a cheapie breakfast instead.
author: Betty N.

description: Liked the tiling in the men's room. The salsas and guacamole were good, but the rest was very pedestrian and very expensive. Had the carnitas which was $18 (meat and tortillas only) and had to add the rice and beans as side items, which I vaguely recall was about $5 each. The tortillas were pretty good but the meat was dry and salty. The $10 beans and rice was salty as well. The oversized wooden chairs were uncomfortable, and lots of body rubbing through the bar area if you need to exit the restaurant during the dinner rush. It is not a bad restaurant, but I'm only saying this because I didn't have to pay for it. If you're trying to impress a girl by overpaying for Mexican food (rather than going to a place like El Faro), this is the place to do it at. This was my experience. Don't let it discourage you from trying it.
author: Stevey K.

description:
February 8th, 2015
Cramped, crowded, food with little taste. Guacamole was very good, smooth, creamy with a good bit of lime. Fish taco's were tasteless. Stuffed poblano pepper was also tasteless. That amazed me that a Mexican restaurant could have little taste. The three hot sauces were average at best. We had to mix them to make them have pop and flavor at the same time. I would not eat here again. 
The hostess and staff were great, but cannot make up for everything else. I wish I could be more positive about this restaurant.
author: Mark B.

description: We went there as a family. "Nothing for children on the menu that is not spicy " is what the grumpy waitress told us. Lamb shank tasted old, meat had no flavor and a bad after taste. no sides on the plate for a $26 plate was unusual!  just a shank and some bitter sauce over it! Carnitas meat also tasted old, hard and dry. When we told the waitress who did not care, she brought the manager who also offered nothing other than saying we make all our plates same day. No smiles or apologies. I gave them 2 stars because the host who seated us was very polite and did not make us wait at the door. Would not recommend this restaurant.
author: hana R.

description:
Guacamole and Ceviche hit the spot for me ($2 extra for chips...REALLY???)
Octopus carpaccio was interesting, but not something I would reorder. 
I didn't really eat much of the main courses (yes, I stuffed my face with the big bowl of guac and 2 orders of ceviche lol), but my friend was pretty disappointed with his mole.  The chicken dish with spicy sauce was a hit though.  Desserts were an epic fail - worst warm chocolate cake I've ever eaten and churros were eh too.  I didn't care too much for the Sangria either - too syrupy for my liking.  For the $$$, I was not impressed.
author: Bhavnak K.

description:
Rarely have I had food this good, and I both eat out a lot and cook a lot.

First, the chicken was possibly the best chicken I have ever eaten.  The chicken!  It was somehow cooked, with the skin on, to a point where all of the fat had rendered from the skin, leaving it as just a crispy coating on the meat, and the met was cooked perfectly.  I suspect sous vide and sear, or sous vide and some sort of fast application of high, dry heat to just the outside of the bird.  Amazing.

They also accommodated our request for a side of refried beans, which were creamy black beans with cubes of cotija or a similar cheese on top.  

The Margaritas are both great and respectful of what makes a great Maragaita: trying different types of tequila and Mezcal instead of adding different fruits and liquors.  Great.

Posole was quite good but not the best I've had.  Chips and guac were great, but at $12 for a bowl of guac, I can make it as well at home--guacamole is simple:)

Service was a little slow/spotty and when we came in and were sat next to a huge group table being set up, and asked to move to a nearby booth to avoid some of the noise, they obliged but seemed flustered by the suggestion.  Colibri is more of a nice casual restaurant with great food than a fine dining establishment (the latter, in my opinion, put a large amount of effort into service, but don't necessarily have better food.)

On my scale, Colibri gets a 3

Scale:
1: Would not go back alone and would protest if a friend suggested we go
2: Would not go back alone, but would not protest if a friend suggested we go
3: Would go back happily and willingly alone
author: Lauren J.

description:
Drinks were very good, food even better.  The bartender was very helpful.  I would go back to Colibri!

Try the many tequila's......
author: Kenneth G.

description:
Farewell CPK, hola Colibri! I was surprised by the transformation from a once bright yellow family-style establishment, into a refined Mexican restaurant with great ambiance.  Good for hanging out with your buddies or on a date.  One of those places where you can don your casual threads, or dress up.

We came for their *weekend* brunch ~ 10:30a to 2:30pm. Walking in, we were immediately greeted by a smile and shown to a booth.  The service throughout our meal was excellent.

Order their fresh guacamole.  It's made table-side and you can request hot, medium or mild spice.  Comes with fresh-off-the-press mini tortillas instead of the usual chips.  Definitely a treat.

Since it was the weekend, we indulged in a refreshing cocktail.  All of their drinks and entrees on their menus were tempting, making it very tough to decide.  

I had the Huevos Rancheros ~ "two eggs "over easy" on a blue corn tortilla served with salsa molcajeteada, refried beans and nopales (cactus)" and their sangria. Delicious!

Sign board says they have live Music on Monday nights and a happy hour.  I look forward to coming back soon!
author: Cathy K.

description:
We went to Colibri for Sunday brunch, hoping to match (in quality) the prior morning's fabulous meal at nearby Canteen (http://www.yelp.com/biz/canteen-san-francisco). And while Colibri has a lot of things going for it, spotty service and some other imperfections hold it back from a five-star experience.

First, the many pros: The restaurant itself is warm and inviting, and the menu is great, with lots of delicious-sounding options. The guacamole and hand made mini-tortillas are excellent. I could eat just that as a meal; they were that good. The Torrejas Colibri (home made Mexican cinnamon pastry with fresh berries and agave honey syrup) was outstanding, although a touch undercooked in spots. The cinnamon-berry-honey combo worked perfectly. My girlfriend had the Mole poblano, which she really enjoyed.

On the down side, our two-person table was kind of small (it was crammed once all our food came), and it was very close to the table next to us. The servers had to squeeze through, bumping the table (or things on it) a few times. Our waiter was very friendly, but service was spotty. The guacamole took a long time to arrive, to the point that we'd thought he'd forgotten it. Then my girlfriend's meal was brought out several minutes before mine, which I expect was poor planning by the cook. The decaf coffee was mediocre at best.

Still, the most important thing is the food, and the food here is really really good. Maybe next time I'll swap out the decaf coffee for the bottomless Mimosa.
author: Andy S.

description:
Came here at 8pm on a Friday night with a friend from out of town.  Sorry that I did.

If you want good mexican food, please go to the Mission district.  If you want edible food, go anywhere else but this place.  The ambiance was nice, and our server was pleasant but this place was less than 1 star for me.  The food has zero flavor.  I asked for the hot guacamole and it tasted like eating avocado with some cilantro and other weird crunchy bits maybe in attempt to stretch the guac because whatever other ingredient used (jimica probably) is cheaper to buy. (not to mention that the "hot" salsa was not hot, spicy or flavorful in the slightest.  The chips (that do not come with guac?? what the?) that we had to ask for, were stale.

Prices are outrageous for crap food.  I like mexican food.  A lot.  This place is terrible tex-mex at best.  Margs are made from a sugary mix, gross. Ceviche was 3 stars but the avocado on top the ceviche was brown.  "Mexican" rice has frozen peas and carrots and is as bland as nursing home food. And the carnitas, please Colibri, please please please do not call a chunk of meat on a plate with a side of "sauce", carnitas. 

I do not understand how this place EVER got anyone's 5 stars, or 4, or 3.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Wow, what a pleasant surprise. This place was great. We came in on Valentine's night on a whim and they found a table for us, even though the place was packed. From beginning to end the meal was exceptional. From appetizers to a perfect dessert, with good tequila drinks in between. All the flavors were clean and distinct, nothing bathed in cheese or sauce.

I have eaten in a lot of decent Mexican restaurants but only a couple great ones. And this is right up there as one of the greats.
author: Chris M.

description:
I'll start this off plainly with saying I won't be back again. I will say, I had fun.

We were headed for mexican when we remembered reviews for amazing guacamole in the area and were so curious if $12 guacamole could really be that amazing.

Grabbed some horchata and shared a main course with the chips and guac as our main goal. The tortillas were warm and delicious and definitely great with our main, however we did pay extra for chips for our guac cause it wasn't quite the same with tortillas.

Guac was not made at our table, but made better by us. It was much smaller than we expected and good...after we added salt and dumped our salsa into it. Main course was good and horchata was small and boring.

Overall overpriced and feels hyped. Drinks were too expensive to try. Laughed that we fell for the yelp love and still joke about that $12 guacamole.
author: Sam H.

description: Service was good. They serve you tortillas with a few sauces: medium, spicy, and sweet. I'm not big on tortillas, and I just found them so-so. I ordered the carnitas, which were tender, though a bit lacking in flavor. Overall, not the best I've had, but certainly not the worst.
author: Sarah B.

description: I love this place! Their Sangria is made with punch and it's so delicious! It's tapas style so bring a lot of people and order one of everything!
author: Izzy D.

description:
What a wonderful little Mexican gem here in San Francisco. The Mole Poblano is absolutely delicious, along with the Chile Relleno. The food is served promptly, at the proper temperature and serving sizes are quite ample. 

Cocktails were perfect: the margarita made with fresh lime juice. Highly recommend. 

Ambience was cozy, warm, lively and fun. Service prompt, friendly and met every request. Looking forward to returning to try another delicious meal.
author: Lisa L.

description: Sorry but this place sucks in my opinion. It's over priced and the service is horrible. The guacamole was decent but the fact that chips are extra and have to be ordered is a bummer for me. Our food never came because there was a mix up with ordering. We asked for queso and they brought out some greasy fried looking cheese with meat in it and I don't eat meat. They didn't offer anything for the fact that they didn't bring us food amd we had to leave to get to our show. Never again! Very typical Union Square.
author: Tali L.

description:
A great, friendly restaurant hidden from the madness that is Union Square. Because of the quality, and the location, they have the right to give you a "side" or rice thats a good two scoops and charge you $4. You can get someone to make you your guac right in front you and add whatever you'd like, and have it be almost an entree than a side, as well as charge you extra for a side of chips, rather than the complimentary tortillas you're given.

The couple of times I've been here I've been nothing but impressed. From food, to presentation, to the staff and bartenders. They know a good margi. Mama likes. 

The atmosphere is a bit dim, with mariachi or live music occasionally. A great place for a second date. 

Everything I've ordered has been great, however I have ordered the tortilla soup twice now and have never been truely amped on it.. A bit bland for a soup.
author: Amanda S.

description: The Prawns with Tamarind mòle was so good I wanted to lick the plate. Outstanding service. Delicious spicy pineapple cocktails. We'll be back.
author: Lisa M.

description:
My sister introduced me to this restaurant and I'm glad she did!

I hate drinking Margaritas, never found it very tasty..., BUT the bar here makes one of the BEST Margaritas I've ever had. 

For dinner, I ordered the "Ensalada Flor de Verano", which is one of the BEST salads I've ever had! This ensalada has slices of avocados, mangoes, and flower petals... yea I know it sounds a bit too PRETTY to eat, but heeeey trust me it was good with em flower petals. And the cilantro-basil vinaigrette they used as a dressing wasn't too over-powering, it balanced a lot of the flavors of the salad just right. 

 I also ordered the "Filete Mignon", the steak wasn't too dry since I wanted my steak cooked "WELL DONE". The mash-potatoes was sooooo delicious and well seasoned along with the chipotle chile sauce .   

Now for desert, we had the "Churros Rellenos", which is a drizzled caramel and cinnamon covered churros with a scoop of dulce de leche ice cream. I know what your thinking... this sounds like, "I can make this at home and SAVE 8 bucks" kind of a desert, but the churros was soooooo YUMMY. The churro wasn't hard to chew, it just basically melts in your mouth. The ice cream was sooooo good too, I used it as a dip cause the churros was a bit too hot to eat and I love how it wasn't too sweet to pair it together.

Service here is very friendly.
author: Johanna M.

description: Really good queso fundido and guacamole. Quite authentic (flavorful) plus good handmade tortillas. Loved it!
author: Gerardo S.

description: Went here last night, the food was perfect mexican cuisine with the best homemade tortillas and salsa. The house margarita was strong and delicious. However, the price point of yelp's seems under matched. I would have given it $$$.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Amazing food, very cozy decor. Perfect for a date or fun dinner with family. Has a great bar.
author: Shobhit G.

description:
First, NO BURRITOS!  Yay.

Fairly serious high-class Mexican.  Terrific handmade tortillas.  Interesting variety of food, including chicken stuffed with Huitlacoche, queso fundido and a couple of mole sauces.  Good service -- they put up with us waiting 45 minutes for our fourth person to show up, without a complaint (we tipped appropriately).

The only thing holding them back from five stars is that the food could have been just a bit better seasoned.  Classy Mexican food, like French food, involves a lot of long-simmered sauces, meats and vegetables, and other time-consuming preparations, and the food at Colibri was missing that long-cooked savory flavor.  So, still Cal-Mex rather than Mex-Mex.

Still, I'd go there again if I wanted dinner near Union Square.
author: Josh B.

description: It's fun dining on company money as the two of us spent $220 at the bar eating dinner here.  Started with margaritas using some of their better tequilas.  They were smooth and perfect.  Heard the flamed jalapeno drinks were really hot but they looked interesting.  Had their $14 guacamole and their ceviche.  The guacamole and chips were great but probably not worth $14 if I were buying.  The ceviche was good also and came with some nice tortillas.  We both had the duck with pumpkin seed mole and some fritter using corn and rice.  The fritter was excellent and worked well with the baby spinach on top.  The duck was cooked perfectly.  The mole was surprisingly delicious as it looked like pea soup but tasted great.  I learned the mole could be any combination of spices, kinda like curry, and not just that red stuff.  Also had the churros which were very good and went well with their ice cream.
author: Steve T.

description: 1st time here I would recommend a reservation it's a busy place. We ate at the bar so service was excellent. I had the tacos tingas & they were delicious just a little overpriced, husband had the Chile rellano it was just ok.. lol.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Delicious! If you are stuck in the Union Square area and you're looking for a great place to eat, definitley check this one out! (although it does get busy, so I'd recommend a reservation). The food is delicious and they have killer margaritas!

Ups: Delicious food, convenient location, amazing margaritas.

Downs: Wee bit on the expensive side, no parking, can be hard to get a table.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I have eaten here twice.

The first time, my husband and I happened to be near Union Square and found this place. We had a selection of appetizers for lunch and it was wonderful and flavorful and we enjoyed our food immensely. So much, that we decided to return several months later with out-of-town guests.

The biggest mistake you can make at this restaurant is ordering an actual entree. The appetizers are really great, but the food on the main menu is not very good.

My teenagers ordered the flautas. They were totally inedible, but because my kids didn't say anything and tried to suffer through eating them (it was like eating cardboard), I couldn't send the entrees back -- and they SHOULD have been sent back. They were an abominination. Flavorless, impossible to eat, wtih terrible dried-out chicken inside.  My kids felt slightly sick for hours after lunch because of this. I didn't realize how bad they were until after we had already paid the check....THEN my kids piped up, and I examined what was on their plates and tried to eat some of it. It was truly awful, and I told them that if this ever happens again, they have to tell us immediately that their food is bad so we can send it back.

The other entrees we ordered were only so-so in terms of flavor. Frankly I've had better at the likes of Chevy's, and certainly much better at the Mission area taquerias. 

I was surprised and disappointed and left wishing that I'd taken my guests to a better restaurant.

This is great place for drinks and appetizers. But be careful about ordering a full meal, and I would advise you not to be shy about sending anything back that doesn't meet your expectations. Do yourself a favor and avoid the terrible flautas.

I'm surprised to see so many 4 and 5 star reviews of this restaurant. Maybe if you get really drunk on Margaritas you won't notice the low quality of the food.  But we didn't have any alcohol, so I give this place 2 stars and I won't be coming back anytime soon or recommending it to anyone.
author: Gomez B.

description:
Loved the pechuga ranchera chicken. I have generally negative feelings on fine dining mexican food but this place pulled it off. The orange sauce was very flavorful and the chicken was cooked perfectly. It was like a high class enchilada without the tortilla.   

I agree with previous yelpers that it's not enough to replace the beautiful simplicity of hole in the wall mexican food, but it would be nice to indulge yourself here if you're in the mood for a nice sit down dinner.
author: David G.

description: This is not your typical Mexican restaurant in the US.  Instead, you'll be treated with dishes more from Southern parts of Mexico.  They give you tortillas instead of tortilla chips, which I actually like better.  Their salsas are good, but their table-side guacamole is fantastic.  They also have awesome top-shelf margaritas, with a nice variety of tequilas from which to choose.  Just make sure you realize that this restaurant is on the pricey side, otherwise you'll have a nasty shock when you get the bill.
author: Scott E.

description:
About a year since our last visit, but very disappointing change in food quality and value for money. No longer a place I'd recommend to friends or visitors. 
Service has not deteriorated as much as the food quality has, we had Ceviche, Sopes, Guacomole & Fish Tacos. 
All were now very average for prices which have been jacked up about 35% since our last visit, and it's fair to say overheads have not increased that much. 
Very sorry to say this is our last time here and I don't recommend.
author: Steve L.

description: This place is great, food is really nice, service excellent, bartenders are phenomenal .
author: Mark B.

description:
It is way too easy to find Mexican food in San Francisco but hard to find a nice, sit down place. I really enjoyed Colibri. Fresh tortillas and salsas, good menu, OK prices.
Don't fear the tourist crowd that congregates here, this place is worth the trip down town.
author: Jose S.

description:
So, it is possible that I smuggled three fresh, delicious corn tortillas out of Colibri's in my purse. Alright, fine, I confess - I TOTALLY put tortillas in my purse and continued to walk around downtown until I discovered them while looking for a pen while enjoying live jazz at Make Out and being absolutely thrilled at my foresight. Come to think of it, I stole that pen I was looking for at the time from Colibri's too.
 
What can I say, they got some amazing stuff that I wanted to cram into my face and purse and take home and enjoy forever. I had the Reposado something or other (I drank that info right out of brain and they don't have their drink menu online) and it was a damn fine margarita. Thanks to Colibri's, I was reminded that I actually do like margaritas, it's just that it's so rare to get a good one that doesn't taste like some 13-year-old found his parents' liquor stash and mixed god knows what with some lime-aid.
 
The bartender was nice as could be and seemed to truly enjoy his job and educating rubes like me in the art of fine tequila. I ordered the guac (so I could try those tortillas I heard so much about!) and my friend ordered a quesadilla. 

OK, here's my one gripe about the place, which they handled well but kind of put a damper on the experience. The guac appeared...and sat there, and sat there, and sat there, right in front of us with no tortillas. The bartender said some would be up in "just a minute." About 10 minutes later he came by and said "sorry, I know this is torture, but we're training a new tortilla girl and it's taking longer than usual." OK. Finally 15 minutes they gave us chips instead and apologized again. Another five minutes later three come out in a napkin. 3?! My friend and I get 1.5 each? I wanted to ask if more were on their way, but the bartender was too busy. So the quesadilla arrived and we ate that. Then, a whole new set of six tortillas finally show up, hot and melt-in-your mouth awesome. But by that time I was full! 

I felt betrayed...
 
So, you see, I HAD to smuggle those tortillas out bc I refused to squander my chance to eat every morsel of their deliciousness I was entitled to, dammit! I hope you don't judge me too harshly.
 
A shout out to Chris D, who helped me pinpoint this place's exact name and location, and for suggesting a dish. I would loved to have dined in full here, but we hit it up on our last night and by then I was counting my pennies. Next time I'll get those "stupid good" carnitas Chris, I promise.
author: Lauren V.

description: I could not really decide if i was going to give this 3 or 4 stars.   But the "Avocado/Guacamole" made freshly for you or me... :) pushed it to the "4".   Highly recommend you have reservations because they get filled for the evening quickly.  Great margaritas and we shared the queso con chorizo "Delicious"  Great experience!
author: David R.

description:
After a long day of work I wanted to start my weekend early and just get happy real quick or should I say find a happy hour real quick. 

Found Colibri hiding a little over a block from Union Square. Our happy hour/early dinner took off to the land of happiness with their tequila flight. After 3 shots of tequila, I was in my "nothing can go wrong" zone, feeling happy and ready to deal with whatever they served me good or bad.

Once we got settled in our happy place, we started dinner with some warm tortillas and Queso Fundido con Chorizo.....this dish put me on cloud nueve. The dish was small but packed a heavy punch. I kind of wanted to stop there but the tequila and glass of sangria in my system advised me to  get more food in my body.

So for dinner I had Chile Relleno with Carne. The beef was excellent but I took a bite of the pepper and it was very bitter because it had been incinerated instead of lightly charred. I don't know what crimes that chile committed in it's past life but it definitely paid for it in this one. 

Still as I said before the stuffing for the chile and sauce that came with it was delicious and the sweet yet savory Torta de Elote helped with the bitter taste in my mouth. 

At the end of my journey I already knew that I would give this place a strong 4 star rating. Because of the chile pepper I had to take down one star. As usual the waiter asked, how was your meal? We responded it was excellent with the exception of the pepper being completely charred. He apologized and I said it's okay because I still ate the stuffing. A minute later the restaurant manager came over and stated she heard we had a problem with the pepper. At this point I felt bad and stated again it really wasn't a problem because I ate nearly all of the stuffing. She offered to take it off the bill and I disagreed BUT when our bill came to the table they didn't charge me for the dish stating they didn't feel right charging me for something I wasn't completely satisfied with. 

Tear........sorry just give me a moment.

Okay, now that I've regained my composure. I'm giving them 5 stars because this was definitely an exceptional experience from the tequila to the service and probably one of the happiest hours I've had in a while.
author: Troy R.

description:
This place always hits the spot when I'm in town. Yes, you can go to the Mission and get equally awesome (if not better) food, but this place was close and wasn't packed, so my friends and I hopped in for din din. 

Things you must order: Cheese Tamales (I wanted to eat the entire plate, but my mom's "You should share" voice was reminding me not to), Guacamole (freshly prepared at your table - BOO YAH!) and sangria. It gets sweet after a glass or two, but it's still well made (it's got nothing on Esperpento though!). 

Also ask for a basket of chips. They usually serve warm, soft tortillas which are muy excelente, but to mix it up, ask for chips too. Hey, you can even go all "Taco Bell" and add chips and guacamole to your tortilla and have a classy crunch wrap supreme! Well, sort of...
author: Shachi B.

description: The Chicken Mole was amazing, and they had probably the best jalapeno margarita (I think it was called the 'Macho Margarita') I've ever had.  Only slight downside is that the portion sizes are a bit on the small side.  But I'll go back just for that drink!
author: Tim H.

description:
Yeah the food was interesting and the wait staff were nice and helpful. It's in a touristy area without making you feel like a tourist. I'd go here again if I had the urge for Mexican food in SF, and I 'd try some of the other dishes. We especially enjoyed the freshly made avocado. 

I ordered the scallops, corn meal and peruvian mashed potatoes. It all worked great together in a very strange way....fun stuff.
author: Brent C.

description: I don't usually believe in paying high prices for Mexican, Chinese or Indian food, but this was completely worth the premium. I had ordered a few things here because it was the closest take out place I could find, and we were so surprised at how amazingly good everything was.
author: beverly l.

description:
OMG!!!  The best sangria I have ever had! Seriously!  
The food was pretty yum too.  I had the scallops and they were perfect!  But the sangria!  The SANGRIA!!!!!!!  $22 a pitcher and 3 of us had two pitchers!
One thing that I found kind of random was that on a Tuesday night we couldn't get a table without reservations.  Hmmmmm....seems random but we were able to sit at the bar.  
Did I mention the sangria????
author: Avon T.

description: We came here for brunch and Audrey was phenomenal. We live close by in the neighborhood and will definitely be back. Though she wasn't our server, she definitely made sure we were happy throughout our entire experience. Thank you Audrey!
author: Ben S.

description: Amazing!  Wished I lived in the area so I could eat here more often. Great food, service and atmosphere.
author: Michelle M.

description:
was looking for something different in SF to eat before a play (and you know how difficult it is to find something different in SF (cough)), stumbled across Colibri.  What convinced me to give it a shot was the concept of guacamole being prepared to our specs at our table.  I knew this would REALLY make the wife happy - and the huge tequila bar would be a bonus (and it was...oh yes how it was).

Aforementioned guoc prep was pretty cool.  Tomales were incredibly fresh.  The mole was excellent.  Cold beer on tap.   

What's not to like?

Oh.....hands down, bar none, the BEST churro for dessert I've ever had.  Ever.  No....really.  EVER.
author: Bill O.

description: I was excited to try an upscale Mexican restaurant in Union Square (not the Mission).  The menu is a nice change from the typical enchilada, burritos, quesadilla fare.  As others have mentioned, the guacamole is excellent and plentiful.  They asked how spicy we wanted it and delivered (quite spicy)  The presentation of food is lovely and a nice change from the typical smashed beans & rice you find elsewhere.  I thought the Sangria was too sweet and not very strong.  My chicken mole was ok, but not as creamy as I expected and the chicken was a bit dry.  So my meal was so so.  My companions liked their soft tacos and we enjoyed the corn bread appetizer.  On the whole, it was a pretty good experience.  The ambiance was nice, but I wouldn't be in a hurry to come back.
author: Debbie W.

description: The atmosphere was great. We ordered the table side guacamole, ceviche pescado, and carnitas. Food was great and adult beverages had a good punch.
author: Nikki R.

description: Excellent in all regards.  Service was fast, courteous and interactive. Food was exactly what was hoped for, zesty but not overkill.  Would definitely go again.
author: Chris H.

description:
I went two days in a row. Once with a friend after visiting Kabuki in Japan town. We had a great time. The tortillas were fantastic and homemade. Yum! Also, the $5 margarita with our lunch was the bomb. Had a pork taco on a bean stuffed tortilla. It was amazing and I loved the portions. I ate carne asada with nopales (cactus) and onion. It was also very good.

You get tortillas with three salsa's. The green one was bright and fresh. The red one was good and earthy. The orange one was OK. I could taste the mango but it was really sweet. I wish I would have received more tortillas with my meal.

I returned the next day with my husband, who's Mexican. We found out the evening before that John Santos was giving a free concert. We usually go to the mission district for food. But I wanted to show him Colibri. We went in (Oopsie - I think they may not have opened quite yet, and he went to the bar and ordered some Mezcal. He talked with the bartender in Spanish and then ordered one. He was actually given a small sample of another one and liked it as well. The waiter showed my husband the bottles so he could write the names  of the mescal down. Needless to say he was as impressed as I knew he would be.

The menu was slightly different from the previous day. No more $5 margarita. Aack! Also, I ordered the special which was made with Chile Morita, but the mole didn't have the smokiness of the chile that I was expecting. It was an average enchilada. Had I known that I would have ordered something else. My husband liked his dish. He said that he would definitely return. He also said that it's better than Comal.
author: Jacqueline F.

description: Fantastic wine, service and food! Delicious guacamole! Very happy to have found this spot
author: Chelsea R.

description: This was a new experience for me as it was a very fancy Mexican restaurant. They started us with three cups of salsa: a very spicy green salsa and red salsa which was also spicy and a sweet mango salsa. With a side of flour tortillas. Apparently people there eat the salsa with flour tortillas instead of chips. For starters we had the empanadas which were different from was I was used to though still tasted good. They were fried well and served with red cabbage for extra crunch and a very good sauce. I had the duck dish which I found very delicious the duck was cooked perfectly and was cut for me. Next to the duck was a type of croquet topped with arugula which was also very delicious, fried perfectly on the outside and soft and creamy on the inside. The green sauce was okay I didn't taste much flavor from it.  I saw on the other tables bowls of guacamole but found it peculiar that it was served in a plastic bowl placed in a stone bowl. It seems that they do not make the guacamole in the stone bowl and you get less guacamole than it seems. Also the guacamole is not served with chips. All in all the restaurant does not serve the usual Mexican food but still has some very tasty dishes.
author: Karyn G.

description: There's Mexican, then there's upscale Mexican. It's date-night Mexican. It's impress your boss Mexican. It's all about flavor, and whether sauced, dressed of spiced, they always get it right. Just make sure you have some room on the old credit card ... This one is gonna make a dent.
author: Joey E.

description: The good and service were good. We had brunch from the menu and my chicken fresca omelet was very good.
author: Steven J.

description:
When the neighborhood roach coach or taqueria just ain't cutting it anymore and a craving for real Mexican food hits, Colibri is a sure bet. Not everybody is a worldly motherfucker like Mike Z* who has to occupy the last seat at the gorgeous tequila-filled bar and chat it up with the bartender, flash a $20 and prostitute himself for a few free tastings of booze. 

Some of us are worse.

Not only do some of us do all of the above, but some of us also take up a greater circumference in front of the big screen showing classic black and white Mexican films, drown our liver with tequila, margaritas AND beer, gorge on Pato en Mole Verde Pipian (pan-seared duck breast in a delicious green mole sauce made with pumpkin seeds, tomatillos, nuts and spices) and Chamorro de Cordero (lamb shank marinated in a paste of Muscat wine and spices, wrapped in banana leaves and steamed to perfection) AND unapologetically indulge in Pudin de Chocolate (Mexican chocolate mousse covered with dark chocolate and sea salt). Some of us even ask for seconds and maybe even thirds of fresh, homemade tortillas with a trio of salsas in order to lick our plates clean. Some of us also dance on tables when we're drunk and flash our tits at Mardi Gras.

By some of us, I don't mean ME. Just sayin'. Don't get the wrong idea.

--

* Straight from the horse's mouth...Mike Z's that is.
author: Anastasia B.

description: Not impressed.  Chili relleno was forgettable.  The guacamole was good.  I also liked the drinks.   Service was great at the bar top.  Food was just okay though.
author: Brandon T.

description: Had the Crepas con cajeta. It was amazing.. The taste and the texture were top notch.. It was one of the best desserts I have ever had. It's a must have. The 5 stars is purely for deserts. I have not been here with the intention of having anything other than the dessert
author: Arvind G.

description:
A friend and I stumped upon Colibri while shopping in Union Square and found ourselves highly impressed. This restaurant is an upscale Mexican Bistro. Its much like Consuelo's in Santana Row, however, I prefer Colibri over Consuelo's. 

We started off with the Guacamole and it's dipping sauce which was so good we asked for more tortilla's 3 times!! 

I got, "Callos con Crust de Tortilla, corn tortilla crusted scallops over purple Peruvian mashed potatoes and sautéed poblano pepper, cactus leaves, corn and portobello mushrooms," with "Papas al Gratin, potatoes au gratin with poblano chile cream" as a side dish which was wonderful!!

Atmosphere, cleanliness, hospitality, location, size and seating all past my smell test!! =)
author: Michele A.

description: In town for the week and asked for the best authentic Mexican food in town and I was directed here. Absolutely met and exceeded my expectations as the ambiance was very relaxed and cozy. The food was warm, fresh, and full of flavor. I definitely recommend this place!! Miguel waited on me and he was super cool! :)
author: Khadijah A.

description: Been here twice now. Both times the food and service were excellent.  I like that they play old Mexican movies as well. Adds to the feel. The space is tiny though so expect to be sitting elbow to elbow with other dinners. They do take reservations and my favorite thing is I can get delta points here to with my sky dinning miles. This is my go to spot in the city.
author: Lucille B.

description:
Unexpected find after a meeting downtown - we popped in for a quick lunch and it was delicious! Saw some comments on the noise - it was perfeclty fine at lunch time and no mariachi bands playing! Guac was delicious, my colleague got the fish which looked and apparently tasted great and I had a really good salad complete with jicama and some good heat!
Got to imagine it would be good for a pre or post theatre dinner with some cocktails!

definitely worth a visit
author: Jo S.

description:
GREAT Mole! And I love the fresh Guacamole and Tortillas. The food is very good and every dish that passed by I want to try. They also have some grade A tequila that's really smokey. I can't remember the name, so sorry. But I'll find out and update. 

This place is nice inside, although almost hard to spot from the street. Make reservations if you can. Might be best on a weekend. It was really busy. I really enjoyed it here.
author: Charlene K.

description:
I can't believe I've lived four blocks from this place for the past three years and have never stepped in.  I had the Pozole and it was FABULOUS!  I've been looking for a decent Pozole in SF and I've found it.  

What I liked the most was that our server was so attentive and that even though we were finished with our brunch, he continued to pour us mimosas (all you can drink!) without kicking us out or making us feel like we needed to leave.  

I don't know why everyone is complaining about the $$$ - I only spent $60 (which included a 20% tip and all you can drink mimosas! We must have had 6++ mimosa's a piece!  WELL WORTH IT!

Bringing my sister and brother in-law who are visiting from out of town this weekend.  Can't wait to try something new!
author: Noneya B.

description: More often then not you find hole-in-the-wall Mexican joints, so it's nice to go to an upscale Mexican restaurant every once in a while. We went here for Saturday brunch and started with the guacamole. It was just your average guacamole, but I like they can customize the spice level and they do give you a lot (you have to pay extra for chips though, which is unusual). For brunch I had the carnitas. It was hunks of pork, some rice and spicy salsa. Again, it was good, but I expected more from reading reviews. My mom had the quesadillas, which come 3 to an order, with a thick blue corn tortilla. I think the quesadillas were more doughy tortilla than anything else and the cheese was absolutely flavorless. Maybe brunch is not the best time to try Colibri and their actual lunch and dinner menus looked good, so maybe we will return for that.
author: Hayley H.

description: Delicious authentic Mexican cuisine. Delicious- I would go back in a heartbeat. To make things even better, I am vegan and gluten intolerant and they had several options for me. The beverage menu had full  descriptions of the margaritas and tequila options-one was the Avion Margarita! Delicious!! Don't miss the chance for great food and service in union square!!!
author: Jen C.

description:
Guac was great.  We asked for one spicy and one mild and they tasted similar.  Had to add more hot sauce to mine but the taste was good.
A bit pricy for Mexican food.  I can get similar food from a taco shop for half the price but the ambiance is what you pay for.
Looks like they have a fully stocked bar so drink up if you must.
Didn't try a margarita but they had a variety to choose from.
Friendly and efficient service.
author: Grace P.

description: This establishment is tiny & cozy, but the food, guacamole, and cocktails are fabulous! you won't be disappointed...unless you have a bad attitude!
author: Court S.

description: Pleasantly surprised. They took us just 20 minutes to closing and we still received great service. The food was excellent. The margaritas were not to strong just right. My date had cochinita pibil, the pork was tender and tasty with just the right amount of cinnamon. I had the Sinaloa style of Pozole that comes as green Chile broth with a silky texture was delicious. The mango creme brulee did not disappoint. We are definitely going back and having that again.
author: Ed L.

description:
I've been to Colibri a handful of times and all in all, it's a great (slightly upscale) Mexican restaurant. 

Most recently I ordered the Ensalada Flor de Verano which I loved. It was a lot bigger than I expected but as a fan of edible flowers, I very much enjoyed it. I had that with the Tortilla Soup which was underwhelming. Maybe it's because my mom makes an amazing Tortilla Soup but it was nothing spectacular.

I've had the Queso Fundido con Chorizo in the past and it is superb! It's a lot of cheese so be ready to go a little crazy with the calories but I highly recommend sharing this with the table, it's a winner.

Rather than chips and salsa, you are served tortillas and salsa. The salsas are very good and cover the bases in terms of spiciness. I do with you could select chips rather than tortillas without paying extra.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Good guacamole, I'm a fan :)
The Filet, and whatever was the dish they had on special list was great

The tamales weren't a blast out of the 3 one was actually yucky..
I love Queso Fundido - and Colibri didn't disappoint :)
author: I B.

description:
I was writing a review for another Mexican restaurant and realized I hadn't reviewed Colibri. I used to work around the corner and literally still crave their guacamole.  

This place has the best appetizers and guacamole (they make it at the table).  It comes with warm flour tortillas vice chips too.  Yum!

I am not a huge fan of their entrees, but their drinks and guac make up for it!  You should check this place out!
author: Eric S.

description:
I'm convinced that anyone who rated this a 4 or higher is on the payroll.  Lord knows they didn't spend their time serving their customers, so it's conceivable that they were instead huddled in the back, crafting fake yelp profiles, and singing their own praises to fool unknowing patrons into dining here.  

If you like chips and salsa be prepared to pay $2 for a small handful, and I mean small.  Salsa is "complementary," served in thimbles, and will never be refilled.  I suppose this is done intentionally so you can save room for the bland entrée with portions that inspired Charles Dickens to write Oliver Twist... "Please Sir, may I have some more?"

The drinks were incredibly watered down.  I only saw our server when he asked if we wanted more tonic waters masquerading as mixed drinks or more overpriced food - basically anything that would raise the bill (higher tips?).  We were not asked how the food was or if we needed anything else.  The water server was on it though, we had full waters the entire night.  

The ambiance consisted of a single TV playing an old black and white spanish film without any sound.  How do I know it was a spanish film?  Because it ended halfway through the meal and sat on the title menu for the remainder of the night.  Did I mention it was Monday Night Football and playoff baseball?     

My overall impression is a place that overcharges for everything, provides poor service, and shorts their customers for more profit  Little, if any, thought is given to customer experience or satisfaction.  We should have waited at the first restaurant we went to!
author: Michael R.

description:
Ugh Colibri.

2.5

Walking home to my hotel, I was suckered into this restaurant by the "People love us on Yelp" sticker outside, that and it was right across the street from my hotel, damn you lazy mind. Anyways I walk in and the atmosphere is okay. If you like loud . I ate in the bar area, the obvious place for the single traveler as I was surrounded by other single travelers. Waited over five minutes for my server. I order the appetizer tamales ($10.00) which is theory sounded really yummy on the menu: corn dough tamales stuffed with Oaxaca cheese served with tomato sauce, queso fresco and white corn. Famished I also asked if I could get some chips and a Firestone ale. So chips and beer come and here is where I start to get excited. The salsa! OMG. So delicious. They had a salsa trio, trinity, what have you, and all of them were really good. The chips were delicious and the salsa were also served with yummy little homemade corn tortillas. I was starting to get excited about my tamales. They came and I bit into them, anticipating the delicious medley I was about to taste and I frowned. The red sauce tastes like Chef Boy R-D ravioli or Spaghetti-O sauce. No lie, this my instant connection in my mind. Although the tamale itself was good (but by no means fantastic), I was dismayed that after wiping off the ragu like sauce, only one of my tamales actually had cheese in it. Not happy. But did it matter if I was not happy? Nope! Because I never saw my server until she dropped the check off 30 minutes later. Good thing I had a book. Looking around I notice aggravation on one other of my single traveler faces as he looked for someone to flag down. We made significant eye contact, you know the kind that says, "Hey we are in this together and this place sucks". The kind of look usually reserved for airport lines. 

Oh by the way, the tortillas are NOT free. I was charged $2.00 for them. Not once did my waitress mention this but then again she was not much for conversation over than "Are you ready".  $20.00 bucks for a meal and service I was not impressed with. Good thing this was on the company.

2.5 stars for the salsa but I would not come back here.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
Stopped for a little lunch on a recent visit to SF and boy was I surprised. The food was amazing. Different from your standard Mexican fare. It was outstanding. So much so that we went back again the next day. 
I'll be back!
author: Marty H.

description: Enjoyed dinner and lunch the next day. Pleasantly surprised by the delicious food and great service.
author: Janet G.

description: We ate a lane diner here in a group of six persons. The service, although friendly, didn't care very much that my seat was stacked in a small space inbetween the tables. The ordered rare filet mignon was delicious, but very small which is unjustified for its high (22 USD) price. The waitress didn't know very much about offered beers and I ended up with a crappy mexican lager which tastes the same as every other mainstream beer in the world. I also didn't like the fact that on the bill you have added 2 taxes and an ostentacious recommended tip calculation - better bring a scientific calculator when you need to split the bill. Never again.
author: Maciej M.

description: After a bike ride at golden gate park all I wanted was a margarita and chips and salsa. We found a gem here! Great happy hour specials and they give you fresh tortillas with your salsa! So glad we found it!
author: Stacy A.

description:
This place is TASTY. Been here a few times, and love the atmosphere, the food AND the drinks!

You can specify how hot you like your guacamole (it does have onions in it) and fresh made tortillas (all there salsas are amazing). I've had numerous small plates, and cannot say much about the large plates, but I have no doubt they are delicious. 

Great spot to come by for a drink before a show in the area, or have a date night with a friend or sweetie! Strawberry basil margarita was amazing!
author: Angela F.
