description: I brought a client here. Found the food a bit disappointing. The mole poblano sauce was delicious, yet the chicken had a very strange consistency, and seemed overcooked. The rice on the other hand, was not very hot.
author: CJ M.

description:
Oh my goodness, this was a great meal.

First of all. I'm not sure how anyone could call this "too expensive". I think food prices in San Francisco are pretty comparable to DC so I'm used to paying a bit more for good food. I can see how an out-of-towner not used to city prices would be a little taken aback, but less than $20 for most entrees to me is not unreasonable.

I went here with a small group of coworkers while we were visiting and I will definitely be back next time we're in town!

We each had a margarita to start (different ones; all delicious), and the guacamole. We added on the tortilla chips which were worth the couple of dollars just to have something crunchy. The guac was very good, it was fresh and cold and had just the right taste to it, in my opinion. (Note, I like cilantro.)

For dinner everyone was extremely pleased with their entrees! I had the mushroom-stuffed chicken breast, which came in a great garlicky cream sauce that I would have licked off the plate if I hadn't been in public. The side of veggies was tasty too. Someone else in my group had the filet mignon stuffed with goat cheese, which he loved. We were too full for dessert, but people nearby were eating some that looked pretty tasty.
author: Lindsey N.

description: Incredible Mexican restaurant just a few blocks from Union Square. I had the tortilla soup, ceviche and fillet mignon main course and they each were some of the best I've tasted! service was stellar. A must visit...
author: Reza Z.

description:
A bit on the pricey side for Mexican, but the food is great and waiter service is very attentive! 

Margaritas - MUY BUENO!!

Parking is a bit of a challenge, but there is a garage right around the corner.  Nice decor, the bar has 1 TV that plays Mexican Novels from back in the day (black and white).

A nice experience!!
author: Jorge C.

description:
I loved this place from the tiny homemade tortillas to the delicious table side guacamole and salsas. My man and I where catching a show at the Golden Gate Theatre (4 blocks away) we had made reservations but the obstacle of getting in from the east bay made us totally late. 

Since I got there first I went in got seated and let our server know that we where trying to catch an 8:00 show. It was already 6:45 but she was awesome took my order and got everything out super quickly. She also recommended this delicious drink that I cannot remember the name of I think it had ginger in it. Well, either way they have a great drink menu. 

We had the Tostadas de Tinga, Sopes Surtidos, Ceviche Veracruzano, and Guacamole prepared table side, Pechuga Rellena de Huitlacoche and torta de elote. This was the perfect amount for the two of us. We only wished we had more time to enjoy it because everything was delicious. 

I wish we could have sampled some of their desserts. We are definitely going back.

BRUNCH! Brunch is amazing here. 
A few things I heart about brunch here:
- French Toast 
- The Chorizo con Huevos 
- The bottomless momosa
author: Caro S.

description: Food is ON POINT. Small portions and pricey but so delicious. Perfectly cooked filet minon and salmon. Well made drinks. Lots of tequila and mezcal. We had to sir at the bar but is dinner so it's understandable. Great food.
author: Tandis N.

description: I had the Pato En Mole Verde Pipian. Absolutely heaven on a plate. Easily the best preparation of duck I've ever had. The duck breast was cook perfectly, with a juicy reddish-pink center. The green mole sauce was a great accompaniment with a nutty richness to it. Service was awesome. They were polite and attentive. And the Margaritas were good and strong. Nice change from my usual Tex-Mex faire.
author: LaShawn G.

description:
Went to Colibri for the first time this weekend. I recommend to make a reservation because even though there are empty tables all around the staff will not seat you. Honestly, that was probably the worst part of it... well... they were also out of Don Julio and Partida and a few other tequilas. If I am going to a full bar that is known for it's tequilas, I would appreciate them having a few extra bottles of the most popular ones at hand. 

The good... it wasn't all bad! :) The food and mixed drinks were very tasty. Had something called the Refreshing Bliss which was pretty good, a bit of sweetness combined with a good amount of tequila, not too strong, but enough to taste it. This is the description from the menu, I would say it's right on... "muddled cucumber, mango puree, Pomegranate Infused Tequila, Partida Blanco Tequila, fresh lime, served up." Tried the Guacamole and a few other of the "antojitos" like the sopes surtidos and they were bite size and delicious. 

To summarize: 

- Customer service - 2/3
- Drinks (or lack of) - 3
- Food - 4 

Hope this helps you decide!
author: Ivannia D.

description:
I hate to give a well loved place a bad review, but I must be true to the experience. 

First time diner, and I was disappointed.  The guacamole was good, but overpriced.  Ceviche de Pescada was too salty for my taste.  The carnitas were dry, I would definitely NOT recommend getting this.  Margaritas were decent but I can't say I was blown away like some of these other Yelp-ers. 

I wanted to love this place like so many others do, but after this experience, I just don't get what all the hype is.

Sorry Colibri !
author: Maxine C.

description:
I went here for a drink at the bar while waiting for my table at Katana-ya, next door. The very friendly hostess ushered us to the bar where we found open chairs in an otherwise very full restaurant. The bartender was a little terse, especially to my boyfriend (he was perfectly nice to me, but then again, I have boobs). He actually threw the drink on the table a bit. 

I had the Tequilito ($10), which is basically a Mojito with Pomegranate. It was very good and very strong. I did feel like girl with a bright red drink in my hands, but hey, whatever. 

The boy had one of the special Margaritas ($12), which, truthfully, tasted like a good, normal margarita. 

But the atmosphere is nice. It's lively, happy and upbeat. Good place to come for a drink. I'll have to come back for the food :)
author: Mariko F.

description: Had good experience in the past.  What happened?  Worst experience ever!  Bartender with the nose ring is in a trance or something!  Blank stare and no willingness to showcase the huge selection of Tequila behind him.  We seemed to be interrupting his social with other staff members. Service sucks!  Apparently our server loved mole, because the only words out of his mouth were, "Mole. Anything with mole." Excuse me. He did ask if we wanted drinks in the beginning. No suggestions, no entrée descriptions, no nothing.  Must be a tourist trap now.  Can't think of locals ever coming back here.  Zero Stars if I could!!!
author: Johnny C.

description:
I'm glad that we finally made it out to Colibri.  But I have to say, while the food was fine, it didn't really live up to all the hype ("Best sit-down Mexican in SF evvvuuuuuurrr!"  Yeah...not so much.)

We were told to get the made-fresh-at-your-table guac, which we did, and while it was perfectly edible, it was far from spectacular, a little salty, and quite small for the price.  The fresh-made tortillas they bring with it were pretty good though.

We tried a variety of things (mole, enchiladas, rice and beans, cactus, maybe a few others?), and while they were all solid, they were certainly not the best sit-down Mexican food I've had in SF (though I'm glad we had the cactus, because I really liked it, and haven't seen it anywhere else).  Also, value leaves something to be desired -- frankly, the food would have to have blown me out of the water to go back and pay those prices for the amount of food you get.

We did really enjoy the cocktails, though -- I can't remember off the top of my head which ones we ordered, but I think we tried somewhere in the neighborhood of 6-7 of their margaritas or other cocktails and liked just about all of them.  The prices for these were more in line with what you'd expect for high-end cocktails in the city ($9-12 each).

Bottom line -- I'd go back for drinks, or for food if someone else was paying, but I certainly wouldn't put *my* wallet on the line.  And I'm still in search of the "best" sit-down Mexican in SF.
author: Angela B.

description: Went here with the bizzaros for the annual bday brunch.  We have been driving past this place for a long time, but given the location (theater district), we never quite made it there.  As for brunch, was VERY impressed.  A high quality traditional Mexican brunch.  We started out with the guac and the best tasting mimosas.  We followed up with the tacos.  Will be coming back.
author: Sheetal P.

description:
I was treated to a mexican food at this place. 

I love it when I get treated. 
I love it when she treats me out. 

With that being said, she likes guacamole and so we ate guacamole. It was just plain great. I like raw tomatoes in my guac, AND the cilatrno, lemon, and onions were good. I forget what specific dish I had but it was great. It was prepared perfectly and the ceviche was equally delicious. 

And so ends another great day!
;D
author: John-Michael C.

description:
My surprise birthday dinner was held here last week with about 10 of my girlfriends. I've never heard of this place, but I'm glad I know about it now. It can get a bit pricey, but trust me, the food is delicious. We started off with some guacamole... this was deceiving as the kettle it came in looked a lot deeper than what it really was. But man, was it delicious. It had a nice kick of spicyness at the end. Complimentary salsa trio and fresh, hot tortillas were provided as well. Delish!

I ordered the chile relleno ($14) with a black bean puree. This isn't your average mexican food. It's definitely more of mexican food meets awesome gourmet chef.

And I almost forgot the best part of the meal-- the margaritas are phenomenal! I stuck with the classic margarita, and it was dangerously good. I'll have to come back and try more of their specialty margaritas at another point in time.
author: Ashley D.

description:
Great place!  

Granted I was drunk for most of my meal and I'm a New Yorker, therefore not the best judge of Mexican food, but this place definitely hit the spot.  As did the blackberry margarita.  Heavy on the tequila, of course.  

I'll keep this place in mind next time I need a fun, casual meal in Union Square.
author: Parisa S.

description:
We came here for dinner after catching a play in the area. We'd previously been for brunch (which was great), but I was really disappointed with the dinner.

The food was okay. Nothing amazing, but it was incredibly over-priced for the quality, flavor, and portion size. I guess you're paying for the proximity to Union Square, but personally, I wish we'd taken a cab to grab a bite to eat somewhere else.

Overall recommendation - brunch is great, but skip dinner here.
author: Emily C.

description: Yes, the corn tortillas and hot queso and chorizo dip are amazing.  (Ignore the grease at the bottom!)  The guacamole is good and chips are passable.  The Herradura margarita was fine, though full of ice and and not generous in size.  I had a pork-filled chile relleno that was uninspired.  The portion was also small considering the price.  The first time I visited, I had the mole, which I would definitely return to next time though I might just stick to the appetizer menu.  Both times I have been at Colibri, we have been seated in the back next to the kitchen/serving station/bathroom path and I was constantly being knocked in the shoulder by people passing through.  If I were to return, but definitely hold out for a different table.
author: Joyce D.

description: Colibri was a very good Mexican restaurant in the touristy City center. The guacamole was amazing with great chips and homemade tortillas. The margarita with strawberry helped I'm sure. The carnitas was amazing, too. Overall, a great experience. Definitely will return.
author: Phil N.

description:
After hearing how my BF wanted to try this place, I went on Opentable.com to make my reservation for it for the next week. We came here this Wednesday evening around 8 and this place was packed. The wait time without reservations were 1hr long! Thank goodness I made it or else we wouldn't be eating there. The hostess was sweet and funny. "I love reservations!" So do I!!! We got seated right away. The table was for seating face to face but my BF and I love sitting next to each other so we did and shared literally half a table but the waiter was so nice to have offered to turn the table for us. Plus for that! 

We first ordered our drinks and since we had a drink at Michael Mina before we came here I didn't want to have a strong alky drink. There was the longest margarita list ever! Every one of them sounded good but we went for the Margarita Con Fruta. You can choose the fresh fruit you want. I think there was kiwi, mango, pomegranate, strawberry... I ordered it with strawberry and he got the mango. The drinks were reasonably priced at $12. Probably my favorite margarita ever! The fresh strawberry/mango does a lot to a drink. Tasted really refreshing.

Everything on the menu sounded pretty good. But since I was starving after I got off that afternoon, we went to The Cheesesteak Shop and had a large order of curly fries with cheese and a bite of the BF's sandwich so I wasn't super hungry... We started with the Guacamole. They make it right by your table, your choice of how spicy you want it, three different sauces, my fav was the mango pineapple, and also home made tortillas. Very, very goood guacamole. I can just sit in front of the t.v all day and night eating that. Fresh GREEN chunks of guacamole! MmMmMMm super good.  

For entree, I ordered the Pechuga Ranchera ($14) tender chicken breast smothered in a creamy guajillo chile sauce, over mashed potatoes with sauteed spinach and garlic. The best part was the spinach in the mashed potato.. The chicken was also good. Not dry at all, good flavor, and the sauce they put over it tasted perfect with the chicken but the spinach mashed potato was yummy. BF ordered the Filet Mignon ($18) filet Mignon with ancho chile stuffed with seasoned goat cheese, over mashed potatoes with sauteed spinach and chipotle chile sauce. This has got to be the SMALLEST filet mignon ever. I think he could of probably ate 10 pieces of that to be full. It was smaller then my fist! I didn't taste it so I don't know how/what it taste like and if it was good. You would have to wait for his review!

DESSERT!! So even though I was super full, we decided to order dessert. We ordered the Mango Creme Brulee and the coffee tequila flan both $8. The Flan was just OK. But the creme brulee was pretty good. I love how the had a layer of fresh mango on the bottle. Custard was creamy ad not overly baked but I wish the burnt sugar on top was thicker since I love hearing the crackle noise when you dig into it.. But it was still good!

Total bill was around $90 but since they were on restaurant.com, I got to use my gift certificate! Very nice restaurant, good margaritas, guacamole, spinach mashed potatoes, and creme brulee! Amazing service and nice atmosphere. It's not the quietest restaurant if you wanna take a date here.
author: Juliane N.

description:
Friend and I stopped by here for lunch and food and service were pretty good. I like the complimentary tortillas, but wish they had served chips and salsa instead. What's Mexican food without chips and salsa?

I had a steak sandwich that looked a bit small, but was really tasty and filled me up. I opted to add churros to my meal and my friend added the tortilla soup to her cheese enchiladas and we shared the soup and dessert. They poured the soup from it's pot tableside and I thought that was a cute touch. 

I wish the prices were better because I did feel that I was being overcharged simply because I was eating in SF. I get it, it's part of the deal of eating in a city that is so expensive to live in, but it still doesn't make me happy.
author: Jamie S.

description:
I've been here a few times, and I really love the homemade corn tortillas that they serve prior to your meal. The first time I tried their ceviche, and it was flavorful but really spicy. I was told that wasn't normal, but I still liked it.

The second time a bunch of us wanted to try it for dine-about-town. I had the carne asada with grilled cactus and soup to start. The soup was a tomato base with chunks of cheese, avocado and tortilla strips. It was "ok." My carne asada had a leftover grill taste to it, but I must say I really enjoyed the grilled cactus. I also had a strawberry Fresca which was refreshing and nice!

I took a star off because although our server was pretty good, it took quite some time to get our main dishes. This would've been fine had they been busy, but we were the only group in there along with an individual diner at 1145 (they open at 1130).

I'd definitely recommend the ceviche and homemade tortillas!
author: Berna P.

description:
Followed reviews on here, and plumbed for a safe bet for my first night in SF, VERY disappointed.

Chicken was full of grizzle, cheese was bland, service ok, Mojito was good hence the only star wish I had gone next door.
author: Malcolm D.

description:
If I could afford to eat here everyday I would!

Yea, the guacamole is delicious and when they feel like it they will add the  spices and seasoning in front of you at your table. However, the queso fundido is by far my favorite appetizer and I rather order this instead of the guac.

The salsa trio (red, green, and yellow salsa) is good and comes with tortillas rather than chips... not just any tortillas, handmade tortillas and yea there's a difference!

All in all, you cant go wrong with this place! the food is great ( and innovative, like other have mentioned) the atmosphere is lively and complimented by great music, service can vary but it's not awful.

Don't think twice, just do it!
author: Carlos M.

description:
An exceptional place. Food was very fresh and clean. How do I know it was clean? I can tell these things in my gut. Salad had fresh mango and edible flowers that you really enjoyed eating. Guacamole served with small, warm tortillas. This alone would be worth the trip.  Waiting now for the molten choc cake which will probably put me happily over the edge. It did!! To die for - and I mean that almost literally. 
Do make reservations here, or else you won't get a table. We ate at the bar, which was fine, and the bartender was very attentive. Man, this place is really, really good.
author: Rob F.

description: Got the seared duck and it was delicious!  Wasn't expecting the menu, but happy with my choice.  House Margarita was not sweet....which I prefer.
author: Keith M.

description: I'm Mexican and as such have been eating Mexican food my whole life. This restaurant is one of the few that managed to nail the authentic Mexican food flavor in most their dishes. One thing I did not like is that you have to pay extra for chips and salsa- but I think that was my only complaint. I have taken my kids there but only for lunch. Being that the restaurant is close to the theaters I would assume it turns more to a bar/ adult dining place for dinner (but that is only an assumption as I have never had dinner here).
author: Angie B.

description: Interesting cocktail selection.  Love the fresh warm tortillas with salsa to start.
author: John W.

description:
They make delicious gourmet Mexican food. We had the torita de papas (a potato dish) and the chamorro de cordero (lamb shank). Both were unique dishes that we had never had. It was a little expensive but worth every penny. Make sure you have the guacamole!

It is more upscale, so I don't recommend taking your kids unless they are well-behaved. Make sure you make reservations!
author: Tori F.

description: Poor, high priced mexican food.  My rice was gummy, and I felt the entrees lacked flavor. I had better Mexican in Philadelphia. I was actually disappointed.  The cocktails are good though.
author: Rina C.

description:
There are several positive things to say about this restaurant but the overall experience was mediocre.  We came here to have brunch/lunch with a group of people and while this is a nice restaurant, it does not accommodate large groups.  They have "large" booths but in reality, the booths fit 5-6 comfortably for average and not large people.  It's a gigantic square table with no leg room.  

Service was terribly slow, waitresses and waiters lacked personality and didn't seem friendly and could barely understand English. When we buy $10 of all you can drink champagne, they better keep the champagne flowing, otherwise don't call it all you can drink.  I don't care if we down a glass every 5 minutes for however long we're there, keep it coming! Water refills were a disaster.  Expect to be thirsty during meal. 

The food was relatively good, at least what I ordered.  I ordered the Mexican breakfast or "desayuno."  Do you get the bang for your buck?  NO.  First, I specifically asked for no beans and sausage but to add extra rice and potatoes to make up for it.  WTF did I get?  5 pieces of potatoes and a bird size portion of rice. At lease they got the no beans and sausage right.  I have to give them kudos for the guac, it was effin delish!  But freaken $20 for guac and you got to pay an additiona few bucks for a small tray of chips.  Ridonkulous! Bottom line, food was good, not exceptional besides the guac, and extremely overpriced. 

If I would do brunch/lunch over again, I would walk right pass this place.
author: CatLadyHon N.

description: Not impressed at all.  My husband and I each ordered the Chile Relleno (fire roasted w/ veggies & cheese) and we were so very disappointed!  Being Latin, I love seasonings.  This dish needed a massive makeover when it comes to seasoning, the "fire roasted" chili did not have that "fire roasted" taste, it was bland.  The veggies and cheese inside also bland... veggies looked like frozen diced carrots and potatoes and we did not see or taste any cheese.  It felt like this was more of a social  "let's drink" spot... one girl and friends came in drunk and she shouted across the room to her friends, which I found annoying after the 6th shout...especially since Colibri seemed to be "shi shi".
author: Dorie W.

description:
Ate here on a Sunday afternoon.  I was bowled over by the margarita (over rocks, not blended).  I had the Camarones with Tamarind mole sauce and kept saying, this was the best mole I ever had.  It was served with a savory corn cake, again just wonderful.  I can't wait to go back and try some other things.
The service was attentive with out hovering.  They let us sit and enjoy ourselves without pushing us out the door.  Nice atmosphere.
author: Mary B.

description:
This is still one of my favorite places, especially since it's so convenient for dinner before a play at the ACT or a gig at the Warfield.  One of the bartenders, Luis, is incredibly nice and also makes excellent drinks.  

Try the pozole (hominy soup with pork), which is incredibly flavorful; it's best with all the fixings it comes with (radishes, lemon, etc.).  Also very good are the rellenos.  And the ceviche is still one of my faves.  You can order it as a main if you want, and they give you an even bigger portion.  

Bueno apetito!
author: Kimberly Q.

description: Great tortillas and guacamole.  The mole is respectable.  Service is great, but it is a little loud.  Best Mexican so far in SF.
author: Tyler J.

description: Food is good but it's quite expensive. Hit up Mission instead.
author: Alfred L.

description:
This place is a nice gem on the border of the tenderloin and union square area. They were quickly able to seat my party of 8 on a Sunday night without a reservation. The service was prompt/polite and the workers were extremely nice.

The ambience was nice. It has that rustic, mission type feeling. Adobe type walls, beautiful painting, big booths and large wooden chairs.

Their beers and mixed drinks were on par with any high end mexican restaurant.

The guacamole was amazing, but still a bit much at $12.

I shared their chile relleno stuffed with carnitas and their special of the night, a stuff chicken dish topped with tomatillo sauce, which was quite tasty. No real complaints and a good time was had by all. We were the last group out and had to pay via multiple credit cards, due to billing purposes, but they were extremely gracious about it. A classy joint.
author: D L.

description: Last year when my family was in town we went here for dinner and had a really good time so we thought we'd come back this year. I called two days in advance to make a reservation for 7 and everything was fine. Yesterday when we got there, there was no reservation for me, which would've been fine, I understand that reservations can get lost. But the lady accused me of lying and told me the reservation was for last year. I'll never ever come back here again.
author: Johannes J.

description: Visiting SF for 2 nights.  Liked it so much the first night, ate dinner there again the 2nd night.  The ceviche was divine and margarita's strong!
author: Denise P.

description:
The food at Colibri is really super delicious. The margays aren't half bad either. The mole on our chicken tamales last night? Like butter. The chile relleno? Yummo. The tres salsas that came with the cute as a button tortillas? Scrumptious.

If you really want to sit at a table and have a grown up meal, make a reservation. Do not expect it to be a quiet and sedate affair. You can eat at the bar too.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I was here with hubby  when on a extended weekend holiday. We were staying in the Union Square area, and stumbled on this restaurant quite by chance.

We got Guacamole and Pozole for appetizers.The soup was very flavorful and tasty. For once I didn't add any additional seasonings. Guacamole is made at your table, needless to say it was very fresh and tasty, with just the right amount of lime juice.

For the entree I got the Carnitas. It was VERY, VERY good. Hubby got the Filet minigon, he complained it was too small. I thought the portions were just right. The margaritas were good, I had to get 2. The corn tortillas are awesome, they are thicker than the store bought ones and very soft. They make it in the kitchen, the waiter told us.

For dessert we split the cajeta crepes. The cajeta itself was very, very good.

I really enjoyed my dinner here. I am looking forward to my next visit to San Francisco so I can eat here again!
author: Rachel H.

description: Utterly boring food and there was a needle on the bathroom floor. Real classy
author: Gretchen S.

description:
If you haven't had high-end Mexican you will definitely be impressed with Colibri. The guac prepared table-side is a fun and delicious treat and the butterflied fillet mignon is very good as well. 

I live near Colibri's competitor Maya and go quite often, so I have a lot of experience with nouveau Mexican. Though Colibiri puts in a solid performance, their ambiance is less elegant and their entree presentation is more basic. 

So Colibri doesn't win the crown for best nouveau Mexican, but they're still worth a visit when you're nearby.
author: Jeremy S.

description: The food is quite good, and the prices are very reasonable. My favorite dish is their fish of the day. Their guacamole is quite good, though a bit overpriced. I would recommend this place as a quality new age Mexican restaurant.
author: Brendan W.

description: Food was pretty good, but the company was better. Portion sizes are small, but I know that's a good thing in most cases.  The quac was really tasty. I had the Mole and it was yummy, but kinda wish it was a bit bigger. I ordered black beans on the side and that was the perfect pair. My husband got the pork and was satisfied. Another person we were with had the Chile Relleno and he ate it so quickly he ordered the soup to eat, as well. Good Margaritas.
author: Lindsay K.

description:
Can a theater-lovin' brotha get a good meal?!  Si, claro que si!

Colibri delivers.  No, not literally.  This Mexican slice of heaven is directly across the street from ACT, and is my number one place to meet-n-eat in the theater district. And that's not just because the food is excellent.  The tequila list is topnotch, and like so few places in the world, they make a great margarita.  If you only eat burritos and never check to see what kind of tequila you're being poured, then I can also warn you that you probably have no interest in this place.  Owned by one of the founders of World Wrapps, this place couldn't be further from it, or my favorite Mission burritos shacks and Mexican Taco Carts...

Food deets:
The table-made guacamole es muy excelente.

Great ceviche, ole!

The mole poblano is to die for, oh so tender.

Almost anything they do with duck or squab is worth ordering.

Beyond that, the ambiance is excellent, with decor a step beyond Ameri-Mex to Spanish Colonial.  The service never falters.  But let them know your curtain time.  For what it's worth, they seem to specialize in friendly, sexy, young waiters and waitresses with international accents...yeah, you so hate that, stay away. Ha ha ha!  It's not cheap, so if you're on a budget, just hit the bar, or drop by for dessert after your show.  It's oh so worth it, totalmente!
author: Ted R.

description: Great atmosphere and location. Loved the decor. But not sure what all the hype was about the food. The presentation was good but the flavor was lacking. The guacamole and chips were great but a bit expensive for the portion. So maybe it was just the dishes we ordered. But not sure I will visit again. Maybe give it one more try.
author: Javed S.

description:
It's weird how I tend to review places I've just been to once or twice, but I ignore places like Colibri which I go to all the time. It's also weird how my second toe is so much longer than my big toe. 

Well, that's all changing.

I pretty much only sit at the gorgeous tequila-filled bar when I've been there because I love tequila, but i don't know that much about it, so I like to befriend the bartender and get tequila tips. The entire left side of the menu is a listing of different kinds of margaritas, all made the exact same way with fresh lime, but each using a different tequila. These are the best margies ever. If you're nice, the bartender will give you little tastes of the different margaritas made with different kinds of tequilas, and it really is amazing how the tequila affects the flavor. 

What's that?  You want to know about the food? God, you're annoying. 

Just do what I do, and order a few things off the appetizer menu, otherwise known as antojitos if you're a worldly motherfucker like me. 

I like the guacamole made super spicy in front of me and served with fresh hot tortillas. The tostadas de tinga are excellent as well and go beautifully with the delicous ceviche and the "al pastor" fish tacos, served taco-truck style with onion, cilantro, and a bit of pineapple. 

Did I mention the tequila?
author: Jay Z.

description: We ordered the Filet Mignon and carnitas, both AWESOME, the filet was to die for!! great REAL gourmet mexican food, great service and fair prices for that kind of quality.
author: Cecy S.

description:
When my friend suggested we meet here, I got really excited (who doesn't get excited for Mexican food, right?!)...but it was a bit of a disappointment for me at the end of the night.

However, the drinks were really good, I had a couple of Mangoris (rum with mango puree) and my friend had the House Margarita and a Mojito. I love that they make the Guacamole fresh right at your table...that was pretty fun to watch! I got the Queso Fundido to share and I got a Pozole as my entree. The Pozole was definitely mediocre and the Queso Fundido was an epic failure because the cheese congealed into lumps and you couldn't really dip your chips into it.

But the worst part was when our bill came and it was $100 for only 2 people--yes, we did have 4 drinks between the 2 of us, but the rest of our order only came from the Appetizer, Soup, & Salad menu. I wouldn't have cared paying that much if the Queso Fundido and Pozole were really good or impressive at least...

I still gave them 3 Stars because the drinks were good, the freshly-made guacamole at your table, and for the good and friendly service. I would probably give them another chance and try one of their specialty dishes next time. But definitely be warned, it's a pricey Mexican dining experience!
author: Barbra C.

description: Oh please!  One quesadilla order costs over 9 bucks.  For that you get 3 small corn tortillas with plenty of queso fresco inside, one lousy leaf of epazote, and a sliver of roasted poblano pepper.  Rip off!!!
author: Lxs S.

description: All I have to say is, you can get any dish in their menu for one fourth the price, three times the portion and much tastier in mexico. You basically pay for street/homemade mexican food that is served in any low to middle class home In mexico, except here its served on a big plate, small portion, and accompanied by a robust check
author: Jaime C.

description: Food = five stars. Problem is you have to put up w horrible service. Hostess was super rude. Bartenders super slow. Waiter brought our appetizer and entree before our drinks. So sad I was so looking fwd to coming back here this trip. The service really marred the experience. :-(. I was also informed that their rum options for mojitos are now ltd to Bacardi. Used to be a great place to try different rums.
author: Sara B.

description:
Great Mexican food. Authentic flavors. Reminiscent of Frontera Grill in Chicago. Had the ceviche and carnitas as comfort food and I am satiated.
Made a second visit and had the chile relleno. Delicious.
author: Don M.

description:
Per the recommendation of my favorite Yelper, Anne E (lalaluv her) We went here to celebrate the birth of Claire P two Fridays ago and I was surprisingly pleased :) 
They set up our table in the back of the restaurant (kinda felt like we were on vacay in Meh Hee Koh) and we ordered apps... tasty quesadillas, perfect guacamole and ??? hmmm its all a blur until out came my filet mignon :) Ahhh it was perfect! Juicy, flavorful and a perfect portion (or at least thats what my trainer says). I usually don't order dessert (would rather save the calories for a mojito) but in the spirit of celebrating Claire... I did and Oh My Gato!!! This little piece of heaven (Crepas con Cajeta) on a plate wore me out with its outrageous goodness... I seriously would've licked that Cajeta sauce off my plate if I could.

Definitely worth a visit if you're in Union Square, however, I do recommend a reso cuz it does get packed!
author: Anna S.

description: Chicken Poblano was delish. Get the churros for dessert. Melt in your mouth good. Too many tequila drinks to choose from, so I asked the bartender to make me a spicy margarita. My drink with the jalapeño floating in it did not dissapoint.  Super busy, but I was by myself and found a spot at the bar quickly.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
It's rather tough to dislike guacamole made fresh at your table (unless you're some sort of strange statistical outlier who resides in California but hates avocadoes). Beginning your meal with the guacamole at Colibri will almost absolutely ensure apleasure-filled experience at this upscale Mexican restaurant in the theatre district. For good measure, get yourself a mango daquiri too!

We ordered what was probably, in retrospect, too much food. Here's the run down:

The pechuga ranchera a la nata, described on the menu as "tender chicken breast smothered in a creamy, well balanced guajillo chile sauce, side of sauteed spinach with shallot and garlic" was tasty though I could have done with a better balance of flavors in the sauce.

We also chose the Chile relleno - "fire-roasted poblano chile stuffed with vegetables and cheese, over a black bean sauce". I wasn't crazy about this dish but I know that my favorite vegetarian would love it.

The Tostadas de tinga "crisp golden hand made tortillas topped with stewed chicken, garnished with avocado and chipotle sour cream" were a stand-out. Unique and interesting flavor. Would definitely order again.

The Arroz a la Mexicana was your basic "traditional Mexican rice with diced vegetables." Tasty.

As a potato lover, I was quite enamored of the Papas al gratin --- "potatoes au gratin with poblano chile cream." Would not go back to Colibri without ordering the papas!

All told, Colibri was good but not great. I'd return if invited but probably wouldn't choose the place on my own volition.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Colibri Mexican Bistro is another one of those places where you wish you were a kid again so you could lick your plate when your Mom wasn't looking! 

It is a shame to leave even a small morsel of this food behind!

We shared the - 
      * Tamales Oaxaquenos
      * Chile Relleno
      * Ensalada Cesar

 . . . . . with 2 Margaritas de la Casa and a glass of Sonoma Cutrer.

I would not hesitate to order exactly the same thing again, time after time. 

It was that good.

Only drawback to the dining experience at all was the fact that it is not a drop in place . . . . the hostess told us that, if we wanted a table we would have needed to make reservations 30 days in advance.  I assume they don't get many tourists?  

So, as all good San Franciscans would do . . .we sat at the bar!
author: Rachel C.

description:
I really want to give this place 4 stars, but I can't. Had I come with a group of 4 people I might be able to. But I ate alone, and I really felt like I was an annoyance for the restaurant because of it. Service just wasn't up to par. 

The table-side guacamole is excellent, though expensive. I understand you are paying for the experience of getting to watch it made, but it's not as though this is cherries jubilee or bananas foster. Getting to watch my guacamole made is really just giving me proof that it didn't arrive on a Sysco truck this morning in plastic tubs. It's not a spectacle. And it's not as though any of the ingredients are expensive or rare. I can't argue with the flavor, but the pricing isn't appropriate. The guacamole is served with pieces of soft tortilla rather than chips, which was actually better than I expected.

Wonderful selection of tequilas. And they are happy to make you a margarita from any of them. At the prices, they should be happy. But given the location, I have far less quibble with the tequila pricing than the guac pricing.

Carnitas were flavorful, but too fatty. The side dishes were somewhat bland. I wound up making little tacos out of the mini-tortillas with the carnitas and guac.

The dessert, Crepas Con Cajete, was spectacular. I would almost come back just for the dessert. Rich caramel with velvety crepes. It was delightful. I wound up walking away with a smile on my face because of the dessert. 

I'll return, with plans of getting the guacamole again, the tequila again, and the crepes again. Maybe I will like my entree better, and maybe the service will be better. Until then, it's a 3 star.
author: TJ P.

description:
I love love LOVE this place! 

Every time an "out of town" friend comes to SF 
I bring them here :) Its always a sure thing. They make the guacamole fresh at the table to your desired spice level. Which is nice, because I am the biggest wuss in the world and cannot handle spice at all! LOL

My favorite dish (that I get every time, I don't even look at the rest  menu!) is the "Pechuga Rellena de Huitlacoche." Its a Chicken dish with corn and zucchini, and the most wonderful sauce. I highly recommend it.
author: maria K.

description: Great place, good service, food and drinks. Little rustic and noisy but that is something U can expect at this central location.
author: Mikael J.

description: The male waiter was extremely unfriendly. The food had no taste. The decor was good enough, but the restaurant does not live up to its four star rating.
author: Bradley V.

description: Authentic Mexican- delicious food and very good service. Waiters know what they serve and also can explain in detail :) try the beet salad and catch of the day! Both great, found this place just because it was close to my hotel and will come back for sure
author: Tendü Y.

description: I love this place! It's my favorite date night spot. As a local, I love to go into places where I know I'm going to be treated with such care. From the bar tenders to the waiters. Luis is an amazing mixologist! He can make just about anything in you can think of.  Yes is priced high but you're getting quality food and quality drinks! The food is as close as south of the border as you can get. From the music to the ambiance just one awesome place! I'll be back anytime Luis is at the bar serving good drinks!
author: Jezabel D.

description: Delicious guacamole and nice ambience. Would definitely return.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Some visiting friends actually introduced me to this restaurant.  I guess that I don't eat out in the Union Square area all that often - I had never heard of Colibri.  After eating here, I feel like this is a place worth coming back to.

We stopped in for brunch/lunch on a Sunday afternoon.  The place as an elegant ambiance to it - dark wood tables and some authentic, interesting Mexican decor.  The restaurant definitely looks "fancier" than their prices actually reflect.

We started off with a heaping bowl of guacamole.  It was deliciously smooth and creamy and had a bit of spiciness to it, which I really liked.  What made the guac even better was that it came with some warm corn tortillas which were fantastic.

I saw huevos rancheros on the menu and immediately knew that this would be my dish.  The over-easy eggs were perfect, the pureed refried beans were flavorful, and the blue corn tortilla that it all rested on had sucked in a bunch of the flavor of the rest of the plate and was quite tasty as well.

I want to come here for dinner sometime.  Now, in addition to Tropiseuno, I have a second great mexican restaurant that's very convenient from downtown.
author: Tim N.

description:
I'm a huge mexican food fan, and well, this place blew me away.  The food was so good and the Guac, well it speaks for itself.  I was in SF on business and tried to go back to Colibri the next night and it was full :( - good for them, bad for me.  But yes, it was so good I tried to go twice!
The margaritas are also very very very good!

Enjoy!
author: Valerie W.

description: Our third experience, still great.  Despite a busy Saturday night, they accommodated our request to change our reservation time at the last minute.  They got our substitutions exactly correct; wonderful service.   We don't live in SF, so we don't eat here more often (once a week wouldn't be too much).  On this visit we especially enjoyed the tequila flights, chile relleno, chicken tacos, warm tortillas (so much better than chips, right?),  Mexican coffee, and of course, the salsas!  Why can't LA have this quality Mexican food?
author: Lyn A.

description:
I've been to this place a few times and always had a good time but never wholly impressed.  Once the manager asked my friend and I to move from our table because we were taking too long, we weren't all to happy with that even though he said we can go to the bar and drinks were on him.

But I had my B-day dinner here recently and have to say I'm very happy with how it turned out.  We had a table in the back, so we could hear ourselves talk and with a table of 15 people that's important.  The food was great, every person at the table was happy with their meal, when does that happen?  The food also came out at the same time, that's a huge thing because how many times are 14 people hungry and staring at their good but waiting for that last dish to come out that somehow is always late.  The drinks were great, and the cost was very reasonable, about $30 per person, for a group dinner with tip that's great.    
The only thing that they should do better is have the table ready on time, we sat down 30 minutes late.  Of course we were at the bar having a good time, but if all of us were really hungry it would have been a different story.
author: Inga W.

description:
Things you must try: 
Corn Bread! a really homemade quality to it
Carne Asada - comes out in big pieces so you need to shred it yourself. 
Guacamole - ask them to make it spicer as they made it in front of you

Service: Average because when we needed something, our server was not to be seen for at least 5 minutes.  Bussers or other servers didn't really respond or ask if we needed anything.

Lots and lots of tequila if that's your thing.
author: Debbie N.

description: Excellent, high quality mexican, and at decent prices for downtown area.  Carnitas and Mole excellent!
author: Hapy M.

description:
I loved the variety of margaritas.  We tried a couple of them but the most memorable was the  Macho Margarita which is made with roasted jalapenos.  It took a long time to get the drink but was worth the wait.

The food was good but nothing really stood out for me.  The service was pretty slow.  If I go back, I'll sit a the bar and order drinks with some appetizers.
author: Deb R.

description: I spent 5 days in SF and this was the worst restaurant by far. Average service, Mexican rice with no flavor, among others, will not recommend to anyone
author: Randy R.

description: I thought Tropisueno was amazing Mexican food in San Francisco , but Colibri topped it!
author: Cynthia N.

description: Great guacamole. A must try is the carnitas meal !! We missed our reservation by one hour because of the new year Chinese Parade and they were able to accommodate us with a small table by the main door, of course after being persistent. Very good food and service.
author: Emilio L.

description: Try the Guacamole- they come with "melt in your mouth" soft tortillas and tasty salsa's.....
author: Krystle T.

description:
The priciness is why I give it only 3-stars.  We got the guacamole and chips, the corn dough tamales, a salad, the stewed chicken tostadas, the duck, the scallops, the lamb shank, and the prawns with corn cake.  I got the feeling that the waiter was aware that the amount of food he recommended for us may be too much.  Anyhow, the scallops are delicious as it melds well with the mashed potatoes, cactus leaves, and other veggies it sits on.  The lamb shank is remarkably tender.  Good homemade tortillas.  

For dessert, we split the flan and the crepes.  I recommend the crepes.  The light crepe with the cajeta and ice cream is a party in your mouth!
author: Arthur L.

description:
All I have to say is: $5 for a small bowl of chips.

It's been mentioned in other reviews, but it's hard to believe that a Mexican restaurant would charge its patrons for tortilla chips. What is probably more egregious is that a side order of rice is also $5 (beans are also $5), but somehow, in the same way that "music wants to be free", I feel like chips at a Mexican restaurant also want to be free.

The first time I went to Colibri was for lunch with a coworker. The food was good and authentic (I grew up in Mexico City, so I know), but a little pricey. Now we go to Los Socios for lunch instead.

The last time I went to Colibri was for a birthday dinner with a party of 10. For appetizers, we got 2 orders of $10 guacamole, 2 orders of $9 sopes, 2 orders of $8(!) quesadillas, and 1 order of $16 ceviche. So that's about $70-worth of appetizers. When we saw that the ceviche came with chips, we asked the waitress if we could also have a bowl of chips for the guac. She said "well, chips are $5 per bowl". "Wow," we said, "make sure you bring us a big bowl". The bowl was the size of a small cereal bowl and had about 15 chips in it.

The food is good. I will give them that. But the value is nowhere near what you can get from a cheap taqueria that makes great authentic tacos with lots of flavor for $2.50 each. If you really want to experience Mexican haute cuisine, go to Maya. Their food is much better, and you'll deal with a lot less BS.
author: Andrew M.

description: I don't care how good your food is if your first interaction at an establishment is a rude hostess who can't be bothered to even acknowledge people as they walk in. Then it takes 30 minutes for your bland food to come out and you only see your waiter 2 times in the entire time you're there... steer clear of this place not worth the price.
author: Adriana R.

description:
a good spot for downtown. i would have thought less of the food since it's in tourist central but the food was decent. 

queso fundido - (4/5 stars) if you loveee cheese. could have used some more chorizo
lamb shank (3/5 stars) the lamb was doused in sauce and i wasn't particularly a big fan of the sauce but the meat was decent
carnitas (4/5 stars) very generic mexican dish that was made well
author: Janet Y.

description: Rude staff , poor service and crapy food. I walked in and they were all standing talking to each other and the restaurant was empty . I asked to be sited they made me wait 10 min before they do that so after 10 min I sat my self. After I asked them what's good in the menu and she recommended some tacos that were nasty. I've been to Mexican restaurant before but this one is so garbage I would not go back ever.
author: Sha Y.

description: The food here is amazing! Stopped in for dinner. Had the guacamole with fresh handmade tortillas, green pozole, sopes, and ceviche. The service was great and the atmosphere in the whole place was very welcoming.
author: Joe R.

description:
Upscale Mexican food. More and more I'm becoming a fan. So I love Tropisueno and have been meaning to try this place. We had reservations somewhere else but my manager didn't want to be anywhere near the Dreamforce conference so we score reservations super easy here for our team dinner.

We get there and the place is half empty but it's a Tuesday night so that was great for us. Our server was uber nice and perfectly attentive. But it's really about the food. Mole prawns with this amazing cornbread that wasn't like a traditional cornbread. It was much more moist that crumbled and went well with the mole sauce.

Drinks were excellent as well. My coworkers raved about the Sangria and the margarita was on point.
author: Hyung L.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  Especially prior to going to a show.  The location is perfect for many of the theaters in the area and the service will get you to the show on time.  The food is delicious and much better than the normal Mexican places I've often had to go for a fix of Mexican food.  The home made tortillas are one of my favorite parts of the experience.   I've become an aficionado of margaritas on the rocks and their Cazadores margarita ranks among the best I've had.   Although the service is adequate, I think being more engaging with their guests would get them the other star in my book.  All in all, I think you'll enjoy yourself here and want to come back.
author: Mark K.

description: I really enjoyed the ambiance, margarita and delicious food. It was really crowded though.
author: Dani C.

description: I've become a city snob and "as a local resident", I try to stay away from Union Square restaurants and any places that are near or around hotels, but it's kind of hard to avoid in our tiny 7x7 city.  After having driven by here hundreds of times, I decided to give it a try and was pleasantly surprised!  The ceviche was great, the special of the day, which was a essentially a Yucatan Pork Chop, was delicious.  I think I'm going to start trying daily specials instead of ordering off the menu and getting my comfort dish as I really was impressed.
author: Alex T.

description: I recently went there for my friend's b-day dinner and it was my first time have to say that it was really good. I had the tortita de papas but the pozole verde looked delicious and I really wanted to try. I would so go there for a casual date with a date or with just friends. I would recommend this place to any one but make sure you have money in your pocket cause it is a little expensive but worth it
author: Rosa A. F.

description: We were visiting San Fransisco for a few days while at a conference. This place was within walking distance from our hotel, so we decided to give it a try. We sat at one of small tables in the bar area. Someone forgot about us, because after I told the hostess that no one has been to our table, she apologized and took our order. I had the sopas which were very flavorful (except for the veggie one). The server, Maria, only visited our table ONE TIME to drop off our food. Who was responsible for taking care of our table? Hostess? Bartender? Server? I'm not sure, because no one checked on us to see that we were missing almost everything! Again we were neglected. We never got water as requested, never got the chips and salsa as promised, didn't have condiments, there wasn't salt or pepper at the table, utensils were not provided with our food, etc. We had to hunt for the things we needed ourselves. We literally had to flag the bartender or summons the hostess to provide salt, pepper, water and utensils to our table. We never did get the chips and salsa though. Anyway, we paid and gave our tip to the hostess and bartender, instead of to the server Maria. Good food, but beyond horrible service! Beware.
author: Michelle M.

description:
A bit expensive but the food is good. The margaritas are very good. I like the mood, not a fan of the molcajete with a plastic bin, but besides that it's a great place to go with a friend.

The waitress was a bit distant but friendly.
author: Guillermo A.

description:
Upscale Mexican food in a location that you might walk past and not even notice the restaurant.

I wanted to try the Mole Poblano but they were out of mole sauce.  I opted for the Flautas de Pollo, and these were good with fresh ingredients.

Service was good and the ambiance was nice.  Recommended!
author: Peter S.

description: This place is amazing, no complaints. The bottomless mimosas were great. I got the Eggs Benedict with carnitas and my friend got the chile relleno and both were cooked perfectly. We went on a Saturday morning and even though they were crowded the service was spot on. I will be coming back here again soon.
author: Amanda C.

description: The tortillas could not have been more delicious. The service was great and they even offered to make a dish that was no longer on the menu. Can't wait to go back!
author: Jaclyn M.

description: Pozole Verde was excellent. It's a modern take on Mexican cuisine; however, this does not explain the price-point. Food is solid, drinks are on-point and service is quality. If they took down the price a bit the place would be perfect! It's almost too pricy. You'll enjoy the food. You will be happy with your order.
author: Michelle A.

description:
"Completely unplanned, unexpected, surprisingly amazing goodness! "

I've always had a bias against Mexican food, I like it and all, but I never thought it can be "awesome" or "innovative".  (I actually feel the same way about Chinese food ..... but anyways!)

Drinks:
I got the Basil + Strawberry Margarita - it was AWESOME.  They used fresh strawberries!  I tried some of my friend's Macho Margarita as well, it was definitely interesting, for one I had no idea that jalapeno's can go into drinks......

Appetizers:
Sopa de Tortilla - OMG IT'S SO GOOD!   So tortilla strips, avocado, cheese and sour cream were all in the bowl, but it wasn't until that got to you before they pour the tomato soup on top of it.  So the tortilla strips is still kind of crispy, and everything else retained its taste while swimming in delicious tomato soup!  Seriously one of the best soups I've had.  And unlike most soups (in america), it is NOT over salted, instead it is tasty and o so good.  Highly recommend!

My only regret is not getting the guacamole.... i love guacamole..... doh!

Food:
Callos con Crust de Tortilla - delightful!  The squishy texture of scallops topped with crunchy corn tortilla bits was a great move.  Very good!

Dessert:
Flan al cafe y tequila - it was good, but not spectacular or special like the rest of the dinner.

Churros rellenos - stole some of that off my friend, now these were positively delightful!  Recommend!

Conclusion - comfortably full and happy with good food.  Will definitely visit again when I'm in town, perhaps to try some of the other dishes.
author: Jessica L.

description: Had the Guac and Chicken Mole, super delicious. Grab yourself a Strawberry Basil Margaritta and enjoy the taste of smooth as hell Tequila. Sit at the bar. Watch them make drinks. Amaizng place if not a little pricy.
author: Patrick M.

description: Very delicious food and drinks! Amazing tortillas and good lunch potions. Extremely prompt and attentive service.
author: Sarah S.

description: Try the Mole Poblano. What amazing flavor profiles. Plenty of food and inexpensive for the City by the Bay.
author: Jordan B.

description:
I've eaten here about 5 times and sometimes hangout at the bar and I've never had a bad meal.

I always found the service friendly and competent but it never really wowed me.  All that changed on my last trip when the bartender kicked out an annoying old goat.  A commendable effort considering how some other restaurants would have put up with this harpie's song and dance. But Homey don't play that at Colibri and even though the shrew barked and try to create a scene, the staff stood their ground and kicked her out!

On a side note, reservations are highly suggested as this place is always packed!
author: Roger H.

description:
I would have given it 4 stars last year, when I first ate here. I feel the quality has gone down since then. I ordered the Guacamole, and was surprised when it was just brought to me already made. Before they made it in front of you, to your specifications. It was fun to watch. Was still good, although needed a little salt. 

The carnitas dish was overcooked, and dry. I've had better at cheap places, and more on the plate. 

The chips that came with the Soup I ordered were a bit stale, old, definitely not fresh. That was not expected. The soup itself was good, although no as good as I remembered it last time.

Tamales were good. 

In sum, for this place given the price, serving sex, I just expect the food and service to be consistently high end, to match the high end price, but it was not. Last year was better, and I wonder, reading others reviews, if indeed there has been a quality drop. I can get better value for the food at other places.
author: Giovanni N.

description: Carnitas are very good. The place is small and noisy. If you're in Union Square it's worth a stop.
author: Bob K.

description:
Yum... A nice cold margarita on an insanely hot day. I had one of their muddled fruit blackberry margaritas it was delicious. I also had a nice glass of sangria. Not the best ever, but pretty good.

Where they really shine is with their service and their food. The food was so good! I ordered the scallops and tasted the carnitas and both were perfectly cooked, tender, and flavorful.
author: Dani D.

description: We ate lunch here and it was great! Very flavorful! The guacamole was delicioso! We will definitely will return!
author: Marisa K.

description: I'm really not a fan of this place.  They didn't have some of the basic food courses we were anticipating prior to choosing this place, based on massive reviews. Even after being open minded, we found the food to be at best -  bland.
author: Ryan K.

description: Absolutely delicious food, and the service I received was top-notch. I ate here twice during my stay in San Francisco, returning a second time because I so enjoyed the first visit. The server not only remembered me, but remembered my order from the day before. I ordered the catch of the day on my first visit, which was simply amazing, and on my second visit I enjoyed a near-perfect bowl of ceviche, which I will now dream about from the opposite coast. I do not remember the name of the drink I ordered, as it was something I chose because it was unique and sounded good and contained rum, was out of this world. High praise for this place, and will make it a point to go again on my next visit to San Fran.
author: P. M.

description: Colibri is amazing. Wonderful mimosas, mixed drinks, and food.  However, Marta, the hostess, is a very rude individual. Very poor people skills, we did a $400 tab and she asked to leave less than an hour and a half of being there because she had another group waiting.  That being said, the place is great, Marta is just the worst. Thank you.
author: Cara D.

description: This is easily one of my most favorite Mexican restaurants in SF. Yes, it is on the pricey side, but it's upscale, the food is great, and the service is always fantastic. I can't think of a better place for a night dinner out.
author: Damien T.

description: Nice place, good food (not exceptional nor tremendous), we went here on Sunday evening quiet late, and everything went fine. The only thing is the price...70 USD for two plates, a guacamole and a margarita, I found it very expensive. At least, was the feeling we had getting out. Does it worth it? No.
author: Carlos C.

description: My best friend and I ate here before an event last night. First off they do not have the menu you would normally see in most Mexican restaurants so keep that in mind, the atmosphere was very nice, and they have a beautiful bar with drinks I could not drink because I forgot my ID :(. I ordered the Sopes appetizer which came with a chicken, veggie, and pork Sope I enjoyed my Sopes a lot, my friend ordered the chicken taco appetizer and a Cadillac Margarita, she was happy with her tacos, but told me the margarita did not taste like your typical Cadillac margarita and sent it back. The food was very good, and typical price for finer Mexican dining, what I was not happy with was the fact that we had to pay for chips and salsa $2 per a small bowl of chips, and my can of diet Coke was $3, I don't mind the prices for the appetizers and main dishes, but paying that much for  a non-refillable drink, and chips I have never seen at any Mexican restaurant. The service was decent.
author: Monica R.

description:
I was introduced to Colibri by a dear friend.  What an amazing experience! By far the best margarita "MACHO MARGARITA" I have ever tasted! Literally, ruined me to enjoy anywhere else! We loved the staff, food was sublime and yes Margarita too! I have returned 3 times with my husband and another friend.  This weekend will be returning with a couple friends to introduce them to Colibri.  
Location is convenient to Union Square and Current Theater is literally across the street. Not to be missed if you're craving Mexican food that is not the usual but deep rich flavors that are authentic and creative with beautiful plate presentation look no further.  But book a reservation as they are usually quite busy...and once you have experienced their menu and fabulous selection of Tequila and Margarita's you will understand why! Enjoy
author: Cheri C.

description:
If you want to visit your soon to be favorite Mexican restaurant, you should stop into Colibri. 

I went here on Saturday night with a friend, and although we didn't make reservations (which you really should do for this restaurant as it is ALWAYS packed on the weekends), we were able to grab two spots at the very large bar. (Insert mental, YES!) Then we went on to enjoy an awesome, hand to mouth, eat as much as you can, type of meal!

The atmosphere here is Spanish chic. The restaurant and bar is adorned with beautiful tequila bottles, dark wood, rod iron chandeliers and lanterns, and  just makes you feel at home. It is comfortable and very nice, but not too over the top fancy. Actually, it sets the tone quite nicely for the food and drink to come.

Now, things I love:
1. They bring you homemade corn tortillas hot from the oven, and three salsas to start you off vs. the standard chips and salsa. (although they will bring you chips upon request if you miss them) 
2. You HAVE to get, their fresh guacamole, I swear this could be the whole meal and I would be happy....but let's be honest, of course I eat more than this...
3. Their margaritas are awesome and well priced, 11 - 13 seemed to be the price range for very good tequila selections, and although they are not large, they are well made with a good amount of tequila ;-). I enjoyed the pineapple, margaritini - which was served as a martini - if you didn't guess by the name - DELISH!
4. THE FOOD IS FANTASTIC, and AUTHENTIC. We had their Carmita's and Queso Fundido appetizer which we topped with the homemade guacamole and salsas and were pretty much in heaven. The Carnitas were actually fried, as they should be, and moist and flavorful. Really good.
5. Lastly, the churro dessert. It is large, (4 homemade churros) drizzled in caramel sauce, and with a scoop of ice cream. It is to die for. 

Check this place out, it isn't too pricey,  and the qualify of the food and drink are worth it!

I should also add the bartenders, although somewhat distracted with their friends at the bar, were very friendly, super knowledgeable, and gave us a free shot of mezcal to taste. (as we had never had it) That kind of treatment always makes the experience way more fun, and this now is my new favorite Mexican restaurant!
author: Leslie H.

description: YUM! My friend and I came here this past Saturday for lunch and I was so impressed by the food. We ordered three things to share; medium spicy guacamole, ceviche, and the enchiladas divorciados. All three were wonderful. We especially liked the enchiladas and the red sauce that came on them. Our waiter was friendly and helpful and we had a great experience there. Next time I'm in the city, I will definitely be back!
author: Bridget S.

description: Damn Good Guac, GREAT drinks, fun yet loud atmosphere.  Great for a group outing.
author: Nadia N K.

description: I loved this place!  I had lunch here with my good friend, Linda the Great.  How great is she?  She's so great, she makes Alexander the Great, look like Alexander the Wuss!  Linda had the Enchiladas Divorciadas.  I'm the one getting divorced, so I should have gotten those too!  But, I wanted Mexican eggs, and they weren't on the menu. They made them for me and they were great!  The food was very flavorful, but not too heavy(as some Mexican food is).  The portions were appropriate for lunch, the decor was nice, and the service was extremely attentive.  The bottomless mimosas were really bottomless!  It didn't seem that pricey, and it's near Union Square.  I told our hot server that I hoped I would dream about him, and he said, "I hope so."  Woohoo!
author: Blondie R.

description:
Some friends and I, starving and in Union Square, went here for dinner last night. They were staying at a hotel nearby, so when both Yelp and the concierge pointed us toward Colibri, we thought we were in for something really good.

And the service was really good. The hostess set our group of 9 - no reservations, 8pm on a Saturday - up at the bar and got us to a table in much less than the predicted 45 minutes. The food was also good, albeit not quite what we were expecting (gourmet Mexican rather than California-style burritos and nachos). The guacamole was especially good, but for $12 plus an extra $2 for chips we would have hoped for more of it and limitless chips. Really, paying for chips at a Mexican restaurant?

I guess that should have tipped us off that the portion sizes wouldn't exactly be generous. The chile relleno was laughably small, and although the dishes weren't that expensive, we all had expected more for the price. Service and flavors get it the 3 stars, but I wouldn't come back hungry unless I wanted to spend a lot on multiple plates.
author: Emily W.

description:
For Mexican food, this is totally over priced, not very authentic, and not that tasty. They charge $6 for a side order (about 1.5 cups) of rice. This is indicative of other items on the menu.

The guacamole with tortillas was delicious, but not $12 good. I would not go back here. They focus too much on ambiance and service and not enough on quality food.
author: Caitlin H.

description: In the city for a night and found this place off of help. Made reservations form8, we got there early at 7:30 and were willing to sit at the bar until our tab,e was ready and drink but surprisingly we were only waiting for 5 minutes until they found an open table for us. It's a very small place, crowded and loud but if you're like me then you won't mind. The wait staff is very nice and helpful. Micheladas are $6! And the lime juice tastes very fresh. I ordered the stuffed chicken and it was a perfect portion and was seriously oh so good! The chicken was moist on inside and crunchy on the outside, veggies were perfect and cream sauce was just enough to compliment the flavors of everything else. Def order the gauc and homemade tortillas because they are amazing! Would def go back,must make sure to make reservations are go after 8:30 because that's when it started to slow down a little.
author: Nicolette C.

description: I stopped in here for a quick lunch. Located across the street from the Clift Hotel. The food here is delicious! Service was great. Started off with homemade corn tortillas and 3 types of homemade salsa ... I wish I lived in SF so I could buy the green tomatillo salsa from here - it was that good! For lunch I had the tortilla soup, perfectly spiced (on hot side but tolerable) and wonderful, and the Panuchos de Cochinita Pibil. Amazing!  The food was presented beautifully. I highly recommend to my friends with a craving for Mexican when staying in Union Square. You will be in for a treat. Enjoy!
author: Cathy B.

description: A modern take on traditional Mexican food, in my opinion. Service was good. Food was overall quite good, although my entree portion was quite small. Rice and beans are extra, which was annoying. Rice was decent, but not $5 good.
author: Norman F.

description:
Now THIS is a business lunch. In and out in 45, impeccable service, delicious food. As other yelpers note, you won't find better chips and salsa anywhere. Just go ahead and try, I dare you! 

My table mates opted for mole poblano and flautas de pollo, which looked great, but I can't imagine trying anything else than the tacos surtidos--especially on a maiden voyage here. Each bite was increíble! I don't even know how to choose between perfectly cooked steak with pickled onions, melt-in-your-mouth grilled fish with marinated pineapple, and chicken with mango salsa. Well, actually, the order I just listed is probably a pretty good ranking. That steak was amazing. 

I will eat here again when next my travels bring me southward.
author: Dawn C.

description:
My replacement to Guaymas.. As you all know, Guaymas in Tiburon has gone down hill. This really bummed me out because i loved their authentic style and the margies were always perfection..

Well thanks to Kells she intro'd me to Colibri. SO I scheduled a lunch date with the girls. Now downtown SF is no Tiburon, but we were in it for the food this time. 

Service was super slow - which is why I took away one star..

Strawberry and Basil Margaritas - SPLENDID
Guacamole - They make it fresh right in front of you.. just like in Mexico - AND it's GOOOOD
Tortilla Soup - Has the taste and consistency of Mole - which I like
Ceviche - Fresh, limey, delicious. 

This is our new go to Mexican spot.. Loves!
author: Monica S.

description: Excellent, fresh guacamole with chips and soft, steaming tortillas.  Nice, friend service. Went in with a party of 7 and no problem getting separate checks that were correct!
author: Ashley H.

description: I am a bit disappointed.  I was hoping first notch Mexican food. The food was only decent, the guacamole was a bit below average.  The quality of food doest not justify for the price.  And I live inNew York, where good restaurants are pricey too.
author: Kai L.

description: Delicious hight end food, very authentic and flavorful; excellent presentation. Full high end tequila bar and good margaritas
author: Moy V.

description: I stumbled upon this place while visiting San Fran, the food was ok. Ive had better Mexican food in NY
author: Gloria F.

description: Food was excellent! Guac was prepared fresh (not tableside, but close by) and served with homemade corn tortillas, that were delicious. Some of our group did not prefer those, so we ordered traditional chips. I believe we were charged for each set of chips, but all were very good. The trio of salsas was amazing - hot medium and mild, all with great flavors and clearly made freshly.  All of the main courses were well prepared and had great depth of flavors.  Thumbs up!  Margaritas were ok, and for $11 each, were not huge or amazing. That's the lost star in my review.  I'd definitely return!
author: Jodi S.

description: Fantastic margaritas and guacamole! Great spot to enjoy some gourmet Mexican food. Definitely recommend reservations!
author: Michael G.

description:
An ACT employee recommended this brunch place before a theatre show. So glad she did! We've been back many times since.

Guacamole made at your table. Delicious brunch entrees that have more sophisticated preparations and more depth of flavor than at your average Mex joint. When we bring guests, they are delighted by the bottomless mimosas with fresh squeezed OJ.
author: Marina N.

description:
a wonderful find, across from the Curran and ACT.  Inventive dishes with a careful hand at work (Camarones in a Tamarand Mole!! and a wonderfully prepared duck in a wonderfully blended pipian sauce).  Excellent ceviche and do not miss the sopes.

Cannot wait to go back and try some of the other dishes!
author: Paul S.

description:
Yes the place is nice but was a disapointed with the food.

Tamalito appetizer: a bit gummy but decent. Tomato puree sauce
Chilaquiles: Same tomato puree sauce
Enchiladas: OLD smelly chicken and the same freaken tomato puree sauce...

I really wanted to like this place but don't think I will be going back any time soon.
author: E. Y. G.

description: Great pozole and really enjoyed the nopales.  Just those two items will fill your stomach and soul.  Homemade corn tortillas heaven sent.
author: v v.

description:
Gourmet Mexican food? Ooooh, yeah.

While visiting the city last month, I was on the prowl for something a little bit comfort-food, a little bit authentic and a little bit Latin-inspired. As I walked along Powell St. from Nob Hill to Union Square, I decided to take a right turn on Geary St. and on a whim, stepped into Colibri. Not knowing a thing about their menu, service or quality, I thought, how bad could it be? Why not take a chance?

Colibri is at the top of my list for Most Pleasant Gastronomic Surprise and a reminder to trust my instincts. 

If you love margaritas, Colibri provides a slew of versions. I had the Margarita Herradura. It was superbississississimo. (So good, that I skipped desert and had a 3rd one.) The handmade tortillas and salsa trio were...que deliciousness. I finished with the Chile Relleno con Carnitas y Chicharron which was so blissful I had to practice a Zen moment of restraint just to resist licking every inch of my plate. 

If I had a hollow leg, I would probably still be sitting there eating.

Attention Mexican Food Lovers:  do not miss this place. If you're a couple or dining alone, the bar serves a full menu. Otherwise, call ahead for a reservation as they seemed quite busy.
author: Pamela W.

description:
Pleasant atmosphere, though when the site says early 20th century Mexico City decor, I thought it would have been a bit more punched up. They need some more dia de los muertos skulls and some candles for a snappier identity perhaps?

The salsa with fresh tortillas was delicious, but a head's up: they serve them in a cloth napkin so don't be fooled, they're in there! I thought it was just an extra napkin at first and dropped them all on the table. They should actually explain that, but maybe I'm just clumsy.

We had the duck and the lamb and I highly recommend both. The duck had an odd pairing with pasta but in the end it went well with the sides of green sauce (sorry, not sure what the sauce was but it was good). I only give Colibri 2 stars though because the hostess and our server could have been a bit more pleasant. In short, we thought it was pretty tacky that when it came time to use a gift certificate when paying our bill, our server said: "oh, tip isn't included with that." Well duh! We always tip well. Super tacky to even mention that.
author: Kris P.

description: The guacamole was great - good size portion and very tasty.  We ordered appetizers to share - the sopes and mini tacos.  Also very tasty.  I like that they bring three different salsas to try.  I ordered a Macho Margarita and it was super!  The service was attentive, but not overbearing.
author: Jo Anne G.

description: Just fantastic food: a lot of attention to detail and great flavors.
author: Nick C.

description: When I first walked in I saw waiters walking around with what appeared to be huge bowls of guac. I could hardly contain my excitement.  It turns out those huge bowls are actually mostly just bowl, although the small amount of guac that we did get was fairly tasty. The service was painfully slow.  While the food presentation was attractive, the taste just wasn't there. I sprinted for PinkBerry when I got out of here.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
i pass by here all the time and never tried this place out until recently. i came here for brunch on a lazy sunday and the place was nice. there was nothing outstanding about colibri or its food or service though. my table ordered the entrees and appetizers, they got the grub for us within a reasonable waiting time, we ate/enjoy our dishes and then left. 

really, nothing totally remarkable, just your run of the mill restaurant. i wish i had a stronger opinion about this place but it was just average eatery aka not bad not good aka meh.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description: Came here for a last minute lunch and we got seated in the back at a really cramped table. I guess I couldn't be that picky about where we were sitting because we did come during the lunch hour on a Saturday. We kept our order pretty simple: guac and chips and tortillas, and two different carne asada dishes. Their guacamole is very good and the salsas that accompany it are good too. The carne asada dishes were okay, but the meat was cooked perfectly. The service was pretty slow even though they were busy, but I think I'd come back in for another try especially for the margaritas.
author: Sheeva G.
