i got the blackberry margarita and it was very good.  they also had strawberry, mango and a few other fruits i couldnt remember.  they also have a lot of tequilas to choose from.

we also got a ceviche appetizer and that was also very good.  they gave us a few tortillas and salsas on the house which was a nice little gesture.  the tortillas were warm and fluffy and the salsas went from sweet/mango, to a smokey one.

i wouldnt mind stopping in again at all

and ... i did ... their brunch is so amazing!  they definitely should advertise it more.  i had their version of the eggs benedict with corn meal patties, slow cooked pork, poach eggs, potatoes.  good.  their version of french toast with fruit on top was also SO GOOD!!!
author: claudia y.

description: Four of us had brunch here on Sunday after service at Glide.  What a surprising find.  The homemade tortillas, the rich and complex tastes, the reasonable prices.  I had the eggs poblano and the mole sauce was one of the best I have had.  The feeling was unanimous among our group. We will definitely be back.  Great location across from the Curran Theater.
author: Julia R.

description:
Colibri was a nice experience - my co-workers and I were staying in Union Square and wanted to get out of the chain restaurant rut so I found this little place. 

Everyone loved it. Margaritas, tortilla soup, guacamole, tamales, jicama salad, we tried it all and it was fantastic!

Service was excellent - quick and attentive.
author: Kristen C.

description:
Let me just preface this by saying that guacamole is at the top of my "prefer-not-to-eat-list." There's no particular reason, it's just not one of my favorite things. But I have to say, there is something about the guac at Colibri that had me wanting more...this stuff was delicious.

Luckily for me, my entree was even more delicious. I had the Mole Poblano and I swear that chicken was cooked in Heaven....right next to my Mojito.

Check this place out!
author: Todd O.

description:
A superb meal that knocked-my-tastebuds'-socks-off.  Unlike toher restauants where a basket of bread is proffered, HERE you get a plate of warm tortillas with 2 condiments.  I thought this was one of my courses, tomalitos...but it was a classy complimentary treat.  My entrees were scrumptious, served really quickly by smiling, sweet male and female waiters.  Beyond this, the price was ridiculously low considering the theater location, the nice surroundings and the high quality of the food.  
...I'll be back...with some more friends :)  Thumbs Up!
author: Francois T.

description:
I'm going to preface this with a brief statement:  I went here with a large (25 people) group for a birthday celebration and perhaps my experience was atypical due to the size of our group and menu options.

A few months ago I went to Colibri for dinner.  We had a preset menu (due to the size of our group) with a few choices for each of the three courses.  First we ate tortillas with salsa.  Oddly, this was our "appetizer."  The tortillas themselves were not horrible, but I thought that it was really strange that they didn't offer us anything else to eat with them other than salsa.  

The next course was a choice of chicken or pork with rice.  I was provided a ridiculously dry piece of pork and a side of rice.  No sauces, no nothin'. That's it.  

Last course was dessert with a choice of flan or churros.  Take the churros, because the flan was rejected by everyone at the table.

Tortilla + dry piece of meat + donut = horrible meal
And mind you, we paid $45 per person + 18% tip just for food. It goes without saying that I was extremely disappointed.

Again, perhaps my experience was atypical due to our prefix options, but overall I was NOT impressed.  Go to the Mission to get some real Mexican food and you'll still have some change left over for a cab ride home. 

In short, I would not recommend hosting your birthday party or large group celebration, for you might lose a few friends.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Food & service are pretty good, kind of expensive.  If you plan on dining here, go to restaurant.com first and purchase a gc.  

I must had the wrong bar guy that day, there was no alcohol in my sangria.
author: Cali G.

description: The place reminds me of the good restaurants are in Mexico, beautiful place where things American are combined and classic Mexican atmosphere, the attention of the place is wonderful, always attentive and smiling, the food is exquisite, always dressed with traditional Mexican sauces, very rich individual dishes and tortillas, I recommend a shot of Jose Cuervo tequila.
author: John B.

description: Awesome guacamole and pork rellenos! Very loud. Great service.
author: JoAnn S.

description: Maybe coming from SoCal my pallate for "fancy" mexican food isnt as refined but Ifound this place to have okay food. I went for the mole since I couldnt justify a $15 burrito or whatever it was. Chicken was tender and mole was good but a tad pricey for what it was.
author: Dustin W.

description:
I have to admit that I knew I was gonna luv this place before even going. Traditional, non-taqueria Mexican food is not always easy to find and I love it. Nothing against taquerias. 
Homemade tortillas lets u know that you're in for a treat right off the bat. 
Tried almost everything and its all good, but the mole and pechuga were my fav. Awesome place if you're a real tequila aficionado too.
author: Brett H.

description:
The hostess was great. She saved our reservation as we were stuck in traffic and seated us immediately once we arrived. 

It took a while for the server to appear but I guess that's because they were busy. We ordered their famous table-side guacamole but the preparer didn't bring us any tortilla chips with it. We waited thinking that they were out and in the process of preparing. When we saw three other tables receive their bowl of chips and we still didn't have ours, we had to ask them for it. I couldn't believe it...shouldn't it be automatic to bring chips with the guacamole?

The rest of the meal did go well and their Mole is delicious! I ordered the Ahi Tuna which was fresh and I loved the mango salsa that came with it. We also ordered the Mango Creme Brule which was yummy!
author: Melissa L.

description: The guacamole is amazing! I would def try it out as an appetizer. The desserts are also delicious. My husband and I tried the flan and mango creme brûlée - yummy!
author: Maxine M.

description:
Oh my... Mexican food at its best. The food is outstanding, that's a nice place, the service is awesome Highly recommend. 
Too bad the sangria was watered down, they don't give open table points (that suxs) and it is super hard to get a table if you are the spontanous type.
author: Carpe D.

description: This one was difficult. Overall, the food and service by the bar staff was a solid 4. Salsa verde good, salsa roja not so much. Food was tasty, with the chicken tinga appetizer standing out. 1 star deducted for a rude and dismissive hostess who would be better suited to work at the DMV. I generally prefer to be guided to a seat at the bar with more than a dismissive wave and turned back.
author: David P.

description:
Rolling in with a group of 14 ladies from work last Friday for a workie bachelorette celebration we came here because the honoree loves tequila. We got here late due to the after work traffic (foot, car, and trains). The service had to be fast because we only had an hour to order, eat, and have the honoree open her gift. 

They do not serve chips unless you order it separately, instead they give you mini tortillas and three dipping sauces. I ordered their Margarita de la Corazon for drink which was okay, but not strong as other margaritas I have had in the past. I had ordered the Pechuga Ranchera, but instead the server didn't pay attention to where I was pointing my finger because I got what looked like shredded pork over mini tortillas and I am still unsure what I had. 

Although the service was quick, there was at some points where the servers tried to take drinks or food before we were even done. Uncool. And then when one server dropped a glass, wherein some shattered by my feet (luckily I was wearing closed toed heels), I just wanted to heave-hoe out of there. 

I'm not sure I would want to come here. Due to pricing and well just okay service. I may just want to go elsewhere for tapa-styled food.
author: Jamie L.

description:
4 1/2 stars.  Stumbled upon this place tonight and had an awesome dinner.  My friend lives on Eddy and so we just wanted to go somewhere within walking distance but also wanted to try something new.  We decided on mexican; yelped it and I made the executive decision of choosing Colibri. :)

Once we got there the hostess let us know it was about a 30-35 minute wait for a table, but there was one table near the bar.  We snatched the table; had a pitcher of sangria and ordered the carnitas; chile relleno; a chicken dish and a salad; all served tapas style and was perfect for our small party.  Everything was great!  Love the fresh tortillas and the mole sauce.  Yuuuummy!!  

Thanks yelpers!
author: Regina B.

description: Service was excellent. We called 30 mins prior to our arrival and we were able to get reservations on New Years Eve. Ramon was an amazing server. We tried the dishes and drinks he recommended and couldn't have enjoyed it more! We will def visit again when in San Francisco! The fresh corn tortillas are extremely good.. try it with a coco mojito!
author: David E.

description: Great food. Great Margs. We found this right by our hotel and I couldn't be happier.  I've now visited twice and hope to return again soon.  This place fills up quickly without a reservation so make one or try to arrive early.  Give the guacamole with warm tortillas a try - they are great.  Our favorite thing on the menu (so far) is the pulled pork appetizer.
author: Scott ..

description:
I never thought that I'd resort to rating service but when the food doesn't wow, the service becomes the deal breaker. The salsas that are brought out at the beginning of the meal were good and the food was ok too though nothing that would blew me away and the guacamole lacked in salt.
Our table was seated close to the door and instead of a waiter we got maybe the manager. She was surly and pressured us to order at least 4 times before we actually did. Since I was seated with a view onto the restaurant, I could see that she continued to give surly orders to all the servers around us throughout our dinner. All this made the meal rather unpleasant and while ceviche and the mole were good, I did not enjoy either having this surly woman constantly around us. 
There goes my critique of others who give restaurants few stars mostly based on service...
author: Yana M.

description: Great food..fresh guacamole, great balanced flavours In all the dishes ordered. Came here for office team lunch and everybody was happy with the food, which is rare. I will be back for their drinks :)
author: Malvika J.

description: The food was decent, but the portions were way to small for the price. Overall, too expensive and the tables are too close together. You will not be missing anything but skipping over this place.
author: Randy W.

description:
I love trying new restaurants, and I have to thank http://www.groupon.com/r/uu197150 for introducing me to this place.  I got a $30 gift certificate for $15 --SCORE!  The only downside about coming to this place is that it's in Union Square... so parking is VERY difficult!  We luckily made our reservations within the 15min-past-your-reservation time frame.  It was pretty packed when we came in, but luckily, our table was waiting for us.  

We sat down, looked through our menus, and 10 min later our waitress appeared.  She took our order, but then instead of placing our order in, she went to ask 3 other tables what they wanted to order... NOT COOL.  Luckily, they didn't take too long ordering either.  

What got me a little annoyed about the service here was that the table next to us got served the tortillas and salsas before we did, even though they got seated 10 minutes after us.  I saw the waiter bring out 2 more batches of tortillas and salsas, but they all went to other tables who sat down after us.  SERIOUSLY??!  how unfair... I had to ask twice for the tortillas.  We eventually got the tortillas and salsa AFTER our appetizer came out.

The appetizer - tostadas with chicken were delicious!  The tostadas came out on 3 small fried tortillas with a mayonaise-like sauce and avocado on top of the chicken.  The chicken had lots of flavor and the creamy sauce went well with it.  I wish it came with more than 3 though!  I got the chile rellenos, which was recommended by our waitress.  I hate to be a complainer, but it did not live up to it's expectations.  There was barely enough cheese in it.. and that's usually the best part! It had lots of vegetables inside... but kind of lacked flavor.  It was just okay... My friend got the duck with green mole.  He LOVED it.  The duck was pretty tasty and went really well with the mole.  It was cooked nicely, but was almost on the side of overcooked.  All it came with was the duck, so he had to order some rice to go with it.  I wasn't a big fan of their rice... 

For tapas-style dishes, it's pretty pricey.  Chile rellenos was $12, duck was $18, the tostadas was $9, and rice $5.  When the bill came, our total came out to $15.75 (after the groupon was used).  Not too bad!  The food was pretty good, but the service was a little slow.  I probably would get other dishes if I ever came back here. I probably won't be back because it's not worth the price of their dishes.
author: Diane L.

description:
While I liked the decor and enjoyed the fabulous service I doubt I'll be back as I can get far better Mexican food for far less elsewhere.

My friend and I ordered the Tacos de Pescado "al pastor" (fish taco appetizer).  Honesty, I would have sent it back as I thought it tasted pretty bad if my friend hadn't thought it was okay.  Definitely not worth the $10.  We shared the Carne asada estilo Sonora (grilled steak) and the Camarones en Mole de Tamarindo (prawns), both were okay but the steak at $14 was a far better value than the five shrimp and 1/2 cup rice for $15.
author: Cristina S.

description: Had heard great things about this place and was disappointed as was our group. Perhaps it was because we went for brunch and not lunch or dinner? I had the eggs benedict and it was dry and lacked flavor. My buddy got a chile releno and wasn't pleased either. The guac was proly the highlight next to the bottomless mimosas.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Colibri was the perfect spot to have a very quiet mid afternoon lunch with a client I had in town today.

We loved the Quesadilla's, Tilapia Taco's, Sangria, and the mysterious dish that I pictured differently but was still delicious.

Staff was very accommodating, and just present enough to make sure we had everything we needed, but gave us plenty of room to talk business.

Small Plates, so I will be ready to eat again tonight!
author: Kevin G.

description: The first thing you notice when you walk in is the massive bar. And for good reason, the drinks are awesome! I started with a tequila flight and ended with the 1942 Don Julio--served in a champagne flute glass. The appetizers were great, especially noteworthy was the queso and chorizo, homemade tortillas, tostadas, fish tacos and guacamole. I'll definitely be back for another happy hour.
author: Marc P.

description:
I don't like to give five stars but it is hard to find something wrong with this place other than the fact that they didn't have a table available when we arrived at 6:30 on a Thursday night without a reservation.

Food:
The three of us had quite different dishes: duck breast, chile relleno, scallops.  I don't like chile relleno but it looked beautiful and the other two were delicious and well presented.  A clear preference for presentation and quality over quantity but not to the point that you would be starving.  Their menu is online and at $15-20 for most entrees, an evening won't eviscerate your wallet if you stick to one tequila (see below).

Service:
We sat at the bar and had a bartender that had an excellent hat and cheerfully answered questions about the tequilas and the food.  We asked him about the peppers he had standing by and he took the time to make a sample margarita with mashed jalapenos and talked about how the pepper brings out the sweetness in a new way.

Tequilas:
Tommy's is historically the place everyone would go to and I haven't been there but I thought Colibri was plenty good in selection and quality.  There are more than you can count--perhaps 120--and they are helpfully organized by the ordinal scale you're used to based on time in the oak barrel but they also divide them by the degree to which the barrels were charred.  I had one anjeo that was practically clear and another that was closer to amber-brown.  Both were great.  Perhaps the only thing one could complain about is that although most are in the $10-15 range--already pricey--the menu includes a few shots in the show-off $60 region and one at $120.  But if some guy wants to waste his money that's fine with me.

Location:
In a part of the tenderloin that was rough 10 years ago but is fine to walk to from BART, particularly if you walk up Powell to Geary.  I can't speak to parking but it seems like there are pay garages within a block.

Atmosphere:
Typical dark tones with big menagerie of bottles at the bar.  Big points for not having sports on.  The bartender actually said that they don't have cable--the night we were there he was playing black and white Lucha Libre movies.  (I wish yelp had a TV/no TV designation since TV makes it harder to concentrate on whom you are with.)

Overall: If you want to go to a place that favors quality over quantity without being too fussy this is an excellent choice.
author: Chris M.

description: Great drink selection. Guacamole was just okay for being prepared table-side and expensive.
author: J. C.

description:
San Francisco Nights... The servers at Colibri are exceptionally friendly, which added to the vacation feeling we had dining there on an exceptionally hot evening in downtown SF. Knowing we'd need several, we chose the slightly-less-than top drawer margaritas this time. They were tasty. 

For some reason I turned my nose up at the notion of guac. Rather, we had:

* Tostadas de Tinga
crisp golden hand made tortillas topped with stewed chicken, garnished with avocado and chipotle sour cream. This was super tasty but could have been spicier. I couldn't really taste the chipotles. I can understand them spicing it mildly in this neighborhood though.

* Frijoles Negros
black beans with epazote herb and chunks of way yummy soft white cheese. Good honest beans. Nice seasonings and the cheese was firm and fresh.

* Papas al Gratin
potatoes au gratin with poblano chile cream. Thinly sliced taters in a terrine with lots of cheese on top, these are the ultimate food for the soul. Not greasy, but what a wow with the green garlic sauce from the Pescado on them. You basically don't need anything else.

* Estofado
zucchini, corn kernels, mushrooms, onions and pasilla chile stew. Good roughage but the big dried red chilis are kind of a shock - these really shouldn't be swallowed but since they are tucked into the chop-mash they can be missed.

* Pescado del Día
Pan seared catch of the day served over a green garlic sauce with chorizo, sautéed green beans and chayote squash, topped with huitlacoche

On the Pescado (Opa), we had told the waiter my friend didn't eat red meat so the chorizo was substituted with some yummy chili oil drizzle. The green garlic sauce also had a hefty dash of cream. This sauce was among the best sauces I've ever tasted in my life. We sopped it up with nopales,  scraped it with our forks, dragged soft tortillas through it, spooned it on top of the Papas al Gratin and then our eyes pretty much rolled back in our heads. I have not had a dish this exceptional in a very long time.

The service was excellent - this is a fun place. It gets super pricey if you drink as many margaritas as you want to.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Excellent brunch on weekends. Good flavors and corn tortillas. Eat at the bar for more action to watch.
author: M M.

description:
The only reason I am giving them a 5 is because of the food.  We both had the carnita's and they were excellent as usual.  We had the guacamole which was very good, not sure why chips don't come with it.  The service wasn't really that great from the moment we walked in the hostess greeted us with a half smile and said it would be a 20 minute wait or we could eat at the bar, so we said no problem and sat down.  We then were asked if we wanted to move and she seated us at one of the 3 tables that were available.  The waitress made up for this but was also noticed other people annoyed that were sitting at the bar when both waiters were carrying on about personal stuff when everyone was waiting for drinks.  
The date we visited wasn't a busy one it was 930pm on Dec 22nd.
author: greg w.

description: Great food! Loved the guac and cornbread appetizers in particular. Margaritas were terrific. My only complaint was the service; rushed, didn't check back in in a timely way; missed one of the appetizers we ordered.
author: Linda L.

description: Stopped in for a quick afternoon snack. The quest fundido was perfect and the margaritas were very good. It was a great place to take a break after a day of shopping.
author: Foodie H.

description: This is a great Mexican bistro, but defiantly over priced!  The ambiance is nice and the service is good, but portions are small and pricey.  I do love the full bar and the food is delicious, though.  Maybe Happy Hour would be more reasonable?
author: Adrianne G.

description: Everything was amazing.  The food, the drink and especially the service.  My bartender anthony made great cocktails and was nice.  Kinda ugly but nice .  I had the chicken and almost cried; it was soooooooo good.  If you happen to be the area I would check this place out because all of the other  places near by are worse then eating my grandmas saddle bags
author: Neil T.

description: Solid upscale Mexican and tasty margs. Good place to hang out with friends in.
author: Faye L.

description:
I'm a fan of anything alcohol and bottomless...However...Their bottomless mimosas were like 99.9% OJ. A bit disappointed with that. And we asked twice for them to make it mostly Champagne but no dice.

The guacamole was too bland and we had to had some peppers, salt and lime to it make it manageable. Chorizo was okay but I've had way better in TX. Ceviche was mediocre but oh well.
author: Helen V.

description: I didn't have an incredibly easy time deciding from the menu options on dinner, but I was confident that whatever I chose would be tasty.  Wrong.  I got the cheese quesadilla and for $4 more, added chicken.  That was my mistake.  Three taco sized quesadillas with flavorless, fatty chicken meat.  They just boiled a bird, pulled off the meat, and slapped it in a tortilla and added some cheese and peppers - flavorless besides chicken fat.  Service was slow and they never asked how dinner was or how we were doing - this surprised me given the fact that two of the three of us at our table didn't even eat a third of our meal and picked all of the chicken off that we paid extra for.  Not a fan, bland food and bad service.  Don't understand the hype at all, could have saved money and gotten full by choosing another place.
author: Lynette L.

description:
The flavors were 3-4 star.  The service was a friendly 4 star. The portions were 2 star.   
  Started out with warm hand made soft tortillas with 3 salsas.  Great flavors and texture here.  We're off to a good start
  Tostada de Tinga... very tasty, but started out thinking small. Three silver dollar sized crispy tortillas covered with seasoned pulled chicken. 11.00 .  4 stars 
  Chicken Mole was 2 little chunks of chicken breast (maybe a total of 2-3 ounces) and a very small un-meaty leg, with a 2" ball of rice, mole sauce over the chicken, LARGE cilantro leaf ...18.00. They're getting a lot of miles out of one chicken breast or was that a Cornish game hen?  Save some of the salsas previously delivered with the tortillas to complement the so-so mole.  That was a nice touch. There was a lot of room on the small plate, especially after my first bite.  2.5 stars
  My wife ordered the pork stuffed Chili Relleno covered with a  black bean sauce, very tasty. ..18.00.  3 stars  That was all that was on her plate. Come on now...I'm beginning to see a trend here.
  There are inventive dishes on the menu and seemingly great ideas but we were looking for some more on the plate, especially for the price.  
  Churros Rellenos...  Four 4" long churros with a small scoop of tasty caramel/vanilla ice cream.  Caramel sauce drizzled over the dish. Lots of sweetness here and a nice combination.  This portion was about average. 3 stars
  This is not your normal kitchen chair Mexican restaurant.  Moderate décor, fit for a night out.  The flavors are very good.  But don't be surprised about the portions/cost ratio.  And watch out for the 13.00 spicy margarita, great flavor 3.5 stars, but 13.00??. 
  Colibri  can refer to a type of hummingbird.  I wonder.....is there a connection here?
author: The B.

description:
I went to Colibri with pretty high expectations after it was on my to eat list for quite a while.  In general i love mexican food (not the abominations known as mission burritos, but "real" mexican food).  In general their food was good, not great, but I left stuffed and fairly satisfied.  

First, their house margarita was great, a good balance of tequila and lime flavours, on the rocks (blended margarita = abomination).  The gaucamole was good, super spicy like we ordered it and the warm, fresh tortillas was very very good.  I also loved the elote corn bread  and the nopalitos and the sopes.  But everything else we ordered was good but not great, well prepared, cooked and presented, but i wasn't dying for more when I bit into the lamb shank, the mole, or the carnitas.  The Scallops were good, but i didn't enjoy my michelada, I thought it was supposed to have some hot sauce  or Maggi in it?  Maybe I'm wrong, but that's they way i like it.  Apparently, some at our table had some sub-par Mojitos, but i didn't try them.

Anyway, Colibri is pretty good for some Mexican and our service was very nice, but not sure if i would go out of my way to get back there.
author: Adrian L.

description:
I stopped by here the other night for a late night dinner with a few friends from out of town, my boyfriend and parents. It is looked in the Union Square area around where all the out of towners were staying.

We started with the guac - a must have - with warm tortillas. 

I split a mole poblano and panchuga ranchera with my boyfriend. The portions are tapas style so our original idea to split one plate resulted in ordering a second thing. Our server was very nice by getting it into the kitchen just in time for it to close! Luckily for us we loved the panchuga! The sauce ( a creamy, chili garlic sauce) was really great. The mole was ok but to me less special. 

The thing I didn't like is that they turned all the lights on at the end of the dinner because the restaurant was closing. We sat down 30 min before the kitchen was closing so I felt like we should have had a little time before being forced out. But it was a good food and good to know there is a good place in that area if I ever need a place to eat!
author: Katie W.

description:
Solid 3 to 4 star restaurant in SF..... We booked a reservation on opentable.com. 

We tried several dishes and drinks....

I enjoyed the stuffed chicken while my wife had the mole....

I really want to go back....
author: Joe B.

description:
Oh, Colibri. I've come here 4 or 5 times and never been disappointed. The chilaquiles are seriously the BEST I've ever had, and I've had a lot. I mean, come on, who doesn't want nachos for breakfast? The guacamole is out of this world, and I recommend that you go for spicy. Everything is just so perfectly seasoned... meat is perfectly tender, sauces are perfection, and they do something to black beans that makes them near orgasmic.

Service is quick, efficient, and kind. Basically, it's everything you want a restaurant to be. Go. Eat. Be happy. And save me some guac.
author: Miranda N.

description:
I will make this quick;


Good 
Bloody Mary (Maria)-good- spicy and made with tequila.

Bad
Service- slow and inattentive- not busy either
Food- not bad but not good- not really flavorful and my chilaquiles was loaded with chicken gristle ICK!
A little too animal friendly- watched a roach scurry up the wall

Should've gone to that sandwich place a couple doors down...
author: Cory R.

description:
Been here a few times and always a pleasant experience. The fresh guacamole is amazing. Waitress was on the spot every time. Knows the menu inside and out. 

Oh, and they make excellent Caiprinihas!
author: Jonathan C.

description: This place gets 5 stars for the amazing tequila selection alone. As much as I love Tequila, I would never claim to be an aficionado or expert. This list is was way over my head. But I'm no quitter, and I'll learn that list soon enough! The ambiance a tad on the upscale side of things for mexican cuisine and the food, as far as I could tell, was the real deal. I could eat avocados for the rest of my life and never tire and their guacamole prepared at table side was soooooo good! The fresh corn tortillas with the different dipping sauces were like crack. I really almost spoiled my meal before it even began. I had the Camarones en Mole de Tamarindo. Um um and ummmm!!! Was never really a fan of mole until trying it here and my only complaint about the corn cake was that there wasn't more of it. Can't Wait to go back here!
author: Shaunte J.

description:
I went to Colibri with my bf on our recent road trip to San Francisco and we were not deceived. Colibri serves all 100% agave tequila and their margaritas are made with fresh ingredients. I had a few of those.. YAY! 
Most Mexican places serve tortilla chips and salsa, but colibri gives you hand made warm soft tortillas with 3 sides.. the masa was GREAT.
We ordered the guacamole, which everyone has raved about ( I know!! it's so good isnt it ?? full of omega 3's!!) and we also ordered the Chicked Mole. Let me tel you that the mole was awesome. There was great depth in flavour.
This was definately a great experience and I hope to be back one day :)
Service was very good too, the margaritas kept coming and they always kept an eye ou
author: Sabrina S.

description: Excellent service and delicious food! Hands down one of the most enjoyable Brunch dining experiences in SF! The servers were extremely attentive and I seemingly never had an empty mimosa glass! It was great! The food was also superb, I recommend their "Queso Fundido." Definitely will be returning to dine soon to try their dinner menu.
author: Ella C.

description:
Great food, lively atmosphere and wonderful service. I love the fresh warm tortillas served with 3 scrumptous types of salsa. The main courses are so flavorful it's nearly impossible to pick just one.
Perfect place to go for drinks and tapas after the theatre.
author: Chantay B.

description: We went here on our last night in San Francisco.  The restaurant was busy but we were seated promptly.  The service staff was quick and sincere in wanting us to enjoy our meal.  We ordered several apps and each had a margarita.  Everything tasted great and arrived quickly.  My wife's drink had a fruit fly in it and when I pointed this out to our server he quickly replaced the drink.  We had a good time and would come back again.
author: Marcus M.

description:
After lounging around the Lyon St. Stairs, basking in the sun, shootin' the sh*t, and feeling oh-so-lazy on my lovely day off, I decided to get my butt in gear and do something productive.... like drink margaritas!

The bf and I meandered on down to Colibri and luckily strolled on in at the start of their happy hour (3:30-5:30 pm). Score! We ended up ordering a couple delicious margaritas on the rocks, Guacamole w/ hand made tortillas, and Tostadas de Tinga ($6).

The tortillas were truly satisfying- served piping hot and perfect for dipping into any of the 3 sauces that were served w/ them. The Tostadas de Tinga (crisp golden handmade tostaditas topped w/ stewed chicken garnished w/ avocado & chipotle sour cream) were a real treat. If I had room, I would've ordered another platter!

I wasn't sure if Colibri could live up to the Yelp hype, but they easily won me over w/ their attentive service and all around drool-worthy drinks & happy hour bites! What a way to round out my 'lax day!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
My wife and I came here for dinner a few nights ago after many friends and family members sang praises of Colibri.  With so many raving reviews, we decided to stop here to celebrate my wife's birthday.

The service was horrible and the food was full of flavor.  We arrived at 5 on a Sunday, and quickly noticed that there were more staff than there were customers.  We were pretty excited, thinking that there was no rush and that we could have a lovely meal together.

We started off with a pitcher of sangria and the tableside guac + chips.  The waiter brought out two glasses for our drinks, set them on the table with the pitcher, and walked away.  Really?  It's not like you're too busy to pour the drinks for us.  They'll even pour drinks for you at Chevy's.  :/  Then two people came to ask us how we wanted our guacamole.  Both times we said spicy, and it came out pre-made and had no heat at all.  I was not impressed, especially for the price.

For dinner, I ordered the pechuga ranchera, and my wife had the filet mignon.  My food was flavorful and delicious, but my wife's was only partially good.   She ordered her filet medium, and it came out red - almost purple.  Our waiter was nowhere to be found, so we were unable to let him know that there was a problem.  He finally came back with dessert menus, and I ordered the pudin de chocolate.  Before my wife could order her coffee, the waiter grabbed the menus and walked away.  Oooookay, looks like we'll find a cafe nearby.  The dessert was very light yet filling and I really enjoyed the touch of sea salt.

Overall, the service was terrible and it seemed almost like a burden that we were there.  I'm giving two stars instead of one because the food was pretty good when it was prepared correctly, and I'm sure the waiter was having an off day.  But he was a representation of the restaurant, and for that, we won't be returning.
author: James R.

description:
3.5

I will say their food is on point! Delicious food and my friends enjoyed every last bite. The Sangria was great as well. I think our server was annoyed at my friend who is quite loud when she has a drink or two in her system so I only really saw her when she took our order and handed the bill. The other helpful bussers did their thing. 

Although I am not, I repeat, NOT, blaming the restaurant... I did find it quite odd that our entire table woke up the next pretty ill. One broke out in hives, another with a slight fever, another with flu like symptoms, myself with a sore throat. It didn't help that I was going to Hawaii the next day.

But, I digress...

My favorite dishes included the Ceviche, the fresh guacamole, and the mushrooms and potato side dishes. Dessert was good... I'm not gonna lie, the Waitress knew we were celebrating my birthday because when I walked in all my girls screamed "HAPPY BIRTHDAY", but the extra mile didn't really go out there. Not that I was expecting a mariachi band to bombard me... but you know how other restaurants at least write "Happy Birthday" in chocolate syrup... that could've been nice...

I'm a bit reserved in going back just cause mentally in my brain I'm scared of getting sick and the location being the cause of it (I don't know.. the brain is funny), but I can't help it. I probably will head there when I have courage... the food was seriously that delicious.
author: Alyson C.

description: The service was very good.  The hand made corn tortillas were excellent and plentiful.  I had the mole poblano and it was very good.  My wife had the chile rellenos and while very good was stuffed with vegetables and cheese and she would have preferred the traditional.
author: Allan A.

description:
I have been to this place a handful of times and this one of the few places in the city that we would go back to (normally we try to go to new places). The food is always good, especially at lunch it's a good deal and I think the prices are pretty good.

Sometimes if you come in early (6is or so) on a Sat night, you can get one of their bar tables to sit at which is just fine, but reservations are normally needed. Drinks are good, queso is delish with the chorizo and the tortilla soup is a show being poured out of a black kettle. The sopas are really good, but I wouldn't order too much appetizer-wise as they bring several salsas and tortillas for snacking from the start.

I always get the carnitas but I've tried the filet mignon and prawns and they're good too. Must get the black beans for a side - best I've ever had. Cornbread was good, but not as good as expected.

Note, they have a sister restaurant at Santana Row, but it's not nearly as good.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Thinking about the guacamole, the drinks, the entrees and the atmosphere makes me want to go to Colibri everyday - well it's mostly the guacamole.

Freshly made, you can have your guacamole spicy or not. We ordered ours spicy and although they could have added a little more heat, nothing beats fresh guacamole...let me restate: nothing beats impeccably made, delicious tasting, fresh guacamole.

My boyfriend and I came here on a whim after researching good Mexican food in Union Square. The restaurant was small and they were willing to reseat us when we didn't like the original table. First thing we ordered were drinks and they were strong. I first ordered a mojito and he got a margarita. We didn't drink much, but my favorite drink was the Tequilito - it was a mojito-esque margarita with crushed mint leaves and tequila along with pomegranate flavoring. The 1.5 drinks I drank had me feeling good.

If you're into tequila, they have an entire bar wall of just tequilas -- all sorts, from all over the world.

For our entrees, I had stuffed chicken and he got the filet. The side dishes come a la carte, so we shared arroz, Mexican rice. 

After reading some reviews, people complained about the portions of the food, but I couldn't even finish my plate. Granted we had a few appetizers, but it was enough to fill me up.

The food was beautiful - everything about it. The way it was presented to the way it tasted, I wanted so bad to finish my dinner, but I also didn't want to pop.

The only downfall was the arroz was advertised as Mexican rice with vegetables -- it might as well have been out of a box. But, nevertheless, it tasted delicious.

Now, don't go here if you don't want to spend a good amount of money on dinner. Colibri is not cheap. But if you're looking for a good spot to eat with that special someone, or just a few good friends, might I recommend going to Colibri.
author: Kissie D.

description:
Contrary to all the great reviews.  I don't know what happened.  -maybe a new chef...

This place looks like it will be something good, for its location and swanky interiors.  Don't let that fool you.  Most all the dishes were disappointing except for the tortilla soup.  Everything is saucy, with a resident tang to it.  The best part was the salsa, guacamole dip, mixed at your table.  You get some nice tortillas with them.  (Chips would have been better.)  I ordered the Pozole Verde expecting soup as described.  It was anything but a soup and I was worried when it looked like a bowl of Kix. It was overloaded with hominy.  There was no soup and the fresh ingredients got lost in carb abyss.  The halibut wasn't any better.  It was sitting in a cheesy red oily sauce (supposedly chorizo sauce) on top of overcooked string beans.  The halibut had a sour taste to it and lacked much other flavor.  I don't remember what my friend ordered but it was at least mediocre.  She did like her tortilla soup though.  I wish I ordered that.

The only thing I was satisfied with is the guacamole dip, great service and margaritas.  This place is better for getting boozed up.  I will not be paying $16 for some overpriced, Mexican crap.  The ingredients do not taste fresh.  Everything is saucy and bland.  This place is blasphemous to good Mexican food.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I love being able to write a review when food is good and I hate to having to take some stars off because of service, but that is essentially what's gonna happen for the next couple of sentences.

Food was really good, we ordered the guac w/house made tortillas (yum-yummy), queso fundido (thank-you-sir-can-I-have-another), carnitas, sopas, chile relleno and some chicken dish with a delish cream sauce.  Oh, and yes the churros.....mmmmmm, and I don't even like desserts.

Too bad the service was really less than professional (code word for it sucked).   Granted they were busy but didn't seem totally slammed.  Our waitress was not at all attentive and food and drink service was really  slow.  Another thing, might have just been our table, but it's really loud here.

Here's a tip, if the kitchen is slammed and running slow, than make sure I get my drink chop-chop.  I'll forgive a lot of things when I've got a drink in my hand and I don't have to beg for a second one.

Sooooooo, 4 stars for food, minus 1 for service.  I wouldn't be opposed to going back, but there a slew of nuevo Mexican restaurants that get more things right.
author: Kim S.

description:
Good food! ...as you can already tell from the millions of reviews.  Service was nice and professional. And the drinks were tasty.  

My first time there though I bit into a piece of plastic that broke off from their food processor in my corn bread.  They gave us free dessert to make up for it... I totally should have faked a mouth injury and gotten the whole meal free. 

But I digress, this place is definitely good place for date night!  And make sure to save room for dessert, especially if its free!
author: Chris T.

description: Guacamole was delicious!  Strawberry basil margarita also outstanding.  Great dining experience.
author: Sherry E.

description: My friend and I went here in early January 2012 after an unsuccessful attempt to find a good open sushi restaurant near Union Square on a Sunday. We were pleasantly surprised! Great tequila selection and Negra Modelo on tap ;-)
author: Jessica J.

description: Creative and tasty, modern Mexican food. Good value for the Union Square neighborhood. I look forward to a return visit.
author: Gabe G.

description: My husband and I went here last minute and it was super crowded. We felt lucky to get a table. I liked the ambiance a lot - it was really well done.  It took the waiter awhile to get to us but that was fine. We ordered our drinks and waited and waited and waited. Our food came and still no drinks. He had forgotten. Okay, no problem. I ordered the chicken mole and the sauce was very thick and pretty bland considering what a mole can really taste like.  The chicken was overcooked and chewy. The portion wasn't very big at all and the rice reminded me of a rice packet you would get at the store. Thankfully I wasn't super hungry. The service was pretty slow so we ran out of time to order dessert but the people next to us got this amazing looking chocolate dessert with vanilla ice cream. However, I would definitely not go back.
author: Deanne A.

description:
I'm not too sure about this place. Went for lunch a few days ago and left with the thought "there's something missing". I think the issue was the greeter/hostess was so fabulous that after we were seated everything became an anticlimax. The waiter 'Dennis' seemed to be in a 'just wanna be somewhere else' mood. We ordered the guac which states "made fresh at your table" - it wasn't, and although delicious, it was delivered to the table already prepared. Main course was good but not great. I did order an 'off menu' margarita and it was fabulous. 

If it was not for the outstanding hostess and a perfect margarita I would have felt this place was a waste of time.
author: Bobby J.

description: This has quickly become a tradition for me and my fiancé when we visit San Francisco. We have now been here twice, and this most recent time we actually went out of our way to make sure we stopped in for a meal. The guacamole is just that good!! The quality of service matches the cuisine, and I would recommend this to anyone who has taste buds. Located near Union Square this is a great spot to grab a bite before going out for the night, or can provide a nice break from shopping.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I chose to come here based on the strong 4-star yelp rating and ended up being very disappointed.

Margueritas- meh, not worth $10.
Fish taco appetizer- overwhelmed by the pineapple chunks.
Duck- don't order this, it's nothing but a chunk of poorly cooked duck and a side of spaghetti!
Potato tortita- seemed pretty good actually.
Churros- awesome sweetness, came out piping hot with a scoop of ice cream, and there's enough to share!

Maybe I just ordered the wrong menu items, but for a 3-dollar sign restaurant I don't think it's too much to expect every item to be quality.
author: Mary P.

description:
I've been to Colibri twice in a couple of years and really enjoyed the food both times.  I'd probably go more often if it weren't a bit out of the way for me; I'm not in the Union Square area that much.

Don't expect a taqueria.  This is a white tablecloth restaurant and priced accordingly.  They have a lot of items that are not typical Mexican restaurant fare or are a twist on the usual.  For example, their chile relleno has  vegetables as well as cheese.  Last night I had a salad and the tostadas tinga as a light meal, and also tasted my friend's tortilla soup.  All were great.  Also great are the small, warm tortillas that are served with three kinds of salsa before the meal.  Everything is really fresh and flavorful.
author: Cindi L.

description: Worst service ever! First I sat 15 minutes at the bar without being greeted. Then I try to order a drink, guacamole and chips. The bartender tries to tell me the guacamole is huge and I should order something else (don't ever underestimate my ability to eat a bowl of guacamole). I order it anyways. Then his coworker friends sit down at the end of the bar and get the same thing. They bring them theirs first and then they bring me mine without chips. I sat there for another 5-7 minutes staring at my guacamole. Then chips grace the bar and they bring them over to the coworkers who looked confused and the bartender says no they are theirs and in another 5 mins I finally get mine. In the end I ate the entire bowl of guacamole and one out of the two batches of chips the bartender brought his coworker friends went untouched. What kind of service is this crap? At least I was a good server when I was in the industry. You people need to step your game up.
author: Brittany G.

description:
In all honesty, the margaritas were excellent and the food was good.  The waitress was not so attentive and I am low maintenance.  We had to keep flagging her down for more salsa, drinks etc..  
I will give it another try when we venture back into the city and will write another review!
author: Grace C.

description:
Chose this restaurant because of the good reviews and took 4 friends here before a play at the Curran (it is ideally located for that--right across the street). We were there for Sunday brunch but it was dreadful. 

The service was really bad. They brought our food one plate at a time with many minutes between deliveries so by the time the last plate came, all were cold including the plate just delivered. My food came last and was literally congealed: an enchilada that bore no resemblance to any I have seen. It looked like mess on the plate with sodden tortillas, near-frozen 1/2" slabs of cheese and cold, tasteless sauce. I had asked for a simple substitution of beef for chicken, which was "not possible." No service at all once food was brought...we refillled our own glasses from a pitcher, nobody came by to see if we wanted anything and when I asked the busperson to take my plate he refused and made us wait another 10 minutes. Took forever to get the bill.

No taste of wine in the Sangria. 

It was so noisy we couldn't hear ourselves talk let alone each other. 

When the bus staff picked up my plate, which had one bite taken from it, he made no comment, nor did a manager show up to ask me if something was wrong...a serious breech. If I hadn't been entertaining I would have requested it be removed from my bill.
author: Annie A.

description:
Tried Colibri for the first time last night thanks to recommendations from a foodie co-worker.  

Margaritas:  they were good and fresh w/ only pure ingredients which is much appreciated.  A bit too much lime for my personal taste.  Once the bartender adjusted the lime, it was quite good.

Tortilla - chips:  The complimentary tortillas w/ dips were surprisingly good and a healthier alternative to the standard tortilla chips.  Their chips, however, were nothing to write home about.  I'll drink $100 worth of margaritas if I have good chips and salsa in front of me.

Food:  Main dishes are really small portions.  I have never seen a chicken breast that small.  I mean, itsy bitsy.  We both thought that the food was just OK.  

I may return for a margarita at happy hour (which ends at 5:30pm), but many more places to try first.
author: Elaine G.

description:
For a destination location (and who actually lives in Union Sq?), Colibri is WAY over -rated.

We went for a friend's birthday, specifically having chosen Colibri because of the high reviews on this sight, thinking, "sounds like the best Mexican in the City."  Wrong.  In addition, the atmostphere is lacking, big time.  

Yes, if you are going to the theater and going to be in the area, Colibri could be a good choose for a quick pre show dinner and drink.  However, if you are looking to make an evening of it, as we were, going anywhere else.

The accoustics are terrible.  When crowded --and I suspect it always is given its location in heavy tourist area U.Sq. --the noise is so loud conversation across the table is almost impossible.  There were three of us, two sitting side by side and one across.  No chance of full table conversation.

The service was inattentive and when a waiter finally DID show up, pushy --"you aren't ready to order yet?"  Twice we had to go FIND a waiter when it was time to either clear the table or get a check.

As for the food:  The warm tortillas served with salsa --excellent.  Table side guac was nice.  However the salad was swimming in dressing --we left half of it.  The carnitas was dry and lacking in crusty outter that really MAKES good carnitas.

A pretty disappointing evening all around --and we drove in from east bay for that!  Donna Thomas in Oakland would have been a much better choice.
author: Dana T.

description:
I received free tickets to last night showing of Grease the Musical at Golden Gate Theater.  Hubby was none to excited to accompany me so I thought some good food and drink might make a cheesy musical go down a little easier.  We found Colibri on Yelp and decided to give it a shot.  What a great choice!

We wanted to make it quick so we asked to sit at the bar and found seats quickly at around 6:15p.  We ordered a Dos XX Amber from tap and the featured monthly margarita with a tequila I don't remember.  The margaritas are a little pricy, but really strong. What impressed me the most was all the fresh ingredients the bartenders used.  I can't remember the last time I sat at a bar and watched a bartender squeeze every last drop from a grapefruit for a Grey Goose and grapefruit cocktail.  You won't find prepackaged juices here.  We also happened to stumble in on a tequila representative looking to sell his new company's new tequila to the team of bartenders.  They were doing a tasting and quickly offered the groups at the bar a shot of each of the three tequilas.  

We ordered off the the full menu: ceviche, sopes, and carnitas.  I liked that the menu starred items that were quick prep tapas, it was great for us who needed to get to a show.  The ceviche was the highlight of the meal.  Tender white fish, cured to perfection served with tortilla chips.  The sopes offered great flavor and variety.  The reconstructed carnitas, served sliced instead of shredded with salsa on the side, was moist and tender while still offering a little bit of crispiness around the edges.  It was  perfect with the homemade tortillas and trio of salsas.  

If in the Union Square, I would definitely consider Colibri again.
author: Kelly I.

description:
Must rsvp and arrive with the mindset to share; it's tapas style here. Tasty yet pricey, small servings. 

I was in trouble when I bit into the guacamole and plentiful steamy, homemade tortillas. So divine, I asked for more!

Fish of the day was mahi-mahi (my order). Other members at my table ordered the camarones, scallops, and carnitas. Everybody was pleased. Odd service. My friend's carnitas was served first, followed by the tortilla soup. And good thing we reminded them to bring out the black beans -- they forgot! 

But the desserts saved the day -- coffee flan and caramel drizzed churros with a side of dulce de leche ice cream. Licking my lips just thinking about it...!
author: Celeste P.

description: I was so disappointed with Colibri, I can't even begin to describe it. I came a couple of years ago and had a good impression then, so much so that I wanted to come here on this visit. Sadly it was not what I was expecting. The food on itself was not bad, but the service and the whole experience left a lot to desire for. The portions were not that generous and we ended up having to prod the hosts to come ant take out order. We also we had to wait a long time between courses... All in all, I would give this place a miss.
author: J R.

description: My friend brought me here for lunch all the way from Hayward and it was totally worth the drive.  Everything was delicious and the drinks from the bar were fantastic.  My only complaint is that it is a little pricey for Mexican food.  But great ambiance and service.  I returned a few weeks later with some friends who also loved it.  It's very unique for a Mexican restaurant.  Definitely a Mexican Bistro!
author: Alexa O.

description: The place is a little pricey, but the food is really, really good. Drinks are nothing out of this wolrd, but they aren't bad either. The place is quite nice but it gets a little noisy when busy.
author: Jorge A.

description:
This is a decent spot to get a bite before heading to the theater across the street. I do think this is over-priced. Perhaps their drinks are worth the price but everything else is like "Seriously?" 

Their mole negro was a disappointment. It's not the real thing. Not even close. The sauce was too pudgy and the chocolate is not the key player and it didn't melt in your mouth with a spicy warmth. If you want the real omg-this-is-heaven mole negro ... head to La Oaxacaneque in the Mission. They get it right EVERY SINGLE TIME! 

I did like their scallops and their fish tacos. Again, overpriced (especially when considering their fancy small portions), but they did them just right with the right amount of roasting and et cetera. Their guacamole was SERIOUSLY good. Truly fresh without any funny fillers and they made them fresh on the spot.
author: Pamela L.

description: I love this place! I have been going to the restaurant for over three years. I always end up getting their carnitas. They are well seasoned and very tender. It's about fourteen dollars but they are worth it.  Their guacamole is to die for as well, it's my second favorite dish. They even make it in front of you. Not to mention their large selection of tequilas and all kinds of different margaritas.  The staff is always friendly and they remember us by name.  A great place to take your boss to eat.
author: Jenna T.

description: This was hands down the best Mexican food I have had in No. cal.  Great service, terrific food.  A bit pricey and portions are modest but all fresh and delish.  We value quality over quantity so we ordered more dishes and kept smiling.  My hubby and kids had e tres tacos plate - all yummy.  My daughter and son had the quesadillas, authentic handmade tortilla with thick cheese.  Don't miss the hand-smashed guacamole with homemade tortillas and three types of salsas.  I had chicken enchilada with green and red sauces.  We all had dessert, loved the chocolate cake and the churros (filled with Carmel and with a size of cinnamon ice-cream) if we had had any room in our stuffed tummies, we would have added the mango creme brûlée.  Park under Union Square and walk the few blocks down for easy access.
author: Tee M.

description:
Wound up having a late lunch/early dinner here on Saturday. I was sleeping in late that day and had literally been dreaming of super tasty Mexican food. I was just about to take a luscious bite of a dream-quality jumbo shrimp taco and wash it down with a frosty margarita when the BF woke me up rather abruptly. Yeah. So in a groggy, semi-grumpy, definitely hungry state we headed to Colibri.

Atmosphere - Woody, warm, masculine, rustic wrought iron chandeliers with golden light, huge mirrored back bar, some padded booths. Overall an inviting, welcoming space off of the Hotel Diva. 

Service - Very friendly, efficient and responsive. 

Food - Colibri's menu is a bit like Mexico meets Carmel. I personally prefer my Mexican food straightforward without the diamond studs, but that's just me. Excellent guacamole served in a huge iron pot that first gives the impression it would serve 5 or 6 people. That's until you swipe a chip in it and realize it is 1/4 of an inch deep. Ah - the magic of illusionist serving dishes. No problem though, plenty for two. However, I must backtrack. I mentioned swiping a chip in the guacamole. Yes. Well, the guacamole is $10. If you want chips, they will cost you an additional $5. 

I just saw a star fall from the sky. 

Yes, tortillas come with the guacamole and they are lovely. That is terrific. But I like chips with guacamole. Chips are made out of tortillas. The tortillas are free and the chips cost $5. This is silly.

Moving on. BF had the Carnitas. The chunks of pork were juicy and flavorful. I had the Tostadas de Tinga - tiny tortillas topped with stewed chicken, garnished with avocado and chipotle sour cream. Delicious. The side salsas and mole were also very good. 

Drinks - Colibiri offers an extensive specialty margarita list as well as tequila flights. We went for the house margaritas which were refreshing and good, but not outstanding. 

Overall, Colibiri would have easily gotten 4 stars from me were it not for the silly $5 basket of chips. It's a detail I realize, but it shows a certain lack of judgment. The prices here are on the upper end of the scale for Mexican food. Chips are dirt cheap. Especially wholesale. Most customers will probably be completely happy with tortillas. But if someone happens to want some chips with their $10 serving of guacamole...do the math Colibiri. Slip em some free salty chips. They'll get thirstier and drink more expensive margaritas. Then I could truly say olé.
author: wendella a.

description:
This place was a nice little find. I came up to the city to meet with a friend that was in town for work and I don't know the Union Square area very well so we just happened to stumble upon it and it worked out quite nicely. 

I have to give the owners props on whoever decorated because it felt very warm and vibrant thanks to the mexican-styled dining space. I ended up having the Chamorro de Cordero (lamb shank marinated in a paste of Muscat wine and spices, wrapped in banana leaves and steamed to perfection) and it was fantastic! Also, the margaritas were strong and they don't do any of those fake slushy kinds either. The highlight of the meal though was our appetizer of chips, tortillas and guacamole because one of the waiters came out with a gigantic tray of ingredients then asked how spicy we wanted the guacamole and made it right there in front of us. I have a thing for guacamole so this was quite a treat.

The service was prompt, courteous and accommodating so I was definitely pleased. I'll definitely be back after building up an appetite after a day of shopping around Union Square ;)
author: Edison C.

description:
Such a fun & lively atmosphere as it's freezing these days!  The service was great.  Food/drinks were off the hook.  Hunny and I ordered the guac (damn.  I mean, DAYAMN.)  I got the scallops for my entree, and he got the beef (filet?).  So good.  My fat a** just wishes there were of the entree. (To their credit, they do warn you that they're tapas-style, just that I'm greedy.  That's all.)

Seriously, I had trouble moving afterwards... I ate so much.  Can't wait to return...
author: Doreen S.

description:
Excellent food, *authentic* mexican. Don't expect just boring chips for starters, they have killer corn tortillas with 3 different sauces, incredible guacamole made at your table.

Every time I visit San Francisco for business trips I make sure that I go here during the trip.

Their desserts are amazing too.

Their margaritas a great, but a little over priced, but other than this, it doesn't get any better!
author: Justin E.

description: Great food, fast & friendly service, at a reasonable price.  There were several options on the menu I wanted to try.  The tortillas were fresh, hot, and exceptional.
author: Jay W.

description:
In my mind this place used to be a solid 4, now its a 3.5 and I rounded down (sorry). I recommend trying it out for yourself, but I just was't feeling it on my last visit. It wasn't bad, just mediocre. The drinks used to be larger; but with a recession comes cut backs, so i wont fault there. The food just seemed ok. The chicken mole was decent; just not jaw dropping. The duck "green-mole" was fantastic but could have included more of a side to compliment (as did the chicken). The tacos appetizer was small but good.

Maybe I just wasn't feeling the atmosphere.  The groupon helped...
author: Morgan A.

description:
agree with the last two 5 star reviews!!!! 
This is the best authentic Mexican restaurant in SF.   Great to see fresh hand made tortillas being offered instead of the typical chips, and I tell you, those tortillas are better than the ones that i have tried in Mexico!!!!
The pechuga Huitclacoche (sp?) we had tonight was one of the most delicious combination of flavors that we have had in a long time!  The crepas con cajeta for dessert were also amazing.
Last but not least the margaritas are absolutely perfect.  Strong but with a great citrus taste.  i had three and could have kept going.
The service is amazing as well.    Thanks for such a great dinner experience!!!!  Keep it up.
author: Emi C.

description: We made reservations here a month prior to our trip, even giving our credit card number for 8 people. On the day of our previously booked dinner they claim there was no reservation. We spoke with the manager who basically was unwilling to accommodate and was entirely unprofessional during this unfortunate encounter. Less than one star for horrible service.
author: Leslie C.

description: This place is bomb, the portions aren't huge but the flavors are, well worth it.  I will also add that the median entree price is like 20$, so not too sure about the two dollar signs on the price but that's just me
author: Lander Y.

description:
I'm too full to write filler.

tortillas- Corn. Good.

guacamole- Best ever.

jicama salad- Too chunky.  Not enough dressing/juice.

queso fundido- Melted cheese + sausage + mushrooms  = nom.

mushrooms with garlic- Fantastic.  You must try them.

mole shrimp- Shrimp were great.  Mole was too tangy.

filet mignon- Small but good.  Tasty mashed potatoes.

torta de elote- Corn bread. The sauce tasted bitter/spicy.  There was no other flavor.

tres leches cake- Loved it.  Large, rustic crumb.  Not too sweet.

I'd come more often if not for the $$$.

Sleep now.
author: Lauren C.

description:
eeeehhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh
EEEEEEHHHHHHHHHHH

that is my overall opinion of Colibri.
Sorry Colibri
I really want to love you, I really really do. There are some really awesome things about you, like your really expensive tequila which I will never be able to afford to drink, and the fact that you give fresh hot tortillas with your guac instead of chips. I also appreciate your "friends on facebook" specials. 
Now to be fair, my dear Colibi, I am not judging you on one experience alone. I have had dinner and brunch twice each before making my final call on your star rating. Now I feel like I could go on and on with little critiques but I dont think its necessary. I think that the overall problem with this place is that its a chain. Yes, its true, it is indeed a chain. Except I think that the guy that owns it tries to cover this fact up by naming the other restaurant a different name, Consuelo in Santana Row, but the menu is exactly the same. Now...I also heard....although I dont know if its true or not, that the person who owns Consuelo also owns a lot of the other restaurants at Santana Row, which for those of you not in the know, is a super bougie richie bitchie area of San Jose. I guess the result of all of this is there is NO love in the food (honestly I found all the dishes I tried to be mediocre, bland, and only luke warm), and NO creativity in the menu.

Colibri! Please take some advice. Fix up the menu and learn to serve HOT food.
author: Yuliya R.

description:
Hello Deliciousness, where have you been all my SF Union square days?

{disclaimer: I am writing this still a bit lit from the drinks.... but is that such a bad thing? I think not.}

Big portions of super flavorful, garlic filled food. Super amazing tasty guacamole and LOTS OF IT. My biggest pet peeve with bistro, gourmet, boutique dining is that the bites are wonderful but the portions small.... not the case with Colibri. This is a fantastic place to dine that will leave you super full and with an aroma of cilantro and onions....which makes me want to eat myself even now. what? the booze are speaking to me again.

We got the Guac.... Tortilla Soup (hellz to the yeah, it's veggie dame's)...fish tacos and quesadilla.... the queso was not memorable, but the fish taco's were off the charts.. the fresh mango with the fish seasoning was perfection. 

yum yum yum. Great ambiance, and on a rainy monday night, the live music really made it feel like Friday night. I'll def be back again. show some love.
author: K B.

description:
El Jardin on Santana Row boasts that its selection of 240 tequila varieties is the largest in Northern California.  Well, I counted, and this restaurant has 300 and last time I checked San Francisco was in Northern California too.  Not to mention that you can do a "sampler", consisting of a trifecta of three different tequila shots, one "blanco" (aged less than 2 months), one "reposado" (2 months to a year) and one "anejo" (aged over a year, sometimes up to 10 years).  If you love ta-kill-ya, this is the place for you.  

Take that notion a step further: if you love ta-kill-ya, have fond recent memories of getting blasted on the junk in Cabo and Mazatlan, and want to recreate those memories in a desperate somewhat pathetic attempt to cling to the past, this is *really* the place for you (the main difference being that this trendy tapas restaurant is clean and you can safely drink the water).  

The ambiance here is warm, robust and masculine.  Lots of low, amber lighting, dark tile flooring, hardwood tables and leather.  Great service; they're attentive and provide useful information about tequila, helping steer you toward your selection.

Definitely don't miss the amazing homemade guacamole, prepared table-side, with fresh homemade flour tortillas and a collection of salsas and hot sauces. We roll into ensalada romana made with fresh, crisp lettuce and a variety of other goodies.  On to tapas, including a very fine mole poblano (chicken), and an impressive filet mignon which was tender, juicy and flavorful and came topped with a warm mound of sharp bleu cheese.  The menu is expansive, with a wide-ranging selection of other dishes as well.

The overall experience is much more substantial and pleasing than fellow trendy nouveau Mexican tapas joint Mamacita on Chestnut.
author: Rick H.

description:
Good food, nice atmosphere. Didn't realize it's across the street from ACT so we had to deal with theatre parking issues. Best dish by far was the cerviche. Enough to be a meal by itself.

But, be sure to ask for a table in the back. Lots more room and much quieter than the front of the restaurant.
author: Elan W.

description:
It's a classic tale. Caveman 1 [CM1] and Cavewoman [CW] meet, give each other eskimo kisses [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eskimo_kissing], and fall in love. Caveman 2 [CM2] wants CW for himself, and basically drags her back to his cave by the hair after knocking her out with his club. CM1, luckily, is good pals with the dinosaurs, and they help him out. They send a boulder flying at CM2, and he's knocked out. CM1 goes in to rescue CW. CW's town cheers for CM1. They give each other eskimo kisses, get married and live happily ever after...

Seated at the bar, my companion and I look up to find this B&W film about cave men and women on the screen between the shelves of tequila. The volume is turned down, so it is uncertain whether or not the film is in English. Doesn't matter though. We can tell what's going on. In fact, we add our own dialogue for each of the characters. 

Several glasses of sangria have sparked our creativity.

We only stopped by for drinks, appetizers, and catch-up time. Between two, a pitcher of sangria, an order of their freshly-made guacamole, and ceviche [a little watery]. Warm tortillas wrapped around guac, ceviche, and a little mango salsa all mixed together? Certainly hit the spot and a little bit more.

Note: Chips are a side order for $5.
author: Tinna H.

description:
UPDATE:

Tapas, n., the rationalization of high prices for small servings.
Ex.
"Dude, they don't give you any food here..."
"Dude, that's because it's 'tapas style...'"
"... ... Dude, they, like, give you SO much food here..."

Okay, I'll admit that the first time I went to Colibri, I was a little intoxicated and had no idea it was tapas until I wrote the review below. Now that I know, the small servings and high prices are okay because it's cool to eat tapas, right? Kidding... Don't get your tapas-loving panties in a bunch... This is uber-quality with some quantity.

-Guacamole ($9), made fresh at the table. They give you a lot, and despite the freshnessocity of the tortillas, they will give you more for free. So good, I invented a word for it.
-Filet ($14), really tender.
-Mexican Rice ($4), really Mexican, and pretty ricey.
-Ceviche ($16), could have gone without it. The watery kind.
-Sangria ($6/glass, $18/pitcher), girly, but too good to care.

Friday evening. Placed a res through opentable, but found it wasn't necessary. I walked in 15 min. early and saw my name at the top of their computer. I requested a table away from traffic, and they readily provided. Really great service.

 I will be back for more guac. Mark my words, Colibri! 

--------------------------------------------------------------

HAHahahAHHhaahaa

I'm laughing because I was just Punk'd: two small pieces of chicken breast and half a drumstick with sauce for $10?!

hahaAHAHahaAHahhaaahhahaa

so friggin hilarious...

Luckily, I just came from Biscuits & Blues (http://www.yelp.com/biz/8oe2cvC0vlQ0DC7Mc_mOjw) and was too inebriated to care about price. (Are you listening restaurateurs? Serve free alcohol as an appetizer to boost your sales...)

$10 for the Mole Poblano, mentioned above. (At least that's the price from the website... I could have sworn it was $11, but I digress.) During lunch, it's only $9 and it comes with rice. During dinner, it's tapas time, which means you lose the rice, pay a dollar more, and get to pretend you're all the more hip. 

I ordered the Poblano with a plate of cornbread ($4), served in it's own sauce. Very good, though also small. Don't get me wrong, the quality is all there. They are both delicious. It's just too tiny for the price and my lardo-Americano standards. 

I was so tempted to try some tequila, but figured I would need enough sobriety to eventually leave the restaurant...
author: Keane L.

description:
A stand-up decent Mexican restaurant a stone's throw away from Union Square in an unassuming space directly across from the Curran Theater. Completely different than what I had expected, based off of reviews on Yelp and the restaurant's website, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.

Pay careful attention to the final word of this review, because despite my criticisms preceeding it, there's a reason this place gets four stars.

WHAT I HAD EXPECTED: Service will take foreverrrrr and oh wow, is the wait longggggg and the food is SO not worth it.
WHAT WENT DOWN: I was going to see a show at the Curran at 8 pm. I made the reservation for 6 pm. Got there early and sat down at 5:45 pm because there was NO WAIT on a Thursday. We were done with our meal and out the door by 7 pm. This gave us ample time to flit about Geary and look in all the historic old hotels and play Tourist.

WHAT I HAD EXPECTED: Best guacamole in the city, it's beyond compare, and can you believe it - they make it right next to your table!
WHAT WENT DOWN: The extent of "customization" is them asking how hot you want the guacamole. Also, I didn't see them make it table side because they did it behind me. What's the point of doing it table side if only one member of the party can see how it's done? And no, it does not have the best guac in the city. That honor is still reserved for Mamacita in -gasp!- the Marina.

WHAT I HAD EXPECTED: Classy decor, upscale layout.
WHAT WENT DOWN: I can't be the only one who thinks this place looks like a spruced up El Torito, right?

WHAT I HAD EXPECTED: Run for the hills! Pricey like none other!
WHAT WENT DOWN: $100 for two people + drinks. Not bad at all. 

WHAT I HAD EXPECTED: Bistro-style food that will be artfully arranged and therefore probably dainty so I should probably load up on appetizers.
WHAT WENT DOWN: My best friend as a kid was Mexican, and whenever I would go over to her house, her mom would make the BEST dishes. They were reminiscent of what I would order at the local Mexican joint, but more flavorful and comfort-foodish. 

I ordered the Pechuga Ranchera - a delicious meal of chicken, potatoes, and spinach. In a single bite, Colibri transported me back to being seven years old and eating at my friend's dinner table. Wow.
author: Devon S.

description:
I'm not convinced that the best things in life are free--after all, dining out and traveling the world leaves me with little except money for laundry--but I am convinced the best thing at Colibri won't cost you a damn thing: The incredibly fresh, piping hot corn tortillas.

Everything else... you can pass on and be able to sleep at night--I promise. My friend and I came for lunch and our server told us the portions were small and we should order a lot. We got the Tacos de Pescado "al pastor" ($10), Mole Poblano ($13), and Carnitas ($14). Holy Mary Mother of Jesus, this was a lot of food! Did the server think we were whales or something? I felt like I had to go shopping for a new pair of jeans after this.

Anyway, nothing blew me away. I don't usually eat tilapia because it's a bottom feeder fish, but the tilapia taco wasn't bad when I wasn't picturing the fish scavenging. Haha. The chocolate chicken was different and decent--I like to separate my meat and dessert, though. The marinated pork was definitely my favorite of the three--it was tender, flavorful, and delicious. Not something I'd go out of my way for, but something I wouldn't mind engaging with if it was in front of me. Like a B-list celebrity at an A-list event. Hahaha.

My search for amazing tapas continues...
author: Liz T.

description: The cuisine is very close to authentic. The service is a bit slow... but efficient the decor was wonderful and reminded me of an old  "hacienda". Two words Bottomless Mimosas for Sunday Brunch more like 5 words.... But overall ok.
author: Julio S.

description:
Um.... This place sucks. The only things I liked menu wise was the guacamole and the drinks. Their tequila concoctions were GREAT. And the guacamole was fresh and I like that they ask you how spicy you want it, cause typically, I'd like to have spicy guacamole, but usually, it never is. 

Otherwise, there wasn't a single thing that I ate that was pleasing to my palate. Maybe the cheesy potatoes gratin, but that isn't really mexican now is it?!
author: Jen D.

description: My husband and our kids ate here because my husband swore it was the best guacamole that I will ever have, which it was! He was a little disappointed because he remembered them making it fresh at the table and they did not do that for us, but it was still delicious! It was difficult with the seating due to the fact we had our 3 month old with us and the walking area between the bar and booths is very narrow. The food was ok, my husband had the tostadas and I had the prawns. He loved his plate but I felt my prawns were on the smaller side and overpriced for only getting 5. Our waitress was wonderful but the front staff was not as friendly.  You would think they should at least smile and greet a customer when they walk in.
author: Allison M.

description:
I'm not familiar with the food, as I only visited this place to fulfill my after-work drink cravings.  
I ordered the Sangria, which was good, but a little heavy on sugar and a little light on alcohol.
Boyfriend got the most expensive Margarita, laden with aged tequila, herbs and lime.  Very good and definitely worth it.
author: Christine M.

description:
Fancy mexican food in Union Square!  

Guacamole rocks.  Salsa's and tortilla's rock.  Impressive tequila menu, and great margarita's.

I've eaten at Colibri a few times now and each time it's the same good consistent experience.  It's fancy mexican food but the place is warm, fun and not stuffy at all.  The service is extremely friendly and personable.  

Last night we ordered the guacamole (which you should do always because it's made to order and is the best outside of making your own), a scallop dish, and a spicy mole shrimp dish with a corn cake.  Everything was melt in your mouth, "oh my goodness taste this!" good!
