A little overpriced for the portions but the food is excellent so that can be overlooked, and it is Union Square.  We walked in at 7:45 without reservations and got seated immediately.  Nice.
author: James M.

description:
I am a huuuuuge fan of Mexican food, especially when it borrows elements and properties of Oaxacan cuisine and this is the perfect example of this fusion! Fried cheese with pork, Fried cheese with mushrooms, shrimp in a thick and deelish mole sauce, sangria, stuffed poblano cheeeelaaays, stuffed chicken and guac they make right at the table that is hands down some of the yummiest I've ever had...well, besides my homemade version of course!

The place is also super cute and cozy and not so loud that you can't hear each other talk. We went as a big group tonight and squeezed into one of the back booths and it was really comfy and super fun. So if you like your food authentic and are in the mood for a taste bud treat, then go to Colibri!

Mmm mmmm!! :)
!
author: Stephy S.

description:
For all of those who think Mexicans only eat burritos and salsa, think again...This is not your Tex-Mex or your burritos kind of joint...it's an authentic Mexican restaurant serving meals only a Mexican native can muster!

Guacamole being whipped table side like a magician doing tricks...

Tortillas warmed to perfection and bottomless.  

Tequila so strong you get tipsy purely by the smell.

My three fave dishes are 

1. Pechuga Rellena de Huitlacoche  - chicken breast smothered in a creamy guajillo chile sauce, over mashed potatoes with sautéed spinach and garlic. 

2. Chile Relleno - fire-roasted poblano chile stuffed with vegetables and cheese, over a black bean sauce

3. Cactus leaves 

The only gripe I have is the waitstaff don't do a good job in re-filling your water glass..
 
Apart from that, all the food is scrumptious and with a name that means Hummingbird - All I can say is - Colibri - "Te Adoro".
author: Karyna K.

description:
Finally got around to having a proper meal at Colibri, and I have to admit all of these Yelp reviews are right on. Colibri deserves to be as packed as it is, I think almost every night.

Make a reservation to go, but even then you might wait a little for your table. Don't sweat it, have a margarita at the happening bar.

When you do make it to your seat, start off with the freshly made guacamole, served with piping hot tortillas. 

You can't really go wrong with the menu, and they recommend ordering as small shared plates. Some of the dishes we tried, and would easily order again, included the salmon tacos, jicama salad, mole poblano, and sauteed prawns. I'd also recommend the fish of the day, and make sure to order a few sides of Mexican rice as well.

If you can, try and secure one of the rounded booths, perfect for a party of 4-6, and I think Colibri functions best as a group dining option.

Our servers were also great, very friendly and efficient, but also great about recommending dishes as well.

I'm looking forward to my next visit, and I hear that they serve a mean weekend brunch to boot.
author: Nish N.

description:
Note to managers:

TRAIN YOUR STAFF. Providing a quality dining/drinking experience is an honorable profession that requires skill and finesse and an intuitive anticipation of the client's needs.  Please pass this information along.

You may actually want to sell drinks - one way to facilitate this would be to teach your waiters to clear empty glasses and - this might sound nutty - but ASK their tables if they'd like more.  Also, since I'm guessing you mainly serve margaritas it would be helpful for the staff to ask the pertinent questions (i.e. any particular type of tequila, salted rim, rocks or up - ya know, the usual) before bounding away.

When people join the table (and the new people have to ask for drinks, for a menu, etc.) you should probably bring silverware and plates so that when their order arrives they can eat it.

I only had the salmon tacos (tortillas were great - the rest was bland) and would have ordered more if only given the chance.  I can't enjoy my food if I'm constantly looking for a server.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description:
Location: 5 Stars + Food:2 Stars = 3 Stars overall?

The best thing about this restaurant is definitely the location. Easy access to ACT Theater, Union Square, etc.  In addition, the service was fast and the waiter certainly knew her stuff.

Unfortunately, my dining partner (who lived for many years in Central and South America) and I found the food to be rather bland and uninteresting.  We started off with the guacamole appetizer which we ordered "spicy", and it was as bland as bland can be.  I'd hate to try the medium or mild!  The main dishes were also rather plain, although our desserts were good.

Also, it seemed quite pricey for what we received.  Maybe not surprising given the location, but I'd rather spend that money on food that I really enjoy!

While the service was excellent and the atmosphere lively, it is not a place that we will return to.
author: Peter S.

description:
This place is amazing! We went there on a Friday afternoon for a late lunch. It was a great escape from the hustle and bustle of Union Square. The place is decked out really well. We were promptly seated, and the wait staff was very attentive to our needs. The most amazing thing, however was the food. It definitely has amazing flavor. My favorite dishes were the Camarones con Chorizo and the mini Tostadas. The margaritas definitely hit the spot. The house margarita is nice and tart, as opposed to the overly sweet ones. My friend ordered the mango margarita, and it was just as amazing. Props to them on that. We finished off with some coffee flavored flan...once again, it did not disappoint. I loved the food there. 

The place is very well laid out, and perfect for a date or a small group up to 4 people. Anything larger, and it might get a little cramped. I definitely suggest you check it out and see for yourself. I have already planned to go back next Friday.
author: Samir P.

description:
How have I NOT written a review of Colibri?  Was it my subconcious way of trying not to share the wonderful-ness of this restaurant in the hopes that it doesn't become too popular and more crowded than it now is?

But to be selfless, let me share:  ALWAYS get the guacamole.  Before anything else, even drinks.  You will not regret it ever.  I've only had margarita's here, and they have a fun variety of margarita's to try and made perfectly.  The food is fantastic.  Carnita's are always perfectly cooked, not dry at all, perfect seasoning and flavor.  The ceviche is fresh and for an appetizer, quite filling as a meal (well, with the guacamole of course).  The tacos are perfect.  You can't go wrong with Colibri.  

Plus, do what my friends and I have done:  start the night with cocktails and dinner at Colibri, and then head down Geary to Rye or the Ambassador to keep the night going!
author: Ria D.

description:
Hmmm.  Colibri is kind of hard to figure out.  I can easily see it as a three star or five star place, depending on the reviewer.  For our meal last night, four stars seems about right.
The food was solid but not spectacular (the guac made table side was definitely a stand out, as were the homemade tortillas served with it)  Drinks were good, not great-I expected more out of my $9 margarita.  Service was friendly...our waitress was great with suggestions and the pacing of the meal was spot on.
Overall?  I'd gladly dine at Colibri again but don't think I'll be rushing back.
author: phil h.

description:
I never really thought about eating here until I saw my favorite Mexi-Can's review.  He said there were some things here that you couldn't get anywhere else in the Bay Area so I was intrigued, plus Mexican food in NYC is terrible so I thought I should have it before I go.   It also ended up being a continuation of my third wheel dinner tour of SF as I met up with one of my favorite couples.  

We had: guacamole, tostadas de tinga, tamales oaxaquenos, duck, lamb, carnitas, corn bread and potatoes.  It was a lot of food and we didn't finish most of it, mostly because there was either a strange flavor or no favor at all in almost eveyrthing except for the carnitas and the sides.

I have to admit the tequila drinks were quite tasty even though tequila is really not my friend and the service was excellent. 

We had an interesting conversation over a 3 hour meal about that which is a part of us but does not define us, boys and girls, scooter rides through the scary parts of town and whether I am going to come back from NYC married.  Are you crazy?  If I get married out there, why would I come back here?
author: Seong P.

description: Sunday, January 23, 2011, 7:30 pm. Whoever the Hostess was, she is rude. She would not seat me at a table for two because I was by myself. She led me to an awkward seat at the end of the bar which had stuff all over it and no room for eating. She just walked away. I followed after her and told her the spot was unacceptable. She just shrugged her shoulders. No apology. Nothing. I walked by there 15 minutes later and the're were many empty tables. They lost the $50 I usually spend. Never again. I will no longer refer people there from my place of business. Screw you Colibri.
author: Phil O.

description:
First of all, I was drawn to the restaurant simply because I liked the sign.  Great design!   I am one of those people that will purchase something from a store if they have cute shopping bags.  So as far as the atmosphere, it was very intimate and reminded me of a European restaraunt.  Great for dates.

With regards to service, my waitress was attentive, but I didn't get the whole "tortilla and salsa concept".  Maybe it's too dark in there, but I honestly thought the server was just bringing me an extra napkin in case I made a mess.  I didn't realize that there were tortillas in there.  And I thought the salsa was just an accompaniment for the meal I ordered.

My dish, the Chilaquiles verdes was very good, and quite filling for an afternoon meal.  I don't think the prices are that unreasonable.  Except $4 for a serving of rice seems a bit excessive.  Not that you need the extra starch anyways.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Slow service. Awesome atmosphere and drink menu. The guacamole was fresh and tortillas perfect! Unfortunately, entrees were sub-par: prawns with mole - yuk, quesadilla was mediocre. 

Go here for a margarita and guacamole then go elsewhere for dinner.
author: Courtney W.

description:
I have this general "ethnic" rule when it comes to restaurants. For example, if you don't see any Thai people eating at a Thai restaurant, that automatically makes it questionable.

That rule went out the window at Colibri. Right from the start, with the excellent mojito and guacamole (and the extremely fresh hot [temperature] tortillas), I already knew I wanted to come back.

The tortilla soup is awesome, which came with my Dine About Town menu. Said menu also came with the most tender and tasty carnitas ever, with a side of delicious black beans that would feel insulted if you called it "just" a side dish. The coffee-tequila flan finished me off.

Others in the party had the fish of the day (mahi mahi), scallops, and shrimp. And another dessert of cinnamon ice cream with churros with dulce de leche. OH MY GOD.

Docked a star for less-than-impressive service. Very friendly for sure, but forgotten orders and then the dishes arriving out of order (the entree came long before the soup). Still, that's not stopping me from indulging once again sometime.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Good eats here - well prepared dishes which are mildly spiced.  Fresh guacamole prepared table-side isn't too shabby... until that is, the waitress limes everyone within a 270 degree radius.

The most beautiful thing they have is the Caipirinha.  Must say, this is the first place that broke me in to this fabulous cocktail.  Beautiful...
author: lulu p.

description:
Colibri is currently my second favorite Mexican restaurant in the Bay Area. The first one being Gaymas in Tiburon.

I could swear that this upscale but cozy place right across the street from the Curran theater was kidnapped from somewhere in the Polanco neighborhood of Mexico City. It shares a lot of similarities with Aguila y Sol, La Tecla and La Destileria which are top notch restaurants in Mexico City.

You will find here Mexican contemporary cuisine mixed with some dishes that, although being classics in Mexico, you never find at Mexican places in the Bay Area. For example, Tostadas de Tinga, Quesadillas de Rajas con Queso and Cuitlacoche and Tamales Oaxaqueos.

Excellent food along with an excellent bar makes this place one of my favorite spots for dinner with friends in the city.
author: Erik Z.

description:
the guacamole is heavenly ( made at the table just for you! ), the soft tortillas all warm and fresh .. just as heavenly and the service great . I had Fillet Mignon for entree. The sauce was tasty .. a little spicey but real good and the mash stunning! 

All in all i would go here just for the Guacamole but the rest was just as delicious!
author: Amy W.

description:
My girlfriend and I decided to try Colibri because we had been in the area so often -- usually drunken at the ramen place or the Thai place or the Jack in the Box nearby -- but had never come to eat here.

It was pretty busy when we got there, and even though we showed up late for our reservation, we were seated immediately.  We started with the guacamole because we saw it at another table and it looked good.  We ordered it extra spicy, and they made it just right, with a good amount of kick from the jalapenos.  It was a bit pricey ($10 I think), but I don't mind overpaying a little bit if the food tastes good.  It was also a little weird eating the guac with tortillas (as opposed to tortilla chips), but the tortillas tasted very fresh, and I liked it in the end.

For our main dinner, we had the filet mignon, the chicken mole, the cornbread side, and the potato au gratin-ish side.  The steak was perfectly cooked, and had a great chipotle sauce.  The potatoes and the goat cheese-stuffed chili were great compliments to the steak.  The only negative thing I have to say about the steak was that it was a little bit too small -- I guess I didn't notice that they considered their menu as "small plates."  I definitely wanted more!

On the other hand, the mole, which was recommended by the server, was the weakest dish we had.  The flavor was much milder in flavor than all the good moles I've had, and I found lacking in spice or "oomph."  I don't know how to describe it, but it just wasn't very good.  

The potatoes au gratin (with a chili cream sauce) was pretty good sized and very cheesy, just the way I like it.  The corn bread was not as good, but still very tasty, and my girlfriend liked it more than I did.  

We didn't have room for dessert after the meal because we ate so much food, but the ones that went by looked very good.  We had the sangria to drink, which was good, but not great.  

Overall, we had a great meal, and we will definitely go back again. . . . We just won't order the mole next time.
author: Pilan C.

description:
Really poor experience.  I am a native of the city, spent years in San Diego, and my wife is from Mexico City.  The food is your typical San Francisco attempt at high class Mexican cuisine which falls short of the mark.  It's not worth the price, and the sangrita was terrible.

Here's particularly why it was a poor experience.  8pm reservation for two on a Friday night. No one came to take our drink order or acknowledge us for 20 mins.  Appetizer was forgotten and they just came with our entrees.  We asked for the appetizer and they just put our entrees under the heat lamps for 15 mins after telling us they wouldn't do that.  

Just as our entrees arrive they seat a table of 4 marina types (or maybe inner richmond), in their 30's, with a 6 month old baby next to us. No big deal, until the baby starts screaming and the mom proceeds to start breastfeeding in front of everyone.  And they acted like they either didn't give a damn about everyone else's Friday night or they're just so full of themselves they're beyond reality. No apology or anything.

Either way, a restaurant that attempts to tout themselves as such a chic place should not allow babies on a Friday night and shame on that woman for even thinking that it's acceptable to come to a place like that and act that way.
author: T G.

description:
Colibri has been on our "places to eat" list for quite a while.  Last time we came here, the hostess told us that it was a 45 min wait.  This time we were prepared to wait; but in actuality we waited about 20 min.

There were definite highlights.  Our inventory of food included:  guacamole, chicken mole, carnitas, homemade tortillas, chili relleno, and the tortilla soup.  Our waiter was very nice, too (prompt service).

But to really put a punch on this meal, we indulged in the "premium tequila flight." At $40, it was not cheap, but I have to say. It proved to me that not all tequila is evil.

So come here, eat good food. But don't be surprised if you end up dropping some pretty serious coin.
author: e a.

description: I love this place! My besty took me here and we had the bottomless mimosas which were deLicious! Not at all watered down and so refreshing. They always made sure our glasses were full too. We ordered the fresh guacamole which comes with little tortillas. YUM! We also got strawberry margaritas. SO good again! Made with fresh berries and juice. I think they were too pricy ($12) which is why I put 4/5 but the service and everything else (relaxed atmosphere) was wonderful! Definitely going back. Perfect place to relax and grab a drink after a few hours of shopping aorund union square.
author: Misty M.

description: The food, the service and the atmosphere was very good. They understood we had to catch a play across the street and treated us curiously and professionally. The drinks added that extra touch to earn them five stars. I'm going back.
author: Alexander G.

description:
I love the AUTHENTIC food!  I hear some of the other yelpers complain about the prices, but it is the same you would spend at any other place in the area.  Personally, I was stuffed with the small plates we ordered, plus the tequilas kept my belly warm.  The guac alone being made table side to my tastes won me over.  
I loved the complimentary salsas and did not mind the tortillas, since that is what they actually serve at authentic restaurants in Mexico.  If you want tex-mex, chips, and "get-a-rope-pace-chili-sauce" place that serves your tacos in "U" shape with yellow cheese, then go elsewhere, like tacohell or something cheap like that. This is a good -traditional food place with great service.  If you are adventurous try the recommendations from the servers.
author: S J.

description:
LOVE the atmosphere.  Convenient location!

& the food is great.  The best Mexican I've ever had!  The warm tortillas & guacamole are addictive!  :O)
author: Minju A.

description: This place was the perfect place to go before going out. We got a few apps and split them and some margs. Try the pineapple marg, it was soooo good!!!
author: Michele V.

description: Pretty solid upscale Mexican restaurant.  Hard to find, actually.  great for taking business visitors from the East Coast, who want a Mexican experience, but in an upscale format.  Always have a great time here.  The carnitas and the guacamole/salsa options are my favorite go-to's here.
author: Flip F.

description:
I came here last night with girlfriends before hitting up comedy at the comedy college.  It's a pretty small size restaurant but it was packed on a Saturday night.  I really liked the atmosphere, it had that old spanish mission style decor and nice lighting.  There were a couple of big tables, so I noted that it would be a fun place to try with a group.

Two of us arrived early, so we grabbed a drink at the bar... I found a new favorite drink: the "Macho Margarita" -- it is awesome, they actually add muddled jalapeno and it gives the margarita an awesome spicy kick while it feels like you are drinking a mojito of sorts...  it was the perfect blend of sweet & heat, similar to my other favorite drink: the Sweet Heat at the St Regis.  The Sweet Heat is a martini style drink, whereas the Macho Margarita is served on the rocks.

They were offering a "Dine about Town" menu, so we all ordered from that menu.  I ordered the ensalada caesar.  It was tasty, with the perfect amount of dressing and a very generous portion.  I had the pork (Carnitas) and it was quite delicious, the meat was perfectly tender and fell from the fork easily.  

For dessert I ordered the Churros.  They were out of this world.  We kept commenting how these "weren't your ballpark churros"!  They were served with a dulce de leche ice cream.  One of my girlfriends ordered the Flan and she said it was good, but not as good as the flan her mama makes!

I'll be back to try more items on their menu and enjoy a few Macho Margaritas!!
author: Sheila D.

description:
The entry and hostess stand was total grid lock, just inside, the bar was 2 to 3 deep, my first thought as we entered Colibri for our Saturday night 8:30 reservation for 8 was, damn, we won't be getting seated anytime soon but... 

Surprise! No sooner had we checked in when the girl called out in so many words,"Crazies, party of eight, your table is ready." Stunned, we walked in and were shown to our table 5 minutes early no less.

Naturally without being prodded, we quickly ordered 2 rounds of Don Julio margaritas, on the rocks, no salt please and same said amount of their famous table side guacamole with fresh hot tortillas and superb salsas. Right then and there it was like the old commercial, "it doesn't get any better than this"

Food orders were taken, more tequila was brought out, food was being served, plates were being shared. All in all, albeit in a tequila state of mind, the food that came out of the kitchen was very good, the carnitas was moist and flavorful and the shrimp were plump and juicy. Along with satisfying sides of seasoned rice, black beans we ordered one of the best side dishes ever, Torta De Elote (cornbread, pasilla chile, onions and BACON!) served with a poblano cream sauce, it was fantastic.

Service was great, even though we probably made the barmaid break a sweat running laps back and forth from our table to the bar. Believe me, happily, we will be back...
author: Keith Y.

description:
So my 2007 theme has been tequila!  And here you could get just that.  All my buddies were eating some incredibly tasty morsels of mexican cuisine, when i all of a sudden found that i have left the table and walked to this 9 feet high glass case(more like an alter) filled with over 10 shelves of various tequila. Needless to say i wasn't eating anything but tequila tonite.

I was going to start with a blood orange tequila, but Luisa (BTW super-hot and nice)swayed me away and said it was best to go with the lime infused tequila cocktail (sorry i forgot the name)  Anyhow, once this was warm-up was over, my pal Chester recommended the tequila sampler- which allows one to try 3 different flavors by shot of one brand- i went with the Chinaco (thx chest!)

Being iam a major patron silver ho-bag i started with the Blanco...muy muy sabroso!  next was the reposado..BTW if your lucky enough to have Luisa serve u, ask for her to say "reposado."  Promise u won't regret it.

Last was the Anejo which i found demasiado spero.  I haven't had this much fun with tequila since...Tommy's on Geary.  Ole!!
author: omar b.

description:
I'm not certain if it was the chiles or the atmosphere, but our group of 15 seemed to agree that the atmosphere was caliente. I'm a veteran of spices so I really believe the heat was due to the proximity to the kitchen. The restaurant could greatly benefit by increasing the number of vent/exhaust units.

Queso fundida with chorizo and mushrooms was filling and tasty. Sopes were nothing memorable. The carnitas entree was tender yet crispy on the outside. Churros with caramel ice cream were fantastic. The lamb shank looked delicious, so I'll have to try it on another visit. Overall, it's a great venue for birthday events, but if you're in need of basic mexican food you're better off at one of the local taquerias. People will favor Las Ramblas for tapas, but check out Colibri for a decent change.
author: Tom B.

description:
Meranda B has restored her credibility! This place is truly, truly, truly delicious. 

They started us off with three lovely homemade sauces with warm homemade tortillas. We ramped that up with warm tortilla chips that tasted like they were made out of croissants. And eff it, we got guacamole in the mix too. It was in my top 3 guacamoles, and I keep a strict running list.

The tapas were all really wonderful - we had the potato gratin and the cauliflower gratin. Both were kind of redundant but I sliiiightly preferred the potato only because the cauliflower was corrupted by mushrooms. I am not really sure how authentically Mexican potatoes au gratin are. Maybe in the Belfast region of Mexico this is a popular dish. But it was goddamn delicious, and that is what matters. The jicama salad with avocado and grapefruit was refreshing and the black beans were simply prepared and flavorful. I really could have eaten my way through a few more tapas but I think this is the kind of place that's better with at least four people so you can order many dishes and try everything.
author: Ella c.

description:
If Mr. Tequila is your friend you will be very happy here - I promise you this... 

I would agree, this is not your typical Mexican restaurant, if you're looking for fajitas you best pack it in...the Guacamole is excellent, but for vegetarians the menu is only so-so...
author: Todd E.

description:
We had an amazing dinner here last night, mostly thanks to Nish's suggestion! So kudos to Nish! Woot!

Started with mojitos and margaritas and sangria, as well as guacamole (I love that they make it for you at the table!!), some cheese-chorizo stuff, quesadillas, and the ceviche (all of them were really good, although I didn't have the chorizo...no porky for ireney).

We basically laid into their menu hardcore: pollo ranchero, filet mignon, jicama salad, another chicken dish, chiles rellenos (some of the best i've ever had), and pescado del dia, which was halibut in an excellent sauce.

delicious all around. also got some rice and beans and nopales (cactus...amazing).

sooo good. i wish the portions had been a little larger, but the service was great and the food was delicious. definitely will try to get back here some time soon!
author: Irene F.

description:
I owe Yelp big time on this one. I gave Colibri a shot based on the reviews here, and was rewarded with Mexican delights undreamt of at the local Taqueria. 

I'm from San Diego, I know what Carnitas are. Not. What I enjoyed at Colibri were delightfully flavored with the most remarkable texture; Crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside. The sea bass was firm and wonderfully flavorful as was the chicken covered in an unsweetened chocolate sauce (Mole Poblano). The Guacamole (made at the table) was also excellent and served with soft tortillas. 

No real negatives to report, though if you want super hot n' spicy you'll be disappointed. Colibri is about flavor, not nuking your mouth with hot peppers. 

Entrees are $10-$15, most appetizers $7-10 and the Margaritas they will work hard to sell you (OK, maybe they really don't need to work too hard to sell them) are $10-15. Service was very quick and pleasant. We walked in at 6:30 on a Monday and sat right down, but by 7:30 it was fairly full.
author: Bill S.

description:
I have never devoured a more delicious churro in my entire life. This is not the same kind of churro you'll find at the LA Zoo or Santa Cruz boardwalk. If I had to create a comparison for these churros, the ones from Colibri would be considered Buckingham Palace and the ones from a random stand would be the White House. 

The White House churros are more authentic and made for (and by) the common man. They represent the majority of churros out there (except for the past 8 years) and they are readily available for us to find. 

The Buckingham Palace churros are pure royality. They are far and few between and they taste like the gold that is lined in the hallways of this establishment. They could be considered more "white-washed," but I'm totally okay with it. 

Give me David Beckham and Helen Mirren anyday. I want the churro that's laced with caramel syrup and ice cream. I want the churro that was born in Piccadilly circus and brought to me on a Crate & Barrel plate, not the churro rotating like a chicken at Boston Market and handed over in a wax wrapper. 

If eating these churros everyday meant living in Buckingham Palace, just  call me Lizzy.
author: Jared S.

description:
You know you are an addicted Yelper when you reach review number 99 and insist that your fiance go with you somewhere new so you have a new joint to review for that oh so special 100.

So, anyway, Colibri was that new joint and I am so thrilled with this choice - it was the best meal out Ive had in long time. The tableside guacamole with fresh tortillas was so good, I could eat just that all day. Well, maybe with a side of those tasty black beans. And, I have to wash it down with a blackberry margarita that is NOT one of those syrupy sweet girly grown up slurpees. And, well, I don't know if I could pass up another one of those chile rellenos stuffed with vegetables (as opposed to those gooey cheesey mush piles covered in batter and sauce which are great when hungover but otherwise so-so). Oh, and those patatas gratin with an adobe cream sauce. I wanna eat that all day too. And dessert! Crepe perfection with the amazing white velvet cocktail. Sigh. Javier, our server, was so cool and helpful, I bet he'd let me camp out all day. Well, maybe. 

I wanna go back. NOW.
author: Lise L.

description:
Ok. First off I want to predicate my review by the fact that I thought i completely reached a saturation point with all the trendy restaurants. I could no longer stand the site of them.

So I kept thinking about what makes the holy grail when it comes to good food, dining, entertainment.. and then thought about it some more.. until i got frustrated and almost threw my laptop down a plight of stairs.

So with all that frustration with trendy restaurants you can probably guess what happened to me last week.."I WAS INDIRECTLY PERSUADED TO GO TO ANOTHER TRENDY RESTAURANT."

I have to say i really liked this place. First thing was the tequila menu was just so extensive you literally couldn't help but go into paralysis by analysis mode. 

There's a very authentic decor inside this place. Roman Castle like high ceilings with expensive chandeliers that look like they're from the Roman Empire days. Everything just felt solid in that joint.

The chips and salsa were the best i've ever had point blank period. You have to just try it with guacamole, it'll take you to another world. The salsa itself is so flavorful and thick it's a full out assault on your palette. I was typical post-work trance and it woke me right up.

For entree's, the filet mignon with ancho chile and stuffed goat cheese were up there with Michael Jordan and Kobe. Filet mignon just melted in your mouth and the sauce was amazing. 

I tried my girlfriend's Sopa de Tortilla which was a slightly spicy dish but done so tastefully and in such a pleasant non-imposing way that you just couldn't help but cherish every bite.

Judging by the reaction of the other 6 people we had in our group, all of their orders more than fulfilled their expectations.

Definitely worth it to go here folks.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
Yeah yeah, the guacamole tableside - great!

BUT the BEST dish here by FAR is the Cauliflower Capeada!  This is an AMAZING dish!

How is it that I have traveled all over Mexico and been to a thousand mexican restaurants and have never tried anything remotely like this?  

Oh, and great selection of inexpensive Spanish wines too...I like this place.
author: Yelper A.

description:
Outstanding. Colibri was great from all aspects: the food, the drinks, the ambiance, and the service!

Rick H. and I decided to check it Colibri last night, and conveniently booked our reservation on OpenTable.

We were seated immediately, and the service was extremely prompt. Oscar was our waiter as well as our "Tequila Sommelier" (okay, so I just coined that phrase but he was the equivalent of that!). The tequila selection at Colibri is truly something to write home about. For anyone who had a couple of lousy nights in college with 5 too many shots of Cuervo (I think that covers just about all of us), I highly recommend giving it another chance.

We ended up trying two tequila samplers (not unlike a wine flight), which featured 3 half shots of tequila that have been aged different amounts of time, from younger to older: blanco, reposado, and anejo. Within each of these categories, the tequila is then sub-classified into the flavor categories gentil, moderato, and agresivo. This was all new to me! Oscar was incredibly patient and helped us choose some great tequilas. The first flight we had in the agresivo category featured a blanco, a reposado, and anejo all with vanilla and honey undertones... uhhh... YUM!

Then we realized... oh yeah, there's food here, too! Rather than chips, Colibri brings out warm, fresh-off-the-griddle corn tortillas and 3 different salsas (ranging from very mild to HOT HOT HOT! The yellow one is the mildest, green is medium, and red is hot). We ordered the guacamole, which Oscar prepared table-side with great finesse. It was perfectly done, not too chunky, not too smooth.

For the dishes, we ordered the Ensalada Romana, the Mole Poblano, and the Filete Mignon. The Ensalada Romana was like a Mexican Caesar salad and extremely yummy. The plate was full of hearts of romaine topped with a zesty lemon-anchovy vinaigrette and plenty of shredded Parmesan.

The Mole Poblano featured a few pieces of chicken (breast and leg) smothered in a ridiculously good mole sauce. The sauce had JUST the right amount of seasoning: a warm blend of spices and a delightful hint of chocolate.

The Filete Mignon was also outstanding. The fillet was topped off with a goat-cheese stuffed pepper and surrounded by a wonderful sauce, begging to be sopped up by the extra tortillas.

During our entire meal (we were there nearly 2 hours), Oscar constantly checked in on us and made sure we were taken care of.

The ambiance is fun and lively, but at the same time, not deafeningly loud.

Highly, highly recommended. I can't wait to go back and try more of their tequilas! Colibri takes great care of their patrons, and I look forward to dining there again soon!
author: Jill M.

description: I try to visit a place twice before writing a review. Therefore, after 2 visits i can confidently say that this place is VERY good. The homemade tortillas are incredible! Also the fish tacos are so amazing. Great flavor, great portion size ! Between the 4 of us at dinner, we were blown away by the food!
author: Britt m.

description:
I was so excited to "discover" Colibri one night on the way to the theater.  I remember telling all of my friends about it, the old-fashioned way, through word of mouth.  Yes, folks.  That was BY.  Before Yelp.

Then after joining Yelp, couldn't bring myself to review it.  I wanted to keep it to myself.  Ha!  Now it has over 200 reviews and is no longer a coveted secret.  But you know what?  Who cares!  It's still great. Sometimes I have to remind myself that just because something becomes popular doesn't make it bad.  And Colibri has maintained the personal service and cozy atmosphere that I was attracted to in the first place.

Always excellent as a pre-theater or post-shopping choice, Colibri is famous for the guacamole prepared tableside and the wonderful margaritas.  I like the 3 dipping sauces with the warm tortillas that start off your meal.  The top shelf margarita as well as the fruit options are all good - my favorites are blackberry and passionfruit as they are not too sweet.

You can make a meal from the appetizers or order entrees.  I am particularly fond of the sauces they use, such as the mole or pipian.  Tonight I had the Pato (Duck) with Pipian with a side of the cornbread smothered in green sauce.  It was delicious.

The other thing I need to remind myself about is that tempting as they are, you can only have ONE margarita before a show.  Otherwise, head-bobs will ensue.  And you don't want to be THAT GUY in the audience with the tequila breath and the bobbing.  No, no.

For upscale Mexican food, Colibri is a dependable and highly enjoyable restaurant.
author: Liz S.

description:
*Margaritas are nothing special.
*Dinner plates are swimming in sauces that do not complement the meat.  Meats were overcooked and had strange flavors.
*Side dishes have either no flavor...or a strange taste.
*Service was below average.

...and to top it off, everything was expensive.  Luckily I was here with good friends, so it was still a good night.  I give this restaurant a two star rating because considering the cost, I expect a certain level of service and flavor to the dishes.  I would not go back or recommend it to my friends.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Yummay!

Upscale Mexican dining with a l-o-n-g tequila menu. Fresh ingredients & friendly staff all make for a memorable dining experience. 

I went here today for brunch and we enjoyed the tamales oaxaquenos, chilaquiles and fresh guacamole... our meals were pretty spicy so we washed it down with delicious margaritas (the Margarita Corazon was wonderful)... we will definitely return and can't wait to try the snapper on the dinner menu.
author: Nenette Y.

description: Colibri is a great spot for solid Mexican food in a contemporary setting. The happy hour food prices are great, the margaritas are solid. What's not to like? Reservations are recommended after 6:30pm if you don't feel like waiting around.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Chilaquiles verdes- yummy! Hands down one of the best verde sauces I've eaten! Unfortunately they flubbed on my over easy eggs. Boo. I personally suck at making them at home and tend to over cook the yolk, but I would expect a professional to get it right. Fortunately it wasn't a total disaster to the dish.
 
Guacamole- fantastic! I was a little hesitant since the guac itself is $10 and you have to add another $5 for chips. Seriously? Fear not, the guac is totally worth it...the chips not so much, but the fresh tortillas and 3 types of salsas? Divine. Worth every penny. Enough to serve 4 people.

Service was friendly and timely. And they actually serve decent coffee.
Today we only got a taste of the brunch menu, so G. and I will definitely be back for some dinner action sometime soon.
author: Carnley P.

description:
Oh Colibri...I already miss you!
I come here 3 times a year and always make a stop in.
The reason for the $10 guac: made fresh when you order in front of you, huge serving! (comes with tortillas)
Recently had the sangria-sooo good!
Had the crepes also: served warm with melted mexican caramel and ice cream...are you drooling yet?
Great Happy Hour starting at 3:30: 6 dollar food 5 dollar drinks
author: erin g.

description: The food and tequila selection are outstanding.  I wanted to give Colibri 5 stars, but the service was lacking.  The fresh guacamole was terrific, but the cornbread torta stole the show.  I could have eaten myself sick on it.  We will definitely go again, but I hope the service reflects the quality of the food next time.
author: Nikki B.

description:
Yum. As others have stated, the guac is a must. I wasn't super hungry, so I just ordered the sopes: three "two-bite" sized corn boats of deliciousness. I opted to get two veggie and one chicken. The veggie was by far the standout; I've been dreaming about it since. Also tried the jicama salad, which I thought was as close to perfection as one can get with the dish. Others in my party raved about their dishes, which included the cauliflower bake and sauteed cactus (nopal), among other things.

We did have an issue with the service. Two peoples' food did not come out until after the rest had finished eating, and the server--while nice--didn't make a solid attempt to make up for it until one of the girls (after having asked after the food twice already) said to just cancel the order, whereupon he offered them each a drink on the house. Everyone makes mistakes from time to time, though, and all-in-all it was a pleasant experience with very tasty food.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
Haiku review:

Guacamole yum
But the service was no fun
Maybe for the drinks
author: Brandon B.

description:
I love this place. The steak is always good. I really recommend the chorizo appetizer, especially if you like eating melted cheese. I know, right?

The service was a little scatter brained that day, kept forgetting stuff we asked for, granted we did ask for a bunch of stuff, but it is the job. 

The tortillas, I could live off those for one week.
author: Philip K.

description:
As much as I hate to give this place 4 stars, I feel like I have to because the tortillas, guac and margaritas are really tasty.  We also had the super tiny very small not very filled with poblano strips quesadillas and the oh so very bland Caesar salad.  Basically we had a post theater snack, for $56!!!  Are ya kiddin' me?  The prices are the menu, yes I know, but sometimes you just feel ripped off. 

While we were waiting to get our table I had found $60 in the pocket of my jeans (!!! You would think I would have noticed when that went missing!!!) I think my finding the cash was an omen of the overpriced vittles at Colibri.  Easy come, easy go.

The chicken tortilla soup that we saw being served at the next table did look divine.  I won't make an extra trip there for it.  But if I'm in the 'hood, I would go and try it.
author: Jackie D.

description:
If you're seeing a play @ the A.C.T. or Curran Theatre this restaurant is amazingly convenient being directly across the street. It's a double bonus because it serves good Mexican food in a casual atmosphere. 

They have a fantastic tequila selection, great guacamole that is made at your table to your specifications. I especially recommend the corn bread side. They consider the entrees tapas. Personally, this makes for confusing ordering if you don't want to end up with too much food because the  tapas are larger than the norm and served as a main with sides. 

To sum it up, I don't make special trips here but I'm perfectly happy with the food when seeing a show across the street.
author: San J.

description:
Hurray! I'm the 494th Colibri yelper! I'll keep this short. 

When you order the guacamole here, and they ask you how hot you want it, remember that they are capable of making it insanely picante. So many restaurants fail to make things hot enough. Colibiri turns the heat up to 11. I lika' the spice, but they rendered the guac almost inedible with spice. Tasty, but HOT. Consider yourself warned!
author: Regina S.

description:
Vivaaaaaaaaa Mexico! Such a wonderful spot. The food is great!

Try the fish tacos and Jicama salad. I do not recommend the Ceviche tho, especially if you've been spoiled by Fresca.
author: Nez B.

description:
Came here with a few coworkers cuz I won the World Cup Pool (Go Italy!) and so, since I wasnt paying I ordered up! Hahahahahaha.
Everyone at my table went nuts over the tortillas with salsa. The ceviche was good (I make it better, neener neener) and the quesadillas were ok too. I had the Yucatecan Tilapia and it was good. I enjoyed every bite.  The only reason I take one star off is that I want my beans! I am a beaner, and therefore I must have my beans. Where's the beans????????
Eh. Overall it was good food and I imagine expensive cuz my coworkers' eyeballs popped out when the check came :)
author: Judith F.

description:
good margaritas, but i make better guacamole.

FOOD:~i loved the sauce & accompaniments with my scallops, but the scallops were wayyyyyyyyyyy overdone. they were practically dried scallops, they were so overcooked.

~guacamole: needs more lime & cilantro. & what's with the charge for chips? i hate that. this place makes a killing off of location, i believe.

~very nice, the bartender sampled some tequila ocho after i ordered el tesoro. but he was wrong, i still went with the el tesoro...the tequila ocho was like for an old man...strong aftertaste.

DECOR: ok

SERVICE: cool

BATHROOM: a fricking mess to get over to hotel diva's bathroom since they're renovating.

OVERALL: i usually stop here for a pre-ACT drink, which is probably their main source of business. i remember having ok ceviche here long ago. that sums it up.
author: miss b.

description:
Screw the chips and salsa! If that's what you want, go to Chevy's. The warm tortillas and salsa are a meal in themselves. I've been here a few times with my girlfriends and I always manage to leave completely stuffed even after ordering a couple of small dishes.

Make sure to order the guacomole that they make tableside. Not to be missed. However the drinks are slightly overpriced and not all that great so just sit back and enjoy the food!
author: Karla G.

description:
Loved the guacamole so much--one of those times where you think you're so full, you can't eat another bite, yet are unable to stop eating it, even when dinner is long over. And then you pay for it later.

The pumpkin-seeded duck was good, but sounded more interesting than it tasted. Tasty but not super memorable. The waiter recommended the rice as a side, of which I'm normally not a fan, but it ended up being just the right accompaniment.  The potatoes gratin were kind of a strange side--belonged at a different restaurant, maybe.

Overall, if I were down in Union Square and feeling okay about sitting in a noisy environment with tables too close together, I'd return to Colibri.
author: Kitty B.

description:
The good:
- The food: I got some chicken with a delicious sauce on top of it
- Decently priced

The bad:
- SLOW service
- The restaurant was about 10-20 degrees too hot... and I was near the window, which should leak some heat, right?  I pity those who sat closer to the kitchen
- The margaritas (I had four) are insanely watered down... do they even put alcohol in those things?
- The seats along the edge of the restaurant are uncomfortable
author: Danny C.

description: Hand made tortillas, only reason this place gets a 3 star rating from me!! The best part was the tortillas and guacamole. Over all  their food was alright, drinks could have been better.  Nothing really got my taste buds going crazy..
author: Maria D.

description: Fantastic guacamole and margaritas to start you off, then super flavorful entrees.  Love it!
author: Laurel S.

description:
Went back for the second time last night. It was delicious, upscale Mexican food served tapas style. The guacamole is awesome -- ask for extra lime in it -- and comes with mini corn tortillas instead of chips. I also highly recommend the jicama salad, cevice, pechuga ranchero, the scallops (I was glad they set that down next to me!), and the potatoes al gratin. Wow! I can't say I was a huge fan of the Mexican chocolate cake, but others at my table enjoyed.

I had some good wine. And while tequila and I are no longer friends, the margarita selection is impressive.
author: Leigh M.

description:
I swear, I really didn't mean to get absolutely dizzyingly drunk off two glasses of white wine. How ridiculous is that? But there I was, leaning over the dinner table, chattering giddily at my date who was treating me to this nice dinner.  The place was a little bit dark, but in a pleasant way. Soft seats, light streaming in through dozens of bottles that lined the glass shelves installed across the window. The atmosphere was rich, boozy, spicy. Perfect for a date.

We shared the tamales oaxaquenos (chicken tamales with mole sauce), and I had the chile relleno, a delicious poblano chile stuffed with veggies, cheese and served on a black bean sauce. There was no room left for dessert. All was good. Next time I have a hot date that wants to take me out to dinner, we're so going there.
author: Tanya F.

description:
You can't go wrong with any meal when you start it with a Joaquin's Pisco Sour.  It not only brings back the most AWESOME memories that I have of a small Peruvian restaurant back in Washington D.C. when I was a college kid savoring my first taste of independence in the form of a Pisco Sour, but it also just tastes good.  Although the ingredients in a traditional Pisco Sour are kinda gross sounding (Pisco, a regional brandy, lemon juice, egg whites, simple syrup, and regional bitters), the result is lemony goodness....mmmmmm....Plus, Colibri does the Pisco Sour well.

The ambiance is much more refined than your run of the mill Mexican and I was impressed by the upscale atmosphere.  The food was solid.  I ordered the Callos de Hacha and was not disappointed with the scallops, seared to perfection.

Then, I tried the Negro y Blanco dessert.....the dense dark chocolate mousse paired perfeclty to the white chocolate cone.....mmmmmm..

For all of the above and the memories...$40.00 (not including tip)
author: Hiromi N.

description: I liked it - kinda noisy, but a nice place to have mexican cuisine and to have dinner with friends.  Wonderful location and the ambience was pleasant.  The presentation of the food was spot on.
author: Anh Et Henry T.

description: Great Mexican food that tastes fresh! Get reservations or you will be waiting a long time.
author: annalisa d.

description:
not a typical mexican restaurant (whew).

with everything that came out, as soon as we sampled it we swooned.

sangria - excellent
guacamole - excellent (with plenty of delicious handmade tortillas)
ceviche - excellent
corn tortilla crusted scallops - good, slightly overcooked and didn't think they went with the accompaniments very well

BUT : the churros rellenos dessert - to...die...for.  seriously, this is my new favorite dessert of all time. 'traditional hispanic pastry filled with cajeta caramel cream' served with icecream

will definitely be back.

3 sangrias, 2 appetizers, 1 entree, 2 sides, 1 dessert, 2 coffees = ~$130 (after tip)
author: Loralyn S.

description: I really don't know why everyone on yelp is going crazy for their guacamole. Maybe if you've never had guac before. It's just okay. The whole place, for being so price, is just okay.
author: Kari H.

description:
My take on dinner last night:

Good:
* Dinner -- I got the carnitas... delicious. Honestly, I was just happy to have options that didn't involve wrapping food within a tortilla.
* Margaritas -- tasty with plenty of alcohol
* Mojitos -- see above

OK:
* Service -- even without a reservation on a seemingly-busy Saturday evening, we were still seated within 10 minutes. The staff was obviously busy and I had to track our server down a few times to get another drink... but I wasn't in a hurry anyway.
* Guacamole -- it was decent and the flour tortillas are a cute novelty, but I really could've used some actual chips. I know, I know.

Bad:
* $140 bill -- but there were drinks-aplenty, so the bill was expected. Still, it's not an especially cheap place, so be prepared for that.
author: Chris M.

description:
Dine About Town
I ordered the Tortilla Soup (which on it's own would have gotten 5 stars), the Carnitas and the Churros.

Hubby got the Mole and a side of rice.

Tortilla Soup was AWESOME. Beautiful presentation and very yummy!
The Carnitas were bland and the sauce they served with it was cold, so I didn't use it. I used the mango salsa instead.
The rice was very boring and bland, we put salsa in it to give it some flavor and hubby thought the mole was just ok.

Once again, as with my previous dine about town experience at Luella's the best part of the mean was the dessert - the churros and dulce de leche ice cream.

The service was ok, although they should have heaters or something, because every time the front door opened, it made our food and us a little bit colder....

Overall, I am unimpressed, and disappointed, because we love mexican. Perhaps a few margaritas would have made dinner taste better.... but we went sans alcohol.

The tortilla soup and the churros are what got 2 stars from me... all the rest I have had  much better elsewhere, and for the normal price would have been severely disappointed...

Seems like a nice bar area though, and i did appreciate the old mexican nacho libre-ish movie on the big screen...
author: Annie M.

description:
I do love the guacamole and tortillas here. I've also been here several times and enjoyed my meal. HOWEVER last night I went with a group of 6 and got a really bad vibe from our waitress, Daniella. 

First she tried to push the margaritas on us. Then when we were ordering our food, she kept trying to upsell everyone on the side dishes--so much so that my friends were worried that what they'd ordered wouldn't be enough. But when the food came, it was so much food, we couldn't finish it all. Also when my husband ordered, he said he was thinking about ordering a side dish (potatoes au gratin), but asked her to come back to him. He never actually ordered it. Then when the food came, they brought the potatoes! 

I don't have a problem with a server trying to upsell as long as they are honest about the food portions. I felt that Daniella was dishonest about that, and also stealth-ordering the potatoes was not cool. 

If it is the managers who are pressuring the servers to upsell, they are doing the restaurant a disservice. This experience left a bad taste in my mouth and I will be reluctant to go back.
author: Miya K.

description:
Showed up randomly with parents in town and had a good time with my roomate Todd and my folks.  Had alot of fun and the food was great.  Only to be devastated when we got the bill for $160.

Pro's:  Great tasting food, lots of tequilas, fun and exciting, servers are really attentive, home made tortillas.

Con's: Wicked Expensive.  4 people $160.00 for mexican food.....  We did get 3 shots of tequila and 3 margaritas though and at Ten Bux Each.  Side of rice and beans $10.00...  5.00 for rice 5.00 for beans.  Oh and the Guac was 10 bux Chips were 5 bux extra....  I always thought chips were free at mexican places.

I would go back if I won the lottery.
author: Shawn L.

description: Mexican food is hard to mess up. This place had very fresh food at a reasonable price. I was solo and I was litterally seated in a corner. It felt like I was in second grade all over again. Main thing, I was able to get reasonably priced, fresh mexican food. I ordered the Carnitas Omelette. It was awesome. Served with black beans and I think potatos but I forgot that minor detail. $10 bottomless mimosas were perfect since I needed to kill time before getting out of town. Great place, great food.
author: David G.

description:
This is the sister restaurant to Consuelo on Santana Row in Santa Clara.  Having eaten at Consuelo several times, I was pleasantly surprised to see this restaurant appear in this neck of the woods. However, for some reason, some luster was lost between the stretch of freeway that separates the warmth and vivaciousness of Consuelo and this smaller, darker version near Union Square.  Maybe it is because it is simply out done by the cosmopolitan intrigue of other restaurants  in this city. Don't know. 

The tortillas and trio of salsas are a great way to start the meal.  So great, that we requested more tortillas. Not once, not twice, not even thrice - four times we had to request tortillas.  Service, as you can probably tell, was lacking. My suspicions about the quality of service were confirmed when I asked one of the waitresses for more tortillas and noted that this was in fact, our fourth request without having received anything. Instead of running off to get more tortillas, our chubby faced waitress gave a sarcastic smile paired with a sharply edged response and waddled back to the kitchen area, only to return a hearty 15 minutes later carrying a stack of perhaps 20 tortillas - sarcasm in corn pancakes, who would have thought? (Note: a sarcastic smile was left by me when it came time for the tip. :) 

Catty commentary aside, the food was decent. The guacamole is a must - they don't serve it with chips but will upon request.  The house margarita is good, just not very stiff.  I would skip the duck (Pato en Pipian) which was a little overcooked; the sauce luke warm.  The carnitas are always a favorite of mine at Consuelo - here they were good, but a little tough.  The chicken over mashed potatoes was good.  The potatoes au gratin are fantastic - just like mom used to make - bubbly and browned with a little bit of green chiles for flair. 

If given the choice between Consuelo and Colibri, I would air on the side of Consuelo.   The extra mileage to Santa Clara is justified by the shopping opportunities on Santana Row...Gucci and Burberry lovers, eat your heart out! When it comes to Colibri, it would be good for a drink and some guac after shopping on Union Square, when you're not in the mood for your more standard Mexican options of refried beans, burritos, etc.
author: Nicole S.

description: We went for brunch and rather disappointed. The food was solid but the service was so slow and clueless, it was painful. The brunch menu had the usual huevos offerings and the sangria as good but nothing was exceptional.  Maybe the dinner is better but I say skip this place for brunch.
author: Barndi K.

description:
This place is so enjoyable that I cannot wait to come home and write my review... is that pathetic?

Just ate there, well about 5 hours ago.  We had a pitcher of Sangria, fresh guacamole, and then 2 dishes that I cannot for the life of me remember their names but boy can I describe them.

Sangria: AMAZING!  Best I have ever had.  Just the right mixture with it being not to strong and not too sweet.  I could drink way to much of it and I probably did tonight.  Best deal is to get the pitcher for $18 instead of glass for $6.  We easily finished it and the glasses are way to small that if I just went by those I would have felt ripped off.

Guacamole/Tortillas/Salsa:  All very good.... especially the corn tortillas.  The guacamole was your standard fresh guacamole but what really grabbed the deal was the warm corn tortillas along with the dipping salsas.  The pineapple salsa was especially good.

Entrees:  Both plates were great and perfectly portioned.  Neither of us could finish... granted we ate like cows with the drinks and guac.  I had a chicken with a red sauce and mash potatoes (with spinach mixed in).  The red sauce tasted like a tomato bisque soup which luckily, I love.  But the mash potatoes really took the cake, very unique and good but bordering too much spinach.

Over all great food.  The atmosphere isn't anything to write home about by the sangria and tortillas give it an automatic 5 star.  The restaurant is intimate so getting in without a long wait can be hit or miss.  We had a somewhat early dinner at 5 and were virtually the first people in there while another time we tried to go at 9:30 and there was still an hour wait.

Definitely a must try.
author: Dani N.

description:
Monday nite, plopped down at the bar with my fellow foodie fiend Elizabeth B. No reservations, just showed up and the evening began un-spooling deliciously. Live music was happenin in the center of the restaurant, just right of our ears, it was loud but good! But we're loud too, and this only boosted our usual volume.

The margarita was wonderfully tangy fresh, Eeb's Sangria might be the best I've had in eons. The little fresh tortillas and salsa, fabulous, especially the yellow (Pineapple?) and the green tomatillo. 

We had the Queso Fundido con Chorizo, Eebs began waxing nostalgic over latchkey childhood memories of her own ghetto microwave version. Colibri's was supremely delish with the fresh tortillas. I could have stopped there, but we proceeded with a fab salad: the Ensalada Mixta. We then split the Callos de Hacha (scallops), and they were soooo good, sooo good; I mean, cooked to perfection and every single thing on the plate belonged on the fork with every bite. Alas, the meal ended there, if it hadn't have been for the filling Queso, we would have been eating dessert.

Not to be neglected in mentioning:

Here are the cool things about eating at the bar, as we did. 

1) The bartender/servers were so awesome, asking us if we liked our food, and it was so obvious we were little pigs and practically rolling in it, that they had a good time with us, and we always had a drink at the ready.

2) The best old-school Mexi-Cinema playing on the LCD over the bar. When we were there, this B&W 1960s Lucha Libre movie was playing, we were inventing the dialogue and howling with laughter...funfun.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Nice upscale Mexican food just 2 blocks from Union Square.   The mole poblano is wonderful.   Excellent, tender carnitas.  For sides, try the grilled cactus.  Instead of the usual chips and salsa there are tottillas and three different dipping sauces.   Don't miss the dulce de leche churros for dessert.
author: Larry P.

description:
Not too bad.  Tapas.  Doesn't fill you up, but then again, people in this city need to realize that tapas are _appetizers_!  Not meals.

I love that they make the guacamole right in front of you.  They have some awesome tequila, which would probably mean more to me if I drank tequila outside margaritas.
author: Chris M.

description:
You've got a lot of other reviews to read and I won't repeat the same things, but take my word on this: get the pechuga ranchera and the tamarind shrimp.  oh, and the mole pablano.  Oh, that's right the cheesy cauliflour, how could I forget the delicious CHEESY dish?  I've never had a dish I didn't like at Colibri.

Simply delicious.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Colibri is a upscale Mexican Bistro at very affordable prices. My friend and I started with the fresh guacamole prepared table side. It was yummy! I was surprised that it was served with warm freshly made corn tortillas instead of chips. Along with the tortillas, it also can with 3 different types of dipping sauces: tomatillos, salsa, and mango pineapple salsa. All were very fresh and delicious.

We decided to order two entrees to share. Taking our waiter's recommendation, we had the stuffed chicken breast with mushrooms and corn. I really enjoyed this dish the best. The chicken was so moist and flavorful and the skin was so crispy. The mushrooms and corn stuffed in it was also very good. Next, we had the prawns and cornbread muffin. This dish reminded me of bbq prawns and herb biscuits but with a Mexican flare to it. It was very savory and tasty. I loved how everything had a south western touch to it.

For dessert, we had the warm chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream. Fantastic! Served warm with melted chocolate in the middle.
author: Denise L.

description:
There is something to be said about having a good time at a restaurant - and this is a place where you'll have one.  I spent a lot of money here.  Loved the guacamole.  Loved the camarrones - even if it wasn't my dish.  The servers were very friendly here.  The atmosphere is a bit loud and even brash - but it's the kind that tells you you can let go and have a bit of fun here.  My friends had a good time.  Even one didn't really like Mexican food - until now. 

When we arrived there, we were told that there was a long wait but they were good enough to get my cell number and call me the minute they had a free table - which was only a matter of 10 minutes.  

All in all - a great restaurant.
author: Lorraine D.

description:
not sure why I havent reviewed it sooner, but I guess a recent trip with a friend from another country helped.

They have really good selection of Tequila. 
I asked for a tasting of taquila under $20 and bartender serves me a $19 tequila in a desert wine glass. it was good sippin.

Guacamole is way the fuck overpriced, though traditional sounding (per our wait-staff) soft corn tortillas were great with it.

I ordered a boneless grilled chicken dish with a smooth creamy  sauce on top served on top of a bed of herbed mashed potatoes. Really tasty stuff. It had hints of spice, piquant, tang, and richness all at once.

Desert was really good too, a mexican chocolate cake (it really does taste like mexican chocolate (I know duh!) but it was really good served with vanilla icecream. instead of lightly drizzling the chocolate sauce on everything, they should have floated the fresh baked cake and icecream in a chocolate sauce puddle.

a good meal option in downtown after shopping or theater.
author: An u.

description: Food was alright - lacking a bit in diversity and options. Service was decent, nothing to applaud though.
author: Pratik T.

description:
YUM, YUM, YUM, YUM, YUM

And this is coming from a person that doesn't really like Mexican food. Was soo good. 

Appies - hubby had tamales. good. I had pozole. mmmmm i havent had pozole since high school and i have never had green pozole. wow. good. $12 or $13 is expensive for soup but I didn't regret getting it. 

entrees - hubby had filet mignon. small portion but delish. cooked perfectly. i had the lamb shank. i have to say that im not a big fan of mole sauce BUT i still liked this dish. the meat was cooked perfectly. very tender. i recc sharing this dish - anytime, anywhere if you order lamb shank. split it.

dessert - voted by me and my husband as the best dessert we've had in SF ever - the churros. classic churro outside, caramel center. dulce de leche ice cream and caramel topping. F**K, we nearly died. so good. i'd go back just for that.

oh yeah, the sangria was the best i've ever had. ever. in life. order a pitcher at $22. glasses are $8. the pitcher is worth it.

service - hmmm. ok. not bad. it was busy. 730pm on a friday night. so i guess it was ok that our waitress was a little absent at times. and was she flirting with my husband??? *eyebrows raised* i'd still come back :)

their salsa isn't anything great but the homemade tortillas are.

so all in all, for someone that isn't into Mexican food, i thoroughly enjoyed my meal and i will definitely return.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
Great guacamole, great atmosphere, but the food....a little underwhelming.  I'd say that if you're in the hood and looking for somewhere to eat, then it is probably worth it, but making a trip to go there isn't worth it.  

The problem is that the food is a little bland and inconsistent.  I got the Tilapia, which was a nice big piece of fish, and tasted pretty good, but my mom got the prawns, and there were 5. Yes, 5.  And it is not like they were big meaty prawns, they were just like normal shrimp....The mole sauce they were in was good though.  

Probably the most annoying thing is that chips are not even on the menu, and when we requested them (and got a small bowl with like 10 chips in it), and then requested another one because the portion was ridiculous, they charged $5 for each bowl of 10 chips!!!!! Please...that's insane.  When I said something to the waitress she said "well I didn't make the menu."  I was like, fantastic, because that is what I was inferring. There is also something about the place that feels a little Disneylandish, or like big franchise Mexican restaurants like El Torito....
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I love expense accounts!! 

Just had a lovely assortment of tapas and drinks at the expense of someone else! Woo-hoo!

We had the ceviche, quesadillas, and the tacos de pescado. Everything was yummy. Nothing special but good enough to eat!

We wandered over after the SF Opera's Bravo Club event at Macy's. The event was fun but the appetizer ladies just scooted by too quickly. Plus my friend is a pescatarian (??? Just fish, no yummy meats!), so she couldn't eat most of the apps. They quoted us 45 minutes for a table but after 10 a table mysteriously appeared.

We had a leisurely graze, a couple margs each (no mixtos here!!!), lots of gossip, and were thoroughly pleased.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Some of the best "true" Mexican food in the city.

If you feel like connecting to your primal roots, get the leg of lamb.  Its a big leg of juicy, barley seasoned (but ever so flavorful) meat complete with a GIANT marrow-filled femur, served atop a giant banana leaf.  Eating it, I felt like an Aztec warrior biting into a giant jungle mutton, its sweet juices pouring down my face.  Fulfillment on many a level.

And they have a giant tequila collection.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Came here with a group of friends after an event who frequent the place and it totally lived up to their rave reviews....We ordered 2 appetizers,  3entrees, and 2 desserts, we had 5 people and the portions were just right. 

The guacamole was out of this world along with the salsas to accompany it. We also got the sopes, they were tiny but tasty. We ordered the carnitas, the steak, and the shrimp....Wow..I can't explain how savory everything was and the presentation was beautfiul to match.

The servers were friendly and their description as they brought out each dish made it even more enticing.

If this wasn't enough...man their desserts are deadly. We got the churros and the crepes....so sweet but so good. Caramel is the theme as the churros are filled with it and the crepes are drenched in it.

Definitely loved my experience here and I recommend everyone try it! You'l love the food and the ambience.
author: Nicolette T.

description:
apparently, by mild guac they mean not spicy at all. =/ a bit disappointed in that. It was bordering blandness. I found it weird to eat a guac with no onion, apparently, all the onions were contained in my friend's last bite. 

I figure another reason why the guac was popular was for the hand made tortillias. I felt bad because I didnt like them that much but my friend did.
author: Candice A.

description: probably the most amazing accidental dining experience ever.  I have high standards for tortillas and these did not disappoint.  I wanted to dump the extras in my purse and continue eating them the rest of the day.
author: andrea v.

description:
Why is it so hard to find a bar in Union Square that doesn't smell like industrial-strength cleanser and isn't attached to a hotel?  Is there not a market for people who need a cocktail after schlepping through three H&M's and who don't want to pay $15 for an Appletini?  How about post-First Thursday-goers, working on a buzz from three different varietals of bad white wine?

My coworker and I went for what she calls "'ritas" (she's cuter than me) at Colibri.  I was skeptical.  Their margaritas are kind of small but they're really GOOD and they pack a wallop.  We didn't really eat- just snacks- but the tortillas were delicious, hot and fresh and flavorful, and the guacamole was possibly the best thing I've eaten in weeks.

Not so impressive - a bit cramped, way too noisy, and no less expensivo than the pomegranite cosmo at the St. Francis. (Yuck.)
author: Ani T.

description:
I've been here a couple of times with friends and we received exceptional service each time!  From the moment you walk in with the Hostess to the service at the table, everyone was friendly and seemed to enjoy their jobs!  To me, this is super important:  Good service, great people and even better food!

The second time around, we had a pre-fixe menu with a three course menu with various appetizers for $55.00, not including drinks, tips and taxes.  It was a little pricey but it was worth it!  As we were seated, the Guacamole was already ready for us and then came a train of random tasty appetizers that filled my tummy pretty quickly!  The Tortillla soup for my personal starter was my favorite!  Followed by the shrimp entree and finished off with the churro dessert.  The filet mignon was pretty scrumptious too!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Outstanding Margaritas, Guacamole to order, fresh corn tortillas = YUM! I've tried most of the menu and the Scallop and Beef entrees are repeatedly and consistently delicious.
author: Kelly S.

description:
It has taken me two days to come up with the will power to write this review, as I am still in a state of reverie from my first time at Colibri's.

The evening started out perfect; getting all dressed up with my stunning boy to go to dinner, gorgeous weather and the absolutely divine thought of having jalapeno margaritas. My date knows the bartender, Adrian, so we settled on having dinner at the bar in order to get the real experience of the restaurant. 

After a few minutes of deciding where to settle in the bar and having the owner coming over to greet us and inquire about our past visits to Adrian (this would be directed at the boy, not me, as I have never been so lucky to come before), a plate of jalapenos magically appears before us and is then drizzled with Cointreau and Cazadores. And what is not the final touch of perfection but a nice roasting session in the tequila/triple sec concoction?!? After 5 minutes of even firing, Adrian removes the jalapenos and crushes them into ice like one would a mojito, continues to build on the flavor by adding the remainder roasting liquid intermittenly between layers of mix and additional Cazadores. Served with a jalapeno, this drink is quite unique as it starts off like a normal margarita but steadily builds with fire as you swallow bits of jalapeos. Very lovely finish.

We then moved forward with our orders of guacamole and my personal favorite, sopes. The guacamole arrives fresh in a mocajete, tasting twenty times better than my Puerto Vallartan uncle's famous grind and served with the world's most delicious handmade corn tortillas. Not to mention that the sopes were finished off with a touch of fried crispness that most restaurants fail to achieve. We followed with a simple, traditional caesar salad and the final finale of carnitas that must have received three hail marys and a blessing of the santos before finding it's way to our bar stoop.

Oh, but of course! there is tequila involved. It's absolutely ridiculous to walk into a Mexican restaurant and order a Fat Tire (as some uncultured sap with his all-elbows wife decided to squeeze in next to me and order...resulting in my bluntly asking them to scoot further down so I could recover my ribcage from being battered)! But let's get back to the positive vibes, as this is about the restaurant and not inconsiderate people.

What is wonderful about Adrian is that not only does he intuitively know exactly what you want to drink, but he watches facial expressions and observes his customers reactions to the ongoing bustle in the restaurant. Please, people, not in a creepy way! He's very quiet and calm and it resonated splendidly throughout our experience. After the jalapeno margaritas, we moved into his suggested tastings. We decided on three anejos after multiple selections that really tapped our heart strings: Don Valente, Real de Penjamo, and Sotol Hacienda de Chihuahua. The final was at the recommendation of a lovely politician gentleman visiting the city from Chihuhua with his two sons to look at colleges. Our evening ended wonderfully talking to the fine senor and trying to undrown his soft-spoken eloquent accent from admist the noise of people and alluring effects of tequila. I lost last minute focus when another bartender started to create a blackberry margarita that my eyes widened three times their normal size at, in which Adrian knowningly nodded and softly asked if I would like one. 

Please note that he does not force you into outlandishly priced drinks or tequila selections, and he always asks to make sure you are getting exactly what you want. I wish I could keep him in my pocket to take along on all future restaurant adventures; he was hands down the best bartender I have encountered in the city.
author: Alita M.

description: This place is fabulous. I ate here once when I took a trip to SF with my friends and we stayed in the hotel right next door. It was really busy that Sunday night but we managed to get a table after waiting for 20 minutes. I ordered the posole sopa and the cactus with mushrooms side. Both were awesome, our waitress was super nice, and my two friends also loved their food (filet mignon and white fish). I would definitely go there again the next time i'm up north!
author: Janice L.

description: This was a find.  We attended a performance at A.C.T.  This was a perfect place to grab a bite before the performance.  All 5 of us that ate had good reviews for the food.  I had the chile relleno and a top shelf margarita.  It was perfect.
author: Irma G.

description:
UPDATE 6/20/06:
My fiance and I finally came here for dinner, and were very happy with the food and service. We were able to get seated right away without reservations on a Friday night. We wondered where we could find someone to make guacamole at home for us all the time. The small corn tortillas went really well with the guac, but I have to say that I still like the guac at Maya better. The carnitas were delicious, and the grilled half chicken wrapped in a giant banana leaf was good. Next time, I'll have to leave room for dessert.

I knew someone who was staying at Hotel Diva so we decided to have drinks next door at Colibri. The mojitos and sangria were so good! We didn't have any food, but after reading all the great reviews, I'll definitely be back for dinner. This is a place to definitely check out if you're looking for a good Mexican restaurant in Union Square.
author: Connie C.

description: Went here with a group last Saturday night and had a great time. The margaritas are delicious and the tortillas are the best I've ever had. I'm not sure what it is about them that makes them so delicious but they are amazing! It's a little on the expensive side and the portions are somewhat small but I would definitely go back.
author: Gina C.

description: Collibri is one of my favorites.   Has the best guacamole that you can order to your taste (mild, medium, spicy).  Three types of salsa with warm tortillas are brought upon seating.  The menu is small plate Mexican; love the chicken mole.  There is an excellent brunch with a $10 bottomless mimosa (best price I have seen it SF ).  Only negative is the service, it can be slow.
author: Jeanne B.

description:
Had lunch here yesterday and what can I say but they need to bring chips to the table, the tortilla thing is nice but I want chips.  

The food is ok, I had the chicken mole and it was ok, too sweet and not spicy enough for me, also I dont think they cook the chicken in the sauce, I feel they boil the chicken then add the sauce over it which is NOT the way to cook mole.

Rice is NOT an expensive ingredient so they could add more than a thimble.
author: G R.

description: Colibri is great. It's expensive, though. The guacamole is good, but they don't give you much for your $8. Drinks are excellent. I prefer to go grab drinks and just a couple of bites.
author: Monika M.
