description: I've eaten here a couple of times and I really love the food.  Its all quite fresh and they do deliver on flavor as well.  Today I had the taco plate... very good.   Fish, steak, and chicken... all were fantastic.  What I love most about this spot are the fresh corn tortillas.  They are out of this world!  Love 'em!   The staff is friendly... I would suggest making a reservation as this spot gets quite packed on the weekends and evenings.
author: David C.

description:
It's rare to find Mexican fine dining that lives up to that name. Because I'm a huge fan of Rick Bayless and the many wonderful Mexican restaurants in Chicago and can cook a mean Mexican dinner myself, I am tired of being directed to Taquerias for the best that SF has to offer in Mexican cuisine.

This place changed my mind! I went here early last December for a special dinner with my boyfriend and his parents. The decor was old Mexico style: beautiful dark wood and large, enclosed booths. Our service was outstanding!! The manager came by to ask how everything was, but the server, a young woman who I wanted to hug after our meal, made the experience. She was friendly and attentive, but not fake or in our faces. I wish I could remember her name... she was one of the best servers I've encountered in years.

I don't know what kind of drinks the other yelpers had, but ours were amazing. We had several specialty margaritas and the berry ones were unique and lovely. More importantly, the food lived up to the great descriptions on the menu.

And, oh, the guacamole... mmmmmm. Save up your drunken taco money and come here for a real taste of Mexican cuisine.

nb.
I just went back here the other night and had to find out that all-star server's name: Bethany. She's terrific!! and the blackberry margarita still rocks.
author: G Z.

description:
I'll keep this short since this place has been reviewed so many times.

First, our service was pleasant but largely absent.

The $10 guac was the highlight, although it wasn't made at our table as indicated on the menu.

They were out of non-fruity-flavored rum the night we went.

It's not really tapas -- the servings are normal entree sized.

The cesar salad is sooo bland.  We requested pepper, but that still wasn't enough to salvage it.

We requested our filet mignon to be medium rare; it came out medium well.

The carnitas were also overcooked and dry.

The espresso flan was pretty good, though (not spectacular, but we ate most of it).

There was a mistake on our bill (we were charged a drink we didn't get).  But service was so slow, that we decided to just ignore it so we could get a move on our night.

We did get 1000 open table points, though.

You might end up here because you want Mexican, but you want a full bar or you want a nice sit down meal.  Do yourself a favor, get over it.  (OK.  I've never been to Maya, so maybe head there.)  Get your Mexican fill from one SF's excellent taqueria's or do without the full bar and head to Mi Lindo Yucatan in Noe Valley.  This place is not worth it.
author: S J.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite places to eat before going to the Curran or Geary Theatre.  It's easy, fast, and quite tasty.  Usually we just get appetizers - my favorites are made-to-order (kinda) guacamole and the ceviche.  yum yum.  Going there tonight!

(it definitely gets crowded, though [at least on play nights], so I'd recommend reservations or getting there early to sit at the bar)
author: Kerry L.

description:
UPDATE 12/29/06:
My last experience here was awful so only one star and that is for the consistently excellent tortillas, guacamole,salsas,  and margaritas.   However,  it was practically empty, and it took FOREVER to get our food and once we got the entrees they were cold, not tepid, COLD.  I don't ever want to go back. 
First time at Colibri today, and I can't wait to go back.  It was super super super tasty.  Excellent Herradura Margarita, Guacamole made fresh in front of you, Hot fresh tortillas, and my number one weakness: mole poblano.  The three salsas were all delicious as well, especially the mango. Colibri has a beautiful bar, and nestled up amongst the bottles behind it, a tv playing an old mexican black and white film. I am hooked.
Update: 10/13 Super good chicken in garlic sauce
author: sarah C.

description:
Wonderful friendly service. Lively cheerful interior.  Tasty food.  And stunning guacamole made right at your table.  Bueno!

And I would give six stars if I could for the waitress who snuck in extra tortillas, still piping hot, for our little bag of leftovers.  :-)
author: Jess S.

description:
Strolled into Colibri with a friend well past 9pm, when many other restaurants around Union Square didn't look too promising. And oh boy, were we in for a surprise!
The guacamole and tortilla soup are among the best I have ever had. The Chile Relleno was also really good! Came back raving about it to my hubby, who was sweet enough to surprise me with a dinner there a month later :)
This time, we also ordered the interesting-sounding Mole Poblano (chicken with a sauce with chocolate in it - among other things!), which was ummm...interesting. I didn't finish it coz it became too much in the end but I am not regretting ordering it.

The ambience of the place is also nice except for the fact that the tables are way too close together.

Service has been good both times. This Mexican dude who was nice and chatty the first time was a little grumpy the second time though...oh well, everybody can have a bad day! :)
author: Shradha B.

description:
It really says something when, on a workday, I get to down pricey margaritas (that's plural) with lunch and don't have to pick up the check--yet I still end up giving a restaurant something of a pan. And here I am giving Colibri a reluctant two stars--it really deserves about 2.5 stars. 

My third trip to this Union Square Mexican bistro--a Friday at lunch--was by far the least impressive, and marks for me a downward trajectory for the restaurant that I once recommended to friends when they were in the surrounding area.

The very small portions of improperly cooked meat dishes (beef ordered medium must never manifest itself as bloody, red and cool to the touch, and carnitas should never be bone-dry and under-flavored) were not quite offset by the fantastic tableside guacamole with fresh, hot tortillas. If we had only had margaritas and guacamole, this review would be much better--alas, we ordered food.

And although the table service was good, our reservation apparently didn't amount to much--we had to actively push for a better table, which they reluctantly gave us. I mean, hey--we're four coworkers looking to chug some premium tequila from their extensive list over a two-hour "working lunch"--don't put us in the freakin' streetfront window. We're not tourists. 

I'm not sure I will return.
author: Raoul U.

description:
This is an amazing place that tends to be a little busy.
It is heavy on the Mole dishes.

Here's my video review:
http://www.kyte.tv/channels/view.html?name=Restaurant_Reviews#uri=channels/18416/67950
author: Oren F.

description:
I was really amazed to find this bistro lurking practically around the corner from Union Square. The dishes are small and almost tapas style, but the quality is amazing. I had the Pechanga Ranchero and Mexican rice, with a few other appetizers that were passed around my party.

The drinks were fresh and I wasn't disappointed at all when it came to everything.

I think the service could have been a bit more responsive, but to be honest at a place like this I don't intend on going in, quickly eating and leaving. I would rather sit and chill for a while with a group of friends and ruminate for a while over some very tasty food.

If you go in with a mindset like that, then the restaurant will be a much better experience.
author: Mark H.

description:
Update:  I'm knocking this place down a star.  It seems to be on the decline.  i recently had crappy service, and mediocre food.

With superb margaritas (really excellent), pretty good food, and a nice atmosphere, this place is a winner.  The service was a little slow, and we were in a difficult to reach corner, so i don't think they came by as often as they should have (it could have been a 4 margarita night if they'd been on it), but over-all, it was very good.

Like so many have mentioned, we loved the quacamole, which we asked for extra spicy.  It caused some tongue-throbbing at first, but later we could scoop it up in big bites.

I had the Fillet Mignon, which had wonderful Mexican flavoring.
lleno

The pretty girl across from me had the Chili Relleno.  She liked it lots.
author: Richard B.

description: Nothing wrong. Nothing special. Tamales and rellenos were fine, but hardly memorable. if I was downtown and needed to eat, I'd go again, but that's all the effort i would muster.
author: David A.

description: Best meal I have had in a long time. I stumbled upon this restaurant while walking down the street looking for a good meal. At first glance the inside looks like a traditional mexican restaurant. Took about 5 min. for the waitress to recognize I was in the building but after I got seated I immediately ordered the civeche for an appitizer. It was amazing! For the main course I ate the sea bass which was absolutely amazing. And for desert I had the churros. Probably the most spectacular things you can get there. (These ain't the churros you find on the street vendors corner) These are as authentic as it gets. Anyways, the food and service was amazing. I would definetly go back and reccommend.
author: Alec M.

description:
Came here again and tried the mole and tostadas de tinga.  Mole was pretty bad and the chicken was tasteless, and the tostadas were OK, but I probably could've done the same with a quick trip to the mexican supermarket and a tortilla chip from Safeway.

Also, our server was rather inattentive and seemingly "forgetful."

Averaging out with our first visit, which was exceptional, I had to knock Colibri down a couple stars.  (Guacamole was still awesome btw)
author: Peter L.

description:
Yes, the guacamole is superb. 
Yes, the drinks are tasty and well-crafted. 
Yes, the entrees are delicious, perfectly executed, and quite tiny. 
Yes, the decor and atmosphere is rustically elegant and lovely.
And yes, the service is TERRIBLE. 

So I roll up to Colibri at 5:30 on a Sunday with some friends, and we tell the hostess we'd like to have a drink or two at the bar and then move to a table. She assures us it'll be no problem and puts our name into Open Table. We settle down to the bar and savor some perfect margaritas and caiparinhas. An hour goes by, and we let the hostess know that we'd like to sit. The manager comes over straight away and takes us to a table in the very back of the restaurant, right by the waitstation and the bathroom. Not really wanting to be in such immediate proximity to the surprisingly dingy and dirty bathrooms, we inform the hostess we'd like to wait for another table. And here's where everything starts to fall apart.

The heavily-cologned manager comes over and informs us it will be thirty minutes before we could be seated at a different table. We say sure, no problem. Thirty minutes will be fine. He asks us again, are we sure we don't want the other table? Again, not a problem, we say. But your bar seats are already gone, he replies. Are we sure we want to wait thirty min? Hmm.... starting to feel like he's threatening us to take the lousy table! But no, we will wait thirty min. We'll have another $12 margarita. 

AN HOUR AND A HALF LATER : 5 walk-in tables have been seated. We watch them walk in, watch them be seated. Frustration mounting!!! We inquire at the host desk. Apparently the hostess marked us as No Show in OT. One of my dining companions gets a bit stern with the manager ( a rarity for him) and we finally , finally get seated. We were very close to walking out, but didn't want to wait for a table somewhere else. 

Once we were seated, the server was extremely attentive. It would have been nice for the manager to send us a round of drinks, or an amuse, or SOMETHING, but he apparently was unconcerned with fixing a bad situation. Ah well. The guacamole was delightful! I love the dipping sauces for the warm tortillas they serve in lieu of tortilla chips.The sangria was ok, and the entrees tasted....perfect. I had the filet mignon, and it was cooked excellently. I would def recommend getting an appetizer as well as an entree, because the portion size it T-I-N-Y. This wouldn't be a problem if they were advertised on the menu as small plates or tapas, but I was expecting a full entree. Hrm. Dessert was average. 

All in all, Colibri could be great if they got their management situation figured out. The bathrooms were unacceptable, the hostess was demonstrably flaky, and the manager himself was rude and incompetent. Oh, and he reeked of cheap cologne-- a major no no for anyone in the restaurant biz. I might go back here, but I'll sit at the bar and restrict myself to drinks and guac.
author: Kristina H.

description: Awesome authentic Mexican restaurant with great ambience and reasonable prices! The guacamole and queso fundido were amazing. Best I ever had! The stuffed filet was very good for the price as well. This is a must restaurant if your looking Mexican in Union Square!
author: Robert B.

description:
Excellent Mexican "tapas".  I'm tempted to remove another star just because evertthing is "tapas". But I'm a fan of small-plate cuisine; I just wish we had other monikers for this fun way of eating.

The made-at-your-table guacamole  is delicious but the concept is kind of annoying.  Benihana Michaocana anyone?

The hand-made tortillas are delicous. Order the crepes with cajeta for dessert. And just enjoy. Reasonable prices, nice atmosphere, great service.

Almost perfect.
author: James E.

description: Eh.  Cool looking interior and a good vibe (aside from some hostess asking us to move closer to the bar to not block the walkway...maybe you shouldn't put a bar in a location where people need to stand, and maybe bring your bar area in 2 feet unless your bartenders are doing Cocktail routines), but why were 3 scallops $18?  $6/scallop...man when I put it that way I kinda want to drop another star.  Scallops with some tortilla on top, resting on a bed of bland bean mash.  We all shared the guac, and it was guac, nothing more or less.  Why are people so impressed with guac anyway?  Go buy some avo, chop it up, add some onions, cilantro, lime and it wont ever be bad.  The homemade tortillas were really good though.  My friend liked her carnitas, and my gf liked what she got.  Then again she didn't pay, so I'm jaded.  I'd go again if I was outvoted.
author: A A.

description: Absolutely delicious food and margaritas!  The homemade tortillas and the tortita papas were fabulous.  Can't wait to go back and try something different.
author: Angela C.

description:
Seriously, a mexican restaurant that doesnt serve chips? 

This no chips thing really did perplex me, I mean really?  Luckily, chips were replaced with homemade warm tortillas, although they were good (and distracting from my original question) I still wondered.... why no chips?

We got the Quacamole served table-side, tasty, for $10 I was glad that you actually do get quite a bit of quacamole.  Still a bit steep, maybe its like ticketmaster and there is like a $3 service charge, just for showing up at your table. (Again no chips, so we had ourselves some quacamole soft tacos)

We shared the Carnitas (meh, very bland) and the Ceviche (great) which was served with (Gasp) chips!  I know, I didnt see it coming either. We enjoyed all 7 of our chips with our ceviche.

All in all, it was an okay meal leaving me craving tortilla chips.
author: Sara Ann S.

description: I love sitting at the bar here and drooling over all of the gorgeous tequila bottles, and watching the black & white silent Spanish movies.  The warm tortillas with trio of slasa's is an excellent start.  Wish they had a few more veg friendly options.
author: Maya R.

description:
Over the course of the last 8 months, I've been to Colibri 3 times.

My first time there was good... I have to say their guacamole is superb.  Drinks are fantastic... their tequila selection is unmatched.  

Recently I've returned and was surprised at how my impression of the place had turned for the worse.  I had the mole and the carnitas on two different occasions, both of which are easy to find elsewhere in the city, and they were not tasty at all.  There just wasn't enough "sabor", or flavor, in either dish.  My date and I both agreed that it just wasn't that satisfying.

Given that this place is overpriced, next time I would only stick around for drinks and a quick guacamole dish and chips, but nothing more.  Save your money and get a real Mexican feast in the Mission or even at  Tres Agaves... their carnitas were much tastier.
author: Jose R.

description:
My husband and I stumbled across this great Mexican Bistro on our honeymoon. It was across the street from our hotel. Boy, were we in for a treat!

They have over 400 tequilas - hopefully you'll catch a spot at the bar when Will's working. He knows more about tequila than my husband does and he's a connoisseur! 

The menu is excellent - I selected scallops and I can't really remember what my husband ordered. All I know is that my food was melt in your  mouth good. So, here I sit in Texas dreaming of some scallops from Colibri! As an appetizer, they'll bring out warm, homemade tiny tortillas and 3 dipping sauces (all are excellent). My husband can't eat spicy salsas and was delighted to find their fruity dip. 

You can't leave this place without having a margarita. They will knock the socks off of any other drink that has claimed to be a true margarita. Their churro and cajeta dessert is divine.

We loved this place so much that we met up with our friends here a few nights later. You will not be disappointed.
author: Stephanie V.

description:
I find myself, once again, in San Fran on business.  I went here for a lunch meeting on recommendation of a colleague familiar with the area.  Wasn't really in the mood for mexican, but I was pleasantly surprised.  The interior was not overly cheesy and was just enough of the mexican flair expected.  Spanish music was playing but not too loud so that you want to wolf down your food to the beat and get the hell out of there.

Started off with the guacamole.  Yum.  I also ordered a sangria.  Very delicious, not overly sweet.  Yum again.  My main entree was the Mole Poblano.  It was pretty good.  Not the best.  The sauce was a little overpowering with the chicken, which was a bit dry.  Overall, good place to go for decent mexican food.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Been here twice now, and ready to say that it's good. 

The tableside guacamole is lovely, and the house-made tortillas are divine. They're put to especially good use in the epazote quesadilla. Another standout dish was the chicken with huitlacoche...mmm. I wouldn't order the chile relleno again -- too much squash in the stuffing -- but everything else I have tried there has been tasty. Service is a little ditzy, but... considering the lack of other decent-to-good food in the area, I can live with that.

Tasty house margaritas, too.
author: anita c.

description:
Good, high-end Mexican bistro, with a very well-stocked bar.

Prices are reasonable if not cheap, and the portions are on the large side for a place that declares the main courses as "tapas style" on the menu.

I found the introductory "Hi, have you been here before" and subsequent explanation of tapas a bit odd, considering we're in a major city, and tapas isn't a particularly new trend.  Maybe there's a large tourist presence?  I probably shouldn't point fingers, as I was only in town for the weekend myself.

The guacamole is good but honestly not as good as I expected from the buildup, although accompanying it with tortillas rather than chips is very nice, slowing down my over-stuffing chip consumption that's the usual product of me and a bowl of chips.

The chicken in mole sauce is excellent: nutty with a hint of chocolate that didn't overwhelm.  The molten chocolate cake with clearly homemade ice cream is delightful, though, so save room.
author: Chris F.

description:
Wow, I had a very yummy brunch here on Sunday!
I thought the place was pretty cute and the service was very good. I loved the hand made, warm tortillas and the three great salsas. I had looked at their lunch menu on line, so I was a bit surprised  with the brunch menu, but I have no complaints. Everything had so much flavor. I can't wait to come back and try their dinner menu.
BTW, huge selection of tequila!
author: Lisa A.

description:
yelp has done it again! I was looking for a good Mexican place that wasn't a taqueria and found this one.

I tried this place this weekend for dinner with an old friend. I had gotten there before him, so I waited at the bar where I had excellent service from the bartender who made me a really delicious caipirinha. (so good, I ordered a 2nd one)

So anyway, for dinner we tried the freshly made guacamole (because of all the reviews here) and ordered it spicy (you get to choose your level of spiciness). I was expecting a really nice, fiery guac but it was pretty tame. Still very good nonetheless, especially with the tortillas and 3 dipping sauces (chili, tomatillo and mango).
We also tried the ceviche (incredibly fresh tasting--probably my favorite dish), mole poblano, tamales (also covered in the same mole sauce--very tasty) and a side of their black beans. Even though it was tapas style, we couldn't finish everything!

 I'm curious to try the other dishes, as they all sound very appetizing and the service was great. I will definitely go back.
author: kristin e.

description:
Since work sends me to Union Square regularly I asked the concierge where to go for brunch and they recommended this spot.  

While I feel rather reluctant about Mexican food in general I was really happy to have come here with my colleague.  We feasted on their warm, rich, fresh tortillas and the amazing dips they offer.  We got the guacamole prepared table-side and it was some of the best we ever had.  Then the topper was the mole that covered our eggs dish. Soft, sultry chocolate flavored goodness.  I left full, happy, make that exuberant, and had a great nap with Mexican themed dreams.  Gracias Colibri!
author: Paulie E.

description:
If you like maximum crowdedness, paired with mouth-watering tapas, you will pee yourself over Colibri. 

First of all, the guacamole is amazing. I hate avocado and guacamole in general (looks like snot to me), but Colibri's gooey green goodness is too amazing not to smear all over a tortilla. 

The portions are small (duh, tapas), but I like that because everything is so good that you can eat multiple starches and animals without looking like an overeater. The chili chicken, spanish rice, potatoes, and filet minion are our ultimate favorites. 

Their tequila bar is pretty impressive too. One of my friends is a tequila nerd and he tried to show up the bar tender, failing completely. This thoroughly amused the rest of us. 

Lunch selection is a little sucky, but if you're looking to stuff yourself with tapas and tequila mid-day, it's time for you to spend your afternoons in AA.
author: Elaine R.

description: Good restaurant.  Food was very authentic and the service very attentive.  The only negative was, being so popular, it was rather noisy.
author: Marcia C.

description: Awesome, had the tostada de pollo or something like it and it was awesome!
author: Matt B.

description:
Wow!  I knew I was in for something good when I looked over the "margarita list" - yes, you heard me, not the wine list, the margarita list!  Who knew there were so many to choose from?  I went for the blackberry and was not disappointed.  And the sangria was so smooth and sweet...just amazing.

And the food!  You have to go for the guacamole, which is prepared for you right at your table.  The guy who made ours was so serious about it that it felt like a sacred ceremony not to be taken lightly, and did not disappoint.  The corn bread was a tasty slice with real bits of corn and a delicious sauce.  The lamb was just falling off the bone it was so tender, and the fillet mignon was excellent as well.

Que rica!
author: Corey C.

description: Definitely a meh. We missed brunch by 30 minutes, so be it, but found the regular menu to be really sparse and somewhat pricey. I only saw one chicken dish under apps, stewed chicken, which might include dark meat, that sort of thing. I ended up with a chili relleno, which was not fried with batter (which I am ok with) but it was really bland. Portions are small, I almost dove into the Jack in the Box nearby after lunch because I left hungry. No chips, no sides with mains that we ordered, and fairly slow service that we had to flag down a few times, even for drink refills.
author: Linda K.

description: I love this place because of their tequila selection. The food is also delicious! It's a perfect place to grab a quick bite before you go to a show at the theater, too. I was able to set up shop at the bar and have some ceviche and a Macho Margarita at the bar. What is this Macho Margarita I speak of? It's basically a jalapeno that they douse in alcohol and set on fire and then after the flame goes out, it's muddled and made into a spicy delicious drink. I think it's a genius drink. I would never have thought of setting a jalapeno on fire. It's almost like a Flaming Moe brought to life.
author: Caroline L.

description: A solid upscale Mexican restaurant.  I tried the fish ceviche which was fresh, but nothing mind blowing.  The guacamole is very good just as the other reviews mention.  They also have a nice selection of liquors to choose from.
author: Orry M.

description:
Colibri...  aka BEST GUAC in SF (ask any of the other reviewers).  They'll do it up to your liking right there at your table (hot, mid, spicy, no onions, extra tomato - whatever you want).  The guacamole is accompanied by warm tortillas and 3 different flavored sauces for you to dip your flour made break like goodness into.

As an entre, I tend to go with the scallops (that are about as big as my fist as I cut through them with my fork like warm butter).  

The staff is on point and moves quick from the time you're seated until the time when you're reviewing the desert menu.  

The place is probably known best for its variety of Tequilas, but do yourself a favor and order up a pitcher of Sangria (unless you're a non-drinker in which case I'd recommend you get a bottle of Voss).  :-)

Either way, Colibri is a great establishment and if you can't already tell from the other reviews, it is not, "your average Mexican Joint".  It has far more class than any reference to "average" could do it justice.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
love, Love, LOVE this place. It's my new favorite restaurant/bar.

Drinks are great, service is friendly, menu is awesome (I want to try everything). So far have gotten the tamales with mole sauce (yum), the duck in green mole sauce (even more yum), and the guacamole they make right by your table (did I mention yum?). I love that instead of chips, they give you handmade warm tortillas and the salsas with it are great. Oh and save room for the chorros rellenos for dessert! Caramel stuffed churros over dulce de leche icecream....mmmmm (I swear this was all on different visits and not all at once! Ok so maybe it was just 2 visits)

Only thing I would say is that if you are a fan of spicy foods, they pretty much stay in the mild range of things. Oh well, it's still good.
author: Sarah P.

description: Came here for brunch last weekend with a few friends. I ordered the Enchiladas Divorciadas with chicken, which were decent but sort of bland. They have 'bottomless' mimosas, which everyone ordered, and those were good. We also ordered the churro dessert to share, which was 2 churros filled with caramel, served with vanilla bean ice cream. That was so delicious. I would go back for the dessert again, but probably after I had a meal somewhere else.
author: Karin L.

description: Went here for dinner with some friends. First time in San Francisco and was hoping to get some good mexican food, but I was sadly disappointed. While the guac was good and the sopes decent, the mole was horrendous! I swear they got it from a jar. however, the Sangria at this place was the BEST! We ordered two pitchers back to back. But overall, me thinks it's over-priced and over-rated, but our waitress was great and the service good. otherwise, skip this joint.
author: Kara M.

description: We came here for $10 bottomless mimosas but ended up liking the restaurant overall.  This is a nice, sit-down Mexican restaurant with a warm, sunny decor.  Crowd is older, which was surprising given they have bottomless mimosas.  They give you three complimentary salsas which was good but I was disappointed that it was served with soft tortillas not crispy nacho chips.  We actually ended up not getting mimosas (alcohol the night before + coffee in the morning + spicy salsa for brunch = not a happy stomach) but the food was pretty good and authentic, so we were glad we found this place. Maybe I'll come back to try dinner sometime.  Freshly made guacamole looked especially good.
author: Jen K.

description:
I came here for an early dinner before a show. Overall, the experience was amazing but a little pricy because items on the menu come a la carte . Other Yelper's were on the mark about the guacamole, tortilla's, sangria, and the dip/sauce/salsa. I have had good and bad sangria and theirs fell into the very very good category. I felt adventurous and tried the Brocheta de Mariscos Estilo Zihuatanejo (grilled seafood, veg, and bacon) off of their Regional menu and I did not regret it.

I recommend reserving a table especially if you have plans after dinner like seeing a show. I would come here again but maybe not often because of the price.
author: H L.

description:
Ok, so I'm sure my friend will be furious I thought to review this gem before him (ha! I'm sly and quick like a fox darling!).  Although to be fair, I introduced him to Colibri last year, so I should have first dibs....

Almost everything about this place gets the double thumbs up.  The atmosphere is a comforting yet lively haven from the consumer-tour-ism driven to-do in this neck of the woods.  The bar is breath-taking with it's endless varieties of top-shelf tequila (some going for thousands a shot) and the tv hanging above it plays black and white Mexican movies - a lovely touch.

The food is a wonderful melange of tastes and textures which all seem quite authentic (being an Eastern-European whitie, I can't vouch for it).  The mole chicken, scallops, and fish are all excellent. And the drinkies, you ask? They're refreshing and tasty - try the sangria (I love chewing on the drunken fruit at the bottom once I've finished!).

As for the obnoxious tourists - well, you can almost pretend they aren't there while noshing and imbibing at this tasty treasure.
author: Ania L.

description:
I am a fan of the Guacamole.  Might go back for drinks cause the food was OK and the service SUCKED.

What is with the rudeness, not to mention the constant drift of cig smoke flowin - as they keep the door open and allow patrons to pretty much smoke within the restaurant - GROSS.
author: Kiki I.

description:
Party of 4, 8:30 reservations.  We over-ordered - guacamole was tasty, nice balance and buttery smooth.  We shared 5 dishes, duck, chicken mole, scallops, shrimp, and carnitas.  All were ok, scallops overcooked, carnitas dry.  A round of strawberry margaritas were above-average; the fresh strawberries a highlight.

Service was fair with the only strong performance put in by the water-filler, who was completely on top of her game.  Trying to clear our dishes while we were still eating...big no no.
author: Jason L.

description: Food, drinks and service are flawless. Those who don't agree, simply don't know any better.
author: P B.

description: My boyfriend and I had stepped off a plane, refreshed at our hotel, and brought our hungry stomachs to Colibri to do it up Mexican style, since where else but in California do you do that!  We were in luck as the happy hour special was going on (Monday thru Friday from 3:30-5:30pm - so good for teachers) and we ordered two rounds of the house margarita (done well), gaucamole and real spicy, I mean it was the spiciest I've ever had it with warm delicious tortillas (SO SO good), some delicious salsas - verde and rojas, and oxaca cheese quesadilla....so good.  It was worth it, and the bartender was so friendly.  Great spot!
author: Namrata A.

description:
I have been frequenting Colibri for about a year now...it is a fantastic little mexican restaurant hidden amongst the tourist traps and hotels of the Union Square/Theatre District.  I have been there numerous times, and always leave very satisfied and VERY full...try one of their mixed coctails, or go with the classica margarita...everything I've had is FABULOUS!  The guacamole is a MUST - prepared table-side to your liking...it comes with warm tortillas and three dipping sauces.  I recommend ordering tapas style; get a number of small appetizers to share!  My favs - the empenadas and sauteed prawns...

The ambiance is perfect and the food is fantastic - this restaurant is a sure thing...
author: Jessica T.

description: really like this place!  Delicious tapas style restaurant.  Guacamole, Queso Fondito, Chili Relleno....and Margaritas (with a selection of 50+ different tequila)....all good stuff.  I'd definitely stop by again!
author: Eric L.

description:
Yet another mediocre and overpriced restaurant in the Union Square area that attracts mainly tourists and theater-goers looking for a convenient bite to eat.  I don't understand the 4-star rating, but maybe the majority were written by middle america out-of-towners who have never tasted mexican food before.

I'll start with the bar...6 of us ordered house margaritas. I can honestly say that it was the worst margarita I have ever had. Not one of us liked it. First of all I prefer blended to rocks any day but they don't even do blended (rolls eyes).  What we got was a flavorless mix of a lot of margarita mix, very little tequila, and a crap load of ice that watered down an already too watery concoction.  The bartender also seemed unfriendly, but maybe he's just not happy working at a sub-par restaurant.

The food....meh....they don't have many classic Mexican dishes that I was hoping for. The entree selection seemed dominated by things that seemed more American to me than Mexican. Just because you throw some Mexican spices onto a leg of lamb doesn't make it Mexican food. I ordered the tilapia tacos. They gave me 3 tiny corn tortillas with very minimal filling, which were $12. I could have easily eaten 3 more and I'm not even a big eater. I also ordered a side of black beans which was $6. I could go to Rubio's (mexican fast food chain) and have the same thing for under $10, which would fill me up more and taste just as good if not better. Ouch.

The prices. We expected to pay a lot because of the location...okay, that's fine, I get it, but give me something I can sink my teeth into if that is going to be the case...the portions were offensively small and there were absolutely no perks.  We even had to pay for the little birthday crepe and tiny scoop of ice cream that we requested for our friend's bday.  

Something really popular here is the made-at-your-table guacamole. It sucks, don't get it, unless watery guacamole is your thing. They put way too much lime juice in it. You also don't get very much. Plus, it's 12 bucks and if you want it with chips, it'll cost you 14. I wouldn't be surprised if they charge for tap water. 

The service was also nothing to write home about.  I don't remember anyone coming to our table to check on us or even to refill our waters.

Needless to say, I won't be back.
author: L. Renee D.

description: Good food.  Interesting take on Mexican food.. Enjoyed the guacamole .. Hard to find huitlacoce..  They had plenty..
author: Robert F.

description:
I had dinner with two friends on June 19 at Colibri' restaurant in Union Square. 
This has been a restaurant I have wanted to try for some time and looked forward to finally getting to dine here and share the experience with my two good friends.
Not being familiar with Mole, I decided to order a starter of Chicken Tamales with a Mole sauce. I'm from New Mexico, so I know a good Tamale when I taste one. The Tamale appetizer came with three small tamales already out of the husk with a light brown Mole sauce over them. They tasted fine but I felt they were a bit mushy, perhaps over steamed because they are smaller than a standard size tamale. The mole enhanced the taste and to me tasted similar to a Satay Sauce only not so nutty. The only downside to the appetizer was swallowing a small chicken bone that was inside one of the tamales.
 
For the next course I decided to try the Jicama Salad with Citrus wedges, avocado, cilantro and Chile Piquin dressing. 
This was a colorful and healthy serving on top of Jicama slices that were in a small stack, the citrus wedges were more crushed than wedge like but definitely added to the crunchiness of the Jicama. The avocado was also a nice layer of flavor and the chile piquin dressing was not overly spicy but more of a lightly sour dressing which added to the sweetness of the citrus.
 
By the time I finished the salad I was full and opted not to order an entree' however one of my friends ordered the Carnitas served with Guajillo and Chile de Arbol Salsa; she let me have a taste. A healthy serving of 4 large pieces of Carnitas was served with the salsa served on the side. The salsa was a bit spicy, but in my opinion it only enhanced the Carnitas. The Carnitas were very tender and flavorful. Anyone who needs a cornivore fix will leave the table satisfied.
 
We ended the meal with Dessert, I ordered the Mango Creme Brulee', my two other friends ordered the Churros and Tres Leches cake. All three were quite good but we felt the Mango Creme Brulee' was the best, very light and the sweetness of the mango brought out the creme brulee'. The Churros are handmade and filled with a Cajeta sauce, rolled in sugar and cinnamon and served warm with ice cream. I felt the churros although tasty were a bit heavy but tasted nice with the single espresso I had with my dessert. The third dessert, the Tres Leches cake was good but our least favorite. The menu said sponge cake with tres leches but we didn't see or taste the tres leches, it was very sweet and light.

One of my friends had a Mojito and I had a soft drink, our bill averaged $40per person.
author: David P.

description:
I was craving for some Mexican food and decided to try Colibri. I walked in without a reservation and got a table for myself though the restaurant was very crowded. That was nice.

The Menu had Vegetarian options and the waitress suggested me to try the Chile Relleno. She told me that the portion is not quite filling so i ordered a side of Mexican Rice. The food was good but the portions turned out to be small as informed. I am not a huge eater still i felt the food was not enough. The service was quick though. But Not worth to pay $20 for half full stomach. 3 stars

The ambiance was good. Little noisy but it was okay. Three stars

Service. The waitress was good but she did not offer me a dessert though i told  her that i was not full.2 stars. Overall 3 is what i feel like today.Maybe will go back to try something else
author: Sankar B.

description: First meal after the SF marathon..Colibri!!! Super quacamole made at your table! Homemade tortillas, chile relano, carnitas...everything was so good! Staff was friendly too!
author: V. S.

description: I am a BIG FAN Colibri's eats n' drinks. I go there "every other time" I visit SF. Why don't I go EVERY TIME I'm in SF??? The prices and portions. Do you enjoy paying $17 for 3 nicely dressed chicken breast chunks of "Mole Poblano"? I don't, but it's OH SO YUMMY. How do I reconcile this HIGH price and LOW portion entree??? Extra complimentary fresh tortillas and salsa (esp the pineapple one) and splitin' the entree with a BFF. Doing so allows this humble educator to AFFORD a $12 premium tequila margarita in a mexi-sexy atmosphere. TRUST that I will still return to Colibri "every other time." Should U care to split some "Mole Poblano" with a Colibri "every other" vato, please LMK. {;o)
author: Serjio A.

description: Excellent food, excellent service. The best margaritas I've ever had. We were in town for a meeting and went there twice because it was so good.
author: William N.

description:
I heard about this place from one of my co-workers who said I had to try it. The guacamole was fantastic. The carnitas were excellent and the mole poblano was very good. The mole is the best restaurant mole I've ever had. It tasted almost as good as my aunt's. 

The atmosphere was very lively. Lots of people. Very crowded as expected on a Saturday night. I'm docking half a star for the service, which was slow. Again to be fair, it was a Saturday night so that's why I'm only docking half a star. But to have to wait 30 minutes for our dessert to arrive was painful. When it was finally delivered, our waiter aplogized profusely. After waiting 30 minutes, it should've been comped. 

I'm docking the other half star for the prices. I thought they were a bit high given the portion sizes. The drink prices were also extremely high. $11 for what amounted to a shot of tequila? I'm only docking half a star because I'm sure the rent near Union Square can't be cheap. After having said all of that, I would recommend it if you're in the area and want to try something new and enjoy a good atmosphere. I'll be trying it again, but on a weeknight...salud!
author: Phil S.

description: Overpriced place. The waiter was rude and the food was very bland. GUACOMOLE and MOJITO were nice but everything else including the desert was really bad.
author: Vivek S.

description: i go back to colibri only if i'm animal hungry and in rush to catch a show at A.C.T. Otherwise mediocre food where you pay 3x more than flavorful mexican spots in the mission.
author: Beril Y.

description:
Dim. Cordial. Festive.

The bf and I stumbled upon this gem while lingering around Union Square - what a find!  The 4 star rating may be slightly attributed to my absence of expectations (I'd never heard of this place), but I did objectively love my piping hot Pechuga Ranchera - juicy chicken breast is always an impressive item - and the unique, bold flavors surrounding it.  

And there's a reason the chips and guac service isn't free!  It's quality all around!  From the fresh avocados, theatrically mixed table-side, to your preference of spiciness (don't be a wuss!), the guac is something you definitely don't want to skip out on!

Entrees range from $14-$20 and I definitely left hurting from an over stuffed, but happy stomach.  

Know Before You Go:
1. This little gem is hidden right next door to Morton's in Union Square.
author: Jane L.

description:
This place takes reservations!  I am sad to say that this excites me, big time.  Mi madre came into town over the weekend and I wanted to take her someplace nice and yummy.  Suddenly, it hit me.  Homemade tortillas!  The surefire way to her heart.
Prices are decent, our waitress was actually pretty good, and the tortillas and guacamole are delectable.  Unfortunately by the time our food arrived, we were pretty much stuffed.  Common downfall, I presume.
The sopes were numma, the jicama salad sounds better than it is, and the chile relleno is healthy goodness.
author: Lacy T.

description:
My friend and I went to Colibri on Friday night around 9:15pm and had dinner at the bar. The service was awesome and we were content with the food. Overall, the experience was pretty great...just not a-m-a-z-i-n-g. 

We had house margaritas (very good), queso fundido con chorizo (good/decent range), carnitas (very very good), and torta de elote - its cornbread with the sauce over it (probably the best thing we ate that night). Unlimited tortillas and fresh tasting salsa rounded out the meal. 

Atmosphere was lively. Service was great. Ramon and the guys at the bar were fun, attentive, and on their game. (Oh yeah, almost forgot to mention that Ramon made us a jalpeno drink/shot thing that was actually pretty amazing. If you like hot stuff, you should definitely ask for this!)

I would definitely go back and try some different entrees and apps but  I would most likely sit at the bar. (Yeah I'm one of those people that likes sitting at the bar when I want something less informal and fast. Bartenders are generally more quirky which = funnnn)  ;-)

Go there, you might just like it.
author: Stef E.

description:
Guacamole:  yes.
Margaritas: my friends loved theirs
Mojito: fair
Chile Relleno: nothing at all like mamacita used to make.  had all the flavor of a boiled bell pepper, and nothing more.
Service: high on pretention, but also on service

it's early, and i'm currently a woman of few words.
author: Tovah S.

description:
I've bartended at a tequila bar, and hell - this bar BLEW my old one out of the water.  

Dish of the night: queso... screw it that I'm lactose.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Colibri is one of the best mexican/spanish restaurants I have ever eaten at.

I was there with a friend again today and as he likes spicy food we ordered the spicy dishes... the guacamole was great, the chicken was falling apart with little prodding, the Jicama salad was perfect with a hint of lemon-mint dressing. 

After eating all of that I had to sit back and remember the flavors my mouth had just experienced. The creamy yet crunchiness of the guacamole with bits of spice that popped up whenever you bit into pepper bits... the taste of chicken smothered in a tangy tomato sauce with a light sprinkling of cheese... Pineapple and jicama chunks dribbled with the tangy-sweet dressing with spiced avocado slices and romaine... delicious! 

All the boys I am looking out for... please take a date you want to impress here. If she isnt that into you, order a bunch of the yummy liberally doused tequila Mojitos or Margaritas.... if nothing else I guarantee she will at the end of the meal think you look studly!! :)
author: Soham K.

description: Colibri is great. It is way more swanky than I had expected based on their Yelp picture, which was a pleasant surprise. The mole poblano was amazing, as was the guacamole that they hand make in individual batches. The only reason I'm not giving them 5 stars is because they were a little pricy with small portion sizes, but definitely worth it.
author: Darcy L.

description: The food was excellent and differentthann your typical Mexican place. Everything was very fresh and the service was great. I would definitely go back again.
author: Elise S.

description:
Colibri is hot and sweaty and not because we had just walked up 2 hills in heels but because it is really hot and sweaty. On a Tuesday night, Colibri is packed with people and we were lucky to get the last table for two.

Not only is Colibri hot and sweaty, Colibri is cute. Colibri also has style. Colibri has great mood lighting, a nice paint job, good bones, beautiful tile, mexican art, and awesome heavy cast iron chandeliers.

Colibri also has a sexy menu. But I just wasn't feelin it that night. I wasn't in the mood to gorge myself the way I do at Buca (and thank God, those days are over). So me and the BFF decided to go small and just order 2 appetizers and a salad. Its the reverse diet of after drinking (not fatty and fried but light, airy and crisp). 

The tomales oaxaquenos were amazing. The chicken was soft and the masa was fresh. The mole sauce was smoky and had earthy flavors. We thought it could be anise or tamarind (pulling spices out of our arses we had no idea what we were talking about but pretended to be foodies on tv describing each bite) and just went on and on about the flavor. The sopes sortidos were yummy bites of tortilla/corn/starch something breads topped with pulled pork, chicken, sour cream, fresh cheese, etc. It was plenty and deliciouso. We were served complimentary fresh mini tortillas with 3 different salsas. Salsa me! I'd slather that stuff on over a chocolate spa treatment anytime. It was really good. We finished off the meal with an ensalada mixta. In theory it sounded good, but at first bite it was sooooooo sour and drenched in dressing. We could see the dressing glazed on the plate. We did not finish it or even eat the bulk of the lettuce leaves. It was just so sour. I don't think when you eat salad you should be squinting and blinking as if you have something caught in your eye. I wanted to let the waitress know about the terrible salad but I refrained only because we were full and we didn't care to have a replacement salad. I'll let that one slide as a miss on the menu. 

I would like to revisit Colibri to give it a chance at four stars. Perhaps on another night when I am more hungry and I can skip the salad and go for the full on plates. Salads are for sissies.
author: Rachel A.

description: Went here alone when traveling on business.  Expensive margaritas that are not really amazing.  Had the filet, which was excellent.  Bar staff was nice and attentive.
author: Jessie H.

description: It was good. Service slow, Margarita's a little on the high side, for mostly margarita mix.  I'd go again.
author: Maria H.

description:
This is a real find.  I must have walked by many times and never noticed this gem.  The atmosphere is great and it's a really cute place.  I trued the Macho Margarita and it was great and super duper HOT!  We had the medium guac and the combination with the drink was pure FIRE!   I kept getting seeds so I did drink a ton of water.  But it was sooo good.

I loved the lamb shank.  It was super tasty and fell off the bone.  Our waitress was also very sweet and helpful.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
While deciding on a girl's night out, we went by what was still available on Open Table - they had reservations for that night and off we went. Our reservations were at 9pm (what happens when you start planning a girls night at 6pm) but got there, seated right away. Restaurant was full, but not overly so (I hate super crowded places where you accidentally butt brush someone else's face while walking to your table). Since we had a few minutes to kill before the rest of our party got there, we decided to start with drinks (although, to be totally honest, when do I not start with drinks?). The margarita and cocktail list seemed to cover a wide range of tastes, though my friend and I both went with the Cazadores margaritas - tasty smooth! 

Once the rest of our group arrived, we got down to business. Ordered the guacamole which was hand made at our table - yummy! Skip the chips (obv store bought) and go straight for the tortillas. The ceviche was big enough for the 4 of us, I thought it was ok - I usually like mine a bit more tart but it was fine. We split  entrees - the filet mignon, the chicken mole, the lamb shank and the duck. Hmmm, now that I type that out it doesn't seem very Mexican food-y, but there you go. Also ordered a side of the corn bread with the poblano sauce. The consensus favorite was the corn bread and the filet; I liked the mole, although it wasn't as robust as I normally like and was a little thin. The lamb was ok and I don't really remember the duck (though that may be because I was on my 2nd cazadores margarita by that time). Topped off dinner with the flan and the chocolate cake. 

Overall, I feel like nothing particularly stood out entree wise except for the mole but that may be because mole just tastes different, period. The guac and the hand made tortillas (YUM, btw) were the best part of the meal. Oh, and the margaritas - should never forget about the margaritas.
author: Elena N.

description:
Steps from Union Square, and NOT overrun with tourists! Customizable guacamole, because they make it right next to your table. And it's a pretty generous portion, too. The pechuga ranchera was moist but well done, set atop spinach and covered with a creamy red sauce. We also enjoyed a cheese-covered colifor dish that came out of the kitchen piping hot. I think I'm becoming a fan of non-taqueria Mexican food!

Speaking of the kitchen, it's all OPEN in the back, so when you go to the restroom, take a look! We had no problem getting a table for two at 7:30 on a Wednesday night, but reservations are probably a good idea for any later, as it quickly filled up. (And if for no other reason, than to avoid getting stuck in the crowded no-reservation for-two section.) Pleasant live guitar music started around 8:15pm, but not too loud to still hold a conversation.
author: Dave K.

description:
Well, that was just...great. Wandered into this place by accident, really, to get out of the rain and meet a friend - and wound up watching (and heckling, ala Mystery Science Theater 3000) one of the "Santos" Mexican wrestler films (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santo)  with two complete strangers. Good times. (The movie was possibly "El hacha diablica" - Santo in the Diabolical Axe.)

The Martgueritas were amazingly great (quite a few kinds), and Ceviche was really great. I tried the Mole sauce on another dish tho, and it was pretty pedestrian - hence the removal of a star...

...I'll be back - for the Martguerita and El Santos.
author: Rob D.

description:
This place is totally OK.  I mean, they make the guacamole in front of you, and its fabulous.  Everything I had was very tasty.

But seriously, whats up with high end mexican food.  I mean, who are they kidding, really.  I can go to a hole in the wall burrito place and have food just as good if not better for like a 3rd of the price.

The tequila selection is top notch though, so its a good place to go if you are in to that.
author: Steve S.

description: I would probably give this place 3.5 stars if I could do halfsies.  It's always "pretty good". But good enough that I find myself hitting it up every few months.  Personally prefer to sit at the bar and ogle the awesome tequila selection.  The bartenders tend to make better waitstaff than the waitstaff (timeliness, attentiveness) anyway.  Nice enough ambiance.  I can't think of any serious complaints I have had about the place.  If the food was killer, another star fo sho.
author: Isa L.

description:
Right off the bat, minus one star for being out of all the drinks I tried to order; Mango agua fresca, Strawberry agua fresca and lemonade, AHHH just gimme a beer. Having said that the service here is excellent and the food is pretty good. I went here as a pre-Sweeny Todd dinner. Our hostess told us to inform our waiter of this and he would expedite our service to make the show. The party I was with had already been here and raved about the guacamole. So we had two orders  (between 4 people), I ordered the tortilla soup, two ordered the chile relleno and the other ordered some kind of seafood dish i will discuss later. 

With most Mexican/Latin American themed restaurants I always expect chips and salsa starters. Not here. Colibri just had to be different. Instead of chips we were served freshly grilled mini tortillas to dip in our mild/Mango, medium/Verde and spicy salsas. It was nice that there was a variety, never had that before. Our guacamole appetizer ($10) was freshly prepared in front of us to order. We all wanted spicy and usually I can't handle the spicy but this was goooood. We chit chatted for a bit and before we knew it our food ha arrived. 

Presentation was beautiful and the overall quality was very good. I do want to touch on this seafood dish though. I love me food from the sea, I really do. Yet all my life I have had problems eating tentacles of anything tentacle-having. I love calamari but will only eat it in steak or fried ring form; preferring the later. The seafood skewer had beautiful mussels and shrimp and a whole octopus. Yep you read it, a whole baby sized octipi. Huge head all eight tentacles and all. Granted it was grilled an discolored but it was all still in tact. I didn't so much gross me out as I just wanted to pull it off my cousins plate and do some "Pirates of the Caribbean" scenes. Just thought I'd throw that warning out there. 

So the food was excellent, we didn't have time for dessert. The attention to our needs was met and we were a happy party.
author: Alia D.

description: Met friends for dinner here on Cinco de Mayo. Great margs and attentive staff. We just thought it was weird that when we ordered a chile relleno, that we had to pick either carnitas or veggies and cheese. No carnitas with cheese. Who doesn't like cheese melted on, well just about anything? That was kinda strange but we had a great time and would go back again.
author: Jen G.

description:
I really liked the food here. The service kinda sucked and took for ever to get those wonderful tortillas.  This is more like Argentianian style of food. 
Everything is a la carte. VERY PRICY! but the GUAC is YUMMY!.. not necessarly at 10.00 for a shallow small bowl. but good.
author: Michelle A.

description:
YUM!!!!!!! :)

i don't know what I can say about this place that a million other people haven't already said...

prices high and portions are small (-1)
otherwise, it's the BEST mexican food i've ever had.  forget the beans and greasy rice.. gourmet mexican at it's best...

I recommend the:
Guacamole (starter)
Quesidilla (starter)
Pechuga Ranchera (entree):  tender chicken breast smothered in creamy guanjillo chile sauce, over mashed potatos with sauteed spinach :)
Pato en Pipian (entree): pan seared duck breaks and dark meat in a delicious green mole made with pumpkin seeds, tomatillos, nuts and spices.
Negro y blanco (dessert):  dark chocolate mousse and white chocolate confection

I think I would come here JUST to eat the Negro y blanco... but then I would be missing out on everything else that tastes so good here...

If I made more money, I would come here ALL THE TIME.  FREAKING YUM.
author: Steph M.

description:
Colibri I love you. I love you with the kind of love that one reserves for sleeping in, great coffee and a warm breeze. Your guacamole is as good as it gets. When I have your small plates, I know that I am one step away from holiness. Your margaritas make me sing (too much. in the restroom.) and when I get that 9.30 table I've waited weeks for, I am golden!

However, we need to talk. That vinyl banquet you make me sit on, the one that shoots up like a one-sided see-saw whenever some other guest sits down or gets up, that one? I hate that shit. What is that?! Can we take a knife and cut out individual seat cushions? I am eating my beautiful food and Guest #5 gets up and "PING!" Fork hits roof of mouth and food falls onto brand new dress. Fuck that. 

So maybe I can sit on the floor? 

We can talk. We'll work it out.
Still yours...
author: Melisa B.

description:
Incredibly disappointing. My girlfriend and I arrived here to meet some friends before a show at Ruby Skye, and we had such a bad experience that I actually created a Yelp account to warn others.

The service was atrocious. We saw our server so rarely that we were forced to go the bar for several drinks. And on that note - I have been bartending for four years, but apparently bartenders in SF are above saying "thank you" for a 25% tip on two shots. It's not that hard, guys.

My girlfriend ordered a "Greyhound" - which I clarified with the server was a "vodka and grapefruit" - that after some absurd amount of time came back as a vodka/cranberry. When our dinner eventually arrived, we were uncertain if we perhaps ordered off the kids' menu. The appetizer chicken quesadilla came as three tiny tortillas with some chicken and cheese haphazardly thrown in the middle. My girlfriend ordered off the salad menu, but it looked more like a side salad at Denny's than a light dinner. And the guacamole that everyone seems to rave about? Save a few bucks and mash an avocado with some tomato, because that's what it tasted like. Certainly not spicy as we requested, and we threw our own salsa in to add the lacking taste. 

When the bill arrived for $140, I was flabberghasted. For whatever reason, the restaurant charged us for Grey Goose, despite no one at our table requesting that particular vodka for our four vodka-based drinks. The management reversed the charge when I inquired about it, but I wouldn't be shocked if they told the servers to just resort to more expensive call drinks.

Inevitably, we should have eaten at the Jack in the Box next door. More food, better service, and a hundred bucks cheaper.
author: Matt R.

description:
Homemade guac = heavenly
Hot corn tortillas = I'm in love
Quesadillas = solid
Ceviche = nothing to write home about
Margaritas = I couldn't taste the tequila!!

Overall, way above average, but some flaws.  Will go back for brunch, I think, and give it a more complete try.
author: Jenn S.

description:
+3 yummy margaritas with awesome tequila selection
+2 tablemade guacamole to your liking (mild, medium, spicy)
+2 appy's score highly, especially chorizo, cheese and mushroom melt and mini-sopas
+1 fast, efficient service (great for a preperformance bite)
-2 dinner portions are itty bitty 
-3 dry carnitas :(

In summary, grab a marg or tequila shot and graze.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Colibri is one of my favorite places in the city for sit-down Mexican food.

In terms of the venue itself, it's not the trendiest scene -- both from the perspective of its decor (think warm, but more family-style) and its location (just off of Union Square / touristy theatre district).

In terms of the food and drinks - they are fantastic.  The sangria is delicous, and Colibri has a great selection of Tequilas to get the night started.  Instead of the usual basket of chips and salsa you get at most Mexican restaurants, Colibri offers warm, homemade tortillas with a selection of three salsas.  They also make your guacamole tableside, which is awesome because I can tell them to make mine super spicy and without onions!  (That's about as customized as it gets).  The duck with tomatillo sauce is by far my favorite dish, and the desserts are good as well.  

Great place to have a dinner with family or a group of friends, although you can avoid a 30 - 45 minute wait by making a reservation.

Monday night (if I remember correctly), they have live guitar music.

Overall, one of the best (and most authentic) "formal" Mexican places.
author: Emily C.

description:
About 7 on a Tue night, my friend and I walked in.  We were greeted a few minutes later and stuck in a small table way in the back.  The table was a bit on the small size, but it seems not to be a place for a party of 2 and geared to larger parties.  

First the drinks, I order the Sangria which was ok, the chunks of fruit was diced into very small pieces, some a bit indistinguishable.    Now to the food, we didn't get appetizers because  my friend is diabetic and couldn't eat most of the items.  We both got Pescado del Dia minus the chorizo from the sauce and a side of Hongos Chileajo (mushrooms) and Nopales Asados (grilled cactus).  I didn't care for the mushrooms there was too much of a tang, but loved the grilled cactus.  The main course dishes were served with a side of corn tortilla which was so delicious and was the main reason I was filled up.  The main courses are "small plates" and the side dishes is a good idea if you're really hungry.  The food had great flavor, really light and ingredients complemented each other well.  Only down side was the 3 different types of salsa that was served with our meal had no heat.

Yes I would go again, because there are more items I would like to try.  The special looked great and something I would like to try in the future.  The noise level of this place is very loud regardless of where you sit, this place was packed with several large groups.  There's a bar area in the front and is a great place to meet up with friends.
author: Twist' D.

description: Stumbled into Colibri in August of 10 for a friends weekend.  And we went back 2 of the 3 days in SF.  Went back to SF for a quick 1 night trip and went back again.  COLIBRI has the feel of a local restaurant in the middle of this big city.  Make a reservation.  As we to sit at the bar.  It fills up fast.  but is understandable, it is REALLY good.
author: Beau P.

description:
Solid Mexican food.  The price is reasonable & it's convenient for when you need a pre-theater dinner.  Portions are perfect--large enough so that you don't feel like you need to purge afterwards.

I recommend the tortas as an appetizer & the carnitas as an entree if you like pork.  The carnitas are so tender & delectable!

Can't compare Colibri's guac to Maya's guac, but I imagine it would be a tough one to beat!
author: Jenny M.

description: Excellent place with upscale Mexican food! Very friendly service and nice environment.
author: Michael M.

description:
What Happened to you?

Colibri, you used to be one of my favorite stops at the city, but you had changed and not for good.  I am sorry to say that I share the same feelings as other of your patrons.  Not friendly staff, staring with the host, mediocre service, higher prices and the worst of all,  bad food. I would love to know how did you manage to loose your salt and pepper and spices containers in  your little kitchen that used to make delicious food.  I just want to thank you for forcing me to go an explore other restaurants in this beautiful city.  I also, want you to know that you are no longer part of my city tradition.
author: Bela M.

description: In The City for a conference and thanks to Yelp, I'll never have to eat at an overpriced tourist trap again. The food here was excellent, upscale Mexican. Like some others have said, upscale Mexican is a totally unnecessary concept, but these folks do it well. Give it a shot!
author: Brendon C.

description:
Can you say Mexican food "sans chips and salsa"?

This place has the decor, as long as you bring the green. Cheapest plates run around 10 dollars, and I had several of their a la carte items.

The Pescado del Dia, which happened to be halibut, was delicious. The chorizo sauce with squash and green beans were by far the best dish of the night. Unfortunately the Carnitas (pork) was slightly overcooked and uninspiring, aside from the sauce. The sauteed prawns were slightly better, although the sauce was slightly overpowering with the tamarind. The guacamole served at the table was cilantro heavy, with underripe avocados.

But why am I giving this place 4 stars? Because the service was fantastic, and the choice given to us regarding the desired tequila choice for our margaritas was perfect. Come for the drinks, and eat the fish.
author: Andy A.

description:
I really don't get why this place is so popular.  I saw all the great reviews and we decided to make that our lunch destination because we were meeting in the area.

Just because this place has palatable Mexican food doesn't mean it is *good*. Expensive does not equal good, even though many expensive places are very good. I'd seriously take a $5 taqueria over this overpriced place any day. The atmosphere might not be great, but the food would be awesome.  On top of all of it those places are just as accessible from the area with a quick BART ride.

I will agree that the guacamole made right at your table and the fresh tortillas were pretty awesome, but a bit much for what it was at $10.

They did have a pretty impressive selection of fine tequillas so maybe that would be a reason to go, but I didn't have one for lunch.

I'd say that unless you are hitting this place for happy hour it is totally missable.  There are much better places in the area for the money you'll pay and if you really have a craving for Mexican food head for the Mission.
author: Raven B.

description:
I have been here several times, and I have enjoyed it every single time. This place is always consistent, unlike a similar restaurant at Santana Row in San Jose. 

If you come here, be prepared to share with everyone at your table. This is a tapas restaurant that features Mexico bistro food. They also offer a full bar with some really good drinks. Try a mojito if you go, or even better a coconut mojito.  

Some of my favorites when coming here are the 3 dipping sauces that come at the beginning of the meal with fresh homemade tortillas, the made at your table guacamole, the ceviche, the carnitas, and the queso fundido. They also have larger dishes which include traditional Mexican dishes such as chicken mole, but I usually stick to the smaller ones.

This place has become the default restaurant when we are hungry and in the downtown SF area, and can't think of anywhere else we want to go. Check it out!
author: Jeff B.

description:
The lunch menu was tasty but ridiculously expensive for
such a tiny portions. And I am not expected the typical fat-American
huge meals but seriously for $14 I would expect a real meal 
with beans or rice instead of a little appetizer. 

Save you money and go elsewhere.
author: Steve C.

description: I hate to give this kind of review the day after Christmas, but it was the worst experience I've had in years.  I've loved this restaurant in years past, but I think its changed ownership recently.  Upon entry, all front tables we're in need of cleaning, and it didn't seem especially busy...it was 2:15 in the afternoon.  We we're seated in the back and promptly ignored.  Tables around us we're in need of a server to take their order.  After 10-15min, we were never greeted.  No sorry, no water, not even a "I'll be right with you".  When we got up to leave, not one member of the staff asked why.  The Manager, at least I think he was, avoided eye contact at all cost!  Sad state of affairs at Colibri.  For the price point, I think they should step up their customer service.
author: Frank M.

description:
Our server pulled a little trick on us -- we asked for a glass of sangria, and they brought out a whole pitcher... which costs about $30! We are way too polite so we accepted,  rationalizing that it was meant to be. However, by the time we reached the bottom of it, our stomachs didn't feel good because we had just injested a gallon of sugar, and we hardly had a buzz-on. So, we drank a $30 pitcher of crappy fruit juice. 
What suckers we are. 
Aside from the trick-sangria, I was really disappointed by the food -- first of all, nothing is remotely spicy unless you're a super-gringo. Also, it's incredibly expensive for how dull everything tasted. Don't get me wrong, the food wasn't terrible, but it was reminiscent of food one might be served in the dining room of a Best Western in Iowa. I felt like I should have been tacking on the price of my meal to my room account. 
I could tell there were a lot of tourists, given this restaurant's convenient location near Union Square, and they seemed happy (probably never tasted a burrito from the Mission District).
author: Sarah H.

description:
The Spanish Colonial interior takes you back a century. The wrought iron gates and chandeliers, the rustic wooden chairs and tables evoke the charm of a place old and familiar. Ironically, Mexico isn't what's familiar in this self-styled "Mexican Bistro." Instead there is a whisper of Havana in the air.

If Hemingway drank tequila, he would have his own seat at Colibri. At the bar the tequila sun also rises in a splendid corona of over 200 artisan and commercial agave nectars ready to liven your mood. 

The personality of tequila as I have gathered over years of friendship is that it's a little bit mischievous and a whole lot irreverent. On the wall behind the Colibri bar you'll see a tequila bottle shaped like a Dick Tracy gun, another comes in a caterpillar bottle where the head is the cork stopper, and when you begin to chuckle inside, you're beginning to understand what I mean by irreverent. The tequilas here span the range of color and depth from lustrous bronze to autumn yellow to ether clear. Whatever shade of flavor you desire, or, didn't know you desire, you can find it here. 

If you're lucky on your venture to Colibri, you'll catch "Adrian" tending bar. Don't be ashamed to request him by name, he enjoys his celebrity as much as you will his drinks. Have him make you a "consuelo" (it means solace) where a medley of fresh squeezed citrus including grapefruit, lemon, lime, and orange go into an adobe bowel filled with ice, then topped with a select reposado tequila. Sipping this refreshing concoction is a step closer to finding your inner joy. 

Accompany your tequila buzz with some delectable latin fusion tapas. The fillet mignon in a smooth ancho sauce over a bed of mashed potatoes is a crowd pleaser. The sweet and mild ancho penetrates to the core of the steak in a powerful flavor boost. The fish tacos of white flakey fish hot from the grill is topped with a cool mango salsa. Add a little lime juice, take a bite and you'll be clamoring for another order before you're done chewing. 

To off set the spicy food and the acidity of citrus, a sweet finish to your meal is in order. Don't miss the caramel filled churro with caramel ice cream. The decadent double serving is the perfect way to leave Colibri on a flurry. But, of course, it's always more fun to have one more tequila before you go. Just one more...
author: Ji D.

description: Oh yum!  I lived in Mexico City for 4 years and travelled extensively in Mexico.  This is the best Mexican food I've had since I've left!  We went for lunch.  I thought the restaurant was lovely, service excellent, and food outstanding and good value.  I will definitely go back!!
author: Suzanne O.

description: Not worth the price! If you are looking for traditional mexican this is not the place for you. Very disappointed. Minimal menu choices. Everything is a la carte so by the time you are done the bill is ridiculous.  Not sure what others see oin this place. I would not recommend  Portion sizes and quality extremely poor. Better off going to taco bell!
author: Brett H.

description: Great Gourmet mexcan food. Not the most authentic or best in the city but good food
author: Irma S.

description: I love tequila! I have only made it there for their late brunch...which was awesome. I got this thing that looked like french toast, tasted like bread pudding...only lighter and airier. That was the best! The highight for me was the tequila. They had every kind I haven't heard of and the prices aren't so crazy. They do have some that are over the top, but you can get a nice shot for 10$ as opposed to 25 elsewhere. Service was really bad both times, even when they were slow, chips and gauc not the best, and they charge extra for chips! whats that?! Mostly like it because of their fine Tequila collection.
author: KatieRae A.

description: Being vegan-ish (mostly vegan except for desserts), this restaurant was initially a let-down as there were no real entree options. So we went with a smattering of side-dishes instead and ended up having an awesome impromptu taco bar meal. The drinks were great, the service was excellent, and the location's kind of hard to beat if you're going to ACT. I'll be back!
author: Benjamin B.

description:
awesome meal here on a sunday night at 9:30 .never felt rushed and service was friendly and sincere. 

margharitas were pretty excellent as was the guacamole which might be the best ive ever had. but for 12 bucks i wish it was a little smaller so we coud have ordered another appetizer to have. 

i had the mole and my girlfriend got the bass. the bass was phenonmonal, very light but full of flavor with a nice semi sweet sauce. 

my mole was....pretty good? i was expecting a little more flavor and complexity but it had a more simple (i wont use the word bland) taste. 

either way its a GREAT find in a neighborhood i really dont like eating in. probably the one of the few and only places worth your money.
author: Mohammad G.

description: Excellent high-end Mexican food.  Great for a pre-theater dinner.  The guacamole is terrific, and they usually have pretty good fish dishes.  You do need a reservation on a weekend night.
author: Julie H.

description: The food was nice and so were the drinks.  Overall, it had more of an Southwest feeling to it than Mexican, and it was a bit pricey.  My halibut was prepared well and the person next to me was a local that was friendly, which made the place enjoyable. The place just had a good feeling to it and I would definitely go back there again.
author: Manny F.

description: I've eaten here a few times and have a mixed feeling. Guacamole is outstanding, I remember one of the soup I tried was good, but nothing outstanding and pricey...like most downtown restaurant.
author: Yoko S.

description: Amazing food.  There seems to be a shortage of quality Mexican food in this city.  This is probably why I was so excited to find Colibri.  The service was fantastic and very friendly.  The margaritas, although slightly pricey at $12, were delicious.  The cheese dip appetizer is the best dip I've ever experienced.  It cost $50 per person including the drinks and tip.  I will definitely go back.  Highly Recommended!
author: Aaron B.

description: I was pleasantly surprised with this place.  It's in the theater district across from the Curran theater.  When I saw the name, I thought of PF Changs Bistro, so wasn't sure what to expect.  I was wrong.  This place felt straight out of Playa Del Carmen, Mexico.  You smell the freshly made tortillas when you walk, there's music playing and the setting is very rustic.  Went with a group of people and their signature appetizer is fresh guacamole made at your table.  It's served with fresh unlimited corn tortillas instead of chips.  Really good, probably could just eat that the whole night.  They specialize in tapas so I tried the Pastor Pescado Taco and the Carnitas.  Both very good, especially the carnitas.  It's a very relaxing environment.  This place blows away Tres Agaves.
author: Josh L.

description:
A Colibri gift certificate was one of my Christmas highlights!  I finally used it in February on a Monday night ( perfect time to go to avoid the theatre crowds and to find parking! ), enjoying the experience with two friends - so we could share several dishes.  

Though the restaurant wasn't crowded, two musicians played Latin songs and even knew an old Puerto Rican favorite, "Mi Viejo San Juan."
The decor was quite lovely, with dark stained booths and a mahogany
bar, replete with many reposado tequilas.  Classic Spanish paintings lined the walls.  

We started off with the guacamole ( yummy ), served with wonderful small masa tortillas and three delicious sauces.  Each of us had a different drink - very good margaritas and a mojito from an extensive 
menu offering far too many choices.  

Our dinner selection included the torta de elote, a savory corn bread with onions, bacon, chile pasilla, and a poblano pepper cream sauce ( $7 ),
definitely not low calorie but delicious.  For entrees, we shared the filet mignon with ancho chile stuffed with goat cheese, over mashed potatoes with sautéed spinach and chipotle chile sauce.
