It was absolutely superb.  Another dish that got raves was the "Callos De Hacha" - pan seared scallops served over a potato-corn purée with sautéed green beans, garlic and epazote.  As if those entrees weren't enough, we also ate pan seared duck breast and dark meat in a delicious green mole made with pumpkin seeds, tomatillos, nuts and spices.  We chose a side order of estofado zucchini, corn kernels, mushrooms, epazote and pasilla chile stew  ( $7.50 ) that was well worth the trip in itself!  

Midst moans that we couldn't eat another bite, after perusing the dessert menu, we couldn't resist  pastel de chocolate -  warm, soft mexican chocolate cake, with vanilla ice cream  and the pastel de tres leches cake, a moist sponge cake covered with meringue frosting and white chocolate shavings - both excellent.....though I was considering the mango creme brulee as well....another time, perhaps.
author: Carmen H.

description: Got packed quickly, but food was fantastic. Stuck strictly with apps, and the pulled pork was out of this world. And the churros .... Oh my
author: Christopher Z.

description: This restaurant was delicious. Drinks were good. Guacamole was perfect. Chile Rellenos was great.
author: Erene S.

description: Yum!  We started with agave sweetened margaritas which were perfect...just sweet enough.  The tortillas with the three sauces were great. Ordered a bunch of small plates (duck mole, ceviche, enchiladas) and everything was delish.  The service was great too.  Our waiter guided us in the right direction and everything he recommended was superb.  Oh, and we were there on Cinco de mayo...a night you might think the service would suffer, but no.  It was perfect.
author: Michelle C.

description:
One of my favorite spots...  all the dishes are pretty delicious and for my taste,  depending on the region bit more true to Mexican cuisine.

One thing that made me smile the first time I ate here, is that when I ordered a 'bandera' , the friendly server didn't look at me confused or ask what that was like some other Mexican restaurants in the city.  
They have a nice selection of tequila's. If you like good tequila, give bandera style a try as a great way to enjoy sipping it  - in any order you like.  Also they offer flights of tequila, usually a good deal for 3 quality shots for something like ~18-20 dollars.
author: T K.

description:
Good stuff!  The food was fantastic; service the night we came was a bit spotty, but they'd also been slammed with a group of 20+ that arrived just as we did.  Actually, the food came pretty quickly, it was our drinks that took forever because the large group slowed the bar way down.  However, the waitress kept us apprised, was appropriately apologetic, and the bar comped us shots of some fine tequila, so I left with a positive impression of the service.

The guacamole is yum (though we asked for spicy and it really wasn't), the ceviche was well-made, and the pudin de chocolat is a dark chocolate lover's wet dream.
author: Krisanne C.

description: This is the 1st place I always recommend to friends who visit the city & want really delicious food at a nice restaurant. This place does not serve your typical Mexican food. This place is definitely a fusion with Mexican flavors and ingredients being the inspiration. But seriously, the food is AMAZING. So far the dishes I've had were so delicious. And the staff are nice & try to accommodate room for you if you have no reservations. Definitely make reservations on weekends and nights since this place can get crowded.
author: Marie R.

description:
A Sunday night at six and we turistas didn't have reservations but we'd heard good stuff about the fresh guac, so we perched at a corner of the bar.  That was a good call because the margarita de la casa was just fine, the sangria was crazy good AND we got to watch the addictively cheesy old episodes of 'Santo', a luchador superhero that makes the Adam West  Batman show look like the Shakespeare Festival.

Service was impeccable. The fresh guacamole was deserving of its rep and the little tostadas that came second on the appetizer menu were delicious.  The tamales oaxaquenos were unimpressive, with an oddly flavorless mole and a gooey consistency.  I had a mango creme brulee for dessert, which sounded good but was too sweet for my taste (I prefer most of the sugar to be in the crust).  My friends would point out I ate the entire thing just the same!

But we ate to satisfaction off the appetizer menu for about $25 each, including a drink and dessert.
author: Tom A.

description: NO FLOUR TORTILLAS! Very dark, crammed establishment. Also very loud.
author: Jim F.

description:
the List:

House-made tortillas. Mini-sized, but oh sooo tasty with the salsa/sauce they serve.
Guacamole. Tableside with the above-mentioned is heavenly.
Filet. One could just order it as an entree. Melt in your mouth - I order it medium.
Caipirinhas. A stiff, sweetened drink. 
Tequila selection. I think they have over 100. I hated tequila until I tried something finer here.
Blue Napkins. I like them, and the feeling that  - save the glass door up front - the restaurant is like the high-ceiling-ed, partitioned-off wing of some old Catholic church.
author: Cheryl D.

description:
Damn!  I love Colibri.  Some personal faves include the table side guac, tortilla soup and the brocheta de filete (lunch menu only).  The housemade tortillas and salsas they serve in lieu of the traditional chips n salsa are also pretty great.  

Service can be spotty, but they have always made an effort to make it up in the past.
author: Kyla B.

description:
I agree with M.D., shut up already about the chips and salsa and prices and tapas portions and whatever.  Go to Chevy's or the Mission for gawd's sake.  I love the fancy Mexican food with no cheese with beans and rice a la carte.  They even had several things that I, a vegetarian, could eat.  I loved the upscale atmosphere and decor, cocktails, the food, the location.  The whole experience was great.

On Thursday night we had to wait about 20 minutes for a table, but the wait turned out to be a highlight since we hung at the bar and I had a KILLER magarita fresco with crushed blackberries and strawberries.  It was so good.  I then had a Pisco Sour, which was divine.  Pisco has a lovely subtle and smooth complex taste and aftertaste.  My cousin had an infused tequila which was also fabulous.

As for the food, we had grilled cactus and portabellos, the awesome homemade fresh tortillas and guac, chile relleno, a Mexican fusion sort of salad with sugared walnuts and the salty crumbly mexican cheese, and my cousin the meat eater had a fish dish.  My cousin is a very picky eater and he even liked everything.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
All of a sudden craving for Mexican food. Where do i find it around union square?? i asked the waitress from the hidden wine bar, and she recommended this place.

After making the wrong turn and arrived at this place. Very nice decoration. I saw the liquor collection on the shelf, then i know it is also a Tequila bar as well.

We sat down and of course the most famous for dish - guacamole. They made it in front of us, and the tortillas is hot. YUMMY~~~~ We also ordered this pork dish and the meat was very tender. We wrapped pork with guacamole. it was the best!!!! the guacamole is fresh with onion and spices. the magarita is also very good .

It's good for a late night dinner and drink your night away without hopping into the cab to another place.
author: Eva L.

description: Besos to the chef the food was amazing.  I had the stuffed bacon wrapped shrimp, ceviche and guac.  Delicious and words can not describe all the wonderful flavors.  I would recommend this great place to anyone.  We happened to go on the hottest day of the year in SF which meant we were sweating most of the time.  The service was decent but the food was even better.  Try the list of cocktails, there margaritas are to die for literally........
author: Daniel W.

description: Fresh torillas instead of chips with salsa! Yum!!!! Cute place, great food. Love the sangria, perfect little cubes of fruit with every sip. Panuchas are so full of flavor!
author: Samia G.

description:
I have to say this first of all.  It bugs a little when I pay 20 some odd dollars for dishes that I make for myselft for a much smaller cost.  I went to Colibri for a friend's birthday though and enjoyed the drinks most of all.  They have great Mojito's even though those are Cuban drinks and not Mexican.  The tortillas were great and the decor was really nice and warm...

Overall: If you don't know how to cook Mexican food than this is a great place to eat with a higher more healthful approach to typical dishes.
author: Jay H.

description:
Colibri is a good choice in this 'hood.  The food was good, although the atmosphere is nothing to write home about.  However, some highlights which give Colibri the nod from 3 to 4 stars:
The delicious guacamole that is made to order, tableside!
The fancy specialty margaritas (blood orange served up in a martini glass, blackberry served on the rocks) and sangria
The 3 yummy salsas (sweet, medium and super spicy) with warm tortillas.  
Definitely enough to get me back there...
author: Lija H.

description:
Good tapas style Mexican food.  I did like the quality of the food here, but I didn't really care for the drinks much (they made a terrible Caipirinha, but I guess that's Brazilian, not Mexican).  

I like this place, but if you're going for the upscale Mexican category in SF, I'd rank them as follows:

1.  Tres Agaves
2.  Maya
3.  Colibri
author: Aaron M.

description:
I really love this place. The food was spectacular. We ordered the guacamole and it was delicious and I LOVED that it was served with homemade tortillas instead of fried tortilla chips. 

For dinner my friends ordered the scallops, and a shrimp dish and I ordered the fish tacos and the sopa. All was fabulous. The fish tacos are appetizers but they were large enough for an entree. 

Plus I love their amazing selection of tequila. Try Gran Centenario Reposado tequila neat. Mmmmm sooo wonderful. 

The service was also pleasant and it's a perfect place to get food before seeing a show at one of the nearby theaters.
author: Andie J.

description: We were happy to discover Colibri bistro.  The service and food were excellent.  The Ensalada be Betaveles was fantastic.  The special was delicious.  I will return to try more of their menu in the future.
author: Terri S.

description:
Went here for lunch with a coworker and was sadly disappointed. We ordered tamales and a carne asada enchilada with mole sauce. Everything was dry. Maybe it was because we came after the lunch hour (1:30pm), but even the flavors didn't excite. This isn't authentic Mexican food, by the way.

The restaurant itself had a fun vibe to it, and the drinks were great (non-alcoholic). I would guess that their bar is fabulous. The food was just a disappointment.
author: Tammy S.

description:
Had a truly *great* meal here.  Their scallop dish actually got three "wow's" out of me before I was done with the first bite.  The broccoli dish was great, too.  Amusingly, I was most disappointed by their Spanish rice (don't bother with it - too bland).  

The margarita list is huge and both drinks that we got were great.  It was a little bit noisy because of a large party next to us, but I still stand by my rating.
author: Suzanne T.

description:
Guacamole is an anytime food for me.  When I woke up at our hotel Sunday morning and realized that I couldn't yelp a fantastic breakfast joint, I was a bit disappointed.  Wandering around union square while my amigo was still sleeping, I came across this place and the brunch menu looked pretty good.  And then I discovered they would make the guacamole fresh right when you ordered it.  And I was in heaven.

Brunch also comes with three bowls of salsas and mini-homemade-corn-tortillas.  I think I had nine of them.  Maybe more, I lost count.  The Huevos Mexicanas with huge dollups of guac in mini tortillas was just what I needed.  I would definately go back.
author: Lauren L.

description:
We went to Colibri this past Saturday with a couple friends.  Overall, I thought the quality of the food, ambiance and service was good.  However, it is really tough to be a Mexican food restaurant in SF with so many wonderful places to eat.  Colibri's distinguishing characteristic is its upscale, trendy environment.  The place has a good vibe and the crowd is very mixed.  

I was pleased with the food, but was not blown out of the water.  In many respects, I've had Mexican food in the Mission that was as good if not better.  Still, what they lack on the entree-side, they more than made up for in drinks.  The margaritas were excellent!  

Given its location and fun atmosphere, I'd definitely go back.
author: Shawn S.

description:
The margaritas are excellent. The tortilla soup missed the mark but the guacamole is superb. The filet is good, the cauliflower was so fresh and amazing and the duck breast was tasty!

Service is OK - never the best, never the worst. 

Portions are actually smaller than you would expect, which makes it a bit pricey.
author: Sarcastic T.

description: Colibri is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. The food is awesome - homemade guacamole tableside, and their tortilla soup comes in a kettle. The ambiance is always fun and it's always crowded! Definitely one of my favorites.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Mexi-nouvre, Mexican Bistro, or "Fresh Mex"- take your pick on the PR marketing spin (although Chevys, this place is definately not- I think my server would give me a little extra montezuma's revenge with my water If I asked for some "el machino"-made tortillas)

The environment was nice- both warm and modern- although a bit loud. The tv showing vintage mexican cinema was a nice touch. 

The food itself was great- the house made tortillas seemed like a cross between corn and flour tortillas- and as everyone has mentioned, the guac was awesome (ask for spicy!). The roasted, stuffed chicked was amazing, as was the cornbread. The filet mignon was good, but nothing differentiated much from other treatments i've seen. The drinks were inventive and really yummy too- beyond just the usual Margaritas.

But what really took away from the overall star-rating was the service. We had a reservation, showed up on time, and after getting seated, were promptly ignored for 10 minutes, then after the waitress made a guest appearance, she was off again. Our waters showed up 8 or so minutes later, and the drinks we ordered showed up after our appetizers. Maybe the waitress was distracted, or maybe she was practicing for the world championships of curling, but tossing desert menus our way- not cool, and the smarmy attitude, also a negatory.. and so S.L.O.W. ...

Overall, great food, nice ambience, not so great service- if i make it back, i'll definately update the review....
author: Tim V.

description:
I love me some Mexcian food. Favorites included the Tequila Nectar cocktail with pomegrante and guava, the guacomole prepared at your table, the creamy scallops, and the warm chocolate cake. 

Delicous. .
author: Netty L.

description:
Atmosphere was great, had a full stocked bar and there was plenty of tequila.  Came here for a birthday where we sat in the back.  Since we had a lot of people, the birthday girl decided to choose a  prefix menu that consisted of two appetizers, a soup and a Cesar salad.  The entree was chili relleno, filet mignon, or halibut.  And for dessert creme mango brulee or tequila leche flan.

Since I was with my bf, I was able to have him choose one dish while i chose the other.  As for the appetizers, the Caesar salad was nothing special aside from the fact that they did not cut the romaine lettuce.  The dressing was nicely coated on each piece of lettuce, but the croutons were not good and the Parmesan was only placed in one area.  The soup reminded me of a a enchilada, it had whole pieces of a Mexican cheese and crispy tortilla chips.

For the entrees, I had the chili relleno.  I am from Salinas and have a good amount of Mexican friends that make fun of me when i say chili relleno con queso because apparently when you think of chili relleno its a given that it has cheese.  I took this into consideration when i chose the chili relleno since I have not had this in ages.  And to my surprise when it came out..it had not cheese!! I guess this place doesn't follow the authentic Mexican culture?? I don't know but it was not good..sad So luckily I had my bf order the filet mignon and that was accompanied with goat cheese and this was decent, not the best but it was edible.  

As for the dessert, the best part of the meal.  The creme brulee was not the best...it did have mango pieces but it didn't seem cool enough, more of a room temperature.  The flan wasn't great either....i guess they like serving room temp desserts.

The only good things about this place is the alcohol..theres plenty of it =) and the food came with a few side plates of black beans, rice, and a medley of vegetables.  As for the bad, not the best Mexican food I've eaten and the service wasn't very great...they did not come by often to check if we needed more water or take our finished plates away.  I would not come here again since there are so many different places to try in s.f.
author: Jemille G.

description:
Colibri Mexican Bistro receives 4 stars for it's awesome food, simple yet beautiful and cozy ambiance and attentive wait staff.  I have to echo everyone else's sentiments on the guacamole--it's simply the best!  Fresh, made to order at your table AND served with warm tortillas, it's definitely a must at Colibri!  (Nice because I last dined there with a picky eater that requested no cilantro in it.)  The sangria is only decent, as I've had much better (eg Fresca's at Fillmore), and the margaritas (virgin and non-virgin) were on the tart side.  I much prefer their mojitos.  In addition to the guacamole the following are others I devoured and thoroughly enjoyed: fish tacos, tortilla soup, carnitas, tres leches cake, and the mango creme brulee.  (Not my personal fave, but my dining companions enjoyed the duck, the shrimp with cornbread and the coffee tequila flan.)

For dinner or for drinks and appetizers, Colibri is a sweet little Mexican bistro.  No over-sized burritos or any large portions of food for that matter here...but you'll be surprised as I always walk away completely satiated.
author: Marie B.

description:
The guacamole is FANTASTIC.  Prepared fresh at your table, the guac is delicious.  They serve it with small tortillas instead of chips.  If you want chips, they cost extra.  We got one bowl...don't get them...they tasted stale.

The entrees sucked.  I had the fish of the day which was drowned in this way too cheesy sauce.  Was too heavy.  My other friends had the tortilla soup, quesidillas, and stuffed chile which were all not great.

But they did like the mojitos.  So maybe this place would be good for drinks and guacolmole, but I wouldn't recommend it for dinner.
author: C A.

description:
So i went here last week and it was really really good. I personally would not call it Mexican food more like tapas with margaritas. The margaritas were delicious they use fresh fruit and lots of booze! The food was to die for! 

I for a stuffed chicken something or other i have no idea what it was called or how to spell it but you will see it on the menu! It was so so so good. What was even better was the potato au gratin.. oh my lord so much cheese and yummyness. I would highly recommend getting the potatoes. Like dont leave without them! 

The staff is friendly and the wait is long without a reservation., BUT you 
can sit at the bar with a full menu! Why 4 stars you ask? Well the guacamole was good but it comes with tortillas .. i wanted chips. In all fairness if i would have read the reviews i would have known! 

Still good! Go there!
author: Samantha R.

description:
First off, this is not your typical $2 taco and burrito kind of Mexican joint, so if that's what you are seeking, I'd head to the Mission and hit up a cheap taqueria.  But, if you are interested in a more upscale Mexican culinary experience, Colibri does it pretty well.

It was a good thing we had a reservation on New Year's Day, because the place was so packed it was busting at the seams-- the hostess was estimating a 60-90 minute wait for walk-ins.  But, even with the crowded New Year's craziness going on, our server was always there when we needed him and did a great job of checking back without ever being pushy.  If anything, the service may have been a tad too quick, with our entrees coming just as we were finishing our apps.

We ordered a full on Mexican feast-- chicken mole, tamales, queso fundido, chicken tinga mini tostadas, whitefish with huitlacoche and even a filet mignon.  On the whole, everything was pretty darned tasty.  The filet mignon had excellent flavor but was a little tough and, honestly, I'm not so sure it was really filet mignon.  The sauce for my fish was also a little intense for my taste.  Everything else on the table was delicious-- including the complimentary homemade tortillas and salsa (yes, it's true... they charge for chips and give tortillas for free... fine by me).  For dessert, I highly recommend the churros, which are filled with a delicious caramel cream and served with ice cream.

They also have about a million Tequilas, so if you are looking for a place to sample Mexico's finest liquor Colibri will be hard to beat.
author: Matt L.

description:
Would give three and a half stars, if I could.  Had a business lunch here today for 4.  For the most part the restaurant was quiet until about 1pm when some additional parties came in.  Dishes tried, chicken mole, just ok, quesadillas, pretty good, guacamole, ok but not great.  They used to make it at the table, but that didn't happen.  Service was ok, not great.
They need to step it up a notch.  I want to like this place more than I do.
author: Ron T.

description: We came here right before a show got out across the street- the calm before the storm. We were able to find bar seating though. The plus of the meal was the ceviche - sometimes you order a $15 ceviche and they bring you one piece of two pieces of sashimi and a lime wedge - but this ceviche was pleasantly a good value. Not everything lived up to the menu descriptions though - what seems to be an intriguing list of margarita variations tended to all taste the same and be fairly weak and there was only a tiny amount of salt on the rim, which is a margarita crime. But what I really did not get was the chips - two dollars! For chips? Well for two dollars they have to be good right, like maybe homemade? Fresh? Not stale and from CostCo? I guess when you are charging two bucks for chips you don't sell very many. Maybe we will try them again on a less busy night. But maybe not.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Great to find a real restaurant worthy of San Francisco so close to Union Square. I went in worried that this would be another place that succeeds here because of all the hotels and never worries about repeat business. I left really happy. 

While I see from some reviews that some people come here looking for standard, Americanized "Mexican" food (plus good guacamole) what I found was a trio of interesting house made salsas and a pollo pibil that would make Diana Kennedy smile.
author: R P.

description: energetic. this sums up this place in one word. came here with some work colleagues. tasty margy's. good food. had the carnitas chille relleno. instead of traditional tortilla chips, they serve soft tortillas. the one downer was the bathroom was a bit of a mess. other than that- the place was rock'n by the time we left around 8:15pm. I'd come back!!!
author: Steven D.

description: My husband, 7 year old son and I walked in off the street on a Friday night to get a bite to eat. There were several empty tables in the restaurants, but the host wanted to check his reservations. After checking his reservations, we were told they couldn't accommodate us. We really, really wanted to eat there after reading all of the great reviews, so we decided to call back and try and get a reservation. To our surprise we were able to get a reservation for 15 minutes after the first time we tried to walk in. The look on the hostesses face was priceless when he saw who his reservation was for. He quickly said, "we had several cancellations!" Yeah right a-hole! Anyhow, in a nut shell, the food sucked and was way over-priced, the service sucked from beginning to end. Would not recommend this restaurant to anyone!
author: Sally S.

description: Food was great, service was mostly good. Friendly staff overall. Definitely gets packed so a reservation is recommend unless you are going at a random time. The fresh guacamole is delicious but even if you ask for it spicy it doesn't get that hot. Definitely a place I would return to again.
author: Yaswanth R.

description:
I tried this place for the first time last week, before I went to see "A Chorus Line" at the Curran.  (I'm willing to bet that half the people in there were doing the same.)
This place is great!  They make the guacamole to order; everything we had was superb, particularly the blackberry margaritas!!  We did have one shrimp dish that wasn't all that fantastic, but I would go back in a heartbeat.  A great date spot.
author: Akemi Y.

description:
Regardless of whether you consider Colibri's dishes to be "large tapas" or just smaller portions, it all tastes amazing. We've been there six or seven times, so we've tried just about everything on the food menu.

First off -- they have the best guacamole!  The "spicy" is way too hot for my palate, but it would probably get some chili lovers' engines revving. 

The entrees are definitely large enough to feed one person.  Tried all of them, and they're all delicious -- even the cauliflower dish!

For dessert, the crepes with cajeta (a caramel-ish sauce) and ice cream are to *die* for.
author: Judy T.

description:
Guacamole lady - I salute you!  I was so inspired by your quick skill while mashing up that avocado that I went home and try to do it myself.  It was then that I formed a true appreciation - for making quality guac like you do is not easy!  
 
I had the fish tacos and they were awesome.  Really awesome.  

As much as I love cheap, dirty taquerias - this is a good place to go when you feel like eating good, clean food that your stomach won't hate you for.  It has a nice Mexico-city ambiance, good music and the little homemade flour tortillas are awesome.
author: Katie S.

description:
I'd give a billion stars for the guac, the blackberry margarita and the vegetable sope. In fact, the next time I come here I will make a meal out of these three items (asking if I can get an all veggie sope appetizer and lose the meaty ones). I'd definitely put your money toward drinks and apps here - they are totally filling and satisfying, so why spend more on an entree?

The stellar food and live entertainment (two guys playing traditional Mexican songs) more than made up for the somewhat inattentive service. I'll be dreaming of Colibri for weeks.
author: Beth T.

description:
Very impressive.  The mojitos were some of the best I've ever had.  

It's tapas style, so don't bring your appetite unless you're wiling to drop big bills (after all, it's in Union Sqare).  That being said, I ordered the guacamole (Nice to mole you... meet you. Nice to meet you, Mole.) extra spicy and they brought it on!  It was good, but at $10, I was expecting the large stone bowl to have a not-so-shallow bottom.  

The poblano mole-moly-moly-moly-moly-moly-moly (there, I got it out of my system) was very chocolately and cooked perfectly.

As others have said, the wait staff was attentive and I'd go again.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Colibri has maintained a consistant quality in food since they opened. Their Sunday brunch is delicious and if you go for dinner, I highly reccomend the pescado del dia as the sauce is utterly delicious. I have tried several dishes, all very tasty, but I always come back for the pescado del dia. 

Also, you won't find fresher guacamole than Colibri- they make it at your table to your specified spicyness! Their deserts are delicious as well (try the mexican chocolate mousse- yummm). 

Service is always good too. Definitely try to make reservations as it is right across from two theaters and gets packed.
author: Lindsey G.

description:
Fanciest mexican place I've been to in a long time. It is more of a spanish tapas type place, vs traditional entrees. Good place for groups to share.

Sangria is really good (maybe slighly too sweet for some, but has yummy mango in it). Guacamole is made fresh and good, but pricey ($10), They have really good fresh made tortillas and tastey salsa to go with it.

The chicken dishes were really good, very tender, moist chicken. The cerviche was good as well.

All in all, a place I would definitely go again. Has a nice atmosphere, good decor. Service was subpar though, with the wait service not being very attentive. Had to wave them down to get service. Look at spending $25-$30 with out drinks, $40 with.
author: Eddy N.

description:
Colibri is one of those restaurants that is worth the price of its food.  I've probably tried or tasted almost all the dishes on the dinner menu and I gotta say all of them are worth trying.

Currently my favorite dishes are the smothered chicken, which has a sauce I could drink like soup, the stuffed chicken, which has the crispiest skin ever, and the catch of the day never disappoints.

The guacamole is fresh and made to order and spread on their homemade hot tortillas is absolutely divine.  The jicama salad was very spicy the last time I tried it, but I still ate the whole thing.

You won't be disappointed.  I guess the only gripe I'd have is that it can get loud and crowded.  But the service is good.
author: Susan C.

description: Delicious homemade tortillas and salsa! the enchiladas were delicious as well as the carne asada! Service was great... would definitely go back!
author: Jamie Y.

description: Upscale Mexican food!  We enjoyed jicama salad, duck breast, filet mignon and lamb shank.  All good but the duck was slightly undercooked.  There was so much meat on the lamb shank that more sauce would have helped.  Guacamole was okay although extra charge for chips was annoying.  The service was good.  The low point was the very high noise level...once the place was filled at 630p you could hardly hear the person next to you so you had to speak very loudly.
author: V W.

description: Just okay  food and rude service. The woman who waited on us was nice, but after spending about $60 and 45 minutes on food and drinks, a manager moved in and let us know we had spent too much time at our table and our party of three should move to the bar. We weren't being boisterous or loud or anything, maybe not spending enough money??  We told him we thought that was rude and he just sneered at us. With so many great choices in SF why go somewhere that treats you badly?
author: Barbara F.

description:
food was ok
small portions 
really small portions
overprice and not spice enough
give two stars because of the service
but tottally not enough food for
the price. We were 2 of us, walk out
with an $ 81 dollars tab, $ 16 gratuity and still 
hungry. Unfortunatly I wont be able to give the second
chance for Colibri.
author: Alex M.

description: Place had an authentic sort of feel.  They apparently have 100s of types of tequila, but no one in my party was in the drinking mood.  All the food was good, but what really stood out was the Churro.  On my lord! Seriously, one of the best fried desserts I've ever had!  Didn't matter how full we were, we finished it in no time. So good!
author: Bubba B.

description: This bistro is a great place to go and meet up with friends and just have a chill dinner. The food is delicious, the service is great and the set up of the restaurant is modern yet authentic. The bartender there is amazing, she is friendly and a joy to be around. Their guacamole (served in tortillas) is seriously amazing! I am definitely going back to this bistro, with my family, my friends or even both! :)
author: Pyae P.

description:
Went here for a bday lunch with the office, had a great time and the waiter was friendly and helpful even though we were a tougher crowd.  The only reason this is a 4-star is because they didn't turn on the a/c.  I don't know if the busser didn't understand us or if they didn't have any, but we were all sweating buckets and sliding in the vinyl seats towards the end of the meal (despite our intake of margaritas to cool us down).

Otherwise great time, just dress in layers...
author: Kasi S.

description:
I'm surprised my fellow yelpers didn't like the place as much as I did! 

I went to Colibri for lunch with about 6 coworkers. The free tortillas and 3 types of salsa hit the spot! Our table devoured it in no time, and the waiter was happy to keep refilling our basket until our food came. I ordered the mole prawns..MmmMmm. It was cooked just right--not overdone like how a lot of places make it. The mole was tangy and complemented the palate. The prices are not cheap, but that restaurant.com certificate came in handy! 

I love the ambiance: bright colors, an updated classic yet modern feel. I think it'd be really fun to come back for happy hour.
author: Ava C.

description: This place was packed. We were seated quickly and provided with a bundle of freshly made tortillas and three salsas--the tortillas were quite delicate and delicious but the salsas were unimpressive--one was too sweet, one was spicy but had a very raw jalapeno taste--the third, just uninteresting. The salad--with mango, avocado and flowers looked pretty enough, but was under-dressed--it also lacked any contrasting notes, or bursts of flavor. Salt helped but not much. The two mains arrived quickly, tamarindo mole shrimp with a corn cake--completely average, again no contrasts in taste or texture, the mole lacked its signature deep flavor profile. The portion relatively small. My partner had the chile relleno with chicarron--the stuffing was mushy and unappealing--the flavors fused together so that nothing stood out. The chile was rubbery. Taste wise very disappointing. The place was packed, I can only imagine it is a place for margaritas and guacamole--but for food, its a pass. The tortillas were the only thing worth praise.
author: J.M. R.

description: The food is absolutely delicious and everything was served in a timely fashion. This is the one place I will definitely eat at again when I'm back in San Francisco.
author: Brian E.

description: I really enjoyed this place! It truly is the best Mexican place around San Francisco.  Since I tried the fish dishes, I can definitely vouch for their fish.  The quality of the food is spectacular and it was very well displayed.  I plan on going back for their drinks alone-totally hits the spot! And not to forget their service, the staff are very friendly and know how to do their job.
author: farzana k.

description:
$10 bottomless mimosas?  Yes, please!

Please note this is not ordinary Tex-Mex style mexican food.  If you are looking for chain-type food stay away!  

We went today for brunch and it was so good I wished I could write my review as I ate.  First of all they brought us a sampler of 3 different salsas and hand made corn tortillas.  I stay away from carbs but I just had to try the tortillas--and they were so worth it!  The green chili salsa was perfectly spiced and there was a sweet corn salsa that was amazing.  The mimosas are also perfect--just a bit of hand-squeezed juice and a lot of champagne.  My husband I both had the carnitas omelet and they were perfect.  I'm not a big fan of omelets because there is usually a lot of egg and not much filling.  This omelet was perfectly balanced between meat and egg, the eggs light and fluffy and the meat in a tasty sauce.  It was served with these yummy, buttery home fries and THE BEST black bean puree I've ever had.  My daughter had the chilaquiles and they were also really, really good.  The service was amazing, my mimosa glass was never empty nor was the coffee or water.  

I would definitely recommend Colibri for brunch, I'm thinking it is not for people who want traditional tex-mex fare.  Don't get me wrong--I love that style of mexican food, crave it even. Colibri is just an upscale kind of take on Mexican food, made from scratch with fresh ingredients and a gourmet flare.
author: Mia N.

description:
Went to this place with a GroupOn for lunch.  Ordered Ceviche ($16) and Carne Asada ($15) and a club soda ($3).  Why one star?

1) All the fish at this place was talapia.  I've paid more than $16 for ceviche, but not for talapia ceviche.  

2) Ceviche came with horrible corn chips from a bag.  This place makes decent homemade tortillas. Why not chop up a few of these babies and throw them in the deep fryer.  

3) Carne asada was about 3oz of what looked like top round on top of a heap of nopales.  About a tablespoon of very blended and liquidy refried black beans (it was more of a sauce than refried beans) and about a quarter cup of rice.  What a ripoff!

4) Everything was way too salty.  

5) They offer three salsas with the entrees.  All are BLAND!!!!  Salty yes, but bland.  If you offer 3 salsas, one should be HOT

6) I originally ordered iced tea, but it was obviously not made fresh there.  It had that Nestea flavor, so I asked to switch it up for the club soda.  

Basically, $40 for a meal not even worthy of Chili's.
author: Mike P.

description:
My son suggested Colibri for a pre Mother's Day dinner - great suggestion! 

Guacamole - excellent (a bit too much salt), love the warm tortillas
Panuchos de Cochinita Pibil - great with the guac and warm tortillas - we made our own little tacos
Tortilla soup - excellent - hot and spicy - perfect!
Filet Mignon - wonderful - delicious flavors
Panuchos de Cochinita Pibil - wonderful - small portion
Mixed seafood and and rice from the specials menu - marginal
Crepes for dessert - wonderful

This place was pretty crowded and busy. I don't usually think of Mexican and Bistro in the same title, but they pulled it off. This is basically an expensive ($160 for 4 - no alcohol, 2 people sharing and 2 appetizers and dessert) mexican restaurant with some american menu items with a mexican flair (stuffed chicken and filet mignon)  - again they pulled it off. Everything was a wonderful blend of flavors and cooked to perfection!

I would definitely go back here!

By the way, if someone from Colibri reads this, love your silverware! Where can I get some?
Thanks!
author: Sue F.

description: Always a great experience at Colibri. The guac is always great and I love the little tortillas they serve with it. I ordered the chicken mole for the first time and it was fantastic, although wasn't the greatest reheated the next day. Oh well! But if you go to Colibri, you MUST try the churros. It will change your life. Perfect warm sweet and gooey churros. I would go just to get these.
author: Colby L.

description: We went to Colibri before going to the theater to see In the Heights. We had the guacamole (which was made at you table) and chips. It was 15.00 ( a little expensive) and very good. I had the chili relleno stuffed with carnitas and my wife had the scallops. They were both really good along with the churro for dessert. We loved the place and the service was great. Very close to 5 stars.
author: Raymond A.

description: My boyfriend and I came here for some Mexican food because we had already had pizza, clam chowder, American ect. SO.... being the super Mexicans that we are, we were in need of some yummy comfort food. The place was nice and we were seated right away but the table was really small and very close to other people and I didn't really feel comfortable having a conversation with him because I felt like i was bothering the people around us. As for the food, I ordered the  Ensalada Flor De Verano which sounded nice but was really just a blah thrown together mess that really didn't impress. As for my boyfriends food, he ordered the Chile Relleno which turned out to be a tiny little chile that didn't even have the traditional egg batter coating. The description boasted that it included chicharron and carnitas that came along with it, but it turned out to be just a small dusting of chicharron and a very small portion of carnitas if any. I felt really bad because after he ate it, he was still hungy.  Overall, I didn't feel like this was authentic Mexican food because it seemed to be more geared toward an American palate. The salsas were very mild and were given to us 10-15 minutes before getting chips like they expected us to taste the salsas with the spoons they provided along with them??? wth? I wouldn't go back and wouldn't recommend this place to someone that knows what real Mexican food is like.
author: Amanda L.

description: Delicious food, great service, and very generous margaritas.  Make sure you save room for deserts.
author: Brent B.

description: Went to Colibri for dinner and made a fabulous one out of a few appetizers. Delicious!
author: Molly S.

description:
Not the average Mexican joint, it features more Southern Mexican dishes from the Oaxacan area, only they're gourmeted up so as to seem upscale.

The ambience is really nice with candlelight but the noise can be overwhelming sometimes.  

The freshly made guacamole is excellent as are the freshly made tortillas.

If you're familiar with Oaxacan or Guatemalan style food, than you'll love this place.  But if you're expecting a menu similar to Chevy's, think again.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
A relaxed, subdued atmosphere centered around a beautiful under-lit bar. The wait-staff was courteous but a bit hard for me to understand; that's OK, as the food speaks for itself. The carnitas are fantastic, the fish is fresh and moist, and the lamb tender and not a bit gamy. The portions were hit-and-miss, as it is difficult to know whether or not to order sides when the sea bass is a minimalist offering, but the lamb might have been about half the actual animal. 

Value-wise, I felt the food items were all reasonable, but the drinks were a bit overpriced, but perhaps this is made up for a bit in volume; the drinks were quite huge.
author: Brian W.

description:
I had a great time here.

Went with a group of 6 for dinner...you walk in off of the street and instantly feel as if youre in for a good time...

We were seated promptly and our waitress came by to inform us of the food and drink specials.  Only drawback...when you ask for another minute to make your choice you get about 15...

Anyway...the guacamole was amazing - and I dont like guac...the melted cheese appetizer was phenomenal and the braised lamb in banana leaves just fell off the bone.

Im pretty sure everyone loved their meal.  Be sure to check this place out...
author: Ken S.

description:
This is my first time to have Tapas style, it was good because I could eat various kind of foods with sharing.  

I went there for dinner.  The atmosphere is really good, dimly lit  and quiet.  Especially I went  with my special friend, that was great time.

I like Papas al gratin this is Potato gratin.  Don't forget to order Guacamole.
author: Hiroko S.

description:
Yummy...go for the tableside guacamole, the stuffed peppers, the 50 tequilias, the fresh tortillas,  and the best mole sauce in the city.

The sevice leaves somthing to be desired, but the food makes up for it.
author: Susan L.

description:
The food is fresh and delicious.  The atmosphere is classy, yet warm.  Service is a little slow at peak times but they are very nice and the food is so good it's worth it.  I haven't yet gone to dinner, but have done brunch and lunch.  All the antojidos were fantastic, as well as the Pozole, Ensalada de Jicama, and Tilapia.  When you order the guacamole, which they prepare at your table side, you get delicious, homemade warm corn tortillas and three delicious homemade salsas.  Get the Tacos Pescado Al Pastor.  Yum!

UPDATE: Did the dinner.  It was equally fantastic.
author: Lita F.

description:
If you go to the website and look at the menu you can see that many of the dishes sound really tasty, and you can see the prices (a bit pricey for Mexican, but this is not a burrito shack) .  If the food sounds good, and the price is right, you will not be disappointed.  (Our bill for 2 with tip was $100...at $8 a pop per drink perhaps we should stop drinking alcohol!)

At 5pm there weren't any tables available because they were holding them for dinner reservations.
We sat at the bar- we had good service here and the bartenders were friendly which always makes things better. 

I had 2 mojitos- both yummy, made just right. 
Matt had 3 margaritas- the first one was perfect- no margarita mix used, just fresh lime, tequila, sugar, and water.
His 2nd and 3rd were a little more on the sour/sweet side and were much more cloudy in color. Not sure of what happened with this inconsistency (different bartender- that could explain it- but it seemed like a different recipe).

Anyway- the food was great! We had the fish of the day, Wahoo, a Hawaiian white fish. It was cooked perfectly, the veggies were great and the sauce was dancing with flavor. 


The second dish we originally ordered was the scallops but the manager came by to kindly tell us it would be about 20 minutes to prepare (which was fine) because they were still frozen (maybe we didn't need to know that part-). 
So we got the chicken instead of the scallops.
The stuffed chicken had mushrooms, veggies, and a sauce-a  lot of flavor. I had a few bites of this  but, wow- I preferred the fish- it was sooo good.

We also had dessert, yikes (but we didn't have the guacamole, so it's OK). The chocolate cake with ice cream- yummy! It takes about 15 minutes for them to bake and prepare, so if you're in a hurry you will not want to try this. But, if you have time to chill out, it was worth the wait. Warm and soft... aah.
author: Amy J.

description:
Expensive- sure ($30per or so with one plate and one cocktail) just like every other small plate restaurant in this city. But there is something very appealing about the types of plates that are available. And most are big enough to eat as a meal or share with the whole table, family style (instead of splitting bites with the table).
I highly recomend their cocktails (although I warn about their standard margaritas - sometimes they are a bit too sour).
All in all - a really great place to sit down for a more formal meal and enjoy the company of friends and loved ones.

*note* my friend ordered the scalops and thought them grand (british folks can get excited about food that doesn't taste like sand...)
author: kristin n.

description:
I know I've been slacking off lately with my reviews. But after my fourth visit to Colibri I would feel ashamed if I didn't do them the favor of a Yelp.

Colibri is nacho ordinary mexican restaurant. (You get a slash for that one, Larry.)

The first giveaway are the warm tortillas. Rather than deep fried chips -- and don't get me wrong, I love me some deep fried chips -- they serve warm, homemade tortillas with three complimentary salsas. Tip: Don't waste your time with the pineapple option. Go straight for the hot, red stuff.

Next, the guacamole is a no-brainer. They make it table-side. Unless you sit in the entry portion of the restaurant, in which they make it table-near. Fresh avocado, fresh limes and tomatoes. Mmm, mmm, mmm. $10 for guac is steep, but so worth it.

As for entrees, I've been blown away by the chile relleno and the cauliflower something or other. Amazing every time. Though I should note, on the weekend they serve a more limited brunch menu. Still tastetastic.

I know the review's going long, but what's new? The drink list deserve a mention and a thorough review upon your visit. With three pages of tequilla offerings, and an eye-crossing list of margaritas it's easy to miss the Michelada. It's beer of your choice, served with lime juice in a salt rimmed glass. A little funky because it has ice, but delightful and different.

I've yet to try the desserts, but something tells me I'll be back soon enough.
author: Josie Z.

description:
Talk about your fancy upscale Mexican eatery with a Union Square-ish feel. This isn't a fast-food, or Mission-like Mexican joint by any means. But the food is good, the ambiance is welcoming, service is nice, and the guacamole is to die for. The guac is made either mild, medium, or hot spicy and served with nice warm tortillas (as opposed to chips). Very nice.

The $$$ is right on. This place isn't cheap, no sir. The guac alone cost us $10. They have pretty every tequila you can think of on the face of the planet and the drinks are also priced well.

PS: I'm still struggling to figure out how exactly you pronounce Colibri
author: Anand I.

description:
I am never sure about places right off of Union Square only because most places suck cuz it caters to tourists BUT I was pleasantly surprised. The place is very homey and inviting. Ask for the guacamole - it's totally fresh and the guy made it in his little table next to us. Rather than chips, they give warm tortillas - it almost tasted like they could have hand made it that day. You can order either tapas style or your own. With my party of 4, we shared. Everything was great - from the ceviche veracruzan style, the jicama salad, chicken mole, and the seared fish. I also tried the chicken soup - had a bit of kick to it if you like spice - like me. Servings were pretty big so enough to share and fill your tummy. Also, apparently they are known for their margaritas - mine was the citrus with a hint of vanilla - very smooth. 

For a little more high end Mexican, (compared to my $4 burritos in the Mission) I definitely recommend this place - perfect place for a hardy meal if you are shopping down town or going to a show.
author: Jen R.

description:
This is a really cool spot to have a few drinks, appetizers, dinner, or any combination of the previous.  They have an extraordinary selection of tequila & all of their specialty margaritas are distinct and worth a try.  The sangria is also quite good, although expensive at $20/pitcher (small pitcher at that).  The food is served in small plates with a limited selection of primarily meat dishes (very limited vegetarian options).

Perhaps the best part about the place is the guacamole they make at your table (to your specifications).  The avocados are always VERY fresh.  If you are a frequent customer, they might even offer you the AWESOME habanero chili guac.

I recommend making reservations for parties larger than 4 - the seating is limited & tightly packed.
author: T D.

description:
If you want to have a serious night of tequila-drinking, by all means go to Colibri. If you're in it for the food, however, think twice.

When my parents and I arrived it was very crowded, especially at the bar, which seemed like a good sign. Our waiter brought us menus and drinks. Then came sign number one that something was horribly wrong: there was no free chips and salsa. Instead there were corn tortillas and some thin, liquidy sauces that seemed to belong at an Indian restaurant. I still don't get it.

So we scanned the menu, decided on guacamole, ceviche, a Caesar salad, and carnitas (de puerco). The guacamole was listed as "made tableside". It's not. A man comes to ask you how spicy you want it, and then it's brought to you in a glass bowl perched in a molcajete, which is the closest you'll get to authentic the entire meal. The guacamole does not come with tortilla chips. According to our waiter, Colibri doesn't HAVE tortilla chips... Sign number two: in the guacamole, my father found a hair.

Soon after, the entrees arrived. My father had the carnitas, which were not carnitas by any Spanish definition of the word. It came as four large chunks of pork which were practically unseasoned. My mother and I split the ceviche and salad. The ceviche might have been the high point of the meal, but we've made better at home. It was a bit sad looking, floating in tomato juice, and there was almost no onion or avocado. The ceviche comes with... get this... tortilla chips! They were also corn, which masks the flavor of the ceviche. The salad was fine, not exciting, but it comes as whole hearts that you have to cut up. I was serious about getting tortilla chips for the guac, so I pulled a different waiter aside and asked for some more chips. He seemed baffled, but soon came back. Sign number three: he came bearing a plate with 7 tortilla chips on it. 

So I'm confused. I'm thinking the four stars must be for the tequila.
author: Victoria N.

description:
This is a favorite of mine!  The hot freshly made tortillas, the gooey-cheesy queso fundido, the guacamole made tableside, the tasty ceviche, the nopales  cactus and portabello mushrooms, and of course, their margaritas!... all of these with the ambience and central union square location make this place a treat!

Great for dinner after the theater or after a day of shopping in union square!  First got introduced to this place on a date.... not a bad place for a first date (unfortunately the food and service was much more memorable than the date... can't remember his name... but I still crave the tortillas with the guac or queso fundido from time to time!!!)
author: Alex D.

description:
So, we're staying at the Mark Twain and want to try something different. We stumble across a relatively new Mexican restaurant whose menu proved promising.... mole poblano, guajillo chiles, handmade tortillas, etc not you're average taqueriila! After some deliberation, we enter. At first glance, the place is beautiful! Handcarved wood bar, massive mirrors that suggested a much larger space, and a charming hostess... the vibe was great. 

To start, we're served handmade tortillas with 3 fantastic salsas ranging from hot to sweet. Okay, we're in for a treat.

Our waiter was accommodating, but definitely green. We ordered: tamales with mole, tortilla soup, enchiladas with a tomatillo-jalapeno sauce, and a side of rice. He then described to us the order in which the food would be served. We expressed to him that we were hungry and the order wasn't of concern. He brought it all at once. Not the biggest deal, but still sort of weird. 

The tides turned when the soup came to us lukewarm. Lukewarm! Not hot. Not cold. Lukewarm. Okay, whats up? 

The tamales: Cold. Way too much Nestle Abuelitas chocolate in the mole. Reminiscent of burnt cinnamon. The rice: Decent. But cold. Ugh. The enchiladas: Neither tomatillos or jalepenos were present. I'm still not sure what the hell that was. We didn't finish it. The soup: As I mentioned, lukewarm, however, the waiter made an effort to rectify this by bringing a hot pan of soup to pour over our already cold soup. This did help the situation, but, not by much. All in all, we're not going back. 

Maybe you'll have better luck? The previous ratings were kind of high? 2 stars - 1 for the hostess and 1 for the decor.
author: Monica S.

description:
I absolutely loved this place.  I recently went with some friends while we were visiting San Francisco and we really enjoyed it.  We split the guacamole for an appetizer and it was fantastic.  We ate it with the fresh tortillas instead of chips (additional cost to get chips) and it was a really pleasing change of pace.  I got a glass of sangria, which I enjoyed quite a bit.  For dinner, i got the Callos con Crust de Tortilla.  I'm not a huge mushroom fan, but this dish was delicious.  It was three large scallops, each over the mixture of mashed potatoes, poblanos, cactus leaves, and portabellos.  The atmosphere in the restaurant was nice and it was clean.  We didn't have to be all dolled up to go in, which was also great since we'd just finished a winery tour a few hours earlier and weren't about to dress up.  It's a little on the smaller side, but we were seated no problem around 7:30pm on a Sunday night.

The only reason this isn't 5 stars is because it IS a little expensive...but I knew that going into it.  I can't imagine it being an every-day place but it's great for special occasions or as a treat when on vacation!
author: Di L.

description: This is my second review of Colibri which says something in and of itself. I love this place.  Its got a great atmosphere and excellent, made-at-the-table guacamole (last time it wasn't made at the table).  The guac and the homemade tortillas ar great together.  I had the Carnitas this night and the pork was melt-in-you-mouth tender perfectly cooked with an incredible mixture of spices.  The sauce that comes on the side was also incredible.  If I live in SF, I would eat here often!
author: Brad F.

description: Maybe we caught them on an off night but it was a rather disappointing experience. The staff is friendly and the service is OK but I was not crazy about the food. The guacamole is great but in most Mexican restaurants it is usually great. I ordered the carnitas a pork dish. I was expecting it to be like a stew and instead I got two pieces of fairly fatty pork meat. The tortilla soup was good, not great. We also had empanadas and again they were not that great. Maybe it is a matter of taste, other people would find the food delicious. But I have been to a lot of Mexican restaurants and I can taste the quality difference. I give it three stars to be polite.
author: Nicolas B.

description: Extremely authentic, been to Mexico many times and this is the place if you want to experience it first hand.  Extensive tequila selection, homemade corn tortillas and dishes with fantastic flavors. Get the poblano stuffed with pork for a real treat.
author: Jason G.

description:
I've been here a few times and always walk away very pleased. Be sure to check out the April special - Mahi Mahi - it tastes amazing. The highlights:

1. Excellent location for locals and visitors to San Francisco. 
2. They call to confirm your reservation.
3. Guac is made right next to your table - fun fun
4. Each dish has impeccable flavor and looks like a masterpiece.
5. The place is gorgeous - all mahogany wood with old light fixtures.
author: Virginia S.

description:
This spot is one of my favorite Mexican restaurants in the city.  The food is always amazing.  Get the Carnitas and Taco Soup, you'll never regret it.  The bar section tends to get a little loud, so if you want a more intimate dinner then request a booth or table in advance.  It's a little pricey, but you get what you pay for, and you're in Union Square so $10 a cocktail is pretty standard. 
  It's a good idea to make a reservation if you're planning ahead, since it's downtown and gets pretty slammed most nights.
author: Nathan C.

description: One of the BEST Tequila bars in SF!  I love the flights, the Guacamole, the fresh tortillas and delicious Central Mexican specialties!
author: Lana L.

description: The fresh made Guacamole is pretty yum. At first I didn't know why they charged extra for tortilla chips!!!?? What's Guac without chips? But they offer hot and fresh tortillas on the side. I ordered the tortilla soup. It came out in a little pot, and the server poured the soup into the bowl with the fixings. The soup tasted more like TJ's creamy tomato soup more than anything else. I paid way too much for that meal.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
Someone needs to talk some sense n' reason, it IS afterall, resolution season. (Since I celebrate Chinese New Year, January is actually "bonus" month, surely as Year of the Tiger launches, i'll be gettin disciplined as all get-up ;) 
It seems we are 15 mins into the meal & all the fresh, warm, thick corn tortillas have been consumed...How odd! Additionally, any willpower to deny the need for a second batch evaporated with that organic margarita..I swear, it was here just a minute ago?
Footprint of a lovely meal.
The guacamole was just dreamy. They asked "how spicy" (i fully support customized Guac to palate.) It came as requested: full-tilt. Even at the end of the meal, the bowl required a lick clean, just to be sure it held up its flavor.. 
Ceviche also great-- limey cilantro fireworks.. A great opportunity to query yet again "Those warm tortillas...?"
The Mole excellent, but I was a little distracted by avocado, masa excursioning to give it undivided attention.
As for cocktail, I vote mojito over margie, as I tried both and mojito was so packed w/ muddled mint and half limes, it's basically an immune tonic. And you know, it is cold and flu season, so you can't be too well hydrated! 
I'd say we have a winner on the high-end Mexican spot for the downtown meet-up.
author: Rachel S.

description: Our waiter offered up great menu suggestions and the food was AMAZING! Very delicious and authentic! I highly recommend going!!
author: Ashley K.

description:
Came here on a Monday night with 5 other people.  We had reservation so we didn't have to wait at all.  The place was really crowded at 8PM.  The live music was excellent but it made everyone talk super loud so the atmosphere here is definitely not "romantic" but almost "chaotic".  Overall I would say it's totally worth the visit if you're in the union square area and want to have a "lively" atmosphere for dinner but also eat a satisfying meal.

What I liked:
Food:
We started out with the freshly made guacamole.  I'll be honest, I make a pretty good guacamole myself but I still can't resist to order fresh guacamole in restaurants.  It turned out to be really good, as i would expect it to be.  We ordered the chips ($2 extra) to eat with the guac but it's the hand made tortillas that REALLY stood out. Seriously, how can i EVER eat another tortilla again after eating this?? 

I also ordered an ensalada mixta, which is just a simple mixed green salad with cherry vinaigrette and it was just ok.  I felt like there was too much dressing to my taste.  

My entree, however, was wonderful.  I had the Chamorro de Cordero, which is lamb shank steamed in banana leaves.  The meat was tender and falls off the bone.  the portion was huge.  I also had a bite of the carnitas but i thought it was a little dry.

The BEST part of the meal was definitely the dessert.  I'm so glad we decided to order some even though we were all pretty full.  The churros were fantastic!! and i don't even like churros!  They're filled with some kind of caramel cream in the center and served with ice cream.  I WILL come back just to eat them.  We also tried the Caballeros Pobres, which the waiter described as bread pudding like pastry served with honey but the group felt it tasted more like french toast.  Whatever it is, it is delicious.  It was the best dessert out of the 3 we tried.  The last one was the mango creme brulee and that was so good too.  Very mango-y with bits of fresh mango pieces.

What I thought was blah:
the service:
There were so many times throughout the night that we had to try really hard to get someone or something for our table.  We also had to check on the status for the food/drinks we ordered a few times.  Even though the answer is usually something like "it's on the way" or "i'll go check on it", I feel like with a restaurant like this, the server should be more proactive with checking on us and communicating the status of our order to us without us having to do that.  One of our drinks didn't come for over 15 minutes and my salad, which the server specifically asked if I wanted to have it before my entree (and I said yes), did'nt come until after everyone started eating their entrees already (including myself).  In neither of those times did the server say anything to us.  We ordered chips with our guac and the chips didn't get served until at least 10-15 mins after the guac was served.  When we asked the server about our chips, he said that the chips are made fresh and are coming from the kitchen, which is fine, but I just felt like he could've told us that.  He was friendly though, but just not attentive enough.

I would definitely come back because of the hand made tortillas and the awesome desserts.  I also want to try some more appetizer dishes since the others in my group had some of them and they seem to have really enjoyed them.  Oh, and yes they have a pretty impressive bar with lots of tequila choices too.
author: Cari H.

description:
I came here on my honeymoon based on the recommendations here.  The menu was tempting, and we were excited that most of the names on the menu were, if not Mexican, probably not those of white businessmen trying to exploiting an exotic cuisine.

We started with the guacamole, which was most definitely not made at our table.  The tortillas were great, the salsas were good (I particularly liked the mango salsa) if a little too thin, but the guacamole was pretty bland.  We asked for spicy (the real version of spicy, we said) but got mild.  It wasn't until we finished the bowl that we felt any kind of burn.

We both had the chile relleno, and we were both pretty disappointed.  The presentation was great, but yet again the flavors just fell flat.  There was simply nothing special about it at all.

At least the sangria was good...
author: Jonathan P.

description: We sampled this mexican spot on a quiet afternoon and were hoping to try some really deliicious, authentic food.   Colibri however fails to deliver.  I found most of the food to be pretty bland and average.   The tortilla soup was pretty good, the entrees we ordered including the fish tacos and mole dish were just so-so.   Even their complimentary salsas were lacking.   They didn't have much flavor or kick to them.   Overall just pretty disappointed in this place.   I've had much better Mexican elsewhere.
author: Mike B.

description: The guacamole was pretty good with good tortilla.  Mole chicken was ok.
author: Elena L.

description:
Colibri is a really nice place with great ambience and wonderful, friendly staff.  It's located right near Union Square and is a great place for lunch, or dinner (after a day of shopping).

The food is amazing and reasonably priced.  You must have the yummy Guacamole, the delicious Tortilla soup, and the amazing margaritas to start.  The entrees are just as great and of course, there's always room for dessert.....  Pastel de Chocolate is my fav.   

Enjoy!
author: Raj D.

description: OMG the tortillas are to die for! Food is great, cocktails are alright, service is OK. But OMG, the tortillas! Did I mention how awesome they are!?!?!
author: JoAnn D.

description: Amazing food, and great service. Good guacamole, but the homemade tortillas are the real stars of this dish. Served with three styles of fresh salsa, I loved the tomatillo salsa the best, but the mango was also very good. The waiter recommended a margarita, based on a few questions, (did I prefer fragrant, sweet, or spicy?. I loved the one he selected for me. Then I ordered the scallops with tortilla crust. Wow. This was the best meal I've had in ages, abs certainly in San Francisco. Also tried the strawberry basil margarita, which was good.  Dinner was $60, kind of steep... But for this meal? Totally worth it.
author: Janna S.

description: I went to Colibri because I was going to the A.C.T. performance across the street.  Since it was all about convenience, I kept my expectations low for the actual food.  I was SO wrong!  The guacamole was tasty, the service was VERY attentive and friendly, and the churro dessert was totally delicious.  My entree (the filet) was actually the least impressive part of my meal, but since everything else was so good, I didn't mind.  The menu has some unusual items, and does NOT have some of the things you'd expect, such as enchiladas.  My husband had the chili relleno and practically licked his plate clean.  We'll be back!
author: Molly P.

description: I'm shocked that this restaurant has a 4-star average review. I was in the neighborhood and had a hankering for Mexican, so I turned to trusty Yelp and you Yelpers completely led me astray! The food was a solid 3, but I'm docking an extra point because of the prices. I don't mind spending some money for good food, but this was thoroughly mediocre food. This is the kind of Mexican food I'd expect in North Dakota, not California! And everything is à la carte - meaning you have to order rice, beans, everything separately. They call it "tapas style," but really it's just an excuse to charge more money. Everyone was raving about the gazillion dollar guacamole, but again - just mediocre. I found myself yearning for Chevy's!
author: Caitlin L.

description:
This is Part 2:


Dessert came in the form of both the budin de chocolate, which was supposed to be mousse-like, according to the menu description. It turned out to be something that was akin to a Jello pudding snack, with only the redolent and chalky taste of bittersweet chocolate to remind you what flavor this was. The limp dollop of cream was entirely superfluous. So too was my mango creme brulee, which had an unusual problem: parts of it were at a different temperature. The sugar topping that was warm --you know, like the scene in "Amelie" where she cracks the hardened topping? Uh well, no-- none of that here. Once I cut through that topping, the custard has tiny bits of mango in it, and not like the "pieces" that were promised on the menu. The taste was fine, but I didn't appreciate the cold, gummy feel of the custard while the top still had the warmth of the torch they used to caramelize the sugar. Big fail.
Finally, did you all think people are fighting to  get in here because of the food? You must be kidding. It's the overpriced margaritas, mojitos and other drinks in the noisy bar. I tried the "house margarita" and, well, it was just OK. Honestly, I found it too strong, which normally people would favor. But I also took this to mean that the strength of the tequila must be a way to ply the customers into not caring too much about the lack of care the chefs would want to put into their food. Far from a complete experience, this place could just live on the weak appetizers and too-strong drinks.
author: Alfonso L.

description:
I liked the steak, even if they do medium-well when you ask for medium-rare --- that's probably the Mexican scale of doneness. The accompanying sauce was piquant -- not my favorite with steak, where I like to taste the meaty juices rather than any sauce on top, but pretty good nonetheless.

The waiters were very friendly, which isn' t something you always get at good joints in SF.
author: Sameer S.

description:
John and I loved everything we ordered here.  We started with the tamales in mole sauce.  Yummy.  The mole is incredible!  We also enjoyed the hand made tortillas and the pineapple salsa brought to the table before the meal.

We had the carnitas and the chicken mole.  Both were incredible, and we devoured everything.

We had the dark and light chocolate dessert, which John liked more than I did.  But then he likes the dark chocolate.

The service was excellent, and while we didn't see our waiter often, we were helped by all the wait staff. 

We would absolutely go back.
author: Gwen D.

description:
OK, my memories of this are a bit more vague than is probably warranted for a proper review: I'd had a couple of drinks at the Redwood Room right beforehand.

But, it was pretty close to completely amazing. We got the filet, some carnitas, an ensalada mixta and some kind of corn bread drenched in deliciousness side. I recommend all of them. Top notch.

For a cheaper deal with similarly high quality food but less fancy/expensive tequila, try Velvet Cantina, but this is a great splurgy place downtown.
author: Dan A.

description:
Wow!

The food was just unbelievable.  The lamb shank was so tender, that the meat just came off the bone.  Their duck mole and torta were also delicious.

They make their margaritas the way I like them, with tequila, fresh lime juice, and sugar, with a wide array of tequila choices.  I like to taste good tequila in a margarita, not sweet and sour.  I will admit I didn't care for the waitress's recommendation, the Magarita Tezon, as the grapefruit taste was too strong, but loved the Margarita Partida.

Their guacamole and fresh corn tortillas are also very good.
author: Steve W.

description:
I think this place is a hidden secret.  

Their menu is extensive and I just wanted to order everything on it.

I can't wait to dine there again.
author: Tiberius A.

description:
Wonderful, delicious, and extraordinary food BUT BAD SERVICE.
Like I said, the food is super- so good that after my first visit to Colibri, I returned the next morning to try out their brunch menu. Now, about the service- it took about five minutes to get water, then another five to get our orders taken, then our appetizers arrived at our table at the same time our entrees did. By the way, I encountered this same service two days in a row. Maybe they were short staffed or having a couple of bad days? Well, the food was so great that I'll be back real soon despite the service.
author: Valerie B.

description: A bit over priced but the wonderful service makes up for it.  Great guacamole!
author: Johnny C.

description:
The hostest was so wonderful. We arrived and didn't have a reservation and there was an hour wait so we were going to leave but she shuffled some things and got a table right away!! Perfect!!
The food was amazing and margartias just right!
Wish I visited SF more ofter so I could go again... and again and again!
author: Newport G.

description:
so we were walking around SF, and we wanted to go to a yummy mexican sit down restaurant, so we found this place on yelp. 

Food: yum! they served warm tortillas with three different types of salsa. one salsa was smoked/tomato, another was green chilis, and the third was a mango salsa. they were all good. the corn tortillas were especially good. (you can order a side of chips for $2) This is more of a tapas style place, so the portions are a little on the small size, but just the right amount when you couple it with the tortillas and salsa. The cheese quesadillas were average, i probably wouldn't order them again, but the carnitas was GOOD! 

Drinks: they have a BUNCH of different margaritas! We had a mango margarita, house margarita, sangria, and a pineapple spice. they were all delicious! 

Ambiance: the place was nice and homey. they have a bunch of their tequila displayed in a nice case. the place is decorated nicely, and its not overkill with decorations or anything. when you first walk in, it appears that the place is really tiny, but theres a whole back section. 

Service: our server, Dennis, was really friendly, helpful, and efficient. He even recommended some drinks and some stuff to order. they also give you unlimited tortillas. holler! 

Price: a little pricey, but worth it. the drinks were DELICIOUS!!! i would definitely come here again, if not to eat, then just to get some drinks.
author: Ashley M.

description: Collibrî - excellent, potentially non-authentic Mexican food. Everybody raves about the guacamole and the margaritas for good reason. It's been a while since I've eaten at Collibrî, and I cannot remember the specifics of what I ordered, but I do recall a genuine feeling of satisfaction with the preparation, atmosphere and preparation. Would definitely go back in a heartbeat.
author: Brett H.

description:
Came here twice, and the food is wonderful.

To start, the tortillas they give you right off the bat come hot and with three delicious sauces.

Tostadas de Tinga: Crispy and light, delicious.

The mole poblano is, for those of you that have never tried it, an experience on its own. It's probably not for everyone, but its sweet+spicy+umami taste is unique and intriguing.

For their June specials, they had a shrimp-wrapped-in-bacon dish that came with rice, which was quite nice, but a little salty.

The duck breast (Pato en Mole Verde Pipián) was tender and the sauce that came with it was perfect.

The best part about Colibri is their desserts. The chocolate cake, the mango creme brulee, the chocolate mousse, the churros - these are all excellent codas to the meal, certainly not something you can find anywhere.
author: Mimi L.

description:
Okay so ive been here a couple of times and I dont remember much about the food (that could be good or bad, keep reading)
I like the fact that they have full bar, and while waiting for any food to come I always indulge myself into excessive drinking and eating their FREE homemade tortillas! Their ceviche is very good but not worth the $16. Their food is good but not great to the point that I will stay sober just so that I can enjoy it.
Nice decor!
author: Ivonne S.

description: The food here is really good! We had the guacamole and they made it fresh at the table. They give you tortillas to go with it and if you want chips it's extra. We asked for spicy and while it was good it wasn't really spicy. So that's why they're only getting four stars. The food was really good... did I already say that? lol I had the stuffed chicken dish which was delicious!! The sauce and the veggies yum yum yum. Boo had the tamarind shrimp dish which was also good. The cocktails were delicious and STRONG which is always a plus. I'd definitely go back!
author: Dana F.

description: Coming from Texas where good Tex-Mex and interior Mexican are plentiful, we were really pleased with this find in the bay.  Homemade corn tortillas were outstanding as were the sauces and fresh made guacamole.  Entrees are a mix of classic and rather unique dishes.
author: Levi S.

description: Really loved this place - Union Square in SF.  High end Mexican.  Fresh guacamole made at your table.  Best enchiladas that I ever had - home made corn tortillas.
author: Amy W.

description: Fantastic restaurant. To say Mexican is limiting. Chef Edgar Castro takes traditional gourmet Mexican to a new level. Great prices, fantastic service and people.
author: Jennifer F.

description: OMG it cost $60 for my 10 year old and I to have lunch!  She had three tiny tacos and I had the chicken mole.  The mole portion was small and the sauce, while authentic, was way too overpowering for an entire meal. Her tacos were only so-so. We both had a drink and I admit that the sangria was very nice.  But aside from that  I feel totally cheated!
author: Errica C.

description: A bit pricy considering the food quantity, however food tasted good and fresh.
author: Ashok S.

description: Not like before anymore.   Overpriced and terrible service.  Not coming back ever.
author: rodrigo d.

description: One of our favorite unexpected gems near our hotel.  Fantastic happy hour.  Extensive margarita selections (house margarita is awesome).  Food was great and we really enjoyed the table-side guac.
author: Brian D.

description:
It was raining and the restaurant I was heading for was blocks away so I tucked in to Colibri and couldn't be happier.  Found a seat at the bar right away.  Seems the bar, as usual, is the "we have reservations" crowd holding place so seats open up regularly.

Bartender was knowledgeable, friendly and fast.  Yay!  Wine choices were priced well and a good value.  Most around me were drinking margarita's, of which there were plenty of choices in the $10 - $14 range.  They looked yummy!
