I had the Mole Poblano.  Delish.  Came with little tortillas and great dipping sauce but who needed it with that Mole sauce?!?  Yes, small portion but I left full.  High quality sauce embellished the moist, perfectly cooked chicken.  Would have been 5-star but I thought a small side would have made this dish sing just to give your tastebuds a break from the rich mole sauce.

Trendy, upscale, loud.  But I was able to easily carry on a conversation with my barmates.  I would go back again, and again.
author: Jenifer W.

description:
I thought it was cool how they made the guacamole in front of you! The appetizers were really good, service was great, bathrooms amazing clean, but was simply okay because let's face it-living in SF...we have the mission where you can get WAY MORE for your buck and even more flava!

But if you want fine dining, stuck downtown, but craving some Mexican food...then come here!!!

Okay, I'll admit my mouth waters as I think about the mango creme bruele dessert.
author: M R.

description:
I've had a couple conversations with friends about how you can't get away with expensive Mexican food in San Francisco. And for the most part that holds true. The thing is, while Colibri is more expensive than a taco place in the Mission, the menu is very different than those places. You also don't have to sit on a park bench while you eat, and there isn't any foil to deal with. One thing to be aware of is that it is central Mexican cuisine. There are no enchiladas! 

Go here on a date, and get a margarita and guacamole. If you're going with a group, definitely make reservations because the tables are small. And go on the weekend. The host Saturday and Sunday nights is adorable!
author: Keith T.

description:
I went there the other night with some friends from work.  It was described as a Mexican "bistro".  What the heck is a "Bistro" anyway?  I've seen places called bistros range in size from a small cafe to, well, this place which probably seats close to 100 people.   Here's a definition I found:  Fr. A small restaurant, featuring simple fare, sometimes with entertainment.

Colibri isn't a bistro, I'd describe it as Mexican-fusion.   It's the only Mexican restaurant where I've seen mashed potatos on the menu.  As far as entertainment goes, the only entertainment was the humor in the gruff and inattentive staff who left us parched and scorched from the hot food that was accompanied by no refills of our water glasses during the 75 minutes we were there.  

The food is tapas-style.  Relatively small portions you'd expect with tapas,  tasty and exotic, but way over-priced.  

Located close to Powell Street and whole Union Square area, the clientele are mostly out-of-towners and tourists which probably explains the over-excited staff.

We were told to "get the guacamole, they make it at your table."  Whatever.  I've made better, fresh guac, and my avos are organic.
author: Christopher M.

description:
The only reason I'm writing a review is because I just wrote one for the Mexican Chocolate ice cream at Mitchell's, so I felt compelled to write one about the Mexican Chocolate cake here.

It was go-od.  So you should try it.  And the bar area is perfect to sit at for dessert and drinks.  I'll have to actually come here for the food one day.
author: Karen L.

description:
I give five stars when I find no fault with my dining experience.  My family and our friend went for Sunday brunch and had a perfect time.  Luisa, our server, was sweet and friendly, the food was delicious and authentic mexican and the drinks were just as good (try the black cherry margarita!).  

I don't mind paying extra for quality (hand-made, super fresh tortillas and salsas,  tableside guacamole preparation), so the prices here seemed reasonable to me.

The restaurant itself is beautiful;  rich, dark woods, deep red walls, gorgeous floral arrangements, etc.

We will be going again and again.
author: Tracey B.

description:
Being from LA where there's a Mexican truck or restaurant on every corner & being with a half-Mexican guy makes Colibri a perfect catch!

I've been craving authentic Mexican food that can match my homemade experiences with the family & my love for Mexico. We came on a Saturday brunch & were greeted by a lovely hostess who sat us next to the tequila collection. They have over 300 kinds! 

We ordered rice, black beans, carnitas & chilequiles. WOW! It was flavorful, pleasing to the eye & tummy, & totally hit the spot (so to speak). The tortillas are small in size, but think in texture & flavor. I also ordered a michelada (beer with lime juice & the glass rim of salt). It reminded me of my days spent in Cancun drinking the slow paced days away. 

Service was great!!! If you order guacamole...they do a preparation show for you by cutting & scooping the avocados right in front of you. You can choose what ingredients & how much you'd like in your guacamole. Watch the servers go chop...chop...chop!!!

I'm definitely coming back & looking forward to trying more dishes. I highly recommend this place. Oh & if you like Latin rock, I heard Shakira in the background during my dining experience. The hostess told us that there's live music on Monday evenings too. See you soon Colibri!!!
author: L S.

description:
Food was delicious . . . again, YUM on the guacamole and homemade tortillas.  Could have been 4 stars if we were judging on food alone. . . 

BOOOOOOOOO on the service.  Is there such a thing as zero stars?  

When I say awful, I mean AWFUL.  Granted, our party of two came in at 10:15 but we called before coming in and they said they close at 11:00.  The hostess was absent and the bartenders (2 of them!) glared at us.  A party of 6 sat right before us freeing spots at the bar so my general feeling is. . .sit at the bar, smile, be nice and order quickly and all should be fair and good in the world, right?

Wrong.  I think our bartender rolled his eyes at us upwards of 4 times.  When we asked for suggestions, he knew nothing, he offered nothing.    Isn't it a bummer that I'm going on and on about eye rolling when I should be talking about how yummy the mole tamales were?  That's what sucks about bad service.  It manages to ruin everything.  

We asked for the bill as soon as the food was served because we were over having to deal with the servers.  My friend talked to the manager (a youngish girl with short hair who seemed more interested in hanging out with the servers eating than talking to us) and her excuse was that they were almost closed.  Duh.  We got that.  

Though the food was terrific and my friend who recommended the restaurant warned me of inconsistency, we'll go to Lolo's next time where apparently the food AND the service allow you to enjoy the company of friends rather than talk about how you can't wait to yelp how bad the service is.   Nuf said. . .
author: Michelle C.

description: The place was very crowded and I sat at the bar for dinner.  The guac was very good.  The carnitas also were quite good.  Drinks good.  All very solid and nice folks.  It's popular and there were a lot of returnees there.  I recommend it.
author: RJ C.

description:
Colibri is Mexican food done really fancy.  Scallops and steak done in a great mexian grill.  
Most Mexian restaurants offer a side of quacamole with ridiculous amount served for a hefty price.  Usually I am not tempted.  But, when they make it in front of you, and you get to choose the spice level, I'm all for it.  Even at exorbitant prices, it's worth it. 
Drink enough of those margaritas with salt on the side, and all the food will taste amazing. If you are the designated driver or don't drink, you might not think so highly of the food. 
The scallops I tried were phenomenal. I think they were actually part of the appetizer menu, but once I downed the hot guacamole, I didn't need it anymore. 
Downsides of Colibri- it is hard to get a table if you don't plan ahead. Especially on a saturday night. Even if you get a reservation, I've had to wait at the front for 15minutes after the reservation time.  Service is also hectic and I felt like we were forgotten for a while.  
Read you bill carefully, they have also added extra drinks on there probably due to the hectic nature of the place, but annoying nonetheless. 
Right across the street from the Hilton- so expect lots of tourists. Overall the food is delicious and doesn't need to be slathered in oil and cheese to make it "Mexican".  The spices are great. 3 and 1/2 stars.
author: Kat T.

description:
Many empty tables but told an hour and a half wait.

It seems to be a phenomenon in too many restaurants these days, poor management.  It was Saturday night so I didn't expect to get a seat right away but I was blown away that they told me an hour and a half wait with all the empty tables I saw.  It's almost like they are asking business to turn around and walk back out the door.  There was a table in the bar area so we took it, probably a mistake because on a cold San Fransisco night it was too close to the front door which was being held open as other potential patrons heard the wait time, looked around, turned around and left.  I went to the bathroom and counted the empty tables of which they were lucky to be slightly over 50% capacity.  There must have been a reservation no show because the hostess came up to us after 15 minutes or so and said she had one table for two open (obviously in my mind i said "not just one table honey").  If it weren't for the hostess being so attentive I would have probably given this place 1 stars.  The one star would come from a pretty decent house margarita and the guacamole the waiter makes for you.
I'm not sure if they are poorly managed or just understaffed but they need some help in this area.
author: Scott M.

description: Oh my goodness, the guacamole! The handmade tortillas! I could spend all day just on the appetizers.
author: Stacy L.

description: Well the food is just ok but who charges $3 for some chips? Thats not a way to run a business. Just for that Im not going bnack there. I can buy a hole bag of chips at Safeways for $3.
author: Jamie K.

description: Colibri surprised me. It's a hole in the wall sort of place, in a hole in the wall part of town. But man! what a tasty burrito. Make sure you don't settle for less than a super burrito, the cilantro and guac are essential. Good place to stop by if you're in the hankering for Mexican and this place is nearby.
author: Adam D.

description: Delicious main dishes. I was there with friends, we've tried 4 different ones and we were all very happy with our food. I've had the filete mignon which was awesome, very tender. The guacamole and the dip sauces were a bit tasteless though. It was missing spices. The sangria was average. The fruits in it didn't look so good. The staff was a little bit too serious and not very friendly.
author: C L.

description: A decent margarita, interesting beers, outstanding ceviche and mole poblano, freshly made tortillas for scooping up the mole, even a really good beet/arugula salad to start.  I'm not sure I need anything more from a Mexican restaurant!  We abstained from the stuff like guacamole and rice/beans.  When I want cheese and rice and beans I'll go elsewhere.  The food is well-portioned.  The mole was a great balance of bitter chocolate/spice and richness.  My friend declared the ceviche some of the best he's had.  The margaritas were only decent, not great.  I'll definitely be back!
author: Laura H.

description: Had margaritas here before at their beautiful bar.  We decided to have lunch here before heading to the airport.  We had Tacos Surtidos: Taco platter of house made corn tortillas, chicken, guajillo marinated fish w/ pineapple & steak w/ onions; Carnitas: Michoacan style marinated tender chunks of pork, served w/ guajillo & Arnold chiles salsa; Enchiladas Divorciadas: house made corn tortilla enchiladas served in Verde tomatillo-jalapeño sauce & Roja tomatoe-chipotle chile sauce w/ cheese.  Our party of four enjoyed every last bite.  Nice to see michelada being served here.  Minus one star for no waiter and busser as hostess and bartender had to do everything.  Otherwise amazing flavors and corn totillias from scratch.
author: Kalani C.

description: The food was good, but no where near worth the price. $10 for gaucamole?!
author: Sophia D.

description:
What a great restaurant...the food is amazing, and decently priced Portions for entrees are a bit smaller than other places, but I like it that way! The margaritas are to die for, very good even though they are a bit pricey....

I had the guacamole this time, very good although I can make it at home so too pricey for me because of this. They made it spicier than we asked, but it was still good.

The live music on Monday was a nice touch, I really felt like I was back in Mexico! Unfortunately, we had a loud group next to us (I mean, they were giving speeches standing up! Really...who does that in the middle of a small restaurant). Not the restaurants fault, but I could hardly hear my friends so I might skip mondays for a quieter environment.
author: C B.

description: The restaurant had a good atmosphere and service was great. The filet with mole sauce was delicious with a spicy kick. The guacamole was ok. The fresh corn tortillas were yummy with the salsas.
author: Catherine P.

description: Got to go with James D on this one. The chicken mole is very good along with the bacon enriched corn bread. Margaritas and guacamole. All fresh and excellent. Great experience and will make this a regular stop in the rotation.
author: Adam A.

description: Excellent food! The guacamole is delicious and so fresh. The service was very good as well.
author: LAUREN G.

description: Over-priced and just not that good! I m all for upscale Mexican- love it, in fact. But give me some flavor! The salsas had not taste, the chicken breast was INEDIBLE. We sent it back twice. I don't know what they do that it cooks so quickly (pressure cookers? Boil bag? Par cook and then finish off? But it was chewy! To their credit, the Chicken with Huitlacolche was AMAZING!
author: Andrea g.

description: My husband and I ate hear last night and was pleasantly surprised to find this little gem in the heart of downtown.  I thought the food was beautifully presented and delicious.  The three different salsas served with the homemade corn tortillas were all very good.  We ordered the Ensalada Flor de Verano, Callos con Crust de Tortilla, and Coliflor Capeada.  All were excellent.  I thought the food was reasonable to typically priced.  I would definitely come again, when I happen to be in the Union Square area.
author: Amy K.

description: Bottomless Mimosas and a big bowl of Guac makes for a happy Canadian on a hung-over Sunday. The chipolte benny was muy bien too.
author: Blaine A.

description:
I picked this place to celebrate my mother's birthday because the menu sounded good and the atmosphere looked great. I was so disappointed with the food, the service, and the prices were ridiculously expensive for the amount of food that you get.

I made reservations for 7 people and when I got there the tables were set up but uneven, which is not a big deal except there were 7 of us and the space would have been too tight for us to eat comfortably. I asked the host to please change the tables and he gave me the biggest attitude! He said "are you serious, but everything is all set up"? he huffed and puffed and asked me to wait out in the front so he could re-arrange the tables. He was so rude! My friend also complained about the bartender being rude to him. The waitress Eloisa, needs to be re-trained because I had to ask the other gentlemen working there for more water and tortillas since she did not come back to check on us at all. I work in the food business and I know the importance of checking up on your customers this girl just had no clue.
Do not order the duck, it is not good and the green mole was more like a sour dressing. Not good at all. The Mole Poblano was also a big disappointment and the pozole was not edible. The only ok dish was the shrimps in tamarind sauce because even the rice needed to be doctored up....
I left this place so disappointed with everything. There are so many good Mexican restaurants in San Francisco with good service and this place is just not one of them!
author: Jacquie S.

description:
To keep it short as everyone already said it before, the guacamole is made right in front of you, and is probably the best one you will have.  It is so fresh that i wanted to lick the bowl, or maybe i should have ordered another serving.

I had the chicken mole.  I must say i never had anything for dinner containing chocolate, but i must admit that this was really good.  It is not so traditionnal but more Mexican fine dinning.

Me and my girlfriend had a couple of margaritas and she had a shot.  We had a very pleasant evening, service was a tad slow (-1 *) but at least they kept our drinks coming.  If you want a good time and a lighter wallet, it's the place.
author: Eric P.

description:
I've been after the Chilaquil conspiracy for 13 years and finally realized that these guys simply have the BEST CHILAQUILES!  

Not sure, but I think they only serve them on Sunday brunch.
author: Ben S.

description:
You get what you pay for when you get the margaritas.  Actual muddled fruit as opposed to syrup.

They make the guacamole at your table.  It is delicious.

The gave me a braised lamb shank which was then steamed in banana leaves.  Soon thereafter I returned to them just the bone (read - it was tasty).

Also shares a door with the Diva Hotel.  Coincidentally one of the best small most thought out detailed hotel lobbies in the city.

Thanks Colibri - If your parking wasn't so difficult (Not a valet person) I'd be back more often,  but I still wrap this into an evening with the ACT Theater being right across the street and near other good places to hang out afterwards.
author: RiCH K.

description:
Let's see... how do I say this? Oh yeah. YUMMMMMMMM!

GF, Mom, and I went here for my mom's b-day (happy b-day momma!) on the GFs recommendation. Nice call, babe!

Service was great, no complaints. We went on Monday night and they had live music as we were leaving, so if that's your kinda thing this would be a cool place to eat around 7:00p or so on a Monday.

Anyway the ladies ordered margaritas, I had a michelada (beer + lime juice + ice). We ordered ceviche for an appetizer. Talk about good. Wow. I know its not hard to make... fish, lime juice, some other stuff... but their ceviche is super tasty and definitely worth the price.

Entrees are nowhere close to your typical Mexican... you know, plate of carne with rice, beans, pico de gallo, etc. but that was refreshing at this place. GF and momma both had filet mignon topped with a pepper stuffed with goat cheese. I thought it was pretty good, they thought it was great. I ordered the fish of the day plate... BAM! Fish was crazy flavorful, it was on a bed of green beans and chorizo! Yeah that's right, chorizo + green beans + white fish = *drooooool*

Best restaurant meal I've had in a while. I'll definitely go back. It's a little pricey if you do a drink + app + entree ($40+/person), but it's definitely worth it.
author: Bryan Z.

description:
Sad to say, but 2 of my married friends from the Peninsula exposed me to this place over 4 years ago.  

Colibri has ranked as one of my favorite spots in the City, especially when I am looking to entertain friends and clients from out-of-town.  I've been here at least a good 20 times, and it's taken me forever to write a review, so the only thing keeping me from giving this place 5 stars is that it is always - always - crowded...with tourists.  Other than that, I REALLY dig this place! 

Getting the guacamole is a MUST!  The warm, home-made, corn tortillas are awesome!  As a creature of habit, I ALWAYS get the carnitas...so good, it practically melts in your mouth!  The pollo pechuga is another favorite of mine!!  All my friends laugh at the notion of a Mexican "bistro", but once they hit Colibri, they totally get a feel for what good District Federal (Ciudad de Mexico, DF) tastes like.
author: A.D. A.

description:
Tasty Mexican place! We are always in the market for good Mexican and this place hits the mark. 

So what did we have....The guacamole and queso are our favorites for starters...the queso is deliciously gooey made with the right blend of cheeses. Both were served with fresh handmade tortillas.  We had the carnitas and scallops for entrees, both great choices. 

Price...a little pricey but didn't seem out of the ordinary for most restaurants in town.

Noise Level...Not too loud. You can easily relax and talk without having to yell to hear one another.

Parking...We first stopped at Bourbon & Branch for a few pre dinner drinks, this place is only a few blocks from there. Street parking is tough in this neighborhood but we did find a pretty cheap garage on Jones just off of Geary ($7 for 2 hours) and right next door to Bourbon & Branch.
author: Angela M.

description: The guacamole & ceviche were great, but the mole and sopa de tortilla were very disappointing. It's sort of a new modern Mexican cuisine, over priced and small portions, would not recommend it at all unless you just want a small appetizer. Also extremely busy, make a reservation.
author: Melina A.

description:
It was O.K.
would I come back. no

luckly i got 50% off from my groupon?

my mole was ok, it just came with mole chicken and nothing else, I was hoping it would come with some sort of side
It was good mole but not the best

my girlfirned got the carnitas and it was not was I expected

The  torillas are really great
author: Donald S.

description: definitely the best and very authentic Mexican  restaurant in the bay area, this is not your taco truck this is gourmet Mexican food and the taste is ..wow !  believe me , I know about it, great place, very nice, awesome flavor and variety , maybe louder MEXICAN and not other music would really make you feel in Mexico.
author: Jaime J.

description:
A very solid choice in the Union Square area. We got in for a 6:30 reservation despite our short notice. The service was very friendly throughout, and generally quick despite how busy they were by the time we headed out. Live music was a nice touch and not overly loud. On to the food:

Overall, everything was good quality and quite delicious. The hot, soft tortillas were a very nice touch and a welcome replacement to the usual fried chips. The trio of salsas were all quite good, with even the "spicy" chipotle being very gringo-friendly. I like soft tortillas with just a pinch of salt, so I ate about half of them that way - and they were as good as some I experienced on a trip to rural Yucatan.

Our appetizer was decent - a simple quesadilla with a nice melt of cheese and some poblanos. Fairly basic Americanized Mexican, but well executed.

For main courses, my wife ordered the butterfish special and I ordered the duck en pipian. Both were excellent. We had planned to share them, but I resisted after tasting how good the duck was. I regretted that decision after tasting her butterfish which was perfectly cooked and moist, and drizzled in a wonderful sauce. Thankfully I was able to convince her to stick to the original plan...

We finished with the churros and ice cream, which were quite good as well. Apparently the diners around us agreed since I think that was about the only dessert I saw being served in our immediate table area.
author: Ryan A.

description:
I just had dinner here and thoroughly enjoyed it.

The atmosphere was buzzy and warm and the service was friendly and relaxed. No-one tried to rush us through three courses in an hour.

The food was some of the best I've eaten in months. The guacamole was the best I have ever had.
author: Leo V.

description: Did someone ask for fancy Mexican eating? No? ... well, ok but if you are looking for one, this is a great establishment for that. This place is a skip and a hop away from some other fine establishments, but worth the trek up the hill for it. First, they have a full bar which they also serve a full menu. If you're planning to go, you're probably better off making a reservation. The establishment is pretty big but it's pack almost every night. The tables are tight, but with the high ceilings, it helps keep the level of noise decent...I hate to be yelling in my conversation. I digress ... great Mexican food. My personal favorite was the Vegetarian Chile Rellano. Keep in mind what you order is exactly what you get. If you want to supplement your meal with something (Spanish rice, guacamole) you have to order that separately...oh, and speaking of the guacamole ... delicious. They come in a shallow big bowl ... talk about deception. Nonetheless, I enjoyed myself and recommend everyone to check it out. HAPPY EATING!
author: Rob B.

description: This was a really good Mexican restaurant.  A gem in the touristy section of SF (Union Square.)  Would go again, and would recommend.
author: Julie D.

description: The food was good.  The portions were the right size.  The guacamole was great.  But they didn't prepare it at our table (as the menu described).  The corn tortillas were excellent.  Warm and fluffy, with a nice bite.  However, the service was just OK; not the most attentive.  I liked the tortilla soup, but I suggest they put less cream in it.
author: Warren L.

description: The guacamole and handmade tortillas compliment each other perfectly. They have great service and bartenders. If your in the mood for a spicy fun drink I recommend the Macho Margarita!!
author: Salvador A.

description: I'm a big fan of mexican food and this restaurant has a lot of quality options. The atmosphere is grand and though the place is a bit touristy, it maintains an authentic feel. The chips were mediocre - I like a lot of salt but everything else was really good. I felt the staff was a bit pushy on the specials and other high priced items on the menu but other than that, it was a success!
author: Eliz M.

description: This place is definitely the best Mexican food in the city.  The fresh guac is amazing.
author: Tony K.

description:
Is it sad that when I leave Texas and travel to San Francisco, the first place I head to is a Mexican restaurant?

Not when it's Colibri.  I've never been sad there.  This would easily be one of the best Mexican restaurants in Austin if it were here.

As many have pointed out, the tortillas and guacamole are fantastic.  Another favorite is the shrimp with tamarind mole.  I dream about that mole.  Could eat it all the time.

They also have a very nice selection of tequilas.  That's important to me, a real tequila snob.  The tequila flights are a great idea, too.
author: Ken C.

description: excellent fresh guacamole, ok ambiance, not so good a waiter service and food was very fresh and flavorful.
author: Monica B.

description: While in San Francisco we stayed at the Clift hotel, luckily there was a Mexican place right across the street! We walked into Colibri without any reservations and they were able to seat us right away, even though they seemed somewhat busy. We ordered the guacamole and chips for the table, which they make to order at your table and ask you whether you want it more or less spicy, awesome! We decided to just order a couple dishes and share them for the table, and everything was amazing. From carnitas to fish to chiles to churros, all of it was great! If you're around the area in San Fran definitely go check out Colibri!
author: Brian M.

description: Not sure how this place got such high ratings. We were very tired from all day walking, and opted for something close to our hotel in lieu of a cab ride (many places were closed on Sundays). What a mistake. No atmosphere, high prices, bad margaritas (hello Triple Sec & instant heartburn) and bad food. After spending $15 for carnitas you could get for $7 at an authentic restaurant, they want $5 for a side of rice....which the waitress forgot to put in for us. Totally corporate atmosphere, but not a chain. I'd rather go to a chain, where you know what you're getting. Free corn tortillas prior to dinner with a choice of three bland sauces. Spent $50 for two and would have thought $25 was too much. Skip it.
author: David V.

description: Let me just start off by saying the tables here are way too small. It could barely fit all of the food let alone leave room for me to actually eat. Other than that, everything was okay. The enchiladas with chicken was really good with just the perfect balance of the cheese and chicken. The guacamole had 3 different sauces, but i thought the mild one tasted too fruity. The quesadillas however were a disappointment. When it first came out it still tasted okay, but after about a minute or two the cheese hardened, and it tasted like hardened cheese and cardboard. Definitely do not recommend getting that. All in all, it's an okay place to eat, but i definitely wouldn't be coming back. I'd rather go to chevy's any other day for a whole lot cheaper.
author: Heidi T.

description: I was originally looking for a Thai restaurant in the area, but when I found it, it didn't look too clean, so  I walked around and came across this little gem.  Very good restaurant, great location, ambience, service and food. This is not your typical 'fast food' restaurant. It was packed when I walked in, but happy to find a open seat at the bar.  The bartender was great, he prepared a couple great drinks and food recommendations.  To start, I had the fish tacos - tiny handmade tortillas stuffed with fish and pickled papaya/pineapple - good, but tortillas were a little on the thicker side and for dessert, I had the churros served with dulce the leche ice cream.  Churros were good, thick and doughy (prefer skinny and crunchy), ice cream was good. Overall, I enjoyed the meal, glad I sat at the bar.  Bartender was great, thankful for his suggestions and also, letting me sample one of their best tequilas. Not a tequila person, but glad he persuaded me to try it .. it was great and cannot be compared to the cheaper quality tequilas.
author: Cristina B.

description: A little above average in price, but to be expected considering its location.  That's the only drawback I could see.  Carnitas were excellent, the mole was great, and the guac smooth and creamy, among the best I've ever had!  If I'm ever back in San Francisco, I'm coming back to Colibri.
author: Mike O.

description: This restaurant is really popular and I was excited to try it, but I was really disappointed.  1, the promised guac made right at your table, but it wasn't.  And then when we did get it, it was rather bland; 2, the seating was crowded, I could barely get in and out of my table so close it was to the next; and 3, the mole (one of my favorite dishes in the world) was not interesting... again, I would say bland.  I'm sorry to say that I can't recommend Colibri.
author: Dayna V.

description: This place and Dona Tomas on Telegraph are two of the best nicer mexican restaurants. Food is presented well, tastes great, made with great ingredients. Everything is just delicious. The best part is that the guacamole is made to order at your table. Sure, it's downtown location may make it seem like a tourist trap but it's delicious.
author: Jena D.

description:
Don't go there looking for tacos or burritos.  However, the selection of authentic Mexican dishes is outstanding.  The food was great and so was the service.  As mentioned by several reviewers, the table side custom guacamole preparation results in a fresh tasty treat that could almost be a meal in itself.

We made the mistake of getting there at about 7:15 and the theater crowd was still eating and the place was packed, so the very nice hostess took our reservation for a little later.  By 8:00 the place was nearly empty as almost everyone headed across the street.
author: Rick P.

description:
Diner: Very good and delicious food, courteous staff, romantic atmosphere. The presentation of the food is enjoyable. I think my lady friend called it "cute." The flavors were excellent. Very high quality. Yumm!

The brunch is a great value and very delicious.
author: Ricardo O.

description:
Consistently great food, authentic, reasonably priced, fresh, delicious for both meat and veggie dishes.  Great place to grab a light meal if you are going to a play or taking a break from shopping.  About a block from the Union Square Parking Garage and across the street from two theaters.  Don't forget dessert!!!

My faves here:
Sopes Surtidos (the veggie one is actually my favorite)
Filet Mignon
some kind of delicious chicken
potatoes gratin
white rice- very delicious!!!
dessert- blanco & negro

ENJOY!
author: Sasha E.

description:
Been here several times and always get the guacamole. They make it fresh and you can customize it to your palate. It's a must! Especially b/c they have fresh tortillas. 

The entrees are all great and diverse. We've had the fish, enchilada, chicken mole (I love chocolate), carnitas, etc. Each dish was great. They may try to push rice as a side dish, but we found this gets to be too much food and often unncessary. Maybe the waiters are just trying to make the extra sell.
author: Debbie L.

description:
I travel to SF at least once a month.  The location is close to the Westin St.  Francis and Union Square.  I rate it a 5 due to the quality feel of a "locals" bar and very good authentic Mexican food.  It would be a three on atmosphere which can be noisy and crowded, but that is part of the charm for me.  

Sit at the bar, get a menu and ask Adrian for his signature Cuervo Platino - top shelf margarita.  You will love it!!  I did and actually asked him his name which is unusual in my travels.  If you stay for a bit you might receive a jalepeno tequila shot for your patronage...my first, but surprisingly not too "hot".  Which was fine by me.
author: Jess B.

description:
Stopped in for brunch this morning after seeing 400+ positive reviews here on Yelp.  Overall, disappointed in our choice.

SERVICE:
Overall, poor.  Waiter tried to upsell more expensive brunch items and almost gave us a pitcher of sangria after we requested 2 glasses.  Overall unfriendly attitude from nearly everyone working there.

FOOD:
Ordered the guacamole appetizer (made at the table!) -- it was excellent.  Not the best I've ever had, but very tasty and a good amount.  It comes with small warm tortillas, not chips -- disappointing, but it's an "upscale" place so that's the trade-off.  Requested chips and received a small bowl of them -- for $5.  Sent it back because it was very stale.  Didn't receive another one, but at least they took it off the bill without being reminded.

Tamales Oaxaquena:  Disappointing.  Tasted very doughy, and the mole sauce overwhelmed what little flavor accompanied it.  The texture was awful.

Enchiladas with chicken:  Tiny, with sweet sauce and tart cheese.  Layered with sour cream, which was an unexpected disappointment to an otherwise delightful entree.

Tortilla soup:  Unexceptional.  Supposedly came with chicken, but I counted only two small cubes.  Tasty soup, but not much in it!

Sangria:  Very good!  Sadly, the best part of our meal.

Not recommended.  Overpriced, bad attitude, and only passably good food.  You can do far better.
author: Sam S.

description: Great food! The guac was amazing if you like spicy, get it extra spicy and you wont regret it. The churro and ice cream was a great finish. Service was amazing even on friday night. Booked the reservation on open table and worked out great.
author: Michael L.

description: Wonderful staff, delicious meal, memorable experience. Bravo!
author: Ericka T.

description: Soooo good! I would say I am a Mexican food connoisseur due to it being my favorite food and having lived in Mexico. It's not exactly traditional, but more on the refined side. The tortillas and guacamole are so good that my boyfriend and I went back the next day for margaritas and the tortillas.
author: Schlinds S.

description: If you like bad food for high prices and horrible table service ... then look no further. I was really looking forward to this place (went on line, studied the menu, etc.) but this place is a disaster zone and is not the high end comida Mexicana that I expected.( I have been to Mexico many times, to Michoacan, Morelos, etc., not to the border towns or Acapulco, etc. ) Someone mentioned the spotty service ...I would go further ... the staff were running around like chickens with their heads cut off. I had the chili relleno but it was quite tasteless. Also, each dish came with that ridiculous old "Spanish rice" ... to fill up the plate, to disguise the small portions. Better to find a taco-truck south of Market.
author: Don S.

description: We stumbled upon this place as we were walking trying to find a place to eat. They had no availability for that night (friday night) but based on the yelp reviews we decided to make reservations for Sunday night. Good thing we did, this place was cool! Too bad i was soo tired from the weekend that I didn't really get to enjoy the atmosphere or have a drink. The guacamole was amazing!!!! The flour tortillas that come with it were perfect! But $5 extra for chips?? come on! Anyways, I had the Cordero (lamb) and it was yummy! Perfect portion for me! My husband had the Carnitas and he loved it too! I do see what some reviews say about the smaller than expected portions and the small "tapas portions" on the menu but luckily we weren't that starving to leave still hungry after our meal. It was a perfect portion. A bit expensive though but whatever lol i think it was worth it.
author: Jimena V.

description: Loved the fresh guacamole and margaritas... Nice atmosphere. Great place to chill out after shopping at Union Sq.
author: Heidi L.

description: Just awesome. The macho margarita is very spicy and very good. Queso fundido, tortillas and the salsa trio are a great start. Terrific carnitas. I can't wait to go back.
author: Ryan T.

description: Very different type of mexican food. Lamb shank, stuffed chicken breast, and the guacamole dip are over rated delicious. It is a must eat place in downtown San Francisco.
author: Motaz H.

description: This restaurant was a true disappointment. The "salsa" sauce served with the soft tortillas was not terribly flavorful. We ordered the guacamole, and they neglected to prepare it at the table ($12). The chips with the guacamole were all overcooked and stuck together. The chips actually cost extra, over and above the a la carte guacamole. I had the shrimp and mole sauce entree: five small shrimps and a small cornbread cake -- you must be kidding.  How chintzy is that?  My wife and daughter had the chile relleno; it was mushy and bland. Not only was the food not very good or plentiful, but it was seriously overpriced.  I would give this Mexican restaurant a miss.
author: Bruce W.

description: I always forget about Colibri, but I think it's because whenever I go it's too crowded and I don't want to wait around or I'm too mad at myself that I forgot to call ahead. They do have THE best guacamole, which is a pity to miss out on. I'm also not a huge fan of black beans, but at Colibri, they are really good. Everything I've ever eaten has been fabulous, so you can't really go wrong. The atmosphere is cozy and the staff are are kick-ass. It's definitely a fav!
author: Gina G.

description:
I love Mexican, especially the classical kind (deep fried tacos are good too) and colibri is awesome.  We love the homemade guacamole (almost as good as ours.) Then the appetizers were outstanding - the tacos were unbelievable, the salads were excellent (especially the jicama based one.)  The main dishes were great: chicken with sauce was awesome, the scallops were very tasty, the chili relleno was to die for (almost as good as Bobby Fley's!) the tortilla soup was wonderful.  But the highlight was the sangria (yes, they have an incredible selection of tequilas and I'm a great fan of it and they look awesome.) The sangria was sweet, red, fruity and pulpy.  It was great.  But wait! The best is yet to come: the desserts.  We had the tres leches cake - to die for, I love tres leches cake and they had one of the best renditions I've ever had.  Then, then, we had an even better dessert: the Churros with ice cream (and stuffed with caramel.). Oh my God!  Incredible!

The ambiance is Mexican/Spanish kitschy old paintings and mermaid sconces, well worn tables, crowded, loud and what appears to be an awesome bar.  The service is good, but a little harried - but the food makes up for it.  I can't wait to go back!
author: mike r.

description: Mexican food doesn't get any better than this. My husband and I celebrated our three year anniversary here and the food and service did not disappoint. We arrived early and was seated almost immediately. Once seated our waitress arrived and started taking our drinks and appetizer menu. The service was so fast and very professional. You never felt rushed at all but they always had an eye at your table just in case you needed anything. The food was heaven sent. You must try their guacamole made table side with the freshest ingredients. I enjoyed their filet mignon cooked to perfection while my husband had their mole dish. Finally, their churros were to die for. Inside the churros was this yummy caramel with a side of vanilla bean ice cream. We will definitely be back soon!!
author: B P.

description:
oh yelp mobil, you've saved my ass once more. a friend and i were staying in "nob hill" aka the tender nob for a quick weekend visit. we took a wrong turn and somehow ended up at the front steps of a meth clinic, a few more wrong turns and we ended up in the middle of Union Square. hungry and a bit rattled by the junkies asking us for a score i whipped out my phone and yelped restaurants in the area. Colibri popped up and we were literally two blocks away. 

I love serendipitous culinary experiences aided by yelp. we sat down, tired, weary and starving. we ordered tortilla soup to start. let me tell you, i love me some tortilla soup, and this was by far the best i've ever had. the drinks were great too, cant remember exactly what specialty margarita i had, but it was super good and super strong, so strong in fact that the details of the actual dinner are a bit fuzzy as i cant remember exactly what i had, but i remember it being of a delicious nature. 

the service was lovely and we made friends with the girls at the next table, turns out we were all from the same hometown. small world! so yes. highly recommend this place, and seriously yelp mobil, you are my god now.
author: Amanda H.

description: I absolutely love this place as one of my favorite places to eat in the city! Take note that it is expensive and I am sure there are about a thousand other mexican restaurants in SF to eat at for less. This place stands alone at the top of the heap for it's fresh and delicious, made to order, guacamole! You can specify how much heat you want in it as well as extra lime and cilantro! Then you dig into it with a chip and realize it is exactly as yummy as it looks! But that's not the best part. They bring "hot off the grill" housemade corn tortillas to eat with it.  You can make a meal of that alone although I always end up ordering more. I recommend the chile rellano and they also have excellent salads. The cocktails are creative and delicious. I have tried several as well as the house margarita.  I like a cocktail to be big and boozy which they could do better on.  Service has always been efficient and friendly each and every time that I have been there. I like to take out of town friends there because I know they will be impressed and leave satisfied!
author: Sage K.

description: The food was delicious, but the tables are small, hard to hold all the dishes and especially the guacamole.  Very noisy and cramped.
author: Peggy V.

description: Haven't been here for a while, but I think about it all the time!  Never had filet mignon in a bed of mole.  TO DIE FOR!  Going back soon!
author: Michelle V.

description: Its hard to find high-end Mexican food (not an oxymoron) in SF   This is one place that does it well.    I mistakenly made a reservation 2 hours earlier than expected.   The hostess accomodated us quickly even though the restaurant was pretty full.    Everything from the quality of the guacamole to the special sauces to dip the hand-made tortillas in were top notch.   The filet-mignon was fantastic.
author: Fred X.

description:
1. Making Reservation/Atmosphere:
  Made a reservation using the online reservation system "Open Table"  on Saturday 11/3 for a 4:30pm dinner on Sunday 11/4 .  The tables had a pretty quick turn over rate to make the restaurant feel busy but not crowded.  This restaurant is small in square footage leaving each table with a chair on one side and just enough space to squeeze sideways into your booth seat on the opposing side. 
2. Service:
  Server was able to find out if a dish was gluten/dairy free. He was polite but not personal or congenial and he also brought us the wrong bill at the end of our meal.    
3.  Food:  
     A.  "Camarones en Mole de Tamarindo" $17:  The taste was flavorful and pleasing.  Unfortunately there were only 5 breaded shrimp and a corn muffin on this platter.  Don't order this entree without a side dish if you are hungry.     
     B.  "Chamorro de Cordero" $22:  The mole sauce was hearty and flavorful while the lamb melted right off the bone. The lamb was placed on top of a banana leaf and was the only item on this platter to my disappointment but it was big enough to satiate my appetite (which is not demure and not huge but healthy).  Make sure to order a side dish along with your entree if you want flavor variation and or a more nutritious meal. The server did not suggest a side dish. I was told this dish was gluten/ dairy free. I believe this to be true because right after eating I was able to comfortably sit through a showing of the "Lion King"(about 2.5 hrs long) without feeling any stomach irritation.  
4.  Price:
     Don't expect to get the best bang for your buck here.  It is in a convenient location to places like Union Square and the near by Orpheum Theater so meal prices are jacked up.
author: Karen Lynne M.

description:
I really like the ambiance here. I've come here on several occasions and it's pretty busy sometimes in the small waiting/standing area they have. But sometimes, the better bet is just to sit at the bar which is first come first serve. 

My friend and I came for drinks and their guacamole. Unfortunately, when you sit at the bar, they don't make the guacamole in front of you, which we found out after the fact. I had a glass of sangria and it was awesome! Good portion and price too!

Guacamole is more than enough for two people to share! I would highly recommend the Mole Poblano (choc over chicken) and their fish of the day. Will be back and be back to their Santana Row location as well!
author: Linda C.

description: Colibri is not worth the time it takes and the money it costs to eat here. The food is okay in taste and quality, but it is grossly overpriced.
author: Kelly M.

description:
We ordered guacamole to start and the Pato en Mole Verde Pipian (substituted the duck with chicken) and the Mole Poblano for our meals. The guac was great and the warm tortillas were delicious! 

Unfortunately, the rest of the meal was very disappointing. The dishes arrived with two halves of a chicken breast and a chicken leg(?) with the sauces poured over them. The Pato/Pollo en Mole Verde had some vegetables (steamed carrots and beans) with it but the Mole Poblano came by itself -- no rice on either dish. To put it simply, the chicken tasted and felt like it had been microwaved. It was tough, dry and chewy and just completely ruined the, otherwise tasty, sauces. 

When the waiter asked us how it was (neither of us came close to finishing our meals), we told him about our chicken. After apologizing, he came back with the bill and told us that both of our meals had been (and we weren't expecting this) comped (meaning we were only charged for drinks and guac). 

The service was good -- fast, attentive, friendly -- but the food was a serious disappointment.
author: s m c.

description: I ate hear for Dine about town.  I shared some carne asada and some pork thing and a tortilla soup. I didn't really like the tortilla soup at all but it could just be that I don't like tortilla soup all together. The food was okay, nothing spectacular but it wasn't bad either. The churros were delicious though. I'd go back just for that. It'd be a nice place to chill and drink with their huge selection of tequila, but I thought the food was too pricy even with Dine About Town.
author: andy n.

description: New Years Day (2010) and I needed a bottomless mimosa and they had it. I would suggest to sit at the bar so the drinks keep flowing. The bartender  " jimmy" was great, love this guy. On to the food: I had the pork ( they came in big hunks of meat you have to cut up- it needed a bit more flavor, but good). The other person had the Eggs Benedict and said the flavors was great. The staff was full of life specially David the server so  funny !!! Overall good place the people make it better!!!
author: Brandi R.

description: fancy mexican food..great taste.
author: Sage W.

description:
really greasy potatoe gratin and i asked for light cheese.  i could of filled a shot glass with all of the oil.  salad was drenched in oil too.  joy.  

where is the staff? 

 i want the check.  oh, there you guys are, reading.  strange.  sunday lunch was just OK.  guacamole was good.  place needs a good cleaning.  gordon ramsay has ruined me.
author: Noel J.

description:
3.5 stars.  I really enjoyed the guacamole prepared at your table - I like it served with tortillas rather than chips - it's a little more unique and puts more focus on the guacamole itself.  I ordered that lamb shank and thought it was very good.  Pretty good margaritas too.  

The atmosphere was a little unimpressive, but I suppose it's not the restaurant's fault that tourists love it.  Also, prices were on the high side.
author: Luke P.

description: Wayyy overpriced for what you get.  We ordered several dishes and there was no flavor, no heat, no nothin'.  My white boyfriend cooks up better Mexican food than this joint (thanks to Rick Bayless).  The margaritas, however, were delicious.
author: Victoria G.

description:
i'm officially a regular here now....i can't stay away. fabulous food in mexican bistro style. this, combined with their amazing margaritas, its simply addicting. no, they don't serve "chips and salsa" or serve their entrees with beans and rice... if you ask for this, you might get a snide look. the best part about this place is Kalfani!!! he is one of the BEST bartenders in the city.... in fact, forego eating at a table and eat at the bar for a better dining experience. Kalfani will make you a mean margarita, serve you a $150 shot in a champagne glass and then slip you a prickly pear "taster" with cayenne pepper lightly salted on the rim...... you'll definitely need all this alcohol to cool your mouth after the extra hot guacamole and 3 different salsas they serve with their warm tortillas. for dinner, i've been so tempted to try other things, but i just can't. i always get the carnitas. i have never had carnitas this good anywhere else in SF.... if you haven't been to Colibri yet, you have no idea what you're missing. well done guys, well done.

PS: and extra points for the night i was waiting at the bar and some guy turned to me and asked, "are you michelle i from yelp?" haha, a truly funny moment. thanks Phil H!
author: Michelle I.

description: I found this place on opentable.com, but didn't do my usual Yelpstigation before booking it for a brunch. It wasn't terrible by any means, but I just was not blown away by the food nor the service. I spent most of the time racking my brain trying to remember what the space USED to be, as I knew I'd been in there before. I finally figured out it was the old Union Square CPK. Anyway, the wooden bar is exquisitely beautiful, but what does that tell you when this review is supposed to be about their food?
author: Gregor G.

description: I used to go here pretty often for business lunches at my old job.  The service is always great and I agree with everyone else, the ritas are to die for! We always get the guacamole SPICY.  I love how they make it right at table for you.  That always adds a nice touch.  The entrees are so so, but I really love the guac and the tortilla soup! Yum.
author: Jenny W.

description: I find that there are some folks on Yelp who tend to review more often when things are negative, I tend to review places more readily when things are positive.  That said...I had a knock your socks off pre-birthday dinner here at Colibri.  Their mojitos were fab and got me primed for a night of cocktail indulgence.  We enjoyed their guac and nopales to start and I had the pan seared scallops served over a potato-corn purée.  Scrumptious!  They of course brought me the obligatory candle adorned dessert, which was delish.  Very nice atmosphere at Colibri and definitely a good spot for a date.
author: Steph P.

description:
chips and salsa!!!... i'm a simple guy. i don't ask for much, but when i'm having mexican food, i must have unlimited supply of chips and salsa. that's not too much to ask, is it? 

well, it is if you happen to be at colibri. you see, after $140 later, the girlfriend and i are wholly unsatisfied with our experience at colibri because they do not serve chips and salsa. instead, they serve you tortilla and salsa.

colibri, how authentic of you to serve tortilla and salsa, but can i also have the chips and salsa option? i mean, after all, my girlfriend and i spent $140 on food and drinks that we feel are inferior and bland to the other fancy mexican restaurant in town - maya. yes, your interior is nicely decorated. it's all warm and rich and classy, but damn it, i want my chips and salsa! so what do you say? will you in the future?

oh, colibri, by the way, did you know when i left to use the restroom, your guacamole "chef" was trying to hit on my girlfriend. 

"hey, how you like my guacamole? you likey?" wink. wink. 

what?!?!?! of course, she told me about the encounter after we got home. classy, colibri. really classy. 

so in conclusion, as you can tell, we were completely underwhelmed and annoyed by the colibri experience. we'll take papalote or velvet cantina any day over colibri.........and they serve beautiful chips and salsa!
author: frisco j.

description: Guacamole, Chile Rellenos and Ensalada Flor de Verano (butter lettuce, mango, avocado, flower petals and jícama with a cilantro-basil vinaigrette) were all delicious. Service was quick and efficient, exactly what we needed because we getting dinner before attending a play. We're definitely going back to this place to try out their other offerings.
author: Wendy L.

description: Great atmosphere, excellent tequila selection, excellent traditional mexican dishes.  The chicken in the mole poblano was soooo tender!  The sole special was incredible.  Wait staff obliged our requestfor sides of plaintains and yucca even though they're not on the menu.  Great little spot.
author: Patrick M.

description: In my opinion this restaurant is a duplicate of Consuelo's @ Santana Row, but a tad better.  We shared the sopes, chx breast relleno - both good, carnitas which I thought was ok, and cornbread.  I also had the blackberry margarita which was so delicious - I'd highly recommend.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Does my ass look huge in this restaurant?  Why yes, yes it does.  Colibri seems like a go-to restaurant for the pre-theater crowds that it was quite hoppin when I got there at a little before 7pm.  We got seated in about 20 minutes at the two-top in a row of tables at the banquette.  And.  Well.  Um.    I was mortified when my fat ass made friends with the upper arm of the dude at the table next to ours because the seating is so close together to maximize the burst of business before 8pm.  After 8pm, everything calmed down and it became less likely that my ass would rub up on anyone who didn't ask.

The food was satisfactory for the most part, maybe it's better when you go at off-peak hours.  I think the best thing is the hot, handmade tortillas that come with three different salsas at the beginning of the meal.  I wanted to ask if I can take a huge stack of them home, but we made do with a small stack of seconds with our entree.  We got the ceviche which was okay--it didn't elicit the "aaahhh, refreshing!" response I expect from fresh seafood and citrus because some of the fish pieces had a styrofoam-like texture.  For entrees, we ordered the chicken mole and the duck with the pumpkin seed sauce.  The mole sauce was lush, rich, and quintessentially mole-like in a perfect way, but the chicken itself was definitely underseasoned, which was a shame because the dish could've been a winner.  The duck included both the breast meat seared medium and the leg as a confit.  While the leg meat was good, the breast was a minor disaster.  The sliced meat looked dry (and was dry), as if the dish sat on the pass for a long time waiting to be taken to the table, and the skin wasn't rendered enough and had a rubbery texture.  While the prospect of a pumpkin seed sauce was enticing, in practice, it didn't have the richness or the toasty flavor I had hoped for.

At the suggestion of our server, we also ordered a side dish of potato gratin infused with poblano chiles.  This was a winner.  It sounded like it could potentially be a pedestrian fusion experiment, like an item at TGI Fridays, but the poblano flavor really came through all the cream and the cheese.  Just make sure to avert your eyes after you eat all of it because the pool of grease at the bottom is disheartening....if "disheartening" also means your heart is on the verge of malfunction due to arterial blockage.  Similarly at the suggestion of the server, we split the crepes with cajeta and ice cream.  This, too, was something that I enjoyed because I am a huge fan of dulce de leche/cajeta (I don't know enough about Mexican cuisine to know the difference, but I love them both!).  The longer the crepes sat, the more it became one with the cajeta, creating this eggy-caramely mush.  It's a mush, yes, but a noble one.  Honestly, I really wanted to ask for the handmade tortillas to sop up the cajeta, but that would've gone straight to my caboose and  I would not be able to make a graceful exit to redeem myself.
author: maiko h.

description: Fresh, tasty, traditional dishes with quality turned up and attention to presentation.  Looking over the drink menu I spied some tequilas listed with hefty prices next to them and thought perhaps these were small bottles of premium liquor that could be purchased for the table, so I asked our server about them.  Not a bottle.  Oh no.  That 35-100 bucks buys a SHOT.  Luckily the sangria is mighty fine and quite affordable as are the specialty cocktails.
author: L W.

description: Extra yummy, definitely tastier than the other candidate for fancy-pants Mexican, Maya. The guacamole prepared table-side was most excellent and the cornmeal torte was full of flavor and unexpected. The interior though. Pottery Barn does faux Spanish New World Colonial? More than a bit self-conscious in a Holiday Inn trying to be upscale sort of way.
author: patrick g.

description:
This was the first place at which I became a "regular" when I moved to the city a year ago. Sadly, my little hole-in-the-wall became very popular, very quickly and it became a little difficult even for me to get a table (damn you ALL!). I've put off doing a review, hoping not to add to the celebration of the place, hoping that the crowds would die down, but that's clearly not going to happen any time soon, so, here it goes.
I lived in Mexico City for two years and with Mexicans from all parts of the country for 9+ and from my hate-ridden experiences with Mexican cuisine I learned to expect overly done meats, roughly boiled beans, nausea-inducing corn tortillas and zero depth of flavor all topped by raw onion, raw cilantro, pickled green chiles and the ubiquitous lime and salt; truly heinous. Colibri, however, taught me that Mexican food can not only be good, but can be some of the best, most interesting food that I've tasted. All of the menu is good, but highlights include the Halibut, the Potatos au Gratin, the Stuffed Chicken and the Zucchini. Oh, yeah, and the tortillas... soo good.
I've heard the criticism that the portions are small, but that I really don't understand. I'm a big eater and I've always left stuffed. Just keep asking for more tortillas to sop up those delicious sauces. All in all Colibri is one of my favorite casual places to eat in the city so far.

======================================================

Edited 12Oct

Colibri used to offer a discount to employees of my company. Yesterday I was told "no mas". I certainly do not expect a discount every time that I go out, but why offer it for so long and then take it away? Yes, y'all are a popular business now, but please don't spit in the face of guests who dined with you when you were an upstart. Minus 1 star for avarice.
author: Daniel W.

description: I'm not sure how I feel about Colibri yet..Eating off Rachel C. and Gwynnie's plates was delicious, and when Siamak S. picked up the bill the second time I went, that was great, too.... If I have to pay the next time it may be another story.
author: Jason R.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!  one of my all time favorites.  I've been here for lunch, happy hour, and dinner and I've enjoyed every moment.  Good eats, good atmosphere, good alcohol.  Best food to try would be the Guacamole, Quesadillas, Carnitas, Brocheta de Filete, and of course Sangria!  This place can get crowded on Friday nights and weekends, so be prepared.  My only objections are size of the restaurant (limits the number of large party reservations) and pricing.  It is tapas style, so don't expect large portions, and know to share.  The service is so-so: sometimes excellent, other times mediocre.  Other then that, I'm always down to go back.
author: Gail L.

description: The guac is amazing, and I really liked all the small veggie-friendly dishes. Don't pass on the margaritas- I had a blackberry one, and it made my day.
author: Bee H.

description:
as one of the first few "authentic" mexican places i've tried, colibri mexican bistro made a decent first impression. guacamole prepared fresh, nice! having to spoon it onto a soft tortilla instead of scooping it up with a tortilla chip, took some getting used to.

entrees were fine but i think i was concentrating on the table conversation more.

and although the meal was pretty filling, we decided to include a dessert. the crepas con cajeta with vanilla ice cream sounded good, so we got that. and it was pretty good. not too sweet, not too heavy. just right. fun pre-theater dinner.
author: spiff e.

description: Great place.  Not too loud so you can have a decent conversation and a comfortable atmosphere.   Totally on the recommend list.  But if you're ordering a martini and don't want olives, make sure you repeat yourself 3 times.
author: Tim M.

description: Delicious, original, interesting Mexican cuisine. Pleasant, timely service. Excellent margaritas and wine list. A little noisy, no space to wait for a table. Loved it, will definitely go back, especially before a show at ACT or the Curran.
author: Jo Ann S.

description: Move over Platinos & Maya, there's something yummier!  I know it's a bold statement, but I think Colibri is the best gourmet latin american food I've had in san francisco. The guacamole was beyond the beyonds, and they serve it with an endless supply of soft round tortillas, tucked into a cloth pouch to keep them toasty warm throughout your meal. The fish of the day and the chicken were wonderfully tender and came with delicious vegatables in creamy, slightly spicy sauces - just talking about it makes me want to eat it again!  The place is very pretty, if a bit loud.  Don't be fooled by the "tapas" instruction the waiter will give you - we ordered one appi (the guac, of course), two "medium" plates and two sides and we were swimming in food.  If the food hadn't sealed the deal on the five stars, the sangria would have.
author: Debbie A.

description:
Colibri Mexican Bistro is in the heart of the theatre district.  Colibri, "Hummingbird" uses only the freshest quality produce, and the most authentic recipes.  Colibri is in a true cantina setting and once you are indoors you truly feel as though you have traveled to another land!  The food is fantastic and the margaritas are next to godliness!  The staff was extremely attentive as well as knowledable....the bartender even gave me a lesson on tequila!!!  (they have an enormous selection of tequila...) I enjoyed a Pink Cadillac, El Tesoro Resposado sour mix, splash of cranberryjuice, a float of Grand Marnier, served on the rocks while munching on chips and guacamole.  The guacomole is made fresh to order at each table!!!!  Delicious!  For dinner I ordered Pechuga Ranchera: tender chicken breast smothered in a creamy guajillo chili sauce, over mashed potatoes with sauteed spinach.  And for dessert.....I had another margarita!!  (heheheeheh) this time I ordered a Margarita Con Fruta, Flavored margarita with fresh fruit muddled in a glass, lime juice and sugar and 100% Blue Agave Cabrito Tequila.  
Colibri is a dynamite restaurant that does not mess around....I love it and cant wait to go back!  One of my new (old) favorites....It had been so long, I forgot how good it was! YUM

............................
also, don't forget about bruch here on Sat & Sundays.....just went and had an excellent brunch and washed it down with Cantaloupe Agua Fresca.
Yumm Yumm
author: Michele K.

description: I liked this place. My first encounter with them I thought they were snooty and annoying. We ended up not eating there. But the second time I had reservations, and it wasn't Saturday night, so everything was way more pleasant for all parties involved. I thought the service was friendly and the food superb. I like them making the guacamole at the table. You know it's fresh!
author: Cris L.

description:
One of my fav restaurants in the city!
Always consistently good with friendly service. It's warm, inviting place that makes killer margaritas and mojitos. The food is upscale mexican - try the mole.
author: Gwen H.

description: I absolutely LOVE the guacomole they serve here. This is the BEST mexican restaurant in the area. I absolutely love the mojitos here. All I need is some guac and mojitos here and im a happy chick. Oh, the dessert is good too. I forgot the name of the dessert but its the one with the ice cream on it. Ask the waiter, im sure they can recommend a good one.
author: Bren L.

description: I love this place their handmade guacamole and margaritas are to die for! I would highly recommend it!
author: Evgenia V.

description:
If you take the wine list out of my hand and then take TWENTY minutes to bring me a drink while my food gets cold, I will not be a happy girl.
...Regardless of how delicious your guacamole is.


(Around $50 for 2 drinks, an appetizer and 2 plates at brunch.)
author: A W.

description: This place is great.  The guacamole was delicious and I loved how it is served with warm tortillias instead of chips.  Everything is meant to be shared, but I guess you could eat your own plate as well.  The chile rellenos were not the traditional deep friend bundles of joy I expected, but were good nonetheless.  Lots of flavor, less fat.  The carnitas was delicious served to reflect warm butter melting in your mouth.  YUM!  And the chicken was yum.  The carnitas and guacamole were really spectacular.  I would definitely go back for those two and a Margarita Milagro.
author: Justine D.

description: Good.... the guacamole, the margaritas and the service.  Bad.... the other items we had were not that flavorful. And it's a bit pricy.
author: Michelle S.

description: We went to Colibri last night prior to going to Jersey Boys at the Curran. We made reservations online, which made it easy. Got seated immediately. Luisa recommended the blackberry margarita, which was excellent.  Medium-spicy guacamole had perfect texture and seasonings. We ordered scallops, lamb, au gratin potatoes.  All were excellent, along with a bottle of Bernardus pinot noir.  More than adequate portions. Luisa, here's your review!  You did great!
author: Tim C.

description: I stopped in here on a Sunday evening with my friend looking for a glass of wine and something little to eat. We sat at the bar. The bartender was very nice and not pushy. We ended up with a bottle of Spanish wine and a portion of the guacamole, which comes with some amazing tortillas and 3 types of salsa. All in all, I enjoyed myself and the food a lot. This is definitely a place to remember.
author: Veronica W.

description: I came here with a friend for margarita's and chips/tortilla's and salsa..I was impressed by the fresh tortillas ...the drinks were alright.  I did not order any food off the menu, and may try it out in the future due to the great reviews I've read, but I never have paid $12 for a margarita in my life...and don't ever plan to again any time soon.  I came here for just a few drinks...and chips and salsa.  And ended up spending way more than I intended.  The ambiance is great, the service was wonderful....maybe just alittle over priced.  Seating was not a problem, no wait at all just as most of the other reviews pointed out, and I honestly think that is due to their overpriced drinks.
author: Charla M.

description:
small plates of fancy food.
tequila list a mile long.

one of the times i went there was a live band playing - which is kind of a nice idea, but it's not really a big enough restaurant for that kind of deal.
author: dave w.

description: YUM yum Yummy yumster yummy in my tummy. upscale mexican food is pretty commin in the Bay area, and it can go horribly wrong. luckily, Colibri gets it right, with ambiance, good service, excellent drinks, and of course, amazing flavorful food. i always leave happy!
author: Natasha F.

description: I went here with some friends, before hitting a club, and it was the perfect start to the night. It reminds me of Consuelo's at Santana Row...and they're affiliated, I believe. At Consuelo's,  I usually get a pitcher of sangria and an order of guacamole. At Colibri, we got the same thing, plus some random dishes that were good but are forgettable. Great place to eat, drink and be merry with good friends!
author: Mary T.

description: The guacamole alone is enough reason to go. The taste of fresh made-to-order is just.. unf. *Unf* I say!  I get a chill up my back just thinking about it.
author: Jordan M.

description: Pretty good upscale Mexican food, though a bit expensive as everything is ala carte.
author: Randy C.

description: The high tourist factor makes it feel a bit like a rich people's Chevy's, I'm not gonna lie. But when you catch it at the right time (lunch is better) it's fresh, "authentic" buen sabor with tasty mexi-cocktails and spanish colonial decor that makes you want to get naked and swing from cast iron scrollwork. Or something.
author: Megan W.

description: Good guacamole, bland carnitas, overpriced entrees, and the worst service I've had in years.  While I enjoyed a few aspects of this dinner (the Papas al Gratin were very tasty) the service (which could've been an anomaly) was inexcusable.  In all seriousness, we saw our waitress 3-times in 2-hours.  This place might be great if it was in another part of the city.
author: Ryan P.

description: I've been here probably half a dozen times and it's been great every time except the last time I came to Colibri.  They have amazing drinks, a beautiful space, and great mole sauce.  They also do amazing things with cauliflower (never would have guessed...)!  I recommend it but probably won't be back for a while because I was disappointed in my last experience.
author: Alyssa W.

description: Really excellent food - carnitas was out of this world - great Tequila selection
author: Andrew M.

description: Great food. Fresh table side guacamole made table side to your perference.  Nice strong cocktails. One of the few places where I can get a caipirinha and a good one at that. The yummy ceviche and the steak....unbelievably good.   A nice hot Mayan chocolate to end the night.  Can't ask for anything more.  Service was prompt and professional.
author: Chris C.

description: Where it not for the tragic lack of consistency, I would grant this place a Fiver.  When I've been there, the food was simply amazing.  Guac at your table, delicious, moist, and flaky fish in a homegrown tortilla that's got more flavor than the salsa, carnitas that are basically THE BEST, a fun and entertaining staff, and live music.  For upscale Mexican, it doesn't get any better... well, that is if you come on the right night.  From what I hear, coming here is a dice roll.  Too bad. 3.5 ... rounding up cuz it's Friday.
author: Calvin N.

description: Correction 3.5 stars. We wandered down to the square on a Sunday to grab lunch and thought that this place sounded yummy. The food was good, but I felt a little guilty and hungry after a $120 lunch on a Sunday afternoon. Just because your portions are minimal as can be, does not mean they are tapas. The price tag was certainly not tapas, nor the need to buy a side separately. Marg was decent, but mostly ice. Guac was yummy and I loved how they just bring you fresh tortillas to eat witht hem. The pozole was way undercooked, the carnitas were great, more than 3 bites would have been fabulous. Do not misrep tapas! I know they have high rent and it is a tourist trap, but it was still a bit shocking! I guess I better shut up and get to the Mission.
author: Cassie C.

description: The Filet Mignon was superb. The cactus dish was intriguing and succulent. Bravo to the hundreds of tequilas on the menu, the open, airy cafe atmosphere, and the service was quick, responsive, and made some excellent suggestions. I recommend, along with any on here, to get the guacamole made at your table, it's entertaining and delicious! We went in at 7:00 on a Wednesday night and were seated immediately.
author: Braden B.

description: I wish I ate here, but these 5 stars are based on the great drinks and warm ambiance. I'm not sure who was charming whom, but the bartender was doling out seriously strong margaritas last night in this lovely space. I promise to go back and see if the food is just as enjoyable!
author: Gretchen T.

description: Went there for dinner last night. Tried to make a reservation for four but it was booked. We put our name in anyway and sat at the bar. The hostess hooked us up and got us a table a few minutes later! Shrimp and mole was outstanding however, the best part of the dinner was the Mango Creme Brulee! Walked out stuffed and happy. Super service, great attitude from everyone.
author: Discourser T.

description: Decent food, but EXTREMELY over priced. With such amazing Mexican food in SF I am disappointed I spent a meal here
author: Hudson H.

description:
The Juevos Rancheros are savory and full of flavor.  The arrangement of egg, sauce, and tortilla on the plate beautifully accents the way the flavors and textures of each compliment the others. These are an homage to Juevos Rancheros, clearly conceived by someone who loves the dish with an adoration sufficient to elevate it to gourmet subtlety.  The presentation is also artful and visually impressive.

If you like spicy food I recommend ordering the Guacamole made with Habanero peppers.  This is fresh guac, made tableside, and served with fresh from the oven flour tortillas and three sauces, one red, one yellow, and one green.  Unfortunately they don't offer corn tortillas, but the flour ones are great.

The coffee is somewhere between McDonalds and Starbucks quality and is served in a cup so tiny that it goes cold seemingly seconds after it has cooled to a drinkable temperature.  I had some trouble getting refills/warmups on coffee... Needless to say, hot coffee tastes incredible with the Juevos Rancheros, so it's worth the slight hassle in spite of the $2.50 charged per cup.

Enjoy.
author: Matt M.

description:
colibri was so on the mark last night.. and i thought there weren't many good restaurants downtown!

the guacamole was freshly made at the table, and even though i was full from the jicama salad and the guacamole and the free tortillas (hot and steaming and oh so good!), i couldn't stop eating the pisole. 

the best part was the mole. the last time i had mole sauce, i didn't like how bitter it was. it reminded me of a burnt flavor. the mole sauce last night was incredible -- you could taste the slight tinge of bitterness from chocolate, but also a wealth of flavors i couldn't even name.

great margharitas and awesome, awesome service.
author: monkey l.

description:
+ atmosphere, food, staff.  the manager, hannah, is truly amazing.  she goes out of her way to make sure each table is happy, stopping by more than once on her rounds and helping to bring out food.  

- not too many vegetarian options, but mexico offers even fewer...
author: pete c.

description: Cute Mexican place with ample seating and a fully stocked bar.  The food was fresh and had the right amount of spices and flavors, complementing the entire dining experience.  Service was great, and the guacamole was really tasty.  Food is served tapas style, so it is wise to order several plates and share with your friend(s).  There is also an open kitchen so you can see how everything is made.
author: Megha S.

description:
The service at this restaurant was terrible.  We had a going away party for my friend there--it was middle of the week.  I arrived late--all of the staff were sitting at the back of the restaurant talking.  The restaurant was pretty much empty with the exception of the eight of us for my friend's party.  No one came to the table to even ask me if I wanted something to drink.  I would have ordered something off the menu except no one came to ask me if I wanted anything.  
 Since my friends had already ordered they said they had plenty and I just ate from what everyone else had left over.  I was finally able to pull someone over to ask for a Margarita and some silverware.  The food was good although a bit on the salty side.  Considering the service though, I don't think I would go back.  Had it been a Saturday and busy I might have understood but with that many staff and not one person to offer help--that to me speaks volumes about how they view their customers.
author: Alisa D.

description:
It was a cool June evening and I had only just arrived in San Francisco the day before.  I knew that my time was limited in this town so I was hoping to enjoy a culinary moment that would stay with me for years to come.  After all, who knows when I would ever return?  I did my due diligence and saw an interesting pattern developing around Colibri Mexican Bistro on various websites. Could all of these reviews be true?  Impossible, I thought.
