At approximately 7pm I endeavored to make the short walk from my downtown hotel to taste and see if the reviews of Calibri were credible.

     The restaurant was busy with a cultural plethora of happy customers basking in the old world Latin charm that colored the dining room,  as a contemporary,  Latin duo massaged the air with their soothing, soulful tunes.  Clearly, the only remedy for my skepticism would be a margarita.  So I bellied up to the bar and asked the bartender to mix me the margarita he would drink if he were opposite himself at that moment.  His flair was only eclipsed by his gracious pour.  "Salt?" he asked.  "Of course." A subtle, yet sturdy concoction awaited my lips.  From the moment my tongue felt the bitter sting preceding her sour, then sweet charm, she had my attention.  She was indeed magnificent.  By the time I ordered my second dose of bliss, I nearly forgot about dinner.  I wasn't really hungry, but the Mole Poblano had garnered such rave reviews that I felt a bit more than compelled to order it, though I had no f*&king idea what it was.  Within fifteen minutes I would have the chance to find out.

     The bartender laid out a stack of small corn tortillas along with three different sauces.  Was this what I ordered?  I should just be patient to see if there would be a main act to this side show.  Soon he presented a plate of chicken drenched in a dark brown sauce.   My knife cut through the tender pile of white meat like a mermaids fin slices through the ocean on her journey to Neptune to spawn.  Her magical, fiery flavors seduced me into submission.  I would kill to taste her again; for once I was convicted and sentenced to death, she would be the last meal I requested.  I felt like I was having an affair.  I couldn't even look up.  Was it even appropriate to feel this good in such a public place?  I was embarrassed, but like a shamed addict, I had to inject another bite into my system.  "I love you," I whispered, as the bartender knowingly glanced my way, as if to say, "now you know."
author: Gregory G.

description: I love this place.  I went here for dinner over the weekend for the 3rd time.  I always love eating at this place.  The margaritas are very strong!  We had the guacamole, black beans, chile relleno, tamalitos, and 2 margaritas.  We were very happy with our meal.  The ambience is always very pleasant.  I highly recommend.
author: Samantha S.

description: Great house margaritas and the guacamole was fantastic.  One note, the guacamole is served with tortillas (not chips) that are wrapped in a napkin - they are not on a plate, so you have to look for them a little bit if you aren't used to this arrangement.  I had the scallops with cactus and my friend had the duck, and both were good.  The dessert was delicious, kind of like a donut with honey and cinnamon ice cream on top.  I would recommend this place if you had a smaller group, because the tables are kind of small and they seem to have fewer tables for more than 4 people.  But overall, a good find.
author: Brittany S.

description:
If spectacular traditional central Mexican food is the itch your taste buds can't quite shake, Colibri Mexican Bistro located in the heart of Union Square is your destination. Adorned with an impressive wall of both traditional and unique Tequila, Colibri is guaranteed to satisfy a grumbling tummy as well as quench your thirst. Reservations are recommended but if a casual walk in is more your style, plan on dinning early or planting your behind at the tequila bar for a cocktail or two. Colibri also possesses a delightfully warm atmosphere adorned with dark stained high-backed booths, a glistening mahogany bar, gold-rust sponged walls, and splashes of bright colors and trinkets that remind me so much of Mexico City. I usually begin my experience at this venue by indulging in a traditional margarita made with one of the many unique tequilas followed by a sweeter strawberry or blackberry margarita, yum!! I have indulged just about every entre item but there are a few favorites I must share, so here goes!

Antojitos:
     Fresh made guacamole made right at your table is the only entre I choose to indulge in due to my desire to pamper my stomach with a three course meal. Customers are allowed to choose the level of spice but be careful; I once requested to have my socks knocked off spicy and the chef bounced back from the kitchen with two habañeros which lit up my mouth. Stick to simply "spicy" made with the tamer Jalapeño chili and you will surely be pleased! Served alongside fresh hand made tortillas and three unique salsas, your taste buds are guaranteed to be tantalized!

Especialidades:
     Fire roasted Poblano chile stuffed with vegetables and cheese served over a rich black bean sauce; fabulous!! This is a unique Chile Relleno due to the fact that it is neither fried nor breaded but rather fire roasted with a strong thriving chile flavor. Stuffed with perfectly cooked veggies and just the right amount of cheese, this dish was made to please rather than clog those arteries!
 Filet Mignon served alongside an Ancho chile stuffed with goat cheese all atop smashed potatoes with sautéed spinach and chipotle sauce. This dish is the perfect mixture of sweet and salty that simply makes my mouth water; you can't go wrong with this plate! The saltiness of the filet and goat cheese pair perfectly with the savory smashed potatoes and the slight sweet flavor obtained by the Ancho chile.
 Pechuga Rellena de Huitlacoche; for those who don't speak a lick of Spanish this is Chicken breast stuffed with a mix of huitlacoche (sort of a corn pure if you will), zucchini, and fresh corn atop a roasted garlic sauce. This plate is so savory you will have to resist the urge to lick your plate clean! The rich dark chicken meat pairs perfectly with the savory veggies and the mouth watering garlic sauce; if you love chicken you will drool in your sleep over the immaculate flavors possessed within this dish. 
 Mole Poblano, a legendary Mexican favorite made from a blend of spices, chiles, nuts, and chocolate magically transformed into a rich and flavorful sauce served in the traditional Puebla style over chicken. There are so many flavors that burst throughout your mouth with this plate; this is a pleasant blend of sweet and savory. This is one of the better Mole sauces I have ever tasted. I feel as if I should be in a warm Mexican home when I indulge in this delightful dish. 

Postres:
     If you have an inch of room left in your stomach after indulging in a fabulous dinner, you have to order the traditional Churros Rellenos filled with Cajeta caramel cream, served with Dulce de Leche ice cream. How often does one get to indulge in Churros anymore?! The Churros alone are the perfect blend of crunchy and sweet, but the caramel sauce sends these over the edge delightful! Yuuuuuummmy!!!

Colibri Mexican Bistro is an amazing experience for any patron seeking fabulous traditional Mexican favorites. My only complaint in regards to this venue is the rather lagging wait staff and the length of time it takes to receive drinks and dinner courses. It should not take twenty minutes to get a specialty cocktail on a slow early Tuesday dinner, especially when there are two bartenders behind the counter chatting each other up. However, the food at this venue is absolutely fabulous and thus I am willing to slightly overlook the staff problem. I think the pricing is pretty reasonable; a three course meal for two with at least one drink per person should drop you about a bill. Overall this is a fabulous restaurant and one of the few traditional higher-end Mexican Bistros I have found in the city, try it out!
author: Bri C.

description: This place really surprised me.  We walked past it and it was packed.  We found out later it was the crowd from the surrounding theaters.  I really didn't want to go in because there were no seats available at the bar and no backs on the bar stools (this seems to be a common theme in San Fran for some reason).  In addition, I really didn't want mexican food.  I was hoping for something a bit more upscale.  We walked for about an hour just checking out the area at night.  We come to the city a lot, but like to really experience all the restaurants and areas.  We ended up back at Colibri, which my hubby really wanted to do in the first place.  The bar was then emptied out.  I really wanted a martini and was kind of scared to ask for one at a mexican place.  Turns out our bartender was amazing.  He could whip up any concoction I requested to perfection.  He also recommended several dishes for us to try.  They food was really amazing too.  We left feeling like we had really had an upscale dining experience in a trendy mexican joint.
author: Suzanne H.

description: the french toast with agave syrup was by far the best french toast ive ever had in my life! it was served with fresh fruit (strawberry, mango and some kind of berry i forget). a little over priced but definately worth it. i hit this place up every time i go to the city! love the chips and salsa's they serve....3 types of salsa...the mango salsa is dank!
author: Lisa S.

description: Great food. Everything homeade and the servers are cute! ;-)
author: Keith A.

description: Love this place. Only Mexican restaurant where I don't feel like a fat pig afterwards. The dishes are on the smaller side and aren't super heavy. The drinks are yummy yummy. One star off for spotty service but still a place worth going to over and over. Not expensive but definitely not cheap.
author: Heather L.

description:
the food is great - regional mexican cuisine, tapas style, the staff (servers, cooks, bartenders... i.e. the people that actually do the work) is awesome!

big selection of tequila.  i really like the mojitos here (well make sure khalfani makes them) and the sangria's pretty good as well.  for non-alcoholic drinks, ask what their agua fresca is of the day.  

i love pretty much all their main dishes...
from the side dishes the hongos chileajo and the estofado are pretty good.

leave room for the dessert cus the crepas con cajeta's scrumptious!

on saturdays and sundays there's also tasty brunch served.. how about some cafe de olla or hot mexican chocolate to go with brunch?
author: charlotte s.

description: An extra charge for chips when you order their $11 guacamole?? Really?!? Mighty ballsy of you, colibri. Mighty ballsy indeed. They do give some soft warm tortillas with the order at no extra charge. It's so not the same. That being said, the guacamole was amazing. I like the guac at Maya just a little better but they are both pretty tasty. I ordered the filet mignon and it was so tender juicy with a lovely taste. Small portion (probably a size I should be eating regularly, but I like to have some left over to take home) and the prices were pretty steep I feel for what you got. I would definitely go back, but most likely on someone else's dime. If I'm going to spend that amount on dinner (which I like to do maybe monthly) there are several other places that would easily trump Colibri in the decision making process.
author: Magi C.

description:
!HOLA!

y? wazza told it's PERUVIAN???

Nonetheless, 700 brands of tequila.   .   .   da Kine.

but, we went for the food after an matinee across the street ::  Jersey Boys.
Yes, theme dining.   .   .
author: Clifford L.

description: The sauces here are incredible, but I went here on a date and this is just NOT a date kind of place. The tables are all wayy too close...I could hear every single word the couple next to us were saying. And it too noisy!
author: Mansi G.

description: I've never eaten there, but once, a friend bought me two Caipirinha's in the afternoon, and I got drunk by accident. They were very citrusy and tasty, but apparently they've got a kick to them. Enjoy, but be careful! You may make a fool of yourself later in the day, by falling off of your bicycle at a red light.
author: Dan M.

description: We went for lunch at Colibri and while some of the food was good (my friend thought her fish was ok at best), the service was awful. It took forever to even get our drinks. The restaurant was not crowded but when we asked for chips, which we were willing to pay for, the waiter rolled his eyes and ignored us. We had to ask a few times and each time had the same type of response. We were very disappointed and we will not be back to Colibri based on that experience. There are a lot of other restaurants in the city, they should really consider talking to their servers as this will not get them repeat customers. P.S. They did not even offer a dessert menu which we may have ordered from since it was my friends b-day. Oh well we just wanted to leave anyway.
author: Dawn R.

description: Muddled margaritas-- select your fruit and it's mixed with tequila.  YUM.
author: Megan G.

description: Definitely the nicest Mexican restaurant I've been to!  They were very accomodating of our large party, especially when we added one more at the last minute.  The sangria was delicious!  Guacamole was fresh and very good, but they serve it in this big stone pot/dish that is shallower than it seems...a little deceiving/disappointing when you realize you've almost finished the guacamole, haha.  I had the duck breast in green mole sauce, because I'll usually order duck if it's on a menu and wanted to try mole.  The duck was cooked well and the mole sauce was tasty, but I don't know enough about authentic Mexican food to really judge.  Portion sizes are definitely on the smaller side considering the price...most dishes seemed to only have a few vegetables to complement the proteins.  Perfect for smaller people like me, but those with larger appetites should order side dishes as well.  I would come back to try more of the menu and have another pitcher of sangria!
author: Mousputin S.

description: Had read about Colibri before traveling to SF and knew we wanted to try it...ended up getting in without reservations on a Saturday night.  The food was excellent - my husband is a huge Mexican food fan (street and gourmet).  After the tortillas and amazing trio of salsas, we started with the tamalitos which were not our favorite but okay.  Then the pazole verde soup - great toppings, very fresh, and great taste. For entrees, I had the scallops with mashed white corn and he had the carnitas.  Both were outstanding.  Service was friendly and prompt.  The sangria was not spectacular, but hit the spot after a day of travel.  The food and ambiance were most certainly worth the price.  Wanted to return right away!
author: MK G.

description: I went here for my company christmas party. They have really good mexican food and exquisite taquila drinks! They have a variety of good patron reposado and silver taquila mixed with tropical fruit drinks. A good place for happy hour.
author: Michael K.

description: Hands down the best fresh tortillas and guacamole and carnitas, and pipian duck, and mole poblano, and papas al gratin in San Francisco.  The brunch menu is great too.  This is one of my favorite places to dine.  Be sure to try a Cazuela drink when you're here, it's refreshing like a margarita with a presentation makes you feel like you could be in Jalisco http://www.webtender.com/db/drink/2132
author: P H I L H.

description: Love that its open after the theatre- also love that they make the guac table-side and when they say spicy, its spicy. The 2-page tequila menu in size 6 font was impressive and my fresh mango margarita was delicious- not cloying sweet but still tasted like fresh mango.  The  salmon tacos, carnitas, and scallops were all delicious.  The queso with chorizo was also quite tasty, but only for the first 5 minutes- after it got less than piping hot, it formed a cheese layer and an oil layer that was less than appetizing.
author: Noelle Q.

description: A fun festive spot with Mexican small plates. The food is tasty with a lot of vegetarian options which is unusual and nice. This is a great place to have dinner and margaritas with a group of friends.
author: shoba d.

description: I once described the mole chicken to a woman I was showering next to at the gym. If we hadn't finished, I probably would have describe the cheese wrapped in banana leaf. Their fresh made tortillas that arrive hot at your table with numerous salsa options make it worth the price of admission, and sticking around for their dessert.  It's a pretty big place so never much of a wait to get a table.
author: Jean W.

description: Came here for Cinco De Mayo, had Margarita's and appetizers.  Best thing was the homemade corn tortillas.  The girl who makes these is in the kitchen constantly making fresh ones, YUM!
author: bekki l.

description: I'm giving this a 5-star rating for the simple fact that the last time I had guacamole this good, I was in Santa Fe, NM, home of some of the best Mexican food in the world (in my opinion at least). Besides the guacamole, the ceviche was really yummy, as were the cactus leaves. Have a margartia (or three), order the guac, and life will be good.
author: Chris B.

description: Perhaps I would've liked it more if I'd been drinking tequila. My friend is pregnant, so our group went non-alcoholic You will pay heavily even for the non-alcoholic drinks here ($9 for a small pitcher of agua frescas?!?). The guacamole appetizer is great--they will mix it up at the table as spicy as you want it and the generous serving is served with mini hot tortillas. The main dishes were mixed in terms of success. My tilapila tacos were nothing special with little bits of pineapple giving it a little oopmh. The side veggie dish was unmemorable. Chicken mole was tasty enough. Maybe I would've liked it more had I not just returned from Mexico. Maybe it's unfair to call it overpriced, given it's in such a touristy 'hood. Still, it was hard not to feel like this was just another overpriced tourist attraction.
author: Megan K.

description:
when was the last time you had mexican food and no cheese in any of the dishes?  i can't recall, yet colibri does a fantastic job of serving up a wide variety of savory dishes...without a shred of cheese.  it's a welcome change. 

try the smoked duck, with a side of cornbread smothered in some lovely green cream sauce.  wash it all down with a mojito - don't worry, they're not your typical girly variety.

four stars, because 5 stars is reserved for the truly great dining experiences, like la folie.
author: brian w.

description: I love this place.  Hmmm, the guacamole, margaritas.  My favorite is the queso fundido con chorizo.  Everything is great!  The ambience is fantastic also.
author: Jamie E.

description: I love the gentrification of Mexican food, truly.  This place does it well without loosing the flavor.  The food is authentic and loyal to traditional Mexican cuisine.  Yes it is way over priced but the guacamole and tortillas are a heavenly experience.   They make the guacamole fresh at your table and to your spice preference.  They have some of the most amazing tortillas that my my mouth has had the pleasure of enjoying!  My advice: go sit at the bar and have some guacamole and tortillas, along with some amazing margaritas for a "bargain" experience.
author: Mar C.

description: Great choice of Margaritas. Guacamole is made at the table for you. Yummy tortillas and salsas.  Good choice of sides and main dishes. They sat 7 of us on a Friday night as a walk in - but I think we got lucky, it was full of people.  Mucho Sabroso!!
author: Ivan S.

description: So, three stars for an amazing selection of tequilas matched by fresh and delicious margaritas, plus melt in your mouth carnitas . . . The fourth star is awarded for two impressive and unusual factors: 1st, they have a diverse dessert menu that offers more than flan (like delicious pastel de tres leches and a decent mango creme brulee - it could have used a thicker sugar crust for cracking). 2nd, instead of the usual tired selection of sports on the bar television, they were showing this awesome black and white Mexican sitcom featuring cape and mask clad wrestler Santo. We are all going to be Net Flixing THAT asap. Minus one star because the 'spicy' guacamole was not so spicy, and you have to purchase your sides separately - I'm not asking for gigantic portions, it is just a little sad to have to throw down an extra $7 to have some beans with your entree. Still, a great place to enjoy a tasty meal with your amigos.
author: Hannah D.

description: I went for Dine Around Town and had the tortilla soup and carnitas and then shared the churros and flan.  The decor and service were great except our waitress was kind of a close talker.  The soup was so creamy and came in a steamy pot and then poured into the bowl at the table.  The carnitas came with warm tortillas and was oh so satisfying.  The churros and flan were very rich and sinful...just as a dessert should be.  My only regret was not gettting the guac but that just gives me another excuse to go back!
author: Nina L.

description: Colibri is always a favorite. Starting out with the Guacamole is a MUST, it is perfectly balanced and luscious. the Jicama salad is always delightful. Pato en Pipian is duck in an incredible pumpkin seed mole sauce, and on that note the Chicken mole is fabulous as well. The carnitas are as good as they come... i could go on... and on. for a side, get the nopales, they are cactus leaves marinated in olive oil and lemon juice with portabello mushrooms. for dessert go for the tequila flan, it's outrageous. The Margaritas are in a class of their own, my favorite drink is the mango mojito. Enjoy!
author: Margot K.

description:
Thanks Yelp for helping me find an awesome place for birthday dinner :-)
Delicious food, yummy alcohol... rounded off my day in the city very nicely.
author: Beth B.

description: Another positive experience tonight at Colibri. 7 co-workers in from out of town; 2 days of amazing eating.... tonight did not disapoint.  Service was pleasant, friendly and helpful, but slow at times. The food however was the star. My group has a few adventurous souls; some not so, but everyone was satisfied. Tableside guac made to order; one spicy one mild, both tasty. LOVE LUV LOVE the handmade warm tortillas.  And what about that crazy cauliflower dish they do... never tried anything like it.  A great Spanish wine (Madeiro) and entrees all around superb.  At $400 for 8 folks including drinks... not bad at all.  Will continue to enjoy and recommend.
author: Tom C.

description: Based on other Yelpers' reviews, and due to my all-encompassing love for sangria and cabin fever last night, the bf and I went to Colibri to get some dinner.  Great atmosphere and interior, and we were pleasantly surprised to find live music there (the good kind, not the boss' cousin in a jam session kind).  The food was good, the drink selection included all of my favorites (sangria was more than passable)...absolutely get the cornbread, although it is not for the vegetarians.  Staff was very friendly and welcoming, from the host to our waitress to the busboy, who kindly wrote down the ingredients of the tasty mango salsa for my boyfriend.  Absolutely worth a try.
author: Tanya N.

description: I have to say the food was better than Dona Tomas in Oakland, but ambiance not as fun. Not that it was bad, just didn't have that certain something, but service was very friendly. Mole poblano was a nice mix of savory and sweet and the guacamole was superfresh. I loved how the lamb shank (Chamorro de Cadero) was presented in a banana leaf. I give a 3 1/2 stars.
author: Farah S.

description: Finally!  Gourmet Mexican!  Loved it ...  Everything was delicious, but some dishes needed salt.  Specialty tequilas make this a great date spot.  It's rare to find a way to work shots into a semi-fancy, romantic supper.
author: Amme P.

description: Good upscale Mexican restaurant.  I was very impressed by their fresh guamacole service, they bring a station to your table and make it to your liking.  Their tortillas are freshly made and high quality.  Most of their dishes are very good.  They serve tapas style, i.e. small portions.  Their margaritas were really fresh.   I would visit again.
author: Adrian N.

description: Excellent upscale Mexican food.  I dined here with a group of friends last night, and we enjoyed everything we ordered.  I would especially recommend the guacamole served with fresh tortillas and anything cooked in mole sauce.  They also offer a variety of fruit margaritas including some unusual choices such as a prickly pear.  The atmosphere is lively and festive, perfect for celebrations or group dining.  My only complaint is that we were in a rush and had difficulty flagging down our server throughout the meal.
author: Grace W.

description: Each time I go I deduct a star. The food is just not good.
author: Mrs. G.

description: Was recommeded this place, but was extremely disappointed. The menu despriptions sounded great and we were convinced this place was going to be a hit. However, once the food arrived we wished we hadn't came. The portions were extremely small for the steep prices we payed. I ordered the scallops and only got 3, which were overcooked and cold. My mother ordered the Chicken Mole and it wasn't a hit either. I wish I could say that the food tasted so good that we were able to overlook these setbacks, but the flavors weren't rich enough. In addtion, you have to order sides separately for an additional price...a small bowl of rice for $5, you've got to be kidding me. And to top it off they added a 3% Healthy Eating San Frnacisco Tax (whatever the heck this is). The only thing that was good were the tortillas with salsa. Too many restaurants in SF to settle for mediocrity.
author: Brittany P.

description: After several years of walking the block between the Union Square parking garage and the Clift Hotel, this little gem finally made it onto my radar... and how did I miss it before?!  I may never know.  Wonderful sangria (a semi-secret recipe that was divulged one night by a friendly bartender... mmm, mangoes).  Go for the guacamole, heavenly carnitas, and above all- be sure to make the trek for brunch.  There's little better than munching on yummy mexican brunch and a pitcher of sangria, only to walk out into the Geary Street sunshine and realize it's 1pm, and you're a little drunk.
author: Jenny S.

description:
lots of reviews so here are the highlights:

-seems to be lunch traffic, so it was good to go around 1:30
-HUGE fillet minon skewer portion!!  totally tender and had amazing sauces to accompany it.
-great service.
-loved those fresh, warm, handmade on premise corn tortillas with those three amazing salsas:)
-the three sopas were amazing!  who'd have thought that the veggie one would be so freakin tasty!... must have been the cheese...
-the iced tea had honey in it... eh, not my cup o tea, but you may like it!
-skip the salads.

i'd totally return for the fillet minon!  crazy good and a great price:)
author: becky f.

description: Just came from business meeting here, and it was just fabulous.  The tortillas are fresh and flaky, resembling naan a little bit.  The service was very attentive and very in tune with our needs.  The chicken was really tender and tasty.  I wanted to get the tres leches, but someone order churros for the table, and oh, god.  It sucks you have to contain yourself during business lunches, so you don't look like a desperate person with no etiquette, but it was really hard to leave any churros and amazing dulce de leche ice cream for anyone else.  I am definitely coming back, but with people that won't mind my Cookie Monster tendencies.
author: Vivian P.

description:
mexican tapas and small plates are delicious and a great place in the city for some drinks and appetizers with friends.  the dishes tend to be on the small side for what the cost, but they do have a very wide selection of tequilas so they are quite equipped for a good time.
the table side guacamole is simple and delicious but we wished they gave us more tortillas.  everything had great flavor. even though the spice meter is a little on the low side, it's no real loss since they make up for the lack of heat in many other ways.  we loved the torta de elote and the filet mignon.  my brother-in-law ordered a few more dishes that i can't remember what they were exactly (a chicken and a pork dish) that was thoroughly enjoyed as well.
  service is friendly but sparse and they get really busy so know what you want and need well in advance because it could be a while before you get it.
author: Karen Y.

description:
Bottom line....Nothing special about this place.

We went for drinks and a light dinner.  We decided to share a bunch of appetizers for dinner.  The guacamole was really good, but $10 for guacomole that doesn't come with chips better be good!  We also got the fish tacos which were just okay.  The quesadilla was very bland and basicaly just cheese.  Very cheesy with no flavor.  And the chorizo cheese dip was absolutely disgusting.  

We were looking for more authentic mexican food, and I wish we would have done more research because this place was not it.
author: Erin K.

description: not the best. it was, eh, OK. nothing exciting, which is what we were hoping for. no WOW factor. AND it was a bad spot placement, two top in the corner, practically behind a wall. it was our server's fourth time and the prawns were not prawns, they were the smallest shrimp i have ever seen. there is difference between shrimps..and prawns. They did not know that. The bf was  really craving the mole..and nothing. No surprise, just boring. And actually a bit rushed. We got the tortilla soup (again, ok, no fun in it) and mid way through, they put the dinners on the table. So now it's over crowded on the small two top and the entree cooling off. The only thing that was exciting was the tequila taster.
author: Abigail W.

description: Great food and a friendly staff. The guac was great, and we had a nice assortment of food. Everything was excellent! I will most certainly be back!
author: Lisa K.

description:
I made my reservation on OpenTable - it was actually the first time I used that service and I think it's really cool.   Anyways, there was 5 in our party and they sat us at an awkwardly deep table that made it hard to share the shareable tapas-style appetizers and extremely hard to have any sort of conversation with the person seated acrossed from you.
     Our waiter mumbled and wouldn't look anyone in the eye and seemed to be really annoyed with us for not knowing what we wanted within 3 minutes of sitting down.  But at least they were fast with the drink orders.  And did I mention the band?  This place isn't large and it was quite full of people both at tables and at the bar.  It's all tile and mirrors, so the sound bounces - but they had a live salsa band playing (plugged in) and we had the happy accident of being sat right in front of the band which made impossible to hear even the person sitting next to you except at breaks between songs.  Honestly, the music was nice but they reaaally didn't need amplification.  They even played a request for our friend at dinner.  
     As for the food, I have to say I was surprised at the heartiness of the menu.  We got tableside guacamole, which was good but a little awkward to eat with the soft mini tortillas they give you to eat it with (no chips!)  Definitely not a "traditional" Mexican place.  I ordered lamb shanks steamed in a banana leaf.  Really tender, flavorful meat with a good sized portion.  Others at the table ordered ranchero chicken and they said it was delish.  Didn't stay for dessert (we longed for a quiet cup of decaf and a giant slice of cake).  

I won't go back, but it's not just because I was miffed at the noise level and so-so service - it's just not the kind of Mexican restaurant that I like.  Oh well.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I once read a rant by the ever entertaining Tim Goodman, of Chronicle fame, talking about the little man sitting up. He felt the little man sitting up was actually very mis-leading, because you can't tell what he is thinking at all. At least with the little man sleeping or the little man clapping, you have a good clue as to how he's feeling.
That is how I feel about the 3 star review. You're not really sure, did they like it, did they not like it... who knows? I myself am not exactly sure how I felt about my Colibri experience, so I feel a 3 star review here is appropriate. Perhaps after you read my review you can tell me how I felt?

The evening was already shrouded because I was there with a group of friends for my birthday. Whenever you go anywhere to celebrate an occasion in which your center of attention, your judgment is automatically going to be impaired. When we arrived, the table was ready, guacamole already waiting. I was hoping they would make it table side, but for such a large group I can see why they prepared in advance. The Guac? Well it was GOOOOD! You could tell it was freshly made, all the right amounts of cilantro, tomatoes, onions... the guac alone gets 5 stars. Next the drinks - no pitchers of margaritas. WTF you say? Absolutely, WTF. What Mexican restaurant doesn't offer pitchers? Especially for large groups?! A Mexican restaurant that wants to charge you $10 for a HOUSE margarita, that's who. So no pitchers and $10 house margarita = EXPENSIVE bar tab; 1 star.  Since we were a large group, we had to have one of those prix fixe menus with the 3 courses basically chosen for you. Caesar salads were good, nice home made dressing (i think), good size portion, a bit better than a normal Caesar; 4 stars. Then the entrees: our choices were filet mignon, carnitas, and shrimp. No one got shrimp (shocker). Having heard the carnitas were the specialty, I went with the pig instead of the cow. Now I'm not exactly sure how they prepare the carnitas, but they certainly weren't fried, and they were dry as can be. Perhaps this is their version of "healthy" carnitas (lord knows I don't need all of that extra lard thrown in) but still, when you order carnitas you expect crispy flavorness on the outside and juicy ternderness on the inside. That's certainly not what we got; 2 stars. For the desserts, I'll just say this. Have you ever tasted lumpy flan? If you haven't and you would like to, make a trip to Colibri and order the flan. That is exactly what you'll get, lumpy flan; 1star. 

Service was good. She was on top of the drinks, refilling the waters, food came quickly, etc... 4 stars. So lets see, you add up all the stars that gets you 17 stars. Divide by the # of categories (6 in total) that gets you to 2.833333.... 3 stars in short. Now after all of that, I think the 3 star rating is pretty appropriate. Yet its still sends the ambiguous message of, did she like, did she not... do you think I liked it?
author: Lisa W.

description: Took my family here for a 6:30p reservation on a Sunday after seeing a play at the Curran theater right across the street. The experience was pretty underwhelming. I thought the food was really bland and totally overpriced. The Mezcalita drink I ordered barely had any alcohol in it. The quesadilla appetizer was three* very* small pieces, barely enough for one person to munch on (and it cost something like ~$10) I thought their famous quacamole was flavorless and forgettable. The service was poor. It took over 20 minutes just to get some water on the table once we were seated. We never even received the side order of rice and beans that we ordered. There is so much great Mexican food in San Francisco, for a much better price. I would not go back to Colibri.
author: Paul S.

description: This morning was our second visit to Colibri.  We started with the Guacomole and i had the Herradura Anejo.  Both were fabulous.  For starter we had Huevos Poblanos and Chilaquiles.  We found both dishes tasty and to our liking.  The service was excellent.  the only issue my wife had was that the TV over the bar was turned to some weird movie that distracted her.
author: Vivek V.

description: Don't need to say much, cuz it's all been said. Just will say it was Killer. For real. Would eat that halibut every night happily.
author: Julie A.

description: Killer top-shelf margaritas and amazing food were the hallmarks of my visit to Colibri. This is not the ubiquitous ghetto-mex greasy spoon, rather it is a creative, upscale restaurant which specializes in Mexican cuisine. It could be a great spot for a date or an upscale business lunch.
author: Jason M.

description: My favorite Mexican place in the city! Just about every item is good, but the filet is especially good. The fresh guac is a must with every meal, as are their margaritas. This is a great place for a big group - if you get enough tables in the back, its almost like you own the place and can do whatever you want to. Even if you're just going with a few friends, you should call in advance and reserve a booth so you don't get stuck at a regular table.
author: Aden Z.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for our first dinner in SF based mostly on the promise of fresh, hot, house-made tortillas and frankly, they did not disappoint.  The three fresh salsas were great too.  He had a chicken dish and I had shrimp and both were deellish.  I also enjoyed a house margarita.  I'll agree it might be a little over-priced on a regular basis (i.e. we wouldn't go there often if we were locals), but we had that vacation feeling so for us, it was well worth it and was a meal we'll remember for a while.
author: Jenna D.

description: Great churros and prawns, otherwise just OK. Gauc was good, but we make better at home... $10 is a bit steep for gauc, and $3 extra for chips.
author: Court M.

description:
one word...

margarita

if not for the sensuous food go for the amazing margaritas which they hand mash whole straberries into, or whatever fruit you choose,  i had a great time with a girlfriend of mine and truly enjoyed the guacamole which you can choose what heat you want, the filet minon on mashed potatoes which was cooked a perfect medium rare (something i'm such a critic for) and served with a roasted pepper chipotle sauce the ceviche which is both tangy and salty as it should be and the tasty chille relleno i've only been twice and the only thing i can dog on is maybe the fact that my tamales were a little dry so i'd stray but as long as you end with the warm chocolate cake (a girl's fantasy) and the white velvet dessert cocktail, i don't see how you can't be happy

but i would have to agree... it would be better with crisp chips as oppose to tortillas the salsa falls right off
author: janice b.

description: I was VERY pleasantly surprised by the food here. I don't know why I had never noticed this place before, I was looking for a "Latin" place to eat before opening night of In the Heights at the Curran and was shocked to find this place right across the street. The food here was top notch! We started with the guacamole which was made fresh for us and served with fresh tortillas, the guacamole was so good! It tasted super fresh and had a nice balance of flavors from the avocado and onion. We then shared the catch of the day which was a pecan crusted ahi tuna served with delicious mashed potatoes and vegetables. We also split the shrimp with mole sauce and a corn cake which was my favorite of the meal. I love mexican corn cake and the mole sauce was incredible. The shrimp were meaty and went perfectly with the mole sauce. My only complaint was that the portions here are a bit small. We ended with the dark chocolate mousse with fleur de sel. A winner. I will come to this place for all my pre theater dinners from now on!
author: Cathy T.

description: I keep coming back. Great delicious food.  Mole, fish, duck, salsas and handmade tortillas.  Carnitas good but lots more is better and authentic.  Eat here!
author: Charles G.

description:
Let me preface my review by stating that I took my date here solely as a primer for getting laid last Saturday night.  She was Costa Rican with great cheeks, front and back.

Upon entering Colibri, the wait staff notified us that it would be a few minutes for our table.  Before I could count the number of different tequilas on the top shelf, we were seated.  They could obviously tell I was on a mission and needed to get my date drunk quickly.  Glad they were on the same page as me that night.

The interior felt like an old Mexican saloon - warm, dark, and simple yet exotic.  Just the right mixture to put my date in a sexy mood.  I'm soooo getting laid after dinner!

As we scanned the menu - who really reads a Mexican menu in detail?!  Come on people, it's friggin tortillas, guacamole, grilled chicken, pico de gallo, and rice!  It's always the same ingredients - just changes names depending on how the tortilla interfaces with the rest of the food.  Fill it yourself?  Fajita!  Wrap it only part way?  Taco!  Wrapped like a camper in a sleeping bag?  Burrito!!

Like I was saying, as we scanned the menu, I began thinking they had accidentally given us menus from the restaurant next door.  What Mexican restaurant serves filet mignon but doesn't offer chips and salsa to appetize the palate?!  When they brought our plates, I thought for sure my eyes were going bad once and for all.  I've seen kids in TJ selling Chiclets bigger than my dainty filet.  Way overpriced and undersized!!  But it was ok this night, because I was getting laid!

Several drinks in, we started talking dirty to each other.  Ever notice how the more you drink the louder you talk?  Neither did we until couples from around the corner started looking over their shoulders at us.  Apparently I wasn't the only guy in there realizing that this date was definitely going to end up between the sheets.

We had such a great time there.  And our waitress was hot too.  She didn't know it but "Camelle" was my backup plan if this date didn't work out in my favor.  Hang in there babe, I'll be back for you one of these days.

Overall it was a good experience, but the food was average and the prices were HIGH!  Ultimately, the night was a huge success...if ya get my drift.  *wink*  *wink*
author: Bob S.

description: Stumbled on this nice spot when looking for a tasty lunch. The jicama salad was delicious and plated beautifully. It's nice to see mexican food break away from the texmex shakles of burritos and nachoes. The mole was lovey, same for the carnitas, and heat was just right. Definately take some one you love, like yourself, out for a nice treat.
author: j s.

description:
We decided to go to Colibri because it boasted central Mexican food, which is rather unusual in California. 
The menu looked inspired - interesting choices: pipian, pozole verde. 
We ordered the guacamole, which was superb. But then, they gave us handmade tortillas. Now, I give them 2 stars for the effort, but wow, these were some of the worst tortillas I've eaten. 1. The dough was dry, which was apparent from the cracks at the edges (tortillas have to have a smooth rim). 2. They were under-cooked, meaning they were not cooked properly so that there is a visible inside and outer sides and it was doughy inside. Whoever made them did not know that you have to let them poof up (as per other flat breads: naans, chapati) and they were heavy, rather than light. All tortillas poof up. 
Then there was the seasoning. I am not talking spicy, I'm talking taste. When I am eating a 25 dollar entrée (counting the rice), I want it to have flavors (yes, not one, but many).  Colibri simply did not deliver. The duck in pipian was weak. The pozole even weaker. The carnitas were good, but basically a pork confit will always be good. The sopes: the dough, again undercooked. The toppings were bland. No contrast. 
And then there was the salsas. It is absolutely a mystery to me, why, with the range that salsas have, Colibri had only 1. Yes. We asked for a salsa, and the offered us Tapatio. I was floored. I am sorry? Did you just offer me Tapatio in this gourmet Mex restaurant?  
Finally: the service. Our waitress could barely pronounce the dishes, knew little about Mexican food, and although we came in during the middle of lunch and dinner, was not as attentive as we would expect for an almost empty establishment.  Would a "gourmet" restaurant that is $$$$ not have knowledgeable servers?
What I felt like, was more a lack of pride in the food, boastful of quality (and price), but not of taste. 
I came home and made myself some good handmade tortillas, just to remind me that they are not that hard to make. 
One good thing: the micheladas with Dos Equis Amber.
author: Miriam L.

description: Excellent tapas and even better cocktails. Though it's always too crowded, reservations can be made. A bit pricey for what you get, but bottomless fresh tortillas make it all worthwhile.
author: Havana H.

description: I heard such great things about this place ,so me and bf went before a play. They ran out of the  key ingredients for the signature drinks. The margs weren't the best I have ever had. the tortilla soup was really good and so was the steak with mole sauce. I don't even like mole and this dish was great. service wasn't awesome. fresh tortilla's with three different kinds of salsa is really good. fish tacos were not that good at all. we spent a lot of money and only really enjoyed the soup and steak ( which was was pretty small). Mango creme brulee was pretty good though. Not sure if I would go back.
author: kimberly l.

description: Atmosphere is very important to me, and I don't know a lot of Mexican places in this city that offer a great atmosphere, as well as great food and reasonable prices.  Not to say there aren't any - I just haven't been.  That said, I was thrilled to finally try out Colibri.  The tequila selection alone (I believe the bartender said over 300) is worth the trip, and the reason we first ventured in.  An evening at the bar sipping tequila and beer...with the musical trio in the corner.  Awesome.
author: Isabel M.

description: Have always had great experiences here - particularly so on a recent girl's night.  The margaritas here are great -  the real deal and they pack a punch!  Food is great - rich flavors and authentic options. QUALITY guac, which is always a great start!  The tortilla soup is food.  We had several starters to make a meal - tamales, tingas, etc.  (the best kind of meal - getting to taste a lot of different things!!) Muy bueno.
author: Danielle R.

description: Zaii K stole my line! :) I too, created a Yelp! account just to rate this place. My boyfriend and I stayed at the Clift hotel and stumbled into this joint across the street one night. The bar was crowded and there was a wait so we figured it must be worth it. We posted up at the bar for a pitcher of Sangria, which I highly recommend btw, and waited for about 25 minutes for a table to open up. Once seated, our waiter was awesome, very helpful on the menu, and whipped up some fresh guac right at our table. We were seated right next to the cooks making fresh tortillas, and gobbled them up one after another. Recommend the Carnitas and the Chile Rellano, though you have to order everything ala carte (rice beans other sides). A little on the pricey side, but worth it for an interesting take on a date night ala Mexican food! Two thumbs up!
author: Nikki M.

description: I've been traveling to SF for over 6-years consistently for business and the concierge at the Ritz, Clift and Monaco hotels have all recommended this restaurant...but I've resisted and opted for mamacitas, don pistos and tacolicious (all superior restaurants). I arrived at 6:15pm (yes, 6:15pm) without a reservation to be greeted by a smug hostess telling me there wasn't a table for 2 available until 8pm. She didn't even say there was opening seating in the bar or suggest to eat the bar...she'd apparently rather send people to the streets. I then found out my friend was sitting in the back...she had seated him without a reservation?? And there was at least 3 empty tables in the back room which remained that way through my very mediocre dinner which lasted a painful 90-minutes. I ordered a margarita it took 29 minutes. They served us guac with no chips? A salsa trio which was so shallow that I couldn't even get it on a chip when it finally arrived.  The menu only contained one traditional offerings...tacos. No enchiladas, tostadas, etc.... I ordered the mole poblano to find out it wasn't served with any sides until the meal was in front of me. $120 for 2 people when we each only had one drink. I'd say this place from service to food is one of the biggest rip offs in SF and the continental United States. I can only hope this place gets what it deserves...closed doors.
author: Jason B.

description: This place is way over-rated.. Me & about 6 other peeps came here for my birthday, 2007. The waiter had a hard time explaining that they don't serve chips & salsa..  but they do serve tiny little bowls of chips for, I dunno $5 and then you have to order guacamole or a cheesy appetizer to dip them in. This place was just odd.. my best friend still makes fun of me for picking this place for my birthday celebration. I think we were all disappointed.
author: Tracy C.

description: great tortillas, great queso fundido and AMAZING TEQUILA  DRINKS!!! Had a wonderful time. Make sure you ask the Adrian the bartender for his specialty drink (Jalapenos included!)
author: Crf C.

description: Guac was Delish!  Cheese enchiladas just okay.  The waitress was REALLY nice, until she realized that I was using a restaurant.com certificate.  What's it to her?  She still got tipped on the full amount.  ANYWAY, I don't think it's fair to be stingy with stars for that, so Colibri still gets 4 stars for good guac, nice ambiance, and a VERY yummy strawberry basil margarita.
author: Lexi L.

description: Everything I had here, the carnitas, chicken, guacamole, chile relleno, was either overcooked or bland or both. The best part was the sauce that came with the carnitas. The margarita was tasty enough but a bit weak.
author: Stu M.

description: Loved everything about it. Went for lunch and had the most delicious carnitas I've ever had. The pork was melt-in-your-mouth tender. Before the meal, there were three bowls of interesting variations on salsa, served with small thick homemade tortillas. Also ordered the make-at-your-table guacamole, which the waiter did to specification. The staff was exceedingly helpful and friendly, the decor was homey and comfortable, and the prices seemed very fair for the quality of food that was served. Can't say enough about how great my experience was, and I'd go back in a heartbeat. (Next time, I'm going to try the special margaritas!)
author: Zoe H.

description: Surprisingly good.  I took a friend of mine who wishes he was actually a brownie... but he just fakes it.  Apparently the dishes met his demand for authenticity and they were quite tasty.  Get the guacomole - it's spicy and delicious.  I had the mole poblano which was pretty good.  They serve amazing homemade corn torillas and my friends seemed to enjoy their margaritas (but not the blackberry one)
author: Jared F.

description:
great happy hour, and the bartender (adrianne?) was awesome.
he was attentive, and when I asked him what drink he was making that required a microplane and a cucumber, he made me one of his own special drinks with agave, pomegranate tequila, mango and lime.   when asked for the name, he said it had none, and I was the first person to try it.
I call it "This Side of Paradise" and J calls it "pome-cuca-tini".  
you go there and ask for it by either name....
(and the food is awesome)
author: Zachary S.

description: Found this on Yelp (thanks Yelp!), and it's great!  It's best to go with a small group so you can sample lots of dishes - the food is really good.  The atmosphere is very fun and energetic, especially if you go on a live music night.  And the location makes it a nice alternative to the usual vapid pre- and post-theater places.
author: Anna S.

description:
I never eat out alone.  I just don't do it.  But I had no choice.  I was in town for business and my friend hadn't arrived.  And I was starving--hadn't eaten all day, and it was 8:00PM.  I peeked into this place, hoping to do takeout and bring the food back into my room at Clift.  LOSER!  For some reason, I changed my mind.  I took a seat at the bar and tried to act casual.  Honestly, I was flipping out.  I'm allergic to alcohol, despite my best efforts, so I don't go to bars often and like I said, I definitely don't go alone.  

I watched a few people order the fresh guacamole.  It's made to order and it comes in a massive molcajete (it's lined with a plastic container, so kind of a cheat) with mild, medium and hot sauces to mix in.  Best of all, it comes with a stack of homemade, mini white corn tortillas.  Willing to bet that these babies are laced with crack.  They were amazing, and I am a purist when it comes to guacamole--chips or soft, fresh flour tortillas...I could not fathom why they weren't offering one of my preferred accoutrements.  How wrong I was.  I thought, well, I'll do my usual thing and get an appetizer as a dinner and see how I feel...maybe it won't be enough...  Again, wrong, wrong.  The tortillas are pretty thick, and apparently they give you just enough to feel like you're Mrs. Shrek if you can eat them all.  I did, but I gotta admit, the guacamole was so amazing, I was kind of defiant in my gluttony.  

The bartender was civil, given I was hogging a barstool and not ordering liquor.  Perfect first Eating Out Alone experience.  A milestone made better with a bitchin' molcajete.
author: cat b.

description: This is a conditional 3-star rating, which we'll probably change to 4 stars. I ordered the wrong thing (the fish tacos - good but nothing special) and so did my roommate (cheese quesadillas). We weren't super hungry so we didn't get to try the entrees, which we'll have to do next time. The tortilla instead of chips concept was ok with me, and their salsas were really fresh and different. Guacamole was really yummy. I had a blackberry margarita which was really good but the mojitos were nothing special (too sweet). The sangria is really good though. Cute place with more upscale mexican - something new and different. Not very many chairs there, so make sure you don't add anyone to your party.
author: Alex H.

description: A really great dinner! This is a very authentic Eastern Mexican dinner. The guacamole is made table side. Beware if you ask for "Mexican spicy and not gringo spicy." They deliver! The dishes were great and the selection of tequila is awesome. Be sure to order Trago if you go. So smooth!
author: Natali M.

description: Such a cool small plates joint. I had the blackberry margarita which was as delicious as it was strong. All the food was amazing, but it is definitely SMALL plates. we had to order more. Would be really good for a birthday celebration. My new favorite place in Union Square.
author: Katie T.

description: This is one of my new favorite restaurants in town.  I went with two friends from London, one lived in Mexico City for a bit and the other had never eaten Mexican in her life.  I am happy to say they both loved it, plus the waitstaff was soooo charming.  The fresh guacamole is fabulous as are the fresh fruit margharitas.  There is also a decent selection for vegitarians.
author: m.e. t.

description: I LOOOOOOVE Colibri.  Best place for a pre- or post-theatre bite.  The tortillas are always steaming hot and fresh, and they have jamaica agua fresca, which I have not come across in the city (and missed after leaving NYC)!
author: Sheila W.

description: You don't hear the term "Mexican Bistro", often, but Colibri is just that.  My last vist with Katt we ate at the bar and we were treated like Royalty.  I was happy with my food, my cocktails, my wine selection and the bar tender let us taste some great Tequila.  All in all it was a great place to eat and drink.
author: Bags O.

description: I would have to say the hand made avocado made fresh alone with hand made tortillas alone is worth the walk drive bart or bus..I walked up from financial area yesterday with a co-worker. I ordered the Carna, very tender and so juicy with flavor. The price was up there so we paid 50 including tip of 7 dollars. You have to go there..They do take reservations, but  we walked in around lunchtime and was able to get seated immediately on a weds though..
author: Eddie G.

description: Service was great.  Carnitas was very tender and authentic--didn't need any rice or bean accompanyment.  Guac was fresh with a lot of citrus and cilantro.  Tequilla inventory is gigantic.  Slightly expensive.
author: Kurt L.

description:
Excellent

Tortilla Soup- Awesome 

Guacamole- Amazing

Coffee- Fantastic

Huevos Rancheros- Pretty Good

Service was good, presentation was great.
author: B P.

description:
the only reason i'm giving 3 stars instead of 4 is because i had the mole chicken and it was extremely dry. my mom always gets the special of the day and i think she is on to something because her dishes tend to taste much better than mine... this time it was some kind of fish, and it was 100x better than what i had. very flavorful with crispy skin.

other than my dry chicken, the ambience was quite wonderful. we ate a pretty early dinner (around 6-ish) and they already had live music set up. extra points for the hilariously cheesy black and white monster movies they have playing on the flatscreen :)

if you come with a group of people, ask if the booths in the back are free because they are much cozier than what's in front.
author: David P.

description: It is a very nice place to come after work and have a margarita with some friends. I loved the attention the staff gave us. They have a real yummy guacamole and they ask how hot you like it. MMMM we wanted real hot and it was real good. My main dish was real good and light. I didn't feel like I over ate, it was just right and they got these nice home made tortillas. Yum. Of course you know this is high end Mexican restaurant so it is real nice to come to with a date. But please make reservations, it is small and I would say gets packed on the weekends and after work hours. Over all awesome bar, high reviews for the guacamole! Buen Provecho.
author: Eli R.

description: This last time I visited Colibri I have to say I was quite disappointed.  I made the suggestion to some friends who wanted Mexican and close in proximity to celebrate a birthday, so I felt a little bit of pressure from the start.  The hostess was very rude right off the bat and not presented in a manner I thought appropriate for the position she is in.  We ended up waiting almost a 1/2 hour after our reservation time to be seated.  We then waited almost 15 minutes to order.  Our server was very friendly and even brought out dessert and sang Happy Birthday to our birthday girl.  I did leave the place feeling a little embarrassed to have suggested it but I know the service is usually much better.
author: Rise G.

description: OK - lets be honest. Some of the best Mexican restaurants are often dives. And more often than not, "fancy" Mexican restaurants are usually disappointing.   But this place is actually really good (a bit high end as far as Mexican food goes).  But don't be fooled, this is not your typical Mexican restaurant  (with a free bowl of chips/salsa and tacos/burritos on the menu) - it's more gourmet. On weekends it will get super crowded and noisy especially in the bar area where it's a popular hangout for the younger crowd. So for a more quiet dinner reserve a booth in back around the Kitchen (it's not as loud). Also expect to spend over $100 for two if you're having drinks and appetizers - it's not inexpensive.  Ambiance is upbeat, service is usually great. Margaritas are awesome.   Fun place.
author: M D.

description: I used to like Colibri a lot.  The food was refined, well-seasoned, carefully prepared, etc.  It was great to have an upscale Mexican restaurant option in the City.  My recent visit on 7/4/09 was disappointing.  I'm willing to pay for a good drink, but a $10 house margarita?  I know they use good tequila, it was a shame I couldn't taste it.  Just sugar and lime juice.  I ordered the Pato en Pipian,  (duck in pumpkin seed chile sauce).  The duck breast was unevenly cooked.  Instead of a nice, rosy center, it was raw and chewy on the inside and cooked on the outside.  The rice was alright, but nothing special.  The queso fundido with chorizo was alright, but I've had better cheese and chorizo.  With options like Nopalito available now, I don't see any reason to go back and pay a lot more money for substandard mexican food.
author: Anthony C.

description: Had some drinks and apps at the bar last week & returned over the weekend for brunch.  They make great margaritas & sangria.  We ordered the guacamole spicy with habanero peppers & it was delish.  Instead of the typical chips & salsa they bring you yummy  fresh steaming hot tortillas with 3 types of salsas.  The brunch was ok, I liked the bottomless mimosas but you can get those anywhere with brunch.  I don't think I'd return for brunch, it just wasn't memorable.  I would go back for drinks or dinner though!  The service was good, I would call ahead for dinner reservations,.
author: Toni L.

description: Colibri is outstanding! My partner and I arrived around 5pm (had 5:30 rezzies) and sat at the bar wanting a great margarita. With 320 (yes three hundred and twenty) types of tequila, we were overwhelmed. The Bartender was extremely friendly and knowledgeable. He suggested a couple of types of margaritas and he was right on! We also had chips at the bar with the 3 types of salsa - all were great. Then dinner. We started with guac and ceviche, both wonderful! My partner had halibut and I had carnitas. Both entrees were fantastic, the service excellent, then live musica! We loved it and will definitely go back. All in all we spent about $200 and every dollar worth it! Go and try this place, it's awesome!
author: Lee J.

description: Tasty food & drinks and cool ambiance - but overpriced for what it is (as is to be expected with  the proximity to Union Square). The at-the-table guac is a fun perk.
author: Heather C.

description: I used to work in this joint and under-appreciated how good the food was. That seems to happen when you work in a restaurant, you lose feeling for what your serving. I recently went back after returning from college to San Francisco. Most of the same staff as when I was there continue to serve great drinks and Mexican fare. Carlos is the man you want to talk to about a good Margie, and Arturo, the busser, makes the best guacamole west of Oaxaca. I don't think we are west of Oaxaca, but in any event, Arturo es el hombre.
author: Sam S.

description: I came here for dinner before a Tuesday night show. We didn't make reservations and the restaurant was packed. The hostess sat us down at a little booth in the bar area. They gave us a dinner menu and we actully ended up ordering appetizers. They were amazing and surprisingly very filling. The best was the freshly made guacamole. The service was great too. We mentioned to our waitress that we were catching a show and she went out of her way to get our food out faster so we wouldn't miss anything.
author: Sue L.

description: My girlfriend and I were in the Union Square area and just wandered around looking for a place to eat. This place got a Zagat decal on the window and there was no wait, so we decided to try it. Loved their prepared-to-order guacamole. The food is tapas style, but they were in pretty good sizes for tapas. Never had this kind of mexican food before, very good stuff.
author: Andrew N.

description:
We came here on a Wednesday night.  When we walked in and asked for a table for 4, they acted very surprised that we hadn't made reservations.  They were polite, though, and took our name and number and told us it would be about a half hour.

There was no place to wait so we walked around outside for a bit.  We were called a half our later for our table.

The service was pretty good.  The food was good as well.  They have excellent Margaritas.  I'd go back here at some point if I lived in the area.  I wouldn't be dying to go back, but it's a nice place to go in the Union Square area.
author: W Y.

description: I loved this place....lots of fresh tortillas, guacamole was to die for.   I had the eggplant, which was not a regular mexican dish, but was fantastic, i would totally get it again.  I also tried the ceviche, and the black beans with just the right amount of queso fresco on it.  I went out with my office at lunch, so i couldn't sample the wall of tequilas, but next time I want a margarita, I know where to go.  Also, the servers and hostesses were very nice, they didnt look like most other places where they look like they hate their jobs and everyone around them.
author: Janet R.

description: I scored on this trip. I saw a friend that I haven't spoken to in years at the airport and she told me to come here. Our friends picked us up from the hotel and this is where they were brining us. The decor is very warm and inviting. Out of this world guacamole. They make it fresh at your table with what you want in it. I had the carnitas which were very good. The table had the mole poblano, camarones tamarindo, sopa tortillas. I'll tell you, I didn't want to get up because everything was so good. The prices are very resonable but you don't get a lot of food, so order extra. Well it's not trucked in the way I'm used to. These are very normal California portitions. The drinks are as large as the price. I would make this a definite stop on my next trip.
author: Steven M.

description: The food is pretty good! The guacamole is AWESOME! The Sangria's ok. The service well with the servers is good, the host however on several visits has been on the snobbish side and not sure why???? However everything else makes up for it.
author: Rob L.

description:
I tried this place on a recommendation and was pretty disappointed. I thought the decor was a little cheesy. 

Drinks were watered down. The chicken and steak was dry and rather bland. The tortilla soup was very good and I thought the Guac was good. 

I don't mind spending some cash on good food but for the price I think this place is over rated.
author: Chris C.

description: This place was impeccable.  Ended up having our meal at the bar after a drink or two, the bartender was great, he guided us through the world of Mezcal.  Great to get away from traditional American Mexican and try something truly authentic.  A little pricey but totally worth it.  The atmosphere inside was also great, we found ourselves talking to anyone nearby, sharing out thoughts on the food, drinks, places to travel, etc.  One last thing: Kudos to whoever put the low-budget Mexican wrestling monster movie on above the bar; also easy to ignore if you wanted to.
author: Chase N.

description: It lived up to the hype. Good food and service when they were really busy. Horrible caprinias from the bar after they bragged about them. Not to par. Portions a bit small but leaves room to try other things. We had to get the menu again and pony up to eat more but were happy to do so, it was that good.
author: James T.

description: OVERPRICED! I recommend getting a reservation if you are going.....we did not, but they still found a way to seat us, which was nice of them. Then the food came.....and that's were this place disappointed me.....the homemade tortillas were sooo yummy, but other then that.....I did not like anything....It could just be that I like real Mexican food, and this is definitely a Mexican Bistro....they do not even have a bean and cheese burrito on the menu, which happens to be my favorite Mexican dish...=( So I may be a little biased....when it comes to Mexican food....cause...I have favorite dishes and none of them were served here......the Margaritas were not strong and kind of sour to be honest.....The other 3 people I was with agreed that the black beans were definitely not the right side to order....but they liked the tacos, which were a special on the menu that night....All in all.....eating in San Fran is my favorite thing to do, cause of all the wonderful food there is to eat.....and this place was not worth the high dollars....and long wait at all....10 dollars for a small and not strong margartita.....I'llsave my money....Also - just as a side note...everyone says the guac is sooo good....and I do not think it was good at all....but that's just my opinion....
author: Nikki S.

description: Unbelievable mexican food.  Service was excellent.  Drinks were excellent.  Food was excellent.  Desserts were excellent.  What I can say, but it was excellent.  I can't believe this restaurant got anything lower than four stars from anyone!  Must have been an off night.  I would eat here again in a heartbeat.  As a matter of fact, I might come back later this week on my way back through San Fran.  Treat yourself. It is well worth it!!!
author: Scott B.

description: I love this place!  The ambiance is great.  The decor makes you feel like you're no longer in the US.  The service and waitstaff are really friendly and helpful.  My friend from Monterrey, Mexico recommended this place and like it's sister restaurant Consuelo down in San Jose, this place has authentic Mexican food with fresh and flavorful ingredients.  Definitely order the guacamole (made fresh tableside!), the duck was really good as was the pescado (fish).  Drinks like the mojitos were also very good.  Come in for a drink or for a meal before or after a show in the theater district or a long day of shopping in Union Square!
author: Dave L.

description: Premium Mexican.  When you're in Union Square looking for a nice dinner or looking for a pre-theater meal, Colibri is it.  Be sure to make a reservation let your server know if you're trying to catch a show though, because its location opposite the Curran makes it very popular.  They make guacamole fresh next to your table, customized to taste.  The bartenders are great and their fruit-of-the-week margaritas are delicious.  They're great at mojitos if you're looking for a safe drink :)
author: Angela W.

description: This mexican place is very good. The Margarita's are not made from a pre-made mix and they are delicious! I only had apps but they were all excellent. I would definitely eat here again.
author: Jenifer B.

description:
i feel like mormons would really like this place.  it's like mexican food for the nursing home set.

i will say that the guac is good, though.  it's just not enough to make up for everything else.
author: Wayne B.

description: This place is terrific. They serve unusual, traditional Mexican dishes such as quesadillas de cuitlacoche  - cuitlacoche is a fungus that grows on ears of corn, it is delicious, and is mostly unknown across the border. Their interior is open and pleasant with rich wood, iron chandeliers, a nice bar, and high ceilings. Best, there is no wait for Sunday brunch, which is a total freaking anomaly in a city that loves late breakfasts. If you are into upscale Mexican (not the glop of beans, glop of rice variety) this is the place.
author: Brian M.

description: Tequilla. What an array of choices. What shall I choose? I recommend throwing back a few throat burners of worm juice, make an ugly face, then order up some guac. and soft tortilla rolls to dip. Good stuff. The bar is loud and cozy but tidy enough to twist your long mustache and bob your head up and down with a wrinkled scowl.
author: Peter N.

description: This place isn't your normal taqueria, and they have an awesome queso fundido, that's baked cheese with mushrooms and chorizo for the gringos out there. This is pricey gourmet style Mexican tapas.  I highly recommend the wine braised lamb (cordero) shank in steamed banana leaf and carnitas, which is served as a hunk of pork roast accompanied by a side of spicy yet fruity sauce. Pair with one of their signature margarita's or sangria for the perfect casual meal.
author: Rob H.

description: Just had to come here for the guac and mojitos. Was not disappointed. The ambience is pretty good, too.
author: Wella L.

description: THE BEST! Jalapeno margarita is a must.
author: Kathleen A.

description:
Pros
~Amazing, creative dishes (my lamb melted in my mouth and still my friend's shrimp gave me serious buyers remorse)
~Complimentary home-made tortillas that are to do for
~Across the street from the A.C.T. so very convenient before a play

Cons
~Unique, diverse salsas but none that really did it for me
~Like most bars in San Francisco, the drinks are way overpriced
author: C H.

description: The Filet Mignon at Colibri's is the best I've ever had. I recommend you call ahead for a table. But even if you have to wait, the food is fantastic and worth it.
author: A P.

description: Some friends and I hit this up after a long day of walking.  The atmosphere was warm and cozy, and the house margaritas, although expensive ($10), were well worth it.  I got the tortilla soup, which was absolutely fantastic.  They serve it as just a bowl of chicken, tortilla strips, and queso fresco, then pour the soup tableside.  The guac was good but not made tableside like I had heard.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Excellent, creative food. Attentive, professional staff. And the margaritas are good and stiff. 

The food is divine, beautifully prepared, and executed. This is NOT a tacqueria with cheap pitchers, so don't expect to get out of here for less than $30 a person for dinner before drinks. They have a large and select line of tequila (i.e., expensive and very good margaritas). I would recommend coming here with someone with similar tastes in food since ordering multiple small plates to share is the way to go. I ordered from their April special menu and had possibly the best duck that I've ever eaten. The duck was stuffed with fruit, cut into rounds, and placed on top of some kind of mini-tortilla and served with raspberry mole, corn, sweet potato, and pomegranate. It was savory fatty goodness meeting tart, sweet, spiciness. That was perfectly complemented by their smokey (vegetarian?) estofado of zucchini, corn, bean, and at least two kinds of chilies. They also bring to the table mini-handmade tortillas and three kinds of salsas. You can get their very hot salsa by request.
author: Louise L.

description: My parents are visiting and I choose this place to take them for Mexican. It's more gourmet Mexican but it was still very good. It's very easy to over eat. I suggest if you get the guac then maybe split some of the main courses.
author: Jessica S.

description: A very popular place.  Sat at the bar waiting for a table, had a great time talking to the bartender who must get bored making all those margaritas.  We had sangria and it was really good.  We got the guacamole with the warm little flour tortillas.  The tortillas were great, the guacamole was bland though, no spices.  Two of us got the filet mignon, extremely tender and the goat's cheese stuffed in a red chili pepper really made the steak wonderful.  One of us had one of the chicken dishes, the sauce was nice mixture of sweet and savory.  If I was in the Union Square area I would definitely go back.
author: Alison M.

description: We had decent food here, but the prices in no way matched the quantities served and all main courses are ala carte- so you have to pay extra ($6 each) for rice & beans. Drink refills cost also. The guacamole was great, but we had to pay for chips to eat it ($2 for a small bowl). Our service was also impossibly slow- major time passed between a drink order and delivery of that drink, empty drinks waited 10-15 minutes to be noticed and food took 40 minutes to come after ordering. We were enjoying our company, but were ready to eat, as well.Won't be returning.
author: M M.

description: Upscale Mexican food is a great idea in a city like this. Excellent margaritas, courteous staff and wonderful food. They make the guacamole right there in front of you, which was incredible. We split the tostadas and tamalitos, small portions but very tasty. Pricey but worth it in my opinion.
author: Tim L.

description: Great place, very clean.  I love guacamole and this is by far the best I have tasted in a long time.  The chips were fresh and warm.  I would have been happy just that.  I didnt eat the burriot I ordered cause i got too full.  Had for lunch two days later and it was pretty good for being old.  Definately going back
author: amadeas s.

description: Great atmosphere with huge high ceilings and interesting southwest (without being cheesy) color scheme.  Comfortable booths in the back are fantastic, the table side guacamole making is a tasty and entertaining treat, and everything I tried on the tapas (but not quite tapas) menu was good.  Tough parking, but the hotels nearby will valet.
author: J P.

description: Very satisfying meal all around.  The sangria tasted great without being too sweet.  I'd recommend the scallops which were very tender and came with a yummy mashed potato side.  Our cute and friendly waiter recommended the queso fundido con chorizo which tasted sinful with our fresh warm tortillas.  The cheese was great, but it was soaking in oil...just close your eyes when you eat it.  The torta de elote, corn bread side was very unique and delicious too.  I'll have to try the guacamole next time.
author: Yasmine G.

description: Colibri, translated into English means hummingbird and this place buzzes with the vibrations of the flutter of attentive waiters in black guyaberas. I enjoyed the chicken mole at Colibri, the flavors were rich and smoky. The drink I ordered was enormous and I savored each tequila-laden drop with my meal. In so far as Mexican food, it's more Latin-American than truly Mexican (black beans are the tip off) but if you want to have Latin American/Southern Mexican cuisine it makes for a nice dinner spot downtown.
author: Jessica D.

description: Had reservations for 6:30 on a Thurs. and was not seated right away. We ordered a couple margs and hung around the amazingly large bar (do the bartenters really need that much space behind the bar? strange) Finally got seated, next to a large group that was celebrating something fun. We proceeded to be ignored and forgotten the entire evening; casting a fog of annoyance to the night. However, my boyfriend absolutely loved the food (he is a Mexican food freak) and I really enjoyed it as well. Yummy guac, carnitas and my bf's fav - the cornbread side! Would for sure go again (demand a different table?) and reccomend to friends.
author: Jessica D.

description: GREAT guacamole and drinks! i've been to colibri many times and i've had there entrees before also but i like their appetizers more. me and my friends always share a lot of the appetizers (including guacomole.. its a must!) and drinks and becomes our dinner.. a few of my favorite appetizers is guacamole, tostada, ceviche and fish tacos. Drinks are really good also! just make sure to have a reservation before you go
author: Elina A.
